EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong mid-level trough in split flow moved out of the southwestern U.S. on the morning of April 12, and phased with a strong northern stream trough across the northern Plains by April 13. Intense low pressure developed across the central Plains and moved into the Great Lakes, with a strong frontogenetic band of precipitation from Nebraska to Minnesota. Convective instability produced some spotty thunder along with the rain changing to snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled 4.0 inches at Newcastle and 3.5 inches at Concord. Winds near Wayne and Gayville gusted from 35 to 42 mph at times between 0700CST and 1400CST, with visibilities frequently at one-half mile or less, and occasionally as low as one-quarter mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong mid-level trough in split flow moved out of the southwestern U.S. on the morning of April 12, and phased with a strong northern stream trough across the northern Plains by April 13. Intense low pressure developed across the central Plains and moved into the Great Lakes, with a strong frontogenetic band of precipitation from Nebraska to Minnesota. Convective instability produced some spotty thunder along with the rain changing to snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled 2.3 inches at Emerson. Winds at Sioux City gusted frequently to 35 to 40 mph between 0830-1530, and led to frequent visibility under one mile, and as low as one-half mile at times.

Supercell thunderstorm developed in the northern Nebraska panhandle the afternoon of 2 July 2020. This supercell produced very large hail and a tornado touched down near Marsland Nebraska.

Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensity as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to quarter sized hail, up to 74 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.1 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP observer reported nickel to quarter sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensity as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to quarter sized hail, up to 74 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.1 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported estimated 74 mph wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved south into Northwest Kansas during the evening.  Wind gusts up to 60 MPH were recorded as the storms moved through, with the strongest gust occurring near St. Francis.  Hail up to two inches in diameter fell with these storms, with the largest hail reported near Herndon.  As the storms moved south their intensity declined.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated time of report from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of stationary thunderstorms producing heavy rainfall over Dundy County Nebraska expanded south into Cheyenne County.  Rainfall amounts of over eight inches fell, with the highest amounts of rain occurring near the Nebraska border.  Multiple roads had sections washed out, some as deep as 10 ft or so.  Some farms in the northern part of the county were stranded due to all the roads leading out being washed out.  Water in the Republican River was running so fast and deep that trees were snapping.  One bridge in the county was damaged and another was washed out from the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the road damage from flooding occurred north of CR S, with the damage becoming more severe toward the Nebraska border. One bridge was partially damaged east of Highway 27 near CR Z. Another bridge was washed out at River Road and RS 115. A culvert was washed out on CR 19 between CR AA and CR BB. Near CR BB and CR 17 a barb wire fence was washed onto the road. Near CR 15 and CR V flood waters had washed a large tree onto the road. Near CR 2 the Republican River was out of its banks. Hackberry Creek was also flooding where it joined with the Republican River. Damage from the flooding is unknown due to the unknown number of sections of road washed out and the unknown acres of crop land flooded.

The D2 Drought status worsened for the county during the last half of the month, spreading across the southern half of the county instead of just the southwest corner.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The D2 drought covered the southern half of the county during the last half of the month.  Precipitation for the month ranged from 0.77 to 1.97, which was roughly 2.91 below normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid April severe/winter storm system came through Nebraska over the weekend on April 11 and 12. Before the blast of cold air, a surge of warm, moist air in front of a rapidly strengthening low led to severe weather across southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. 3 inch hail was reported near Murray, IA. The next day a cold front moved through the area and the primary precipitation type was snow. A strong pressure gradient led to strong winds with a 58 MPH the max wind gust reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer reported 0.2 inches of snow. Snow reports were lacking. It was Easter, the snow was lighter than expected, and difficult to measure with winds 40-50 mph throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread severe weather produced numerous wind and hail reports across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 25 to 50 percent of normal during July and August with above normal temperatures led to the development of severe short-term drought conditions over much of northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate (D1) drought evolved to severe (D2) drought conditions by mid-month. Rainfall of less than 50 percent of normal along with above normal temperatures contributed to the worsening short-term agricultural drought. Crop damage is an estimate from insured losses. Information provided by the United States Department of Agriculture.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An initially unimpressive thunderstorm complex over northeast Nebraska rapidly intensified during the morning of August 10, 2020. After a few sporadic early morning damage reports, the intensifying storms began to more readily produce damaging winds in excess of 50 kts around 1340Z. Those damaging winds increased in coverage and intensity as the storms moved east into Iowa. The portion of the thunderstorm complex that moved through the NWS Omaha forecast area marked the approximate beginning of an intense derecho that tracked across portions of Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan, and Ohio. Within the NWS Omaha forecast area, there were more than 20 local storm reports of wind damage and measured severe wind gusts, including more than 50,000 power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public personal weather station measured a wind of 54 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Collapsing thunderstorms produced wind damage outside the town of Harrisburg, Nebraska the evening of 21 July 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two empty and un-anchored 10X14 outbuildings, located north of Double L Cafe on Highway 71, 4 miles southeast of Harrisburg, NE, were flipped upside down by wind.  Estimated wind speeds at 55 mph. The outbuildings were all wood construction and had no awning.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from mPing of 1.75 inch hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An initially unimpressive thunderstorm complex over northeast Nebraska rapidly intensified during the morning of August 10, 2020. After a few sporadic early morning damage reports, the intensifying storms began to more readily produce damaging winds in excess of 50 kts around 1340Z. Those damaging winds increased in coverage and intensity as the storms moved east into Iowa. The portion of the thunderstorm complex that moved through the NWS Omaha forecast area marked the approximate beginning of an intense derecho that tracked across portions of Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan, and Ohio. Within the NWS Omaha forecast area, there were more than 20 local storm reports of wind damage and measured severe wind gusts, including more than 50,000 power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Former NWS Employee called in estimating winds at 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level short wave came off of the Rocky Mountains out over the central Plains. This led to a surface low developing over Kansas. In front of that surface low, warm moist air was advected north. Isentropic upglide and led to an overrunning precipitation event that led to some high snowfall totals in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. It was the #5 (5.4 inches) and #4 (4.5 inches) highest April snowfall events for Omaha and Lincoln respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from the public for 6 inches of snowfall from Blair, NE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions remained unchanged across western and north central Nebraska in December. Precipitation was below normal in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle and portions of far southwestern Nebraska. Across the northern Sandhills from eastern Cherry county into Holt county, precipitation for the month was running 50 to 90 percent of normal. Across the central and southern Sandhills, including Lincoln and Keith counties, precipitation was 100 to 150 percent of normal. For the year ending in December, Broken Bow, North Platte, Valentine and Imperial, ran precipitation deficits of: -3.33, -5.48, -1.94, and -9.36 inches respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of December, drought severity remained unchanged across Garden County. Extreme (D3) drought conditions persisted over the western 2/3rds of Garden county with severe (D2) drought conditions over the eastern third of the county. The cooperative station at Lisco reported 0.21 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.42 inches below the normal of 0.63 inches.  The cooperative station at Oshkosh reported 0.19 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.18 inches below the normal of 0.37 inches. The cooperative station at Crescent Lakes National Wildlife Refuge reported 0.33 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.04 inches below the normal of 0.37 inches. The cooperative station at Oshkosh 8SW reported 0.34 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.16 inches below the normal of 0.50 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions remained unchanged across western and north central Nebraska in December. Precipitation was below normal in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle and portions of far southwestern Nebraska. Across the northern Sandhills from eastern Cherry county into Holt county, precipitation for the month was running 50 to 90 percent of normal. Across the central and southern Sandhills, including Lincoln and Keith counties, precipitation was 100 to 150 percent of normal. For the year ending in December, Broken Bow, North Platte, Valentine and Imperial, ran precipitation deficits of: -3.33, -5.48, -1.94, and -9.36 inches respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of December, extreme (D3) drought conditions remained unchanged across all of Chase County. The cooperative station at Imperial reported 0.36 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.14 inches below the normal of 0.50 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level short wave came off of the Rocky Mountains out over the central Plains. This led to a surface low developing over Kansas. In front of that surface low, warm moist air was advected north. Isentropic upglide and led to an overrunning precipitation event that led to some high snowfall totals in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. It was the #5 (5.4 inches) and #4 (4.5 inches) highest April snowfall events for Omaha and Lincoln respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum snow report from public was 8 inches of snow.

Drought conditions remained unchanged across western and north central Nebraska in December. Precipitation was below normal in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle and portions of far southwestern Nebraska. Across the northern Sandhills from eastern Cherry county into Holt county, precipitation for the month was running 50 to 90 percent of normal. Across the central and southern Sandhills, including Lincoln and Keith counties, precipitation was 100 to 150 percent of normal. For the year ending in December, Broken Bow, North Platte, Valentine and Imperial, ran precipitation deficits of: -3.33, -5.48, -1.94, and -9.36 inches respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of December, drought severity remained unchanged across Sheridan County. The western half of the county was in extreme (D3) drought with the eastern half of the county in severe (D2) drought. The cooperative station at Gordon 6N reported 0.62 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.17 inches above the normal of 0.45 inches. The cooperative station at Ellsworth 2W reported 0.34 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.11 inches above the normal of 0.23 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a surface trough of low pressure in western Chase county around 4 PM CT on the afternoon of June 2nd.  As these storms tracked to the east southeast, they produced hail up to the size of baseballs near Hamlet in southwestern Hayes county. Additional strong to severe storms developed over southeastern Lincoln county where they produced quarter sized hail.

A storm system brought t-storms to the area on the morning of Friday January 10th.  Rain and T-storms turned to freezing rain as much colder air surged southward by late morning. Ice accumulation of one tenth and up to around one quarter of an inch occurred mainly from mid morning to late afternoon on Jan 10th.  In addition northeast winds of 20 to 30 mph caused some tree limbs to fall and sporadic power outages did occur due to the ice and wind combination.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kansas Highway Patrol reported ice covered elevated surfaces with around one quarter inch of ice on flat surfaces such as cars and other elevated surfaces above the ground.  Other law enforcement across Riley county reported similar ice build up on elevated surfaces.

A storm system brought t-storms to the area on the morning of Friday January 10th.  Rain and T-storms turned to freezing rain as much colder air surged southward by late morning. Ice accumulation of one tenth and up to around one quarter of an inch occurred mainly from mid morning to late afternoon on Jan 10th.  In addition northeast winds of 20 to 30 mph caused some tree limbs to fall and sporadic power outages did occur due to the ice and wind combination.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EM reported tree limbs down from ice and wind which caused power outages across parts of the county including near MClouth.  Ice accumulations on flat surfaces were reported to be around one tenth up to around one quarter of an inch.  Impacts due to combination of ice build up on elevated surfaces and strong northeast winds of 20 to 30 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of snow, sleet and mainly freezing rain fell across all of the area during the early morning hours of January 17th.  Most observation sites measured anywhere from two tenths to nearly four tenths of flat ice accumulation from this event.  Impacts did include some sporadic power outages and hazardous travel conditions.  However, air temperatures rose to above freezing by mid to late morning on January 17th mitigating more severe impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS measured 0.35 inches of flat ice accumulation at Emporia Airport.  Impacts were limited however as air temperatures rose to above freezing by late morning melting off much of the ice.

A strong storm system moved into Kansas bringing quite a bit of moisture with it.  The main issue with this system would be temperatures and the precipitation type.  Trying to decipher the liquid/frozen line would prove difficult.  Once the transition to ice did occur, it did not last long but did hit with a cause significant issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of snow then freezing rain occurred across the county with ice accumulations between 0.25 and 0.5 inches.

Trying to decipher the liquid/frozen line would prove difficult.  Once the transition to ice did occur, it did not last long but did hit with a cause significant issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice was collecting on all elevated surfaces and a few slick spots were noted on roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system moved into Kansas bringing quite a bit of moisture with it.  The main issue with this system would be temperatures and the precipitation type.  Trying to decipher the liquid/frozen line would prove difficult.  Once the transition to ice did occur, it did not last long but did hit with a cause significant issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few slick spots were being reported but no significant issues had arisen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system moved into Kansas bringing quite a bit of moisture with it.  The main issue with this system would be temperatures and the precipitation type.  Trying to decipher the liquid/frozen line would prove difficult.  Once the transition to ice did occur, it did not last long but did hit with a cause significant issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County roads were being reported as being very icy with travel issues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid season winter storm moved through the area bringing nearly every precipitation type with it. This storm produced around a quarter to a half inch of ice and several inches of snow area-wide. There were several accidents on local roadways due to the ice and snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred through much of the night going into January 11, and caused around a quarter to one-third inch accumulation. This occurred prior to about 2 to 3 inches of snow falling. This resulted in several auto accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought t-storms to the area on the morning of Friday January 10th.  Rain and T-storms turned to freezing rain as much colder air surged southward by late morning. Ice accumulation of one tenth and up to around one quarter of an inch occurred mainly from mid morning to late afternoon on Jan 10th.  In addition northeast winds of 20 to 30 mph caused some tree limbs to fall and sporadic power outages did occur due to the ice and wind combination.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kansas Highway Patrol reported ice covered elevated surfaces with around one quarter inch of ice on flat surfaces such as cars and other elevated surfaces above the ground.  Other law enforcement across Jackson county reported similar ice build up on elevated surfaces.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid season winter storm moved through the area bringing nearly every precipitation type with it. This storm produced around a quarter to a half inch of ice and several inches of snow area-wide. There were several accidents on local roadways due to the ice and snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred through much of the night going into January 11, and caused around a quarter to one-third inch accumulation. This occurred prior to about 2 to 3 inches of snow falling. This resulted in several auto accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter weather system impacted the area bringing wide swaths of 5 to 7 inches of snow. Farther to the south, ice accumulated on top of the snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported of 7.0 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mix of snow, sleet and mainly freezing rain fell across all of the area during the early morning hours of January 17th.  Most observation sites measured anywhere from two tenths to nearly four tenths of flat ice accumulation from this event.  Impacts did include some sporadic power outages and hazardous travel conditions.  However, air temperatures rose to above freezing by mid to late morning on January 17th mitigating more severe impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: DOT reported around one quarter inch of ice accumulated on elevated surfaces early Friday morning January 17th.  Sleet was also reported mixed in with the freezing rain.  Impacts were limited to mainly hazardous travel conditions early on Jan 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic front moving through the region created wind gusts from 40 to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported broken tree branches between Norfolk and Battle Creek and near whiteout conditions with blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic front moving through the region created wind gusts from 40 to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported trash cans blown around and small tree branches broken in Fort Calhoun.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic front moving through the region created wind gusts from 40 to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: OPPD estimated that 22 customers were without power between Mead and Yutan. Winds of 40 to 60 across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic front moving through the region created wind gusts from 40 to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Tekamah airport measured a 59 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic front moving through the region created wind gusts from 40 to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the Lincoln airport measured a 60 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level disturbance pushed across the CWA into the overnight hours on the 28th and throughout the day on the 29th.  The heaviest snow fell at the beginning of the event. Moist upslope flow ahead of this system allowed for some high accumulating snow, especially for southern counties stretching from Liberal to Bucklin pushing around the foot mark with areas north around 6 inches in the Dodge City area and less further north towards Hays. A winter storm warning was issued from Finney to Seward County and points east to Edwards and Comanche. All other areas were in winter weather advisories that saw less accumulations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 9.0 inches was measured in Liberal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A widespread strong wind event occurred on the evening of January 17th across southwest Nebraska after a strong winter surface trough had exited the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The McCook (KMCK) ASOS recorded multiple high wind gusts on the evening of January 17th. A 58 mph wind gust was measured at 2346 CST and a 59 mph wind gust was measured at 2353 CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level disturbance pushed across the CWA into the overnight hours on the 28th and throughout the day on the 29th.  The heaviest snow fell at the beginning of the event. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 2.5 inches was observed in Scott City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level disturbance worked northeast from Colorado early morning January 12 into Iowa by late day.  Broad lift initially within the warm advection zone became increasingly concentrated, with deeper lift in the dendritic growth layer by afternoon across northwest Iowa.  Snowfall rates up to 1.5 to 2 inches per hour were noted across northwest Iowa and northeast Nebraska at the peak during the late afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to briefly heavy snowfall during the afternoon accumulated to 2.5 inches at Emerson and South Sioux City, resulting in hazardous road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Brisk winds in advance of the center of strong arctic high pressure brought wind chill readings to -25 to -35 during the overnight and morning of January 19.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coldest wind chill readings reached -30F at 0300CST January 19 at a location 2 miles east of Concord, and -26F at 0800CST at Sioux Gateway Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic front moving through the region created wind gusts from 40 to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: OPPD estimated that 197 customers were without power in midtown Omaha. Eventually up to 1307 customers were without power. Winds of 40 to 60 across the area.  Winds were strong enough to fling frozen ice out of trees and off power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic front moving through the region created wind gusts from 40 to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 1500' KOLN TV tower collapsed due to ice and high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving compact upper level low pressure system moved out of the Central Rockies and into western Oklahoma on Tuesday January 28th. This feature brought a large area of heavy snow to western Kansas with much of central and southeast Kansas also being affected.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports were sent near Sylvia during the event with a total of 7 inches in the evening of 1/28. Other reports across the county ranged from around an inch to three inches.

Trying to decipher the liquid/frozen line would prove difficult.  Once the transition to ice did occur, it did not last long but did hit with a cause significant issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of snow then freezing rain occurred across the county with ice accumulations  between 0.25 and 0.4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter system tracked across Southwest Nebraska on March 19th, bringing with it high wind gusts over 60 mph as well as reduced visibility from brief heavy snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The KMCK ASOS in McCook, Nebraska recorded a 60 mph wind gust associated with a winter weather system.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter system tracked across Southwest Nebraska on March 19th, bringing with it high wind gusts over 60 mph as well as reduced visibility from brief heavy snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: With winds gusting up to 60 mph and light snow falling, the KMCK ASOS in McCook, Nebraska recorded reduced visibility along with snow or dense freezing fog on March 19th. Visibility was briefly reduced to as low as one quarter-mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought hail as large as quarter size to Logan County.

A strong storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the late morning hours on March 19th, which continued into the early morning on March 20th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 8 inches. The snow combined with northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts around 45 mph at times to produce blowing and drifting snow with visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Cooperative Observer located 10 miles northeast of Oshkosh reported 5 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts of 4 to 6 inches were common across Garden County. North winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused visibility of 1/4 mile at times with blowing and drifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the late morning hours on March 19th, which continued into the early morning on March 20th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 8 inches. The snow combined with northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts around 45 mph at times to produce blowing and drifting snow with visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located near Merritt Reservoir reported 7 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches were common across the southeastern half of western Cherry County. North winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused visibility of 1/4 mile at times with blowing and drifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the late morning hours on March 19th, which continued into the early morning on March 20th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 8 inches. The snow combined with northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts around 45 mph at times to produce blowing and drifting snow with visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located in Hyannis reported 5 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts of 4 to 6 inches were common across Grant County. North winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused visibility of 1/4 mile at times with blowing and drifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter system tracked across Northwest Kansas on March 19th, bringing with it high wind gusts over 60 mph in addition to light snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The KGLD ASOS in Goodland, KS recorded a 58 mph wind gust associated with a winter weather system.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter system tracked across Northwest Kansas on March 19th, bringing with it high wind gusts over 60 mph in addition to light snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The KHLC ASOS in Hill City, KS recorded a 58 mph wind gust associated with a winter weather system.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter system tracked across Northwest Kansas on March 19th, bringing with it high wind gusts over 60 mph in addition to light snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The KGLD ASOS in Goodland, KS recorded a 61 mph wind gust associated with a winter weather system.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small amount of freezing rain on March 13th and 14th led to icy road conditions across Northwest Kansas. At least 2 minor accidents were reported along Interstate 70 in Thomas County due to icy road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thomas County Dispatch reported that at least 2 slide-offs occurred Saturday morning around 7 AM CST along Interstate 70 due to icy road conditions caused by freezing rain which occurred Friday evening into Saturday morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter system tracked across Southwest Nebraska on March 19th, bringing with it high wind gusts over 60 mph as well as reduced visibility from brief heavy snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The KMCK ASOS in McCook, NE recorded a 59 mph wind gust associated with a winter weather system.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were measured out in Cheyenne County along with heavy snowfall across Morrill County. Road conditions quickly deteriorated as initial warm conveyor belt of a digging low pressure system into the Central Plains quickly transitioned into snow during the afternoon of the 19th. Area road closures were in effect as a result for crews to safely clear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sidney Municipal Airport sensor along with other NWS/FAA sensors across Cheyenne County measured blizzard conditions. Deteriorating conditions along portions of Interstate 80 eastward resulted in extended closure of the interstate through the county for crews to clear and move accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were measured out in Cheyenne County along with heavy snowfall across Morrill County. Road conditions quickly deteriorated as initial warm conveyor belt of a digging low pressure system into the Central Plains quickly transitioned into snow during the afternoon of the 19th. Area road closures were in effect as a result for crews to safely clear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer located ten miles south-southeast of Broadwater measured a snowfall total of 7.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the late morning hours on March 19th, which continued into the early morning on March 20th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 8 inches. The snow combined with northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts around 45 mph at times to produce blowing and drifting snow with visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS observer located 2 miles south of Mullen reported 4.5 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts of 4 to 5 inches were common across Grant County. North winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused visibility of 1/4 mile at times with blowing and drifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong gradient strengthened across the area as an Arctic cold front made its way through the high plains. North winds behind the front lasted for several hours with peak gusts over 50 mph in some places with peaks around 60 mph for only a couple of locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported at the Medicine Lodge airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm pushed across Gray County associated with a weak upper level disturbance that progressively crossed the high plains producing a wind gust up to 60 mph. No other reports or storms of anything into the severe thresholds were received.

An isolated thunderstorm pushed across Gray County associated with a weak upper level disturbance that progressively crossed the high plains producing a wind gust up to 60 mph. No other reports or storms of anything into the severe thresholds were received.

Another round of potential severe storms was associated with another shortwave trough around an upper level low across New Mexico. Multiple reports of hail associated with some of these storms warranted significant weather advisories with one instance of severe hail up the size of quarters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail covered highway 50.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another round of potential severe storms was associated with another shortwave trough around an upper level low across New Mexico. Multiple reports of hail associated with some of these storms warranted significant weather advisories with one instance of severe hail up the size of quarters.

Another round of potential severe storms was associated with another shortwave trough around an upper level low across New Mexico. Multiple reports of hail associated with some of these storms warranted significant weather advisories with one instance of severe hail up the size of quarters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a significant accumulation of pea to penny sized hail in a swath from 4 W of Lewis to 7 S Lewis.  There were numerous reports of a hail depth of 4 to 5 inches. Winter wheat fields in this swath were wiped out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low to the south of the region ejected a couple of shortwaves across the area producing widespread rain showers and isolated thunderstorms. Many reports of hail associated with some of these storms near the Oklahoma state line were reported with only one instance of severe hail up to the size of quarters observed.

An upper level low to the south of the region ejected a couple of shortwaves across the area producing widespread rain showers and isolated thunderstorms. Many reports of hail associated with some of these storms near the Oklahoma state line were reported with only one instance of severe hail up to the size of quarters observed.

An upper level low to the south of the region ejected a couple of shortwaves across the area producing widespread rain showers and isolated thunderstorms. Many reports of hail associated with some of these storms near the Oklahoma state line were reported with only one instance of severe hail up to the size of quarters observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power poles were blown down by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low to the south of the region ejected a couple of shortwaves across the area producing widespread rain showers and isolated thunderstorms. Many reports of hail associated with some of these storms near the Oklahoma state line were reported with only one instance of severe hail up to the size of quarters observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 60 to 70 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid season winter storm moved through the area bringing nearly every precipitation type with it. This storm produced around a quarter to a half inch of ice and several inches of snow area-wide. There were several accidents on local roadways due to the ice and snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred through much of the night going into January 11, and caused around a quarter to one-third inch accumulation. This occurred prior to about 2 to 3 inches of snow falling. This resulted in several auto accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of strong to severe storms developed from the evening of the 1st to the early morning of the 3rd as a surface low pressure system tracked from western Kansas southeastward into Red River Valley.  The heaviest rainfall occurred during the early morning of the 2nd when training storms moved over southeast Kansas and produced one to three inches of rain before moving into Missouri.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple low water crossings in Columbus and eastern Cherokee County were flooded due to runoff from recent rainfall over the previous 6 to 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the late evening hours thunderstorms formed and persisted overnight, bringing hail to the area. The largest stones were between quarter an golf ball sized.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball sized hail reported at 175th Street and Mur-Len.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early morning heavy banded snowfall moved across the central and northeast portions of the Nebraska Panhandle producing high snowfall rates of up to 6 inches per hour based on overnight storm reports. By morning observations of various CoCoRaHS, COOP observers, law enforcement and public many county areas were blanketed with up to a foot of snow creating travel impacts as many roads were impassible while waiting for crews to clear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer located twelve miles south of Redington measured a storm total snowfall of 12 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early morning heavy banded snowfall moved across the central and northeast portions of the Nebraska Panhandle producing high snowfall rates of up to 6 inches per hour based on overnight storm reports. By morning observations of various CoCoRaHS, COOP observers, law enforcement and public many county areas were blanketed with up to a foot of snow creating travel impacts as many roads were impassible while waiting for crews to clear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer at station BWTN1 located ten miles south-southeast of Broadwater measured a total storm snowfall of 7.0 inches. A public report three miles east of Angora measured a foot of snowfall with this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A widespread wet snowfall of 3 to 5 inches blanketed nearly all of south central Nebraska on this Friday. This snowfall was associated with a weak and non-strengthening short-wave trough. So, the radar presentation of this event was disorganized. Small patches of light snow began developing from Colorado into Kansas and southern Nebraska during the morning hours. Due to dry low-level air, it took several hours for precipitation to reach the ground on a consistent basis. By midday, a relatively well-organized area of light snow had formed over northwest Kansas and southwest Nebraska. This area moved east-northeast across south central Nebraska during the mid-to-late afternoon. Despite the cloud cover, temperatures had climbed into the low 40s east of Hwy 183, before precipitation began falling. That allowed for some light rain to fall in some areas before the column rapidly cooled, resulting in a changeover to snow. During the daylight hours, the only areas where measurable snow fell were southwest and west of Grand Island, with between 1 and 2 inches of accumulation on grassy areas. Elsewhere, actual air temperature and ground temperature allowed the snow to melt on contact. That area of snow moved into eastern Nebraska by sunset, but in its wake, more patchy areas of snow continued to develop  through the evening. After sunset, snow began accumulating across the rest of the area. By midnight, a fairly large but unorganized area of precipitation enveloped much of the Central Plains, extending from southern South Dakota to Oklahoma. Across south central Nebraska, the snow did fill-in after midnight, becoming steadier, but with diminishing intensity. The snow ended across the area by 8 AM Saturday. There was one isolated report of 6 inches in Minden. Otherwise the highest reports included 5.4 inches in Bradshaw, and 5.0 inches at Palmer, Elwood, and Bladen. Impacts from this snowfall were minimal as it occurred on a Friday night. Schools were not in session and no morning or evening commutes were involved. Due to the recent warm weather, snow struggled to accumulate on roads and parking lots, which also helped. The wet, heavy character of the snow coated all the trees like cotton candy and resulted in a 6-inch diameter tree branch being snapped off near Shelby. ||There was no low pressure system associated with this snowfall. Strong high pressure was over central Canada and extended southeast into the Ohio Valley. A cold front was stationary from the Gulf Coast states across Texas, with its western extent stationary, banked up against the Rockies. In the upper-levels, the flow across the U.S. was west-southwest, with a subtropical high over the Gulf of Mexico. This weak shortwave trough came out of the Desert Southwest, and it weakened further as it crossed the Central Plains. By sunset Saturday, it was a minimal dip in the 500 mb heights over the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches across the county.

That allowed for some light rain to fall in some areas before the column rapidly cooled, resulting in a changeover to snow. During the daylight hours, the only areas where measurable snow fell were southwest and west of Grand Island, with between 1 and 2 inches of accumulation on grassy areas. Elsewhere, actual air temperature and ground temperature allowed the snow to melt on contact. That area of snow moved into eastern Nebraska by sunset, but in its wake, more patchy areas of snow continued to develop  through the evening. After sunset, snow began accumulating across the rest of the area. By midnight, a fairly large but unorganized area of precipitation enveloped much of the Central Plains, extending from southern South Dakota to Oklahoma. Across south central Nebraska, the snow did fill-in after midnight, becoming steadier, but with diminishing intensity. The snow ended across the area by 8 AM Saturday. There was one isolated report of 6 inches in Minden. Otherwise the highest reports included 5.4 inches in Bradshaw, and 5.0 inches at Palmer, Elwood, and Bladen. Impacts from this snowfall were minimal as it occurred on a Friday night. Schools were not in session and no morning or evening commutes were involved. Due to the recent warm weather, snow struggled to accumulate on roads and parking lots, which also helped. The wet, heavy character of the snow coated all the trees like cotton candy and resulted in a 6-inch diameter tree branch being snapped off near Shelby. ||There was no low pressure system associated with this snowfall. Strong high pressure was over central Canada and extended southeast into the Ohio Valley. A cold front was stationary from the Gulf Coast states across Texas, with its western extent stationary, banked up against the Rockies. In the upper-levels, the flow across the U.S. was west-southwest, with a subtropical high over the Gulf of Mexico. This weak shortwave trough came out of the Desert Southwest, and it weakened further as it crossed the Central Plains. By sunset Saturday, it was a minimal dip in the 500 mb heights over the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 5 inches across the county.

Elsewhere, actual air temperature and ground temperature allowed the snow to melt on contact. That area of snow moved into eastern Nebraska by sunset, but in its wake, more patchy areas of snow continued to develop  through the evening. After sunset, snow began accumulating across the rest of the area. By midnight, a fairly large but unorganized area of precipitation enveloped much of the Central Plains, extending from southern South Dakota to Oklahoma. Across south central Nebraska, the snow did fill-in after midnight, becoming steadier, but with diminishing intensity. The snow ended across the area by 8 AM Saturday. There was one isolated report of 6 inches in Minden. Otherwise the highest reports included 5.4 inches in Bradshaw, and 5.0 inches at Palmer, Elwood, and Bladen. Impacts from this snowfall were minimal as it occurred on a Friday night. Schools were not in session and no morning or evening commutes were involved. Due to the recent warm weather, snow struggled to accumulate on roads and parking lots, which also helped. The wet, heavy character of the snow coated all the trees like cotton candy and resulted in a 6-inch diameter tree branch being snapped off near Shelby. ||There was no low pressure system associated with this snowfall. Strong high pressure was over central Canada and extended southeast into the Ohio Valley. A cold front was stationary from the Gulf Coast states across Texas, with its western extent stationary, banked up against the Rockies. In the upper-levels, the flow across the U.S. was west-southwest, with a subtropical high over the Gulf of Mexico. This weak shortwave trough came out of the Desert Southwest, and it weakened further as it crossed the Central Plains. By sunset Saturday, it was a minimal dip in the 500 mb heights over the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 5 inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A widespread wet snowfall of 3 to 5 inches blanketed nearly all of south central Nebraska on this Friday. This snowfall was associated with a weak and non-strengthening short-wave trough. So, the radar presentation of this event was disorganized. Small patches of light snow began developing from Colorado into Kansas and southern Nebraska during the morning hours. Due to dry low-level air, it took several hours for precipitation to reach the ground on a consistent basis. By midday, a relatively well-organized area of light snow had formed over northwest Kansas and southwest Nebraska. This area moved east-northeast across south central Nebraska during the mid-to-late afternoon. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of high sustained winds were measured across the far western portion of the Nebraska Panhandle in Banner and Kimball Counties. Highest sustained winds measured 43 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observation station K1BW in Bravo (Pine Bluffs) measured the reported sustained winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of high sustained winds were measured across the far western portion of the Nebraska Panhandle in Banner and Kimball Counties. Highest sustained winds measured 43 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observation station K1DW Delta near Kimball measured the reported sustained wind speed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On this Thursday, the first severe thunderstorms of the year occurred, followed by windy conditions and even accumulating snow in some areas. A few weak thunderstorms began forming around 1230 PM CST, with two small clusters over Harlan and Clay counties. Other showers and thunderstorms developed south of Interstate 80, and by mid-afternoon, they had moved across and to the north of the Interstate. A couple of these storms became severe and produced large amounts of hail (the freezing level was around 8,000 ft AGL). One storm turned severe from northwest Kearney county into south-central Buffalo county, where hail up to the size of ping pong balls occurred, including in the southwest part of the city of Kearney. There was a narrow swath of Interstate 80 that was covered with hail, and snowplows needed to be deployed. The other severe storm tracked from near Edgar to McCool Junction, where it also produced hail up to the size of ping pong balls. The thunderstorm activity ended by late afternoon. These storms were elevated, on the cold side of a strong cold front. As the colder temperatures near-surface moved in, and lapse rates steepened, north winds increased to 30 to 35 mph, with frequent gusts between 45 and 55 mph. There were a few higher wind gusts, including 63 mph at the Lexington airport, which was the highest gust recorded, 59 mph near Odessa, and 58 mph at Cozad and Hastings. Late in the afternoon, the thunderstorms weakened into showers which eventually morphed into stratiform rain as they encountered stability. This rain moved into increasingly colder air where it changed to snow north of a line from Lexington to Fullerton. One to 5 inches of snow fell, with most areas measuring 1 to 3 inches. The highest amounts were 5 inches near Scotia, 4 inches near Johnson Lake, with 3 inches at Greeley and Ord. Snow began accumulating during the late afternoon, and continued through the evening hours. The snow rapidly dissipated just after midnight CST.||At sunrise, a 1000 mb low pressure system was over southeast Colorado, with a warm front extending east across northern Kansas. A stationary Arctic front was over the northern Rockies and Plains. During the day, the stationary front become mobile and accelerated southward, merging with the occluded low and its fronts. The forward momentum of the Arctic air shoved the combined front south, also forcing the Colorado low to weaken as it migrated along the front into central Kansas. In the upper-levels, the longwave pattern was typical of the mean flow that had stubbornly prevailed since the middle of November. The flow over North America was split, with a trough over the western U.S. and a ridge over the Gulf of Mexico. The flow was from the southwest over the Central Plains, with a potent, intensifying shortwave trough over Colorado and New Mexico during the morning. By sunset, a small closed low had formed along the Nebraska-Kansas border. Due to the confluence of the northern and southern streams, the low quickly dissipated and, by Friday morning, all that was left was a modest shortwave trough over Wisconsin and Illinois.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong thunderstorms in northwest Kansas on the evening of March 30th produced a large swath of dime to nickel size hail in Wallace County which accumulated several inches deep along US Hwy 40.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public shared photos with NWS Goodland on social media which showed several inches of accumulated hail along the roadway along US Hwy 40. The individual hail stones ranged from dime to nickel size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered t-storms produced quarter size hail across Brown County during the evening of March 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter said ground was covered white with hail.

The highest amounts were 5 inches near Scotia, 4 inches near Johnson Lake, with 3 inches at Greeley and Ord. Snow began accumulating during the late afternoon, and continued through the evening hours. The snow rapidly dissipated just after midnight CST.||At sunrise, a 1000 mb low pressure system was over southeast Colorado, with a warm front extending east across northern Kansas. A stationary Arctic front was over the northern Rockies and Plains. During the day, the stationary front become mobile and accelerated southward, merging with the occluded low and its fronts. The forward momentum of the Arctic air shoved the combined front south, also forcing the Colorado low to weaken as it migrated along the front into central Kansas. In the upper-levels, the longwave pattern was typical of the mean flow that had stubbornly prevailed since the middle of November. The flow over North America was split, with a trough over the western U.S. and a ridge over the Gulf of Mexico. The flow was from the southwest over the Central Plains, with a potent, intensifying shortwave trough over Colorado and New Mexico during the morning. By sunset, a small closed low had formed along the Nebraska-Kansas border. Due to the confluence of the northern and southern streams, the low quickly dissipated and, by Friday morning, all that was left was a modest shortwave trough over Wisconsin and Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A post-frontal non-thunderstorm wind gust of 58 MPH was measured by the Hastings Airport ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On this Thursday, the first severe thunderstorms of the year occurred, followed by windy conditions and even accumulating snow in some areas. A few weak thunderstorms began forming around 1230 PM CST, with two small clusters over Harlan and Clay counties. Other showers and thunderstorms developed south of Interstate 80, and by mid-afternoon, they had moved across and to the north of the Interstate. A couple of these storms became severe and produced large amounts of hail (the freezing level was around 8,000 ft AGL). One storm turned severe from northwest Kearney county into south-central Buffalo county, where hail up to the size of ping pong balls occurred, including in the southwest part of the city of Kearney. There was a narrow swath of Interstate 80 that was covered with hail, and snowplows needed to be deployed. The other severe storm tracked from near Edgar to McCool Junction, where it also produced hail up to the size of ping pong balls. The thunderstorm activity ended by late afternoon. These storms were elevated, on the cold side of a strong cold front. As the colder temperatures near-surface moved in, and lapse rates steepened, north winds increased to 30 to 35 mph, with frequent gusts between 45 and 55 mph. There were a few higher wind gusts, including 63 mph at the Lexington airport, which was the highest gust recorded, 59 mph near Odessa, and 58 mph at Cozad and Hastings. Late in the afternoon, the thunderstorms weakened into showers which eventually morphed into stratiform rain as they encountered stability. This rain moved into increasingly colder air where it changed to snow north of a line from Lexington to Fullerton. One to 5 inches of snow fell, with most areas measuring 1 to 3 inches. The highest amounts were 5 inches near Scotia, 4 inches near Johnson Lake, with 3 inches at Greeley and Ord. Snow began accumulating during the late afternoon, and continued through the evening hours. The snow rapidly dissipated just after midnight CST.||At sunrise, a 1000 mb low pressure system was over southeast Colorado, with a warm front extending east across northern Kansas. A stationary Arctic front was over the northern Rockies and Plains. During the day, the stationary front become mobile and accelerated southward, merging with the occluded low and its fronts. The forward momentum of the Arctic air shoved the combined front south, also forcing the Colorado low to weaken as it migrated along the front into central Kansas. In the upper-levels, the longwave pattern was typical of the mean flow that had stubbornly prevailed since the middle of November. The flow over North America was split, with a trough over the western U.S. and a ridge over the Gulf of Mexico. The flow was from the southwest over the Central Plains, with a potent, intensifying shortwave trough over Colorado and New Mexico during the morning. By sunset, a small closed low had formed along the Nebraska-Kansas border. Due to the confluence of the northern and southern streams, the low quickly dissipated and, by Friday morning, all that was left was a modest shortwave trough over Wisconsin and Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A post-frontal non-thunderstorm wind gust of 58 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 1 mile southwest of Roseland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Windy conditions occurred behind an Arctic front on this Thursday evening. The day began with north central Kansas in the warm sector of an occluded 996 mb low pressure system over eastern Colorado. As the day progressed, the low filled to 1000 mb and moved into central Kansas. Meanwhile, an Arctic front accelerated southward and merged with the fronts associated with this low. The momentum resulted in a continued southward surge of the combined front, with its passage in north central Kansas occurring early in the evening. In its wake, north winds increased to around 30 mph, with frequent gusts around 45 mph. Higher one-time peak gusts occurred between 50 and 62 mph in some spots. The highest wind gusts were 62 mph at Beloit and 58 mph at Randall. However, these stations are unofficial and it is unknown if these they are properly sited. Peak gusts at official observation sites included 55 mph at the Beloit airport, 53 mph at Smith Center airport, and 52 mph at Phillipsburg airport. While windy conditions continued through the night, the highest gusts were recorded between 7 PM and midnight CST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A post-frontal non-thunderstorm wind gust of 62 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 1 mile south-southeast of Beloit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick, heavy-snow hitting system passed over the Nebraska Panhandle producing heavy snowfall measuring up to 8 inches in some communities across the northern tier of counties in the panhandle during mainly the evening and early overnight of the 13th and 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow reports of 6.0 inches in Alliance and 8.0 inches in Hemingford were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick, heavy-snow hitting system passed over the Nebraska Panhandle producing heavy snowfall measuring up to 8 inches in some communities across the northern tier of counties in the panhandle during mainly the evening and early overnight of the 13th and 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers near Marsland and Chadron State Park reported snowfall measurement of 7.0 and 8.0 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick, heavy-snow hitting system passed over the Nebraska Panhandle producing heavy snowfall measuring up to 8 inches in some communities across the northern tier of counties in the panhandle during mainly the evening and early overnight of the 13th and 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer located ten miles south of Fort Robinson measured snowfall of 6.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced mainly large hail and heavy rain across eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 1 inch hail south of Staplehurst.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early morning heavy banded snowfall moved across the central and northeast portions of the Nebraska Panhandle producing high snowfall rates of up to 6 inches per hour based on overnight storm reports. By morning observations of various CoCoRaHS, COOP observers, law enforcement and public many county areas were blanketed with up to a foot of snow creating travel impacts as many roads were impassible while waiting for crews to clear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer at station NE-DS-1 located 11.6 miles south of Chadron or two miles southeast of Chadron State Park measured a storm total snowfall of 7.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early morning heavy banded snowfall moved across the central and northeast portions of the Nebraska Panhandle producing high snowfall rates of up to 6 inches per hour based on overnight storm reports. By morning observations of various CoCoRaHS, COOP observers, law enforcement and public many county areas were blanketed with up to a foot of snow creating travel impacts as many roads were impassible while waiting for crews to clear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Official in Hemingford measured snowfall total of 6.0 inches with noted travel impacts as United States Highway 385 was completely snow-covered.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the late morning hours on March 19th, which continued into the early morning on March 20th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 8 inches. The snow combined with northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts around 45 mph at times to produce blowing and drifting snow with visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located near Merritt Reservoir reported 7 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches were common across the southeastern half of western Cherry County. North winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused visibility of 1/4 mile at times with blowing and drifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late-night severe thunderstorm brought hail as large as quarter size to Sherman County as it crossed over the border from CO to KS.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public shared a photo with NWS Goodland on social media which showed a hailstone next to a quarter coin to estimate the size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms moved east then across the CO/KS state line and then began to move northeast across northwest Kansas. The line of storms produced thunderstorm wind gusts up to 85 mph, up to penny size hail, and heavy rain up to 2.6 inches. The heavy rain caused localized Flash Flooding in parts of Sherman and Thomas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS station KGLD in Goodland measured a wind gust of 61 mph that was sustained for 2 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of training thunderstorms set up across southeast Kansas. Several rounds of storms developed over central Kansas and tracked southeastward causing isolated flooding in far southeastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along Lightning, Cherry and Fly creeks causing several roads to become inundated an impassable. Over two inches of rain was measured at multiple locations across Cherokee County. The Co-op Observer in Columbus measured 2.11 inches and Mesonet station BXTK1, 2.12 inches and EW0910, 2.29 inches, measured over two inches of rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of training thunderstorms set up across southeast Kansas. Several rounds of storms developed over central Kansas and tracked southeastward causing isolated flooding in far southeastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CoCoRAHS station KS-CR-3 near McCune measured 2.03 inches of rainfall.

The storms evolved into a forward propagating line of storms later in the morning, that produced damaging wind gusts across the Flint Hills and southeast Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms began developing over central Kansas very early on 5/4. Initial supercells produced very large hail, up to baseball size. The threat transitioned to more of a strong wind concern later in the morning. Winds up to 80 mph were reported with one storm and damage occurred in several different counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Siding torn off a building. Time estimated based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slight severe risk was draped across much of the CWA due to a surface convergent boundary over western counties with an approaching cold front from the north. Supercell thunderstorms developed along the convergent boundary during the late afternoon before forming into a complex line of storms along the front that lasted into the overnight hours. There was ample instability with CAPE over 2000J/kg coupled with decent shear up to 30KT and moisture influx due to the more saturated and unstable southeast low level flow. Early on with the supercells, funnel clouds and large hail were the main threats. Once the line developed and pushed south and east, damaging winds and hail became the hazards with many reports that verified a number of the warnings that were issued.

Persistent rainfall from a potent, slow moving upper low pressure system led to heavy rain and isolated flooding across south central Nebraska heading into the Memorial Day Holiday weekend. The worst of the flooding occurred near the Crystal Lake Recreation Area in Adams County, but pockets of minor/brief flooding were noted in and around Kearney as well.||Rain first moved into the area during the early morning hours of Thursday, May 21st as a closed upper low pressure system slowly moved into the area. More persistent and heavier rain developed within a west to east band focused along the Highway 6 and Interstate 80 corridors around midday Thursday, and persisted through the late afternoon. Brief and minor flooding occurred in poor drainage areas in and around Kearney Thursday afternoon. Activity weakened and became somewhat disorganized during the evening hours, but pockets of light to moderate rain persisted through Thursday night and into Friday morning, May 22nd. The most persistent band of rain, with some embedded thunderstorms, developed around dawn on Friday and blossomed in coverage such that the entire area was seeing rainfall by noon as the upper low slowly inched its way into north central Kansas. Rainfall was efficient through the entire afternoon due to a persistent feed of moisture into the system from the southeast and very slow movement of the upper low. This led to increased runoff into area streams and rivers such that sandbagging was needed by Friday evening in Holstein due to rising river levels along the Little Blue River. Rainfall rates slowly decreased Friday evening and the upper low gained a little bit of eastward momentum as it moved into southeast Nebraska and northeast Kansas. New thunderstorm development in these areas began to cut off the moisture flow into south central Nebraska, with only isolated light showers persisting into Friday night. Widespread rain amounts of 3 to 6 inches resulted in flooding along the Little Blue River, as well as the Crystal Lake Recreation Area, which led to camper evacuations. Flood damages and lost revenue totaled $10,000 for the recreation area alone. Additional damage occurred to infrastructure including Highway 74 near Ayr (which was closed for a time on Saturday, May 23rd), numerous county roads, as well as a BNSF railroad bridge just north of Crystal Lake.||Meteorologically speaking, it was somewhat unusual to have such a potent, slow-moving, and cut-off upper low pressure system so late into spring. The slow moving nature of the upper low, along with nearly stationary forcing from deformation within the northwest quadrant, were the key factors that led to such heavy rain amounts as precipitable water values were not overly high, around 1.1 to 1.4. Persistent cloud cover, cool surface temperatures, and weak mid level lapse rates kept instability values seasonably low, generally less than 1000 J/kg, meaning this heavy rain event was largely synoptic driven, with a lesser convective component than normally seen during late May.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain around and upstream of this area resulted in flooding during the Memorial Day holiday weekend. Widespread amounts of 3 to 6 inches fell, with much of the flooding affecting areas along the Little Blue River. Sandbagging was required in Holstein on the evening of the 22nd due to rising waters. Flooding affected the Crystal Lake Recreation Area near Ayr. All campers were evacuated, with flooding causing damage and a loss of revenue for the holiday weekend, totaling approximately 10,000 dollars. Numerous rural roads were damaged, and Highway 74 near Ayr was closed for a period of time due to debris becoming jammed under a bridge, causing water to rise over the road. The highway reopened during the late evening hours of May 23rd. Major damage to a BNSF trestle bridge was reported north of the Crystal Lake campground due to clogged water drainage and undermining. Flooding subsided on the 24th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Drought conditions were reported for Greeley and Wichita counties in May. Monthly precipitation ranged from to 1.40 to 2 below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts across the county for the month ranged from 0.03 to 0.06. This was 1.40 to 1.60 below normal for May.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of three rounds of storms occurred as a front interacted with very unstable air to produce numerous severe thunderstorms that caused extensive hail and wind damage over portions of the area.||The second round of storms developed near Topeka, KS and roared southeastward into east-central Missouri in the early afternoon, producing substantial straight-line wind damage.  ||The final round of severe storms developed in the late afternoon and evening along a warm front over southeast Kansas and far southwest Missouri, producing primarily large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail to the size of ping pong balls was reported. Several vehicles suffered minor hail damage from the hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported via MPing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold surface high pressure settled over western and north central Nebraska during the early morning and morning hours on May 10th. This caused freezing temperatures in the 20s across much of the area. The coldest temperatures was 21 degrees at Gordon airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Gordon AWOS recorded a minimum temperature of 21 degrees. Low temperatures in the lower to mid 20s were common throughout Sheridan County.

The first of three rounds of storms occurred as a front interacted with very unstable air to produce numerous severe thunderstorms that caused extensive hail and wind damage over portions of the area.||The second round of storms developed near Topeka, KS and roared southeastward into east-central Missouri in the early afternoon, producing substantial straight-line wind damage.  ||The final round of severe storms developed in the late afternoon and evening along a warm front over southeast Kansas and far southwest Missouri, producing primarily large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail from nickle to quarters in size was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail from dime to quarter size was reported.

An early morning cluster of elevated supercell thunderstorms produced very large hail across portions of central Kansas on May 3rd, 2020.  The storms evolved into a forward propagating line of storms later in the morning, that produced damaging wind gusts across the Flint Hills and southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees down in town. At least one tree was down on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold surface high pressure settled over western and north central Nebraska during the early morning and morning hours on May 10th. This caused freezing temperatures in the 20s across much of the area. The coldest temperatures was 21 degrees at Gordon airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Cooperative Observer site located in Atkinson recorded a minimum temperature of 29 degrees. Low temperatures in the upper 20s were common throughout Holt County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold surface high pressure settled over western and north central Nebraska during the early morning and morning hours on May 10th. This caused freezing temperatures in the 20s across much of the area. The coldest temperatures was 21 degrees at Gordon airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site located 6 miles northwest of Dunning recorded a minimum temperature of 22 degrees. Low temperatures in the lower to mid 20s were common throughout Blaine County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearby Cooperative Observer located 8 miles west northwest of Ericson recorded a minimum temperature of 26 degrees. Low temperatures in the mid to upper 20s were common throughout Garfield County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms began developing over central Kansas very early on 5/4. Initial supercells produced very large hail, up to baseball size. The threat transitioned to more of a strong wind concern later in the morning. Winds up to 80 mph were reported with one storm and damage occurred in several different counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EM estimated 75 to 80 mph wind gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree blown over, per social media pictures. Time estimated based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered storms produced isolated severe wind and hail during the nighttime hours of May 13 into May 14 north of Interstate 70.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small hail also observed. Time estimated based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slight severe risk was draped across much of the CWA due to a surface convergent boundary over western counties with an approaching cold front from the north. Supercell thunderstorms developed along the convergent boundary during the late afternoon before forming into a complex line of storms along the front that lasted into the overnight hours. There was ample instability with CAPE over 2000J/kg coupled with decent shear up to 30KT and moisture influx due to the more saturated and unstable southeast low level flow. Early on with the supercells, funnel clouds and large hail were the main threats. Once the line developed and pushed south and east, damaging winds and hail became the hazards with many reports that verified a number of the warnings that were issued.

The first of three rounds of storms occurred as a front interacted with very unstable air to produce numerous severe thunderstorms that caused extensive hail and wind damage over portions of the area.||The second round of storms developed near Topeka, KS and roared southeastward into east-central Missouri in the early afternoon, producing substantial straight-line wind damage.  ||The final round of severe storms developed in the late afternoon and evening along a warm front over southeast Kansas and far southwest Missouri, producing primarily large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of ping pong ball sized hail was received via MPing. Minor roof damage occurred to a home.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ping pong ball sized hail was reported in a mainly rural area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the early evening hours in the Nebraska Panhandle along an approaching cold front. As storms tracked east they became more widespread in nature. Large hail up to the size of tennis balls, and a measured wind gust of 86 MPH was reported at Broken Bow. Heavy rain early in the morning on the 24th, led to flash flooding north of Broken Bow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cramer Canyon Road has 4 feet of fast moving water running over it.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of severe t-storms some supercells developed across parts of northeast Kansas on the evening of May 14th.  At least 4 small short lived tornadoes were documented by storm chasers.  No damage was reported with any of the tornadoes so all will be classified as EFU although photos suggest they were small and short-lived.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail reported at KVOE studios.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dryline pushed out of eastern Colorado sparking up a couple of storms in the Meade County area. There was not sufficient enough low level moisture and instability along that dryline across the CWA staying well south into the Texas Panhandle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slight severe risk for much of the CWA due to a cold front pushing in from the northwest. With ample enough shear over 30kts and low level moisture ahead of it, a number of storms developed along and ahead the boundary giving way to large hail close to 3 inches in diameter. The storms out of eastern Colorado well behind the front came with mainly damaging winds and flooding hazards being more of cluster and lines that moved through the far western counties of the CWA.

Large hail up to the size of tennis balls, and a measured wind gust of 86 MPH was reported at Broken Bow. Heavy rain early in the morning on the 24th, led to flash flooding north of Broken Bow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to half dollar sized hail reported at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of severe t-storms some supercells developed across parts of northeast Kansas on the evening of May 14th.  At least 4 small short lived tornadoes were documented by storm chasers.  No damage was reported with any of the tornadoes so all will be classified as EFU although photos suggest they were small and short-lived.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea to quarter size hail covering the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Drought conditions were reported for Greeley and Wichita counties in May. Monthly precipitation ranged from to 1.40 to 2 below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts across the county for the month ranged from 0.02 to 0.12. This was 2 below normal for May.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept through the area late in the evening triggering thunderstorms ahead of it in the warm sector. With enough instability and shear, 1.5 to 2 inch hail was produced across Clark County. A severe thunderstorm watch was issued for the southern and eastern portions of the CWA with multiple warnings put out, but only three verified hail reports in the severe category.

A cold front swept through the area late in the evening triggering thunderstorms ahead of it in the warm sector. With enough instability and shear, 1.5 to 2 inch hail was produced across Clark County. A severe thunderstorm watch was issued for the southern and eastern portions of the CWA with multiple warnings put out, but only three verified hail reports in the severe category.

A slight severe risk was draped across much of the CWA due to a surface convergent boundary over western counties with an approaching cold front from the north. Supercell thunderstorms developed along the convergent boundary during the late afternoon before forming into a complex line of storms along the front that lasted into the overnight hours. There was ample instability with CAPE over 2000J/kg coupled with decent shear up to 30KT and moisture influx due to the more saturated and unstable southeast low level flow. Early on with the supercells, funnel clouds and large hail were the main threats. Once the line developed and pushed south and east, damaging winds and hail became the hazards with many reports that verified a number of the warnings that were issued.

A slight severe risk for much of the CWA due to a cold front pushing in from the northwest. With ample enough shear over 30kts and low level moisture ahead of it, a number of storms developed along and ahead the boundary giving way to large hail close to 3 inches in diameter. The storms out of eastern Colorado well behind the front came with mainly damaging winds and flooding hazards being more of cluster and lines that moved through the far western counties of the CWA.

Cold surface high pressure settled over western and north central Nebraska during the early morning and morning hours on May 10th. This caused freezing temperatures in the 20s across much of the area. The coldest temperatures was 21 degrees at Gordon airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Cooperative Observer located 8 miles west northwest of Ericson recorded a minimum temperature of 26 degrees. Low temperatures in the mid to upper 20s were common throughout Wheeler County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold surface high pressure settled over western and north central Nebraska during the early morning and morning hours on May 10th. This caused freezing temperatures in the 20s across much of the area. The coldest temperatures was 21 degrees at Gordon airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A RAWS site located 13 miles west northwest of Merritt Dam recorded a minimum temperature of 24 degrees. Low temperatures in the mid 20s were common throughout western Cherry County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold surface high pressure settled over western and north central Nebraska during the early morning and morning hours on May 10th. This caused freezing temperatures in the 20s across much of the area. The coldest temperatures was 21 degrees at Gordon airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The North Platte ASOS recorded a minimum temperature of 26 degrees. Low temperatures in the mid to upper 20s were common throughout Lincoln County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of severe t-storms some supercells developed across parts of northeast Kansas on the evening of May 14th.  At least 4 small short lived tornadoes were documented by storm chasers.  No damage was reported with any of the tornadoes so all will be classified as EFU although photos suggest they were small and short-lived.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm chasers also reported a small tornado on the ground northeast of Alta Vista.  No damage was reported from this tornado.  Other chasers viewing this storm from 15-20 miles east of it also reported a tornado around 825 pm looking west toward Wabaunsee County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of severe t-storms some supercells developed across parts of northeast Kansas on the evening of May 14th.  At least 4 small short lived tornadoes were documented by storm chasers.  No damage was reported with any of the tornadoes so all will be classified as EFU although photos suggest they were small and short-lived.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Additional supercell t-storms developed after 830 pm CDT and produced at least 1 additional tornado near where tornadoes had been reported about one hour prior.  Media outlet KVOE provided a video showing a small tornado northwest of Bushong around 9 pm CDT.  Minor damage was reported to an outbuilding and a trampoline was blown over near the end point of this tornado so it will be recorded as EF0.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours on May 3rd along a surface trough of low pressure in the Nebraska Panhandle. As storms moved east, they encountered better low level moisture and became severe. Hail up to the size of ping pong balls was reported along with 2 inches of rain in Hayes, Frontier and portions of Lincoln county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ground covered by hail up to the size of quarters.
