The late evening of Monday the 24th into the morning of Tuesday the 25th featured one of the most intriguing snow events of the 2019-20 winter season within this six-county North Central Kansas area. While roughly the northeast half of the area (particularly Jewell/Mitchell counties) received little to no overnight accumulation, an intense/narrow mesoscale band dumped as much as 6-9 of wet snow along a northwest-southeast axis through the heart of Phillips and Osborne counties (and clipping northeast Rooks and southwest Smith counties along the way).  Amounts this high concentrated within a swath no more than 10-15 miles wide, with totals tapering off to barely a dusting only a few miles on either side. Per several official reports (NWS coop observer/CoCoRaHS) and a few unofficial ones, some of the highest totals featured: 9.2 six miles east of Phillipsburg, 8.1 in Phillipsburg, 8 at Logan and 7-9 sixteen miles south-southeast of Osborne. To the southwest of the main band, more modest amounts included 3.2 four miles west-northwest of Plainville and 2 at Natoma. Despite the hefty totals within the primary snow stripe, the fact that this was a late night/early morning event and that winds averaged only 10-15 MPH through most of it kept travel impacts somewhat in check through roughly sunrise. However, north winds picked up as the day of the 25th wore on, with frequent gusts of 25-35 MPH combining with residual light snowfall to promote some drifting and reduced visibility. ||Breaking down timing, the main event associated with the intense mesoscale band unfolded over primarily a 7-9 hour span, getting underway between 11 p.m. and 2 a.m. as spotty light rain transitioned to steady snow, and weakening/gradually sinking south of the area between 7-9 a.m. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was a potent shortwave trough diving into the Central Plains from the north-northwest, featuring a compact/intense closed circulation that peaked in intensity while traversing the local area (especially evident at 700 millibars). As the already-strong zone of deep convergence/frontogenesis intercepted a pocket of steep mid-level lapse rates, the pronounced mesoscale band blossomed, starting out oriented predominantly north-south but gradually pivoting considerably more northwest-southeast in response to the movement of the parent system. At the surface, the relatively light breezes through the night resulted from the region temporarily residing within the heart of an inverted trough axis, before this boundary slipped south around sunrise and allowed stronger northerly winds to kick in. Temperature-wise, the wet nature of snow resulted from overnight readings holding up mainly in the low 30s F. From a forecast perspective this was a challenging event, as although it became increasingly evident 24-48 hours out that mesoscale banding might ensue, its eventual placement/intensity remained a major question mark until it materialized on radar. In the end, although forecasted maximum snow amounts proved to be significantly under-done, a good chance for at least 2-4 within the broader general area became apparent by the afternoon of the 24th, prompting the issuance of a Winter Weather Advisory.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall reports generally ranged from 6 to 9 inches, with the highest amounts falling in a narrow 10-15 mile wide corridor that ran north-northwest to southeast through the heart of the county. Extreme northeastern portions of the county had very little snow. NWS cooperative observer and trained spotter totals included 9.2 inches six miles east of Phillipsburg, 8.1 inches in Phillipsburg, 8 inches in Logan and 7 inches at Kirwin Dam. Public-reported totals included 5 inches seven miles north of Phillipsburg and 5 inches seven miles east-southeast of Prairie View.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Shortly after midnight a peak gust of 59 MPH occurred at the Hill City airport.
Another round of early morning elevated supercells produced very large hail across portions of central and south central Kansas on May 4th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was reported to be dime to quarter size. The hail lasted 5 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another round of early morning elevated supercells produced very large hail across portions of central and south central Kansas on May 4th, 2020.

Widespread showers and storms moved across the central sections of Kansas producing very heavy rain and a few lower end severe hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor street and low land flooding was reported in most communities across the county due to heavy rain on top of already saturated grounds.  Most rainfall amounts were between 1 and 2.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and storms moved across the central sections of Kansas producing very heavy rain and a few lower end severe hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle stalled in the water at the intersection of north main street and Mccollum.  Other areas along Main street also noted minor flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and storms moved across the central sections of Kansas producing very heavy rain and a few lower end severe hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Typical low lying rural areas are flooding due to the heavy rains. There was a report of an accident due to hydroplaning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and storms moved across the central sections of Kansas producing very heavy rain and a few lower end severe hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The report was relayed via social media.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm chasers reported a small tornado on the ground south of Council Grove.  Photos were also taken showing a narrow funnel extending near the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms began developing over central Kansas very early on 5/4. Initial supercells produced very large hail, up to baseball size. The threat transitioned to more of a strong wind concern later in the morning. Winds up to 80 mph were reported with one storm and damage occurred in several different counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball sized hail reported by trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brief landspout tornado occurred in Sherman County, Kansas on May 23rd, 2020. The tornado occurred for an estimated 3 minutes according to radar signatures and spotter accounts. No damage was reported with this tornado. Storms quickly developed in the afternoon hours, but it wasn't until early evening when any type of severe weather was produced.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief landspout tornado. Exact times and distance estimated by radar.

Isolated strong to severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours on May 3rd along a surface trough of low pressure in the Nebraska Panhandle. As storms moved east, they encountered better low level moisture and became severe. Hail up to the size of ping pong balls was reported along with 2 inches of rain in Hayes, Frontier and portions of Lincoln county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail and smaller hail stones reported at this location. Time estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and storms moved across the central sections of Kansas producing very heavy rain and a few lower end severe hail reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widely scattered severe storms moved across portions of south central and southeast Kansas during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 7th, 2020.  Hail up to quarter size and wind gusts to 60 mph were reported.

Widely scattered severe storms moved across portions of south central and southeast Kansas during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 7th, 2020.  Hail up to quarter size and wind gusts to 60 mph were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lots of small hail was reported, with some larger stones mixed in. It was hailing so hard the spotter thought the window would break, but the largest size stone was only nickel size.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak wind gust was reported at Eisenhower National Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the early evening hours in the Nebraska Panhandle along an approaching cold front. As storms tracked east they became more widespread in nature. Large hail up to the size of tennis balls, and a measured wind gust of 86 MPH was reported at Broken Bow. Heavy rain early in the morning on the 24th, led to flash flooding north of Broken Bow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser measured a 63 MPH wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over central Lincoln county during the early morning hours of May 21st. Quarter sized hail was reported.

Severe thunderstorms began developing over central Kansas very early on 5/4. Initial supercells produced very large hail, up to baseball size. The threat transitioned to more of a strong wind concern later in the morning. Winds up to 80 mph were reported with one storm and damage occurred in several different counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail reported by trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slight severe risk was draped across much of the CWA due to a surface convergent boundary over western counties with an approaching cold front from the north. Supercell thunderstorms developed along the convergent boundary during the late afternoon before forming into a complex line of storms along the front that lasted into the overnight hours. There was ample instability with CAPE over 2000J/kg coupled with decent shear up to 30KT and moisture influx due to the more saturated and unstable southeast low level flow. Early on with the supercells, funnel clouds and large hail were the main threats. Once the line developed and pushed south and east, damaging winds and hail became the hazards with many reports that verified a number of the warnings that were issued.

Severe thunderstorms moved across central Kansas during the evening of May 24th. These storms produced quarter to half dollar sized hail and damaging winds. Heavy rainfall associated with these storms resulted in flash flooding in Ellsworth, Russell and Saline counties. Some of the higher reports ranged from 3 inches to 6.59 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Courtesy of KAKE television station.

Heavy rainfall associated with these storms resulted in flash flooding in Ellsworth, Russell and Saline counties. Some of the higher reports ranged from 3 inches to 6.59 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Army Corp of Engineers at Wilson Lake.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small amount of quarter sized hail with minimal damage. Time is estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms dropped lots of hail, produced sporadic wind damage, and also caused widespread flooding and areas of flash flooding on May 15th, 2020.  Hail sized remained below 1.5 inches and the winds were between 60 and 70 mph.  Unfortunately, a tree was blown across a roadway and an individual did not see the tree and crashed into it and lost his life.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 160 was closed from the highway 160/99 intersection across all of Elk County to the Montgomery county line.

Unfortunately, a tree was blown across a roadway and an individual did not see the tree and crashed into it and lost his life.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few roads were closed in normal low water crossing areas.  Four mile creek being one of them.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported numerous trees down across the city with some blocking roadways. The time of this report and speed are based on the peak wind gust at the Salina Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ahead of a snow event, freezing rain occurred across areas of northwest Kansas the evening of February 19th into February 20th. This led to several accidents and injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle slid off Highway 25 and rolled multiple times 15 miles north of Colby, Kansas at 22:33 CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ahead of a snow event, freezing rain occurred across areas of northwest Kansas the evening of February 19th into February 20th. This led to several accidents and injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car tire was damaged due to a slide off accident at 1 mile southwest of Levant, Kansas at 22:33 CT. ||A 1 person accident occurred at 3 miles southwest of Gem, Kansas at 22:35 CT.  No other information was provided.||A semi rollover occurred at mile marker 69 on Interstate 70 at 5 miles north northwest of Oakley, Kansas 23:36 CT.||A semi jack knife accident occurred at mile marker 49 on Interstate 70 at 3 miles east southeast of Levant, Kansas at 1:04 CT.||A semi rollover accident occurred at the intersection of Old US Highway 24 and CR 11 at 1 mile west southwest of Levant, Kansas at 3:06 CT.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle rolled just south of the Highway 23 and CR X intersection at 22:50 CT.||A vehicle rolled multiple times at 1 mile south of Campus, Kansas at 00:00 CT.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Vehicle slid off Interstate 70, overturned, and struck a post and KDOT fence 2 miles east of Oakley, Kansas at 00:00 CT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widely scattered severe storms moved across portions of south central and southeast Kansas during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 7th, 2020.  Hail up to quarter size and wind gusts to 60 mph were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two distinct rounds of severe thunderstorms moved into eastern Kansas the morning of May 4. The first round was associated with a supercell that moved into Linn and Miami Counties and produced high winds. The second round was with a line of storms further west that moved through an hour or two later.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rural roads were flooded across the county.  In the town of Independence, Whiskey Creek flooded areas near several homes along North 19th and 15th streets.  It was reported that 2 feet of water was surrounding the homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The late evening of Monday the 24th into the morning of Tuesday the 25th featured one of the most intriguing snow events of the 2019-20 winter season within South Central Nebraska. While the majority of the 24-county area (including the Tri Cities) received little to no overnight accumulation, an intense/narrow mesoscale band dumped as much as 6-10 of wet snow on portions of Dawson, Gosper, Furnas and southwestern Harlan counties. Amounts this high concentrated within a swath no more than 10-15 miles wide, with totals tapering off to barely a dusting only a few miles on either side. Per several official reports (NWS coop observer/CoCoRaHS) and a few unofficial ones, some of the highest totals featured: 10 in Elwood, 9 nine miles north of Edison, 8 in Edison, 6-8 at Beaver City and 7.1 six miles southwest of Lexington. On the periphery of the main band, more modest amounts included: 4.5 in Cozad, 4 at Gothenburg and 3 in Cambridge. Despite the hefty totals within the primary snow stripe, the fact that this was a late night/early morning event and that winds averaged only 10-15 MPH through most of it kept travel impacts somewhat in check through roughly sunrise. However, north winds picked up as the day of the 25th wore on, with frequent gusts of 25-35 MPH combining with residual light snowfall to promote some drifting and reduced visibility. ||Breaking down timing, the main event associated with the intense mesoscale band unfolded over primarily a 7-9 hour span, getting underway between 10 p.m. and midnight as spotty light rain transitioned to steady snow, and weakening/gradually sinking southward into Kansas between 5-7 a.m. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was a potent shortwave trough diving into the Central Plains from the north-northwest, featuring a compact/intense closed circulation that peaked in intensity while traversing the local area (especially evident at 700 millibars). As the already-strong zone of deep convergence/frontogenesis intercepted a pocket of steep mid-level lapse rates, the pronounced mesoscale band blossomed, starting out oriented predominantly north-south but gradually pivoting more northwest-southeast in response to the movement of the parent system. At the surface, the relatively light breezes through the night resulted from the region temporarily residing within the heart of an inverted trough axis, before this boundary slipped south around sunrise and allowed stronger northerly winds to kick in. Temperature-wise, the wet nature of snow resulted from overnight readings holding up mainly in the low 30s F. From a forecast perspective this was a challenging event, as although it became increasingly evident 24-48 hours out that mesoscale banding might ensue, its eventual placement/intensity remained a major question mark until it materialized on radar. In the end, although forecasted maximum snow amounts proved to be significantly under-done, a good chance for at least 2-4 within the broader general area became apparent by the afternoon of the 24th, prompting the issuance of a Winter Weather Advisory.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall reports generally ranged from an inch or 2 across the eastern half of the county, with higher amounts of 4-8 inches across the western half of the county. Reported totals included 7.1 inches six miles southwest of Lexington, 6.1 inches four miles south of Cozad, 4.5 inches in Cozad and 4 inches at Gothenburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two distinct rounds of severe thunderstorms moved into eastern Kansas the morning of May 4. The first round was associated with a supercell that moved into Linn and Miami Counties and produced high winds. The second round was with a line of storms further west that moved through an hour or two later.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A barn was blown down at K-32 and 206th Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms began developing over central Kansas very early on 5/4. Initial supercells produced very large hail, up to baseball size. The threat transitioned to more of a strong wind concern later in the morning. Winds up to 80 mph were reported with one storm and damage occurred in several different counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EM reported golf ball size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slight severe risk was draped across much of the CWA due to a surface convergent boundary over western counties with an approaching cold front from the north. Supercell thunderstorms developed along the convergent boundary during the late afternoon before forming into a complex line of storms along the front that lasted into the overnight hours. There was ample instability with CAPE over 2000J/kg coupled with decent shear up to 30KT and moisture influx due to the more saturated and unstable southeast low level flow. Early on with the supercells, funnel clouds and large hail were the main threats. Once the line developed and pushed south and east, damaging winds and hail became the hazards with many reports that verified a number of the warnings that were issued.

A slight severe risk for much of the CWA due to a cold front pushing in from the northwest. With ample enough shear over 30kts and low level moisture ahead of it, a number of storms developed along and ahead the boundary giving way to large hail close to 3 inches in diameter. The storms out of eastern Colorado well behind the front came with mainly damaging winds and flooding hazards being more of cluster and lines that moved through the far western counties of the CWA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across central Kansas during the evening of May 24th. These storms produced quarter to half dollar sized hail and damaging winds. Heavy rainfall associated with these storms resulted in flash flooding in Ellsworth, Russell and Saline counties. Some of the higher reports ranged from 3 inches to 6.59 inches.

A slight severe risk was draped across much of the CWA due to a surface convergent boundary over western counties with an approaching cold front from the north. Supercell thunderstorms developed along the convergent boundary during the late afternoon before forming into a complex line of storms along the front that lasted into the overnight hours. There was ample instability with CAPE over 2000J/kg coupled with decent shear up to 30KT and moisture influx due to the more saturated and unstable southeast low level flow. Early on with the supercells, funnel clouds and large hail were the main threats. Once the line developed and pushed south and east, damaging winds and hail became the hazards with many reports that verified a number of the warnings that were issued.

There was ample instability with CAPE over 2000J/kg coupled with decent shear up to 30KT and moisture influx due to the more saturated and unstable southeast low level flow. Early on with the supercells, funnel clouds and large hail were the main threats. Once the line developed and pushed south and east, damaging winds and hail became the hazards with many reports that verified a number of the warnings that were issued.

A slight severe risk for much of the CWA due to a cold front pushing in from the northwest. With ample enough shear over 30kts and low level moisture ahead of it, a number of storms developed along and ahead the boundary giving way to large hail close to 3 inches in diameter. The storms out of eastern Colorado well behind the front came with mainly damaging winds and flooding hazards being more of cluster and lines that moved through the far western counties of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was another landspout tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slight severe risk for much of the CWA due to a cold front pushing in from the northwest. With ample enough shear over 30kts and low level moisture ahead of it, a number of storms developed along and ahead the boundary giving way to large hail close to 3 inches in diameter. The storms out of eastern Colorado well behind the front came with mainly damaging winds and flooding hazards being more of cluster and lines that moved through the far western counties of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a slow moving elephant trunk tornado but there was nothing for the tornado to damage as it moved across sagebrush and pastures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across central Kansas during the evening of May 24th. These storms produced quarter to half dollar sized hail and damaging winds. Heavy rainfall associated with these storms resulted in flash flooding in Ellsworth, Russell and Saline counties. Some of the higher reports ranged from 3 inches to 6.59 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Event total of 4 inches in the last 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms dropped lots of hail, produced sporadic wind damage, and also caused widespread flooding and areas of flash flooding on May 15th, 2020.  Hail sized remained below 1.5 inches and the winds were between 60 and 70 mph.  Unfortunately, a tree was blown across a roadway and an individual did not see the tree and crashed into it and lost his life.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a 24 hour rainfall report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two distinct rounds of severe thunderstorms moved into eastern Kansas the morning of May 4. The first round was associated with a supercell that moved into Linn and Miami Counties and produced high winds. The second round was with a line of storms further west that moved through an hour or two later.

Severe thunderstorms began developing over central Kansas very early on 5/4. Initial supercells produced very large hail, up to baseball size. The threat transitioned to more of a strong wind concern later in the morning. Winds up to 80 mph were reported with one storm and damage occurred in several different counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Location experienced about 12 minutes of golf ball to baseball sized hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 39 was closed at 40th Street and Flat Rock Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours on Tuesday April 28th, 2020, an exiting system brought brief high winds. Most wind gusts were below High Wind criteria. A wind gust report of 60 mph was reported near McCook, Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at 1 E McCook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours on Tuesday April 28th, 2020, an exiting system brought brief high winds. Most wind gusts were below High Wind criteria. A wind gust report of 59 mph was reported near Hill City, Kansas.||Strong winds and dry soil caused blowing dust just north of Oakley, Kansas on US Highway 83. Visibilities in the dust were a quarter mile or less.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility down to a 1/4 sm or less due to blowing dust 5 north of Oakley on US Highway 83.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon hours on Tuesday April 28th, 2020, an exiting system brought brief high winds. Most wind gusts were below High Wind criteria. A wind gust report of 59 mph was reported near Hill City, Kansas.||Strong winds and dry soil caused blowing dust just north of Oakley, Kansas on US Highway 83. Visibilities in the dust were a quarter mile or less.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at 1 NE Hill City, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large complex of strong to severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front|during the afternoon and evening as a dry line and cold front moved across the region and interacted with a very unstable airmass. The storms produced widespread straight-line wind damage around Columbus, Kansas before moving into Missouri. Rainfall accumulations over an inch were widespread across the area, with localized amounts over one and a half inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were reported down in McCune via photos on social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm moved through Chautauqua, Elk, Montgomery and Wilson counties. The most significant damage occurred to a National Weather Service CO-OP observers residence, where damage occurred to a couple of out buildings and some trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant damage occurred at a farmstead just south of Hale. Several 80+ year old trees were either uprooted or snapped at the base. Two machine sheds were damaged as well. The spotter was unsure of the wind speed but thought it was at least 80 mph if not stronger.  The Chautauqua Emergency Manager performed a damage survey (including an aerial survey with a drone) and was able to determine that the damage was caused by straight line downburst winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of otherwise sub-severe showers with little to no lightning produced a brief period of 70 mph winds near Jarbalo, KS.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds associated with an area of otherwise non-severe showers with little to no lightning produced 72 mph winds per local emergency management.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level short wave came off of the Rocky Mountains out over the central Plains. This led to a surface low developing over Kansas. In front of that surface low, warm moist air was advected north. Isentropic upglide and led to an overrunning precipitation event that led to some high snowfall totals in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. It was the #5 (5.4 inches) and #4 (4.5 inches) highest April snowfall events for Omaha and Lincoln respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 8 inches of snow at Schuyler, NE.

In front of that surface low, warm moist air was advected north. Isentropic upglide and led to an overrunning precipitation event that led to some high snowfall totals in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. It was the #5 (5.4 inches) and #4 (4.5 inches) highest April snowfall events for Omaha and Lincoln respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP Observer reported 7 inches of snow near Fremont, NE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level short wave came off of the Rocky Mountains out over the central Plains. This led to a surface low developing over Kansas. In front of that surface low, warm moist air was advected north. Isentropic upglide and led to an overrunning precipitation event that led to some high snowfall totals in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. It was the #5 (5.4 inches) and #4 (4.5 inches) highest April snowfall events for Omaha and Lincoln respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many, many public reports coming in over 6 inches. Highest reported total was 8 inches. Official report at Eppley Airfield was 5.4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms moved across central and south central Kansas in the early afternoon and evening producing hail from ping pong ball sized to over three inches in diameter. Wind was another factor with up to 80 mph winds and respective damage reported in Barton and Kingman counties. When the threat moved into south central Kansas, the clusters had congealed and transitioned into a squall line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water reported over Old Highway 40 and 6th Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding, with multiple streets under water. Up to 8 inches deep in spots. Photos via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stubborn cold air remained near the surface while strong warm advection ahead of a mid-level trough resulted in a distinct above-freezing layer. The result was a period of light freezing rain and freezing drizzle, which produced a glaze of ice on objects and roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of light freezing rain resulted in ice accumulation from one to two tenths of an inch, followed by light snowfall with up to 0.6 inches at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough pushed from the southwest across much of the area and combined with a retreating warm front.  That set the stage for a shallow warm layer just above the surface resulting in a freezing rain event for many counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation of a little less than 1/4 of an inch 5 miles SW of Howell (just into Gray county).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough pushed from the southwest across much of the area and combined with a retreating warm front.  That set the stage for a shallow warm layer just above the surface resulting in a freezing rain event for many counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high wind event occurred during the afternoon and evening hours of January 17th with wind gusts in northwest Kansas as high as 69 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Goodland (KGLD) ASOS measured a wind gust up to 69 mph on the backside of a winter surface trough. Sustained winds around 40 mph were measured at times throughout the evening of January 17th in Goodland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high wind event occurred during the afternoon and evening hours of January 17th with wind gusts in northwest Kansas as high as 69 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station about 4 miles ENE of Gem measured a wind gust of 61 mph with sustained winds of 41 mph. In addition, the AWOS in Colby measured a wind gust of 59 mph with sustained winds of 40 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high wind event occurred during the afternoon and evening hours of January 17th with wind gusts in northwest Kansas as high as 69 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cold front passage brought High Winds to Graham County during the early morning hours of January 18th. The peak wind gust was recorded around 1 am after the front moved through on January 17th around 11 pm CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The most significant winter storm during January started as a surge of warm advection, followed by a strong trough through the southern Rockies on Friday, January 17. A period of moderate to heavy snowfall swept across the area, accompanied by southerly winds gusting to 35 to 45 mph. Snowfall then tapered off to a period of light freezing rain and freezing drizzle into the evening hours, before changing back to snow. By late evening and early in the overnight, winds transitioned to northwest and increased to 35 to 45 mph, with gusts of 50 to 60 mph common as low pressure intensified across Iowa. Strong winds persisted most of Saturday as the area of low pressure moved slowly toward the western Great Lakes. Most areas received between 4 and 8 inches of snowfall as well as a glaze of ice, with just shy of a quarter inch of ice in the Sioux City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of heavy snowfall with winds gusting to 30 to 40 mph moved through during the morning and early afternoon of January 17, before tapering to several hours of freezing drizzle. Ice accumulations were generally a glaze to a tenth of an inch, before precipitation changed back to snow in the evening. Winds then picked up from the northwest, with peak wind gusts during the morning reaching 47 mph 2 miles east of Concord. Combined with snowfall and previous snow, winds produced numerous hours with visibility of around one-quarter mile or less with travel not recommended. Total snowfall reached 5.5 inches at Newcastle and Ponca, and 4.4 inches at Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The most significant winter storm during January started as a surge of warm advection, followed by a strong trough through the southern Rockies on Friday, January 17. A period of moderate to heavy snowfall swept across the area, accompanied by southerly winds gusting to 35 to 45 mph. Snowfall then tapered off to a period of light freezing rain and freezing drizzle into the evening hours, before changing back to snow. By late evening and early in the overnight, winds transitioned to northwest and increased to 35 to 45 mph, with gusts of 50 to 60 mph common as low pressure intensified across Iowa. Strong winds persisted most of Saturday as the area of low pressure moved slowly toward the western Great Lakes. Most areas received between 4 and 8 inches of snowfall as well as a glaze of ice, with just shy of a quarter inch of ice in the Sioux City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of heavy snowfall with winds gusting to 30 to 40 mph moved through during the morning and early afternoon of January 17, before tapering to several hours of freezing drizzle. Ice accumulations were generally a glaze to a tenth of an inch, before precipitation changed back to snow in the evening. Winds then picked up from the northwest, with peak wind gusts during the morning reaching 45 mph in South Sioux City. Combined with snowfall and previous snow, winds produced numerous hours with visibility of around one-quarter mile or less with travel not recommended. Total snowfall reached 2.2 inches at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorm developed in the northern Nebraska panhandle the afternoon of 2 July 2020. This supercell produced very large hail and a tornado touched down near Marsland Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS damage survey confirmed EF-2 Tornado that developed 5.8 miles east of Marsland and traveled west-northwest for 3.4 miles. Several large hardwood tree trunks/branches snapped. Trees uprooted, center pivot point mangled and three steel power poles were destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe weather with flooding rains occurred on January 10, with colder air moving into the region. This cold air intrusion then turned the rain to freezing drizzle and snow over portions of southeast Kansas during the early morning hours of January 11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pittsburg Fire reported 2.0 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe weather with flooding rains occurred on January 10, with colder air moving into the region. This cold air intrusion then turned the rain to freezing drizzle and snow over portions of southeast Kansas during the early morning hours of January 11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total snowfall of 3.0 inches was reported by the public 2 miles SSW of Frontenac Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough pushed from the southwest across much of the area and combined with a retreating warm front.  That set the stage for a shallow warm layer just above the surface resulting in a freezing rain event for many counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation of around 1/2 of an inch in Kismet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system moved into Kansas bringing quite a bit of moisture with it.  The main issue with this system would be temperatures and the precipitation type.  Trying to decipher the liquid/frozen line would prove difficult.  Once the transition to ice did occur, it did not last long but did hit with a cause significant issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of snow then freezing rain occurred across the county with most locations between 0.1 and 0.25 inches of ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system moved into Kansas bringing quite a bit of moisture with it.  The main issue with this system would be temperatures and the precipitation type.  Trying to decipher the liquid/frozen line would prove difficult.  Once the transition to ice did occur, it did not last long but did hit with a cause significant issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of snow then freezing rain occurred across the county with ice accumulations up to 0.3 tenths of an inch being reported.  Most locations varied between 0.1 and 0.25 inches of ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level disturbance worked northeast from Colorado early morning January 12 into Iowa by late day.  Broad lift initially within the warm advection zone became increasingly concentrated, with deeper lift in the dendritic growth layer by afternoon across northwest Iowa.  Snowfall rates up to 1.5 to 2 inches per hour were noted across northwest Iowa and northeast Nebraska at the peak during the late afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to briefly heavy snowfall during the afternoon accumulated to 5.0 inches at Ponca and 3.3 inches near Concord, resulting in hazardous road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level disturbance pushed across the CWA into the overnight hours on the 28th and throughout the day on the 29th.  The heaviest snow fell at the beginning of the event. Moist upslope flow ahead of this system allowed for some high accumulating snow, especially for southern counties stretching from Liberal to Bucklin pushing around the foot mark with areas north around 6 inches in the Dodge City area and less further north towards Hays. A winter storm warning was issued from Finney to Seward County and points east to Edwards and Comanche. All other areas were in winter weather advisories that saw less accumulations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 13 inches was observed at a location 5 miles south of Sublette.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed in southeastern Kansas on 4/28, clipping the far southeastern tip of the Topeka CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light freezing rain and dense freezing fog event occurred between the 16th and 17th of January in northwest Kansas. Ice accumulations and poor visibility led to dangerous driving conditions across the area, although only one car accident was reported in northwest Kansas and roads largely remained open.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local law enforcement reported a rollover accident caused by icy road conditions about 3 miles north of the Greeley County line along KS Hwy 27. Local deputies on the scene of the accident reported as much as half an inch of ice accumulation on the roadway and that it was very dangerous to walk on.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light freezing rain and dense freezing fog event occurred between the 16th and 17th of January in southwest Nebraska. Ice accumulations and poor visibility led to dangerous driving conditions across the area. Although numerous minor car accidents were reported in McCook, roads largely remained open.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The McCook Police Department reported that light freezing rain and dense freezing fog had led to icy road surfaces which caused numerous minor accidents across the city of McCook throughout the day on January 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Brief evening period of high winds were felt across the far southwestern portion of the Nebraska Panhandle with maximum winds gusts of 59 mph being measured out in Scotts Bluff and Kimball.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sensor at Scotts Bluff or two miles west of Gering measured the reported wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Brief evening period of high winds were felt across the far southwestern portion of the Nebraska Panhandle with maximum winds gusts of 59 mph being measured out in Scotts Bluff and Kimball.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nebraska Department of Roads sensor NE001 along Banner Road on North 71 near Long Springs measured the period of sustained winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of heavy snowfall fell across portions of the southern Nebraska Panhandle. COOP stations near Broadwater and south of Bushnell measured heavy snowfall amounts of 6.0 and 7.1 inches respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer located fifteen miles south of Bushnell measured a total snowfall of 7.1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of heavy snowfall fell across portions of the southern Nebraska Panhandle. COOP stations near Broadwater and south of Bushnell measured heavy snowfall amounts of 6.0 and 7.1 inches respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer located ten miles south-southeast of Broadwater measured a total snowfall of 6.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong weather producing system moved across the area bringing a mixture of inclement weather, some of which was convective in nature.  Much of precipitation began as liquid, however, the further north in the state, the transition to ice began.  With a strong surface front moving through, cold air was ushered in at all locations and the liquid and freezing precipitation soon turned to frozen precipitation in the form of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulations up to one quarter inch reported in McPherson and surrounding areas.  I small amount of snow was also noted with amounts generally less than one inch.  Roads were being reported as quite slick.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of ice and snow caused significant issues for travel across the county.  Ice amounts up to one tenth of an inch were reported in and around Salina.  Snow amounts were generally less than 1 inch at most locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the county ranged from 2 to 4 inches.  The highest accumulations were generally along the far southern sections of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Brisk winds in advance of the center of strong arctic high pressure brought wind chill readings to -25 to -35 during the overnight and morning of January 19.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coldest wind chill readings reached -30F at 0300CST January 19 at a location 2 miles east of Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few instances of severe winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas just after sunrise on the morning of the 4th. Widespread rain and weak convection occurred the previous night across most of south central Nebraska, but the thunderstorms that produced the severe winds across Smith County were part of a much larger arc of thunderstorms that developed from central into eastern Kansas around and just after sunrise. The majority of this arc of thunderstorms grew upscale and organized just southeast of the coverage area and ultimately went on to produce fairly widespread severe hail and wind across central and eastern Kansas and adjacent portions of western Missouri during the mid to late morning hours of the 4th. There were only two severe wind reports, both in Smith County, and no reports of wind damage, suggesting that the majority of thunderstorms over the local area were sub-severe.||The thunderstorms developed along a zone of low level warm air advection and deep moisture convergence, associated with the nose of a veering 25-30 kt low level jet, co-located with a coupled upper jet structure noted on the 12Z 300mb upper air analysis chart. A moderately strong vorticity lobe ejecting east-northeast across the central Plains from a much larger upper trough situated over the northern Rockies also aided in lift. Thunderstorms were fueled by a large reservoir of most unstable CAPE values of 2000-3000 J/kg across central Kansas, fed north and east into the arc of thunderstorms by the aforementioned low level jet. Effective shear was also impressive, on the order of 45-55 kt, owing to south-southeasterly low level winds veering and increasing to over 50kt in the mid levels. As such, instability and shear was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms, with the greatest combination noted just south and east of the local area.

Thunderstorms brought heavy rain and a landspout to portions of south central Nebraska the evening of Sunday, May 24 into the early morning hours of Memorial Day, Monday, May 25.||Just after 6 PM CDT Sunday evening, weak thundershowers began developing along a frontal boundary that was located from near Stockton, KS to Red Cloud, NE to Shelby, NE. One of these weak thundershowers managed to spawn a landspout tornado a few miles west of Davenport, NE, in extreme northeastern portions of Nuckolls County. This landspout, unlike most, did cause some damage as nearly a dozen empty coal railroad cars were overturned. The aforementioned line of thunderstorms strengthened slightly during the evening, per radar reflectivity, before weakening with loss of daytime heating around sunset. The landspout was the only known severe weather caused by this line of thunderstorms as the main focus for severe convection remained further south across Kansas near the Interstate 70 corridor.||Showers and thunderstorms blossomed over south central Nebraska and north central Kansas after 10 PM Sunday and continued through the entire overnight. This activity remained non-severe, but very slow storm motions and abundant deep layer moisture allowed for heavy rain rates and, subsequently, pockets of very heavy rainfall. The heaviest rainfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches (per radar and ground truth observations) appeared to focus across northwest Adams County and southwest Hall County. Numerous county roads became submerged in water and impassable late Sunday night into early Monday morning. The most severe impact, however, was to a residence northwest of Kenesaw as flood water filled the basement and even encroached on the main floor, prompting their rescue early Monday morning. The rescue had to be done via air boat because so many roads in the area were under water and impassable. ||The heavy rain from Sunday night into Monday morning occurred over areas that were already saturated from recent heavy rains from May 21-23, and this likely contributed to the flooding impacts from this event. Very slow storm motions and seasonably high precipitable water values near 1.5 were also meteorological factors to this heavy rain event. The tornado occurred in conditions fairly typical of landspouts as it was along a surface front with abundant ambient vorticity that was stretched into the vertical axis by steep low level lapse rates and sufficient 0-3 km CAPE near 100 J/kg.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landspout tornado was confirmed via several eyewitness reports and a damage survey in northern Nuckolls County. This tornado formed along a weak frontal boundary and exhibited the classic landspout characteristics of a long, translucent condensation/dust funnel. The landspout moved southwest along the boundary for over 3 miles. The main damage along its path was the overturning of 11 empty coal railroad cars. Otherwise, damage was minimal. The maximum wind speed was estimated to be 80 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few instances of severe winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas just after sunrise on the morning of the 4th. Widespread rain and weak convection occurred the previous night across most of south central Nebraska, but the thunderstorms that produced the severe winds across Smith County were part of a much larger arc of thunderstorms that developed from central into eastern Kansas around and just after sunrise. The majority of this arc of thunderstorms grew upscale and organized just southeast of the coverage area and ultimately went on to produce fairly widespread severe hail and wind across central and eastern Kansas and adjacent portions of western Missouri during the mid to late morning hours of the 4th. There were only two severe wind reports, both in Smith County, and no reports of wind damage, suggesting that the majority of thunderstorms over the local area were sub-severe.||The thunderstorms developed along a zone of low level warm air advection and deep moisture convergence, associated with the nose of a veering 25-30 kt low level jet, co-located with a coupled upper jet structure noted on the 12Z 300mb upper air analysis chart. A moderately strong vorticity lobe ejecting east-northeast across the central Plains from a much larger upper trough situated over the northern Rockies also aided in lift. Thunderstorms were fueled by a large reservoir of most unstable CAPE values of 2000-3000 J/kg across central Kansas, fed north and east into the arc of thunderstorms by the aforementioned low level jet. Effective shear was also impressive, on the order of 45-55 kt, owing to south-southeasterly low level winds veering and increasing to over 50kt in the mid levels. As such, instability and shear was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms, with the greatest combination noted just south and east of the local area.

A mesoscale convective system (MCS) developed over central Nebraska, then moved east-southeast during the early morning hours of Sunday, May 24, bringing damaging winds to portions of the area.||Thunderstorms developed just west of the Hastings County Warning Area (CWA), in Lincoln and Custer Counties, around 10 PM CDT on the evening of Saturday, May 23. Another line of thunderstorms developed over western Nebraska and moved eastward through the evening hours. The central Nebraska cluster was very slow moving, and even stationary at times, which allowed the two clusters to merge over Custer County around midnight on Sunday, May 24. Shortly after this merger, the line of thunderstorms gained eastward momentum and moved into Valley and Sherman Counties around 1 AM CDT, bringing with them strong, damaging winds. The line weakened slightly as it continued to track east-southeast during the early morning hours on Sunday, with the strongest activity tracking along and northeast of a line from Loup City, NE to York, NE. Measured wind gusts were generally near or less than 60 mph, including a gust of 54 mph measured by the ASOS at the Ord Airport, and a 57mph gust measured by a mesonet site at Scotia. The strongest measured gust was 63mph by a mesonet station 6 NNE of Sherman Reservoir at 1:35 AM CDT. Estimated wind gusts as high as 70 mph were reported in Valley and Sherman Counties, which resulted in the toppling of several irrigation pivots in these areas. The line of thunderstorms exited the Hastings CWA to the east between 4-5 AM CDT.||A nocturnal line of thunderstorms (aka MCS), such as this, is common for this area during the late spring and summer months. Thunderstorms were fueled by a 40 kt southerly low level jet, which advected strong instability (most unstable CAPE values near 3000 J/kg) from northern Kansas into central Nebraska and provided convergence/ascent for elevated parcels at the terminus of this jet over central Nebraska. Moderate effective shear up to 40 kt also aided in thunderstorm organization, along with an established cold pool associated with the western cluster of convection.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar estimates depicted an area of approximately 4 to 8 inches of rain fell in a very concentrated area across far southwestern portions of Hall County and far northwestern portions of Adams County. Numerous rural roads were covered in water and impassable for a period of time. A home just northwest of Kenesaw was flooded, and the residents had to be rescued. Due to road conditions, the rescue was not completed until daybreak on the 25th, and was done by airboat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slight severe risk for much of the CWA due to a cold front pushing in from the northwest. With ample enough shear over 30kts and low level moisture ahead of it, a number of storms developed along and ahead the boundary giving way to large hail close to 3 inches in diameter. The storms out of eastern Colorado well behind the front came with mainly damaging winds and flooding hazards being more of cluster and lines that moved through the far western counties of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a brief landspout tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was a fairly windy Tuesday across all of South Central Nebraska, especially between late-morning and sunset, with north-northwest winds commonly sustained 20-35 MPH and frequent gusts 35-45 MPH behind a typical spring cold front. However, primarily between 3-9 p.m. CDT a few bands of high-based rain showers and a few embedded weak thunderstorms passed through the area, allowing more intense gusts of 55-60+ MPH to mix down to the surface along various gust fronts. A few of the strongest official severe-criteria gusts at area airports included 61 MPH at Ord and 59 MPH at Kearney. Meanwhile, unofficial personal weather station clocked gusts up to 63 MPH near Fullerton and 62 MPH near Bladen. There was no known damage from these locally-enhanced winds, but there were several reports (and social media posts) of blowing dust. ||In the mid-upper levels, the strong winds and passing showers were instigated by a potent shortwave trough diving southeastward into the Central Plains. Deep mixing and fairly strong, unidirectional wind profiles from the surface to the mid-levels were present, but ambient wind speeds at the 850 millibar level only averaged 30-40 knots. Thus, it reasons that without the presence of shallow convection, sporadic severe-criteria winds would not have mixed to the surface. However, the low-level environment ahead of the weak convection was supportive of strong downdrafts, featuring steep lapse rates and pronounced surface temperature-dewpoint spreads on the order of 25-30 F, as afternoon highs topped out mainly low-mid 70s F with dewpoints averaging low-40s F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 59 MPH was measured by the Kearney Regional Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain and a landspout to portions of south central Nebraska the evening of Sunday, May 24 into the early morning hours of Memorial Day, Monday, May 25.||Just after 6 PM CDT Sunday evening, weak thundershowers began developing along a frontal boundary that was located from near Stockton, KS to Red Cloud, NE to Shelby, NE. One of these weak thundershowers managed to spawn a landspout tornado a few miles west of Davenport, NE, in extreme northeastern portions of Nuckolls County. Very slow storm motions and seasonably high precipitable water values near 1.5 were also meteorological factors to this heavy rain event. The tornado occurred in conditions fairly typical of landspouts as it was along a surface front with abundant ambient vorticity that was stretched into the vertical axis by steep low level lapse rates and sufficient 0-3 km CAPE near 100 J/kg.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar estimates depicted an area of approximately 4 to 8 inches of rain fell in a very concentrated area across far southwestern portions of Hall County and far northwestern portions of Adams County. Numerous rural roads were covered in water and impassable for a period of time. At least 19 roads were marked with barricades and at least 1 culvert was lost. A number of roads were washed out pretty well, materials like dirt, crushed concrete and gravel were needed for repairs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was a fairly windy Tuesday across all of South Central Nebraska, especially between late-morning and sunset, with north-northwest winds commonly sustained 20-35 MPH and frequent gusts 35-45 MPH behind a typical spring cold front. However, primarily between 3-9 p.m. CDT a few bands of high-based rain showers and a few embedded weak thunderstorms passed through the area, allowing more intense gusts of 55-60+ MPH to mix down to the surface along various gust fronts. A few of the strongest official severe-criteria gusts at area airports included 61 MPH at Ord and 59 MPH at Kearney. Meanwhile, unofficial personal weather station clocked gusts up to 63 MPH near Fullerton and 62 MPH near Bladen. There was no known damage from these locally-enhanced winds, but there were several reports (and social media posts) of blowing dust. ||In the mid-upper levels, the strong winds and passing showers were instigated by a potent shortwave trough diving southeastward into the Central Plains. Deep mixing and fairly strong, unidirectional wind profiles from the surface to the mid-levels were present, but ambient wind speeds at the 850 millibar level only averaged 30-40 knots. Thus, it reasons that without the presence of shallow convection, sporadic severe-criteria winds would not have mixed to the surface. However, the low-level environment ahead of the weak convection was supportive of strong downdrafts, featuring steep lapse rates and pronounced surface temperature-dewpoint spreads on the order of 25-30 F, as afternoon highs topped out mainly low-mid 70s F with dewpoints averaging low-40s F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 61 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 1 mile west of Heartwell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure intensified moving from southeast Colorado on the morning of March 19, into the Great Lakes early on March 20. A strong band of mid-level frontogenesis progressed slowly eastward across the area during the afternoon and evening hours. The system was initially quite warm, resulting in a swath of moderate to heavy rainfall from northeast Nebraska into northwest Iowa. As the system strengthened on the 19th, much colder air was dragged into the frontal band, and precipitation turned quickly from rain to snow from northwest to southeast, and was accompanied by winds gusting 40 to 55 mph. Snowfall was generally from 1 to 5 inches near and south of Interstate 90, with heaviest bands near the Missouri River and again from the Sioux Falls area eastward along Interstate 90.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain changed quickly to snowfall by early evening on March 19, with visibility to one-half mile at times between 1700-2100CST. The intense snowfall rate made travel hazardous during the evening as winds increased to a peak of 41 mph at Yankton and 38 mph at Wayne. Snowfall totaled 5.4 inches at Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of May 4th, several severe thunderstorms moved eastward from Colorado in the southwestern Nebraska area. This episode saw reports of damaging thunderstorm wind gusts up to 80 mph in addition to hail up to 1 in size and rainfall totals up to 1 in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported 1 inch hail at his location via a phone call.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report received of thunderstorm winds causing the following damage at this location: 8 ft wooden fence panels were picked up and thrown across the yard, a tall yard lamp was knocked off its foundation, and patio furniture was pushed over. Estimated wind gust speed based on storm damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured and reported a thunderstorm wind gust of 62 mph at location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not overly-impactful to area travel, Thursday the 16th featured a fairly noteworthy late-season snowfall across the majority of South Central Nebraska (this was the final snow event of the 2019-20 season). Most counties along and north of the Highway 6 corridor measured somewhere between 2-5 of wet snow, with the highest concentration of 4 to localized 6 amounts concentrated within northeastern counties including: Greeley, Nance, Merrick, Hamilton, Polk and York. Snow accumulated most efficiently on grassy and elevated surfaces, while much of it melted/accumulated minimally on area roads due to marginal, near-freezing temperatures. Per NWS coop observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5.9 north of York, 5.5 in Greeley, 5.3 in Osceola and 5.1 at Bradshaw. In the Tri Cities, official amounts ranged from 2.4 at Hastings to 3.8 at Grand Island. At the York and Greeley NWS observer sites, the aforementioned daily snow totals over 5 were the highest on record for so late in the spring! At Grand Island and Hastings, this was the 6th-highest and 8th-highest daily snowfall this late in the spring, respectively. Thanks mainly to the wet nature of snow, drifting was fairly minimal, despite steady northeast winds sustained around 20 MPH/gusts around 30 MPH. Although the sight of fresh snow cover was rather unusual for mid-April, it actually turned into a distant memory quite quickly, melting rapidly on Friday the 17th thanks to high temperatures reaching the low 50s F.  ||Digging into event timing, snow broke out across most of the area between 8-10 a.m. CDT, peaked in intensity late-morning through late-afternoon, and gradually departed from west to east during the evening with the vast majority of locations snow-free by 10 p.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was strong upper level divergence and resultant mid level frontogenesis (quite pronounced at 700 millibars), focused slightly downstream from a positively-tilted parent trough axis positioned over the northern Great Basin and Central Rockies. At the surface, the steady (but not overly-strong) northeast winds were driven by a modest pressure gradient between deepening low pressure centered over the northern Texas Panhandle and broad high pressure stretched from the Northern Rockies into the Midwest. Temperature-wise, the 16th was incredibly cold by mid-April standards, featuring daytime highs of only 32-35 F across most of South Central Nebraska. In fact, this snow was the precipitation highlight of a markedly-cold, six-day stretch centered from the 12th-17th. At Hastings airport, the average daily temperature over these six days of 34.4 F (16 degrees below normal) established a record for the overall-coldest six-day stretch so late in the spring.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches across the county. Cooperative observer reports included 3.5 inches in Ord and 2.5 inches from 2 miles west of Arcadia. CoCoRaHS amounts included 3 inches from 5 miles southwest of Elyria and 2 inches from 9 miles northwest of Ord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early afternoon a landspout was reported in Greeley County.  The landspout occurred in the northeast part of the county.  No damage was reported.||During the evening a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved through Western Kansas.  Part of this line developed a bow echo that produced wind gusts up to 60 MPH.   Nickel size hail was reported from the strongest storm in the line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The report was sent through MPing.

At Hastings airport, the average daily temperature over these six days of 34.4 F (16 degrees below normal) established a record for the overall-coldest six-day stretch so late in the spring.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 5 inches across the county, with the highest totals occurring over the northern half of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not overly-impactful to area travel, Thursday the 16th featured a fairly noteworthy late-season snowfall across the majority of South Central Nebraska (this was the final snow event of the 2019-20 season). Most counties along and north of the Highway 6 corridor measured somewhere between 2-5 of wet snow, with the highest concentration of 4 to localized 6 amounts concentrated within northeastern counties including: Greeley, Nance, Merrick, Hamilton, Polk and York. Snow accumulated most efficiently on grassy and elevated surfaces, while much of it melted/accumulated minimally on area roads due to marginal, near-freezing temperatures. Per NWS coop observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5.9 north of York, 5.5 in Greeley, 5.3 in Osceola and 5.1 at Bradshaw. In the Tri Cities, official amounts ranged from 2.4 at Hastings to 3.8 at Grand Island. At the York and Greeley NWS observer sites, the aforementioned daily snow totals over 5 were the highest on record for so late in the spring! At Grand Island and Hastings, this was the 6th-highest and 8th-highest daily snowfall this late in the spring, respectively. Thanks mainly to the wet nature of snow, drifting was fairly minimal, despite steady northeast winds sustained around 20 MPH/gusts around 30 MPH. Although the sight of fresh snow cover was rather unusual for mid-April, it actually turned into a distant memory quite quickly, melting rapidly on Friday the 17th thanks to high temperatures reaching the low 50s F.  ||Digging into event timing, snow broke out across most of the area between 8-10 a.m. CDT, peaked in intensity late-morning through late-afternoon, and gradually departed from west to east during the evening with the vast majority of locations snow-free by 10 p.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was strong upper level divergence and resultant mid level frontogenesis (quite pronounced at 700 millibars), focused slightly downstream from a positively-tilted parent trough axis positioned over the northern Great Basin and Central Rockies. At the surface, the steady (but not overly-strong) northeast winds were driven by a modest pressure gradient between deepening low pressure centered over the northern Texas Panhandle and broad high pressure stretched from the Northern Rockies into the Midwest. Temperature-wise, the 16th was incredibly cold by mid-April standards, featuring daytime highs of only 32-35 F across most of South Central Nebraska. In fact, this snow was the precipitation highlight of a markedly-cold, six-day stretch centered from the 12th-17th. At Hastings airport, the average daily temperature over these six days of 34.4 F (16 degrees below normal) established a record for the overall-coldest six-day stretch so late in the spring.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches across the county, with the highest totals occurring across far north-northeastern portions of the county. A total of 2.4 inches was reported from the cooperative observer located 6 miles east-southeast of Clay Center.  A CoCoRaHS observer from 5 miles south-southeast of Clay Center reported 2.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early afternoon a landspout was reported in Greeley County.  The landspout occurred in the northeast part of the county.  No damage was reported.||During the evening a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved through Western Kansas.  Part of this line developed a bow echo that produced wind gusts up to 60 MPH.   Nickel size hail was reported from the strongest storm in the line.

During the early afternoon a landspout was reported in Greeley County.  The landspout occurred in the northeast part of the county.  No damage was reported.||During the evening a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved through Western Kansas.  Part of this line developed a bow echo that produced wind gusts up to 60 MPH.   Nickel size hail was reported from the strongest storm in the line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated time of report from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early afternoon a landspout was reported in Greeley County.  The landspout occurred in the northeast part of the county.  No damage was reported.||During the evening a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved through Western Kansas.  Part of this line developed a bow echo that produced wind gusts up to 60 MPH.   Nickel size hail was reported from the strongest storm in the line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weak landspout tornado reported. Difficult to discern exact location and duration. Images were received confirming this tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of three rounds of storms occurred as a front interacted with very unstable air to produce numerous severe thunderstorms that caused extensive hail and wind damage over portions of the area.||The second round of storms developed near Topeka, KS and roared southeastward into east-central Missouri in the early afternoon, producing substantial straight-line wind damage.  ||The final round of severe storms developed in the late afternoon and evening along a warm front over southeast Kansas and far southwest Missouri, producing primarily large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to two inches in size damaged several vehicles and caused minor roof damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although most all impacts from light wintry precipitation (mainly freezing drizzle and resultant power outages) focused slightly north of the state line in southern Nebraska, this was nonetheless a crummy Easter Sunday weather-wise in North Central Kansas. The entire area endured relentless north winds and impressively-cold temperatures by mid-April standards, with gusts commonly 40-50+ MPH and daytime highs only in the mid-upper 30s F (roughly 30 degrees below normal), promoting wind chill values only in the teens to low 20s F. While peak gusts at most local weather stations topped out slightly below severe-criteria, one personal weather station in far northeastern Jewell County clocked a 62 MPH gust during the afternoon. Fortunately, wintry precipitation was extremely-minimal across this area, consisting of no more than a dusting of snow and periods of (mostly non-freezing) drizzle. ||As for the meteorological background behind this unpleasant Easter, the main player in the mid-upper levels was a large-scale trough traversing the central CONUS, highlighted by broad low pressure and various embedded disturbances extending southward from southern Canada, and also a potent southern stream shortwave trough ejecting east-northeast across Texas. Given that North Central Kansas resided slightly south of the main northern stream disturbance, mid-level saturation lacked appreciably, keeping all but very light precipitation at bay. At the surface, a powerful cold front blasted through the local area during the pre-dawn hours of the 12th, turning the pleasant temperatures in the 70s to low 80s F on the 11th into a fleeting memory. The intense north winds were driven by a stout pressure gradient between a roughly 997 millibar low tracking east across the Southern Plains and a 1032 millibar high emanating southeastward from the Northern Rockies.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 62 MPH was recorded by a mesonet station located 6 miles east-northeast of Webber.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As mid-April Easter Sundays go, this one likely ranked as one of the overall-crummiest weather-wise in South Central Nebraska. While the entire area had relentless north winds and very cold temperatures, many places also experienced several hours of freezing drizzle and at least brief snow. In addition to (and resulting from) this combination of weather elements, several counties also endured fairly widespread power outages, both of the brief/intermittent and multiple-hour variety. These power-related issues mainly focused within a southwest-northeast swath through the heart of the area (including counties such as Franklin/Adams/Hall/Polk) as the nasty combination of strong winds and steady freezing drizzle coated power lines in ice, promoting pronounced line galloping and resultant outages/infrastructure damage. As just a few examples: the Grand Island Utilities Director called this one of the top-five worst power outage events of his career; and the Polk County Rural Power District reported at least 25 broken poles. Getting back to the weather itself, the entire day featured strong north winds, frequently gusting 40-50+ MPH. While peak gusts at official airport stations topped out slightly below severe-criteria, a few personal weather stations clocked 58 MPH, including one south of Kearney and another in Nelson. The vast majority of wintry precipitation occurred during the daytime hours, largely ending well-before sunset. Light-but-persistent freezing drizzle was the main issue, especially within the aforementioned, southwest-northeast corridor of counties that experienced the worst power outages. Most ice accretion targeted elevated surfaces (e.g. power lines), with only minimal road impacts given near-freezing surface temperatures. As for snow, the vast majority of the area only accumulated a light dusting of no more than one-quarter to one-half inch, although much of it fell in a short-but-intense burst as a narrow band swung through from west-to-east, briefly reducing visibility to as low as one-quarter mile. The main concentration of slightly higher snow amounts in the 1-2 range targeted Valley County in the far northern local area, as any truly-significant snow totals remained north-through-northwest of South Central Nebraska. Temperature-wise, the 12th was impressively-cold by mid-April standards, featuring daytime highs of only 31-35 F across most of the area (roughly 30 degrees below normal) and wind chill values only in the teens. In fact, this event ushered in a markedly-cold, six-day stretch centered from April 12th-17th. At Hastings airport, the average daily temperature over these six days of 34.4 F (16 degrees below normal) established a record for the overall-coldest six-day stretch so late in the spring.||Finishing up with the meteorological background behind this unpleasant Easter, the main player in the mid-upper levels was a large-scale trough traversing the central CONUS, highlighted by broad low pressure and various embedded disturbances extending southward from southern Canada, and also a potent southern stream shortwave trough ejecting east-northeast across Texas. Given that South Central Nebraska resided just south of the main northern stream disturbance, mid-level saturation ended up lacking somewhat, thus promoting more drizzle than snow overall. At the surface, a powerful cold front blasted through the local area during the pre-dawn hours of the 12th, turning the pleasant temperatures in the 70s F on the 11th into a fleeting memory. The intense north winds were driven by a stout pressure gradient between a roughly 997 millibar low tracking east across the Southern Plains and a 1032 millibar high emanating southeastward from the Northern Rockies.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of an extended period of light freezing precipitation and frequent gusts over 50 MPH resulted in power outages across the area.

Given that South Central Nebraska resided just south of the main northern stream disturbance, mid-level saturation ended up lacking somewhat, thus promoting more drizzle than snow overall. At the surface, a powerful cold front blasted through the local area during the pre-dawn hours of the 12th, turning the pleasant temperatures in the 70s F on the 11th into a fleeting memory. The intense north winds were driven by a stout pressure gradient between a roughly 997 millibar low tracking east across the Southern Plains and a 1032 millibar high emanating southeastward from the Northern Rockies.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of an extended period of light freezing precipitation and frequent gusts over 50 MPH resulted in power outages across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As mid-April Easter Sundays go, this one likely ranked as one of the overall-crummiest weather-wise in South Central Nebraska. While the entire area had relentless north winds and very cold temperatures, many places also experienced several hours of freezing drizzle and at least brief snow. In addition to (and resulting from) this combination of weather elements, several counties also endured fairly widespread power outages, both of the brief/intermittent and multiple-hour variety. These power-related issues mainly focused within a southwest-northeast swath through the heart of the area (including counties such as Franklin/Adams/Hall/Polk) as the nasty combination of strong winds and steady freezing drizzle coated power lines in ice, promoting pronounced line galloping and resultant outages/infrastructure damage. As just a few examples: the Grand Island Utilities Director called this one of the top-five worst power outage events of his career; and the Polk County Rural Power District reported at least 25 broken poles. Getting back to the weather itself, the entire day featured strong north winds, frequently gusting 40-50+ MPH. While peak gusts at official airport stations topped out slightly below severe-criteria, a few personal weather stations clocked 58 MPH, including one south of Kearney and another in Nelson. The vast majority of wintry precipitation occurred during the daytime hours, largely ending well-before sunset. Light-but-persistent freezing drizzle was the main issue, especially within the aforementioned, southwest-northeast corridor of counties that experienced the worst power outages. Most ice accretion targeted elevated surfaces (e.g. power lines), with only minimal road impacts given near-freezing surface temperatures. As for snow, the vast majority of the area only accumulated a light dusting of no more than one-quarter to one-half inch, although much of it fell in a short-but-intense burst as a narrow band swung through from west-to-east, briefly reducing visibility to as low as one-quarter mile. The main concentration of slightly higher snow amounts in the 1-2 range targeted Valley County in the far northern local area, as any truly-significant snow totals remained north-through-northwest of South Central Nebraska. Temperature-wise, the 12th was impressively-cold by mid-April standards, featuring daytime highs of only 31-35 F across most of the area (roughly 30 degrees below normal) and wind chill values only in the teens. In fact, this event ushered in a markedly-cold, six-day stretch centered from April 12th-17th. At Hastings airport, the average daily temperature over these six days of 34.4 F (16 degrees below normal) established a record for the overall-coldest six-day stretch so late in the spring.||Finishing up with the meteorological background behind this unpleasant Easter, the main player in the mid-upper levels was a large-scale trough traversing the central CONUS, highlighted by broad low pressure and various embedded disturbances extending southward from southern Canada, and also a potent southern stream shortwave trough ejecting east-northeast across Texas. Given that South Central Nebraska resided just south of the main northern stream disturbance, mid-level saturation ended up lacking somewhat, thus promoting more drizzle than snow overall. At the surface, a powerful cold front blasted through the local area during the pre-dawn hours of the 12th, turning the pleasant temperatures in the 70s F on the 11th into a fleeting memory. The intense north winds were driven by a stout pressure gradient between a roughly 997 millibar low tracking east across the Southern Plains and a 1032 millibar high emanating southeastward from the Northern Rockies.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of an extended period of light freezing precipitation and frequent gusts over 50 MPH resulted in power outages across the area. The Grand Island Utilities Director called this one of the top-five worst power outage events of his career.
