EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong gradient strengthened across the area as an Arctic cold front made its way through the high plains. North winds behind the front lasted for several hours with peak gusts over 50 mph in some places with peaks around 60 mph for only a couple of locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported at the Garden City airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few scattered storms brought severe hail to portions of central KS. A few reports over 2 inches in diameter were noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Picture sent in via Facebook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few scattered storms brought severe hail to portions of central KS. A few reports over 2 inches in diameter were noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Picture sent in via Twitter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few scattered storms brought severe hail to portions of central KS. A few reports over 2 inches in diameter were noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The picture was relayed to the NWS by KAKE Television.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few scattered storms brought severe hail to portions of central KS. A few reports over 2 inches in diameter were noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A picture of the hail was submitted via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very slow moving complex of storms developed in parts of central KS and produced flooding and flash flooding in Ottawa, Geary and Dickinson Counties during the late evening and overnight hours of 5/24 into 5/25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half dollar size hail reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very slow moving complex of storms developed in parts of central KS and produced flooding and flash flooding in Ottawa, Geary and Dickinson Counties during the late evening and overnight hours of 5/24 into 5/25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter in Culver reports water over many of the roads in town. Heavy rain continuing at time of report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very slow moving complex of storms developed in parts of central KS and produced flooding and flash flooding in Ottawa, Geary and Dickinson Counties during the late evening and overnight hours of 5/24 into 5/25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of a water rescue taking place at Humboldt Creek at Zumbrunn Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very slow moving complex of storms developed in parts of central KS and produced flooding and flash flooding in Ottawa, Geary and Dickinson Counties during the late evening and overnight hours of 5/24 into 5/25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water reported over roadway along Old Highway 40 between Oat and Quail Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic front associated with a strong trough digging into the Northern Plains brought a period of very strong winds, gusting as high as 40 to 50 mph, with a period of light snowfall. While accumulations were generally less than an inch, the areas with heavier snow from February 8-9 experienced an extended period of ground blizzard conditions from east central South Dakota into southwest Minnesota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusting to 35 to 45 mph at South Sioux City, when combined with new snowfall of less than one-half inch, produced visibility briefly less than one mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense upper low led to narrow bands (one county wide) of heavy snow across portions of central Kansas on February 25th, 2020.  This heavy snow band had reports of 8 to 12 inches with additional snowfall amounts occurring further south as the band shifts to the southeast with 5 to 8 inches. Interstate 70 was closed between Salina and Ellsworth Kansas, for a brief period of time due to numerous accidents blocking the interstate. Numerous slide offs have also occurred along Interstate 135 south of Salina. Kansas High Patrol reported from 0400-1200 CST, there were calls of 42 slide offs, 7 property only collisions and 1 fatal collision.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow reports started coming in around 630AM with 5 inches measured in Sylvan Grove. As snow continued to fall, amounts rose near Sylvan Grove. In the early afternoon, a total of 13 inches was reported 2 E of Sylvan Grove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense upper low led to narrow bands (one county wide) of heavy snow across portions of central Kansas on February 25th, 2020. Kansas High Patrol reported from 0400-1200 CST, there were calls of 42 slide offs, 7 property only collisions and 1 fatal collision.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Interstate 70 was closed between Salina and Ellsworth due to numerous accidents. A public report came in at 2PM of a measured 9 inches north of Ellsworth by a mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense upper low led to narrow bands (one county wide) of heavy snow across portions of central Kansas on February 25th, 2020. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Interstate 70 was closed between Salina and Ellsworth due to numerous accidents blocking the interstate. Numerous slide offs occurred along I-135 south of Salina as snow accumulated on the roadways. Some schools released students early. At 7:23AM, a report of 4 inches was provided by a trained spotter 6SSW of Brookville. Visibility was reduced to 200 feet or less.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense upper low led to narrow bands (one county wide) of heavy snow across portions of central Kansas on February 25th, 2020.  This heavy snow band had reports of 8 to 12 inches with additional snowfall amounts occurring further south as the band shifts to the southeast with 5 to 8 inches. Interstate 70 was closed between Salina and Ellsworth Kansas, for a brief period of time due to numerous accidents blocking the interstate. Numerous slide offs have also occurred along Interstate 135 south of Salina. Kansas High Patrol reported from 0400-1200 CST, there were calls of 42 slide offs, 7 property only collisions and 1 fatal collision.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Accumulating snowfall on roadways led to slick conditions resulting in numerous slide offs and some accidents. One accident occurred 2 South of Lindsborg which unfortunately resulted in a fatality and two injuries. Visibility was reduced significantly. Snowfall reports ranged from 2 inches in McPherson to 6 inches in Lindsborg and 9 inches in Canton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense upper low led to narrow bands (one county wide) of heavy snow across portions of central Kansas on February 25th, 2020.  This heavy snow band had reports of 8 to 12 inches with additional snowfall amounts occurring further south as the band shifts to the southeast with 5 to 8 inches. Interstate 70 was closed between Salina and Ellsworth Kansas, for a brief period of time due to numerous accidents blocking the interstate. Numerous slide offs have also occurred along Interstate 135 south of Salina. Kansas High Patrol reported from 0400-1200 CST, there were calls of 42 slide offs, 7 property only collisions and 1 fatal collision.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KAKE reported a measurement of 6 inches at 1313 CST. Law enforcement reported multiple vehicle slide offs as snow accumulated on roadways around 10 CST near K15 and 160th; there was around 3 inches reported at that time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low pressure system lifted out of the Desert Southwest and across the southern Plains during the early morning hours of February 12th, 2020. Snow overspread southern Kansas a couple hours prior to sunrise and increased intensity as the morning commute approached. Temperatures near or slightly above freezing allowed for a heavy wet snow, with much of it melting by the late afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts across the county ranged between 1 and 4 inches in depth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought heavy rainfall as a surface low pressure system deepened over the southern Plains and tracked eastward along the Arkansas and Missouri border. Rainfall amounts over two inches occurred over southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Co-op Observer GIRK1 in Girard reported a 24 hour rainfall of 2.20 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought heavy rainfall as a surface low pressure system deepened over the southern Plains and tracked eastward along the Arkansas and Missouri border. Rainfall amounts over two inches occurred over southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CoCoRAHS Station KS-CR-3 reported a 24 hour rainfall of 2.51 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow fell across much of central and south central Kansas on February 19th into the 20th, 2020.   Most locations received snow amounts of one half to 2 inches in depth, but a few isolated areas accumulated up to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts across the county ranged between 1 and 3 inches in depth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved across the southern plains and across northeast Oklahoma during the morning hours of February 5th, 2020.  Cold air on the north side of the system and copious moisture from the storm system, led to light snow falling over southeast Kansas during the morning of February 5th. Snowfall amounts were mainly in the 1 to 3 inch range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts generally ranged from 1 to 3 inches, with the highest amount reported 1 mile northeast of Caney, Kansas of 2.5 inches.

Snowfall amounts were mainly in the 1 to 3 inch range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts were generally 1 to 3 inches, with the highest amounts reported in Parsons, Kansas of 2.5 inches, and Bartlett, Kansas with 2 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex winter storm began as light precipitation in the form of rain and freezing rain. However, as colder temperatures moved into the region a heavy snow fell from southeast Kansas into central Missouri, where 2 to 5 inches of snow snow fell, with some locally higher amounts of 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire department in Frontenac reported 1.5 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow was measured in portions of Sioux County on the third and fourth. A public report in Harrison had a heavy snowfall measurement of 6.8 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report of 6.8 inches of heavy snow in Harrison Nebraska.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex winter storm began as light precipitation in the form of rain and freezing rain. However, as colder temperatures moved into the region a heavy snow fell from southeast Kansas into central Missouri, where 2 to 5 inches of snow snow fell, with some locally higher amounts of 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported 1.0 inches of snow 2 miles northeast of Sherwin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An ice jam occurred on the Platte River near Fremont. This resulted in minor flooding and at least 1 water evacuation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Voluntary evacuation ordered for Big Island Road. Flooding also occurring on Ridge Road, Ridgeland Ave, and in Hormel Park. One water rescue from a home on County Road 19. An ice jam in the Platte River caused the minor flooding. Two individuals were taken to the hospital, one with minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong low pressure system moved across potions of central and south central Kansas during the late evening hours or June 9th and the early morning hours of June 10th, 2020. Tree limbs were knocked down across central and south central Kansas, with most of the limbs 5 to 6 inches in diameter.  Some power pole were also knocked down.  The winds gusted as high as 59 mph at Wichita Eisenhower National airport, with numerous reports of tree damage in Wichita, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A carport was blown into a neighboring house in Salina, Kansas. Several small branches were also reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued strong wind and plummeting temperatures brought wind chills to 25 below to 35 below zero during the overnight and early morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills dipped as low as 28 below zero at South Sioux City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Confluent flow aloft resulted in a strong and narrow frontal band of snowfall from northern Nebraska into northwest Iowa. A swath of three to six inches of snowfall occurred in the heart of the banding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled 4.6 inches at Concord and 3.2 inches at Newcastle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Confluent flow aloft resulted in a strong and narrow frontal band of snowfall from northern Nebraska into northwest Iowa. A swath of three to six inches of snowfall occurred in the heart of the banding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled 4.1 inches at Emerson.  Visibility was briefly one-quarter to one-half mile during heaviest snowfall.

The winds gusted as high as 59 mph at Wichita Eisenhower National airport, with numerous reports of tree damage in Wichita, Kansas.
A line of strong to severe storms moved across portions of central Kansas, during the evening hours of June 4th, 2020.  The tail end storm along this line produced ping pong ball size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A farmer said the hail was at least ping pong ball size.  It was large enough and lasted long enough to damage about 5 percent of his crops.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread winter weather across the Nebraska Panhandle on the 24th and 25th with enhanced snowfall amounts over the Pine Ridge south of Chadron.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer located two miles southeast of Chadron State Park along the Pine Ridge reported 6.0 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon hours on February 24th and the evening of February 25th, a system brought snow and gusty winds to northwest Kansas. While snowfall accumulation was not significant, snow caused roadways to become slick throughout northwestern Kansas leading to several accidents. Several snow squall warnings were issued due to brief periods of blowing snow leading to reduced visibilties associated with a heavy band of snow moving from north to south across northwest Kansas and far east-central Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow squall conditions were presumed to have occurred based on proximity to other counties meeting criteria as well as radar signatures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Barton county dispatch reported a tree down on a power line on Forest Avenue, in Great Bend, Kansas. A wind gust to 53 mph was reported at the Great Bend airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two accidents were reported. One accident occurred on Interstate 70 with one injury at 2158Z on February 25th, 2020. A slide off was also reported on Highway 24, east of Goodland, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon hours on February 24th and the evening of February 25th, a system brought snow and gusty winds to northwest Kansas. While snowfall accumulation was not significant, snow caused roadways to become slick throughout northwestern Kansas leading to several accidents. Several snow squall warnings were issued due to brief periods of blowing snow leading to reduced visibilties associated with a heavy band of snow moving from north to south across northwest Kansas and far east-central Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple minor accidents along US Highway 36 due to blowing snow and poor visibility reported at 1900Z. Snow squall conditions occurred between 1502Z and 1615Z as less than quarter mile visibility due to heavy blowing snow was reported in Saint Francis, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon hours on February 24th and the evening of February 25th, a system brought snow and gusty winds to northwest Kansas. While snowfall accumulation was not significant, snow caused roadways to become slick throughout northwestern Kansas leading to several accidents. Several snow squall warnings were issued due to brief periods of blowing snow leading to reduced visibilties associated with a heavy band of snow moving from north to south across northwest Kansas and far east-central Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accident along Interstate 70 just east of Goodland, Kansas due to blowing snow was reported at 1845Z. Snow squall conditions were presumed to have occurred between 1443Z and 1657Z due to proximity to counties meeting criteria and radar signatures. The snow squall conditions were due to a slow moving band of heavier snow that led to near-blizzard conditions for less than 3 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms early in the evening produced large hail and landspout tornadoes across parts of far southwest Nebraska and the northern Sandhills. The cells eventually merged into a linear system, resulting in more widespread wind damage in north central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter measured a 67 mph wind gust south of North Platte.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two primary supercells moved southeast from Cherry County and vicinity toward Custer County during the late morning and afternoon. An additional round of storms consisting of a linear system and a supercell moved through north central Nebraska later in the evening. Wind gusts were estimated up to 100 mph and hail to tennis ball size, while multiple reports of damaged crops and flooded buildings were received during the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of high winds and hail resulted in extensive crop damage. Wind gusts were estimated at least 70 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough pushed across the CWA producing a tornado and hail over the size of quarters. A leeside trough over eastern Colorado helped to initiate storms near the state line before pushing across into far western counties coupled with the strong daytime heating allowing for stronger CAPE values under weaker shear environment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued pattern from day before with another shortwave trough pushing across the CWA with a leeside trough near the Colorado state line initiating storms late in the evening before sunset. Hail and wind were the main threats with decent DCAPE and CAPE values coupled with a moderate shear environment allowing for hail size up to the size of golf balls being reported along with wind damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Separate supercells, clusters, and small linear systems moved through the panhandle and northern Sandhills from the evening into the early overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported ping pong ball size hail southeast of Eli.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Separate supercells, clusters, and small linear systems moved through the panhandle and northern Sandhills from the evening into the early overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter reported golf ball size hail southwest of Nenzel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued pattern from day before with another shortwave trough pushing across the CWA with a leeside trough near the Colorado state line initiating storms late in the evening before sunset. Hail and wind were the main threats with decent DCAPE and CAPE values coupled with a moderate shear environment allowing for hail size up to the size of golf balls being reported along with wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs 2 to 3 inches in diameter were blown down by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Substantial boundary layer heating in the presence of an upper level short wave trough was enough to overcome somewhat warm air aloft.  Thunderstorms became marginally severe at a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing across Road R.

Another MCS event occurred, associated with a subtle shortwave that pushed out of Colorado. As late in the night as the storms were, wind was the main threat with gusts as high as near 70 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 2.96 inches was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another MCS event occurred, associated with a subtle shortwave that pushed out of Colorado. As late in the night as the storms were, wind was the main threat with gusts as high as near 70 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 3.52 inches was observed with the majority of the rain falling in a 3 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Over the course of the final few days of July a trough dug into the central part of the CONUS and produced several days of moderate to heavy rain. While the bulk of the flooding occurred on the Missouri side, there was some isolated flooding in Miami County Kansas. Some of the highest totals from the area ranged from 6 to 10 inches of rain. Despite the high rainfall amounts, only minor damage resulted from the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Off and on moderate to heavy rain caused several areas to reach 6-10 inches of rainfall. One area that experienced some minor flash flooding was around the Hillsdale area, where a normally dry creek bed was running swiftly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms early in the evening produced large hail and landspout tornadoes across parts of far southwest Nebraska and the northern Sandhills. The cells eventually merged into a linear system, resulting in more widespread wind damage in north central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Union Pacific mesonet station measured a 58 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multitude of minor shortwaves moved across the CWA during this two day stretch resulting in much needed rainfall. Amounts up to 3-4 inches were recorded with no particular areas being higher than the rest. Some advisory level wind gusts from thunderstorms were also recorded with the strongest storms in the Ellis County area near Hays and Victoria.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 2.52 inches was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early initiation of thunderstorms across northwest zones occurred and pushed southeast ,initially as supercells before becoming linear further downstream under northwest flow aloft. Large hail was the initial threat with damaging winds for the later. It was a weakly capped environment with ample instability in terms of high CAPE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of thunderstorms moved east-southeast during the late evening of July 2nd, 2020.  As the complex moved southeast, it produced damaging wind gusts of 62 to 68 mph.  The damaging winds produced sporadic reports of small to medium tree limb damage.

Early initiation of thunderstorms across northwest zones occurred and pushed southeast ,initially as supercells before becoming linear further downstream under northwest flow aloft. Large hail was the initial threat with damaging winds for the later. It was a weakly capped environment with ample instability in terms of high CAPE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down by the high wind.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large cottonwood tree was blown down by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of storms developed near south central South Dakota and tracked southeast producing wind damage with gusts over 60 mph in Madison, Stanton, and Cuming counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm cell in Knox county produced 1.5 inch hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported quarter size hail at the Santee Tribe Museum. Another report said it was just smaller than a golf ball.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm in Gage County produced damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported tree limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An initially unimpressive thunderstorm complex over northeast Nebraska rapidly intensified during the morning of August 10, 2020. After a few sporadic early morning damage reports, the intensifying storms began to more readily produce damaging winds in excess of 50 kts around 1340Z. Those damaging winds increased in coverage and intensity as the storms moved east into Iowa. The portion of the thunderstorm complex that moved through the NWS Omaha forecast area marked the approximate beginning of an intense derecho that tracked across portions of Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan, and Ohio. Within the NWS Omaha forecast area, there were more than 20 local storm reports of wind damage and measured severe wind gusts, including more than 50,000 power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Personal weather station measured a wind of 54 kts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed on the nose of the elevated instability gradient in the late night and early morning hours. With up to 1000 J/kg MUCAPE, a few storms produced large hail from northeast Nebraska into northwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was found and measured three hours after occurrence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed on the nose of the elevated instability gradient in the late night and early morning hours. With up to 1000 J/kg MUCAPE, a few storms produced large hail from northeast Nebraska into northwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was accompanied by winds strong enough to break 2 inch diameter branches from trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed through during the late afternoon and there were surface based thunderstorms near the Oklahoma border.  However, with a strong upper level shortwave there was strong lifting above the relative shallow cold air behind the front. Therefore, there were elevated thunderstorms above the cold air and some became severe.

A strong cold front pushed through during the afternoon producing some strong northwest winds behind it due to the strong gradient and cold air advection accompanied by it. Most wind gusts ranged from 40-55 mph, but a rogue 61 mph gust was experienced at the Garden City Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Recorded at the Garden City airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moving into southern counties brought unstable air to the southern counties. Small hail and wind damage was reported with some of these storms under the severe threshold.
A warm front moving into southern counties brought unstable air to the southern counties. Small hail and wind damage was reported with some of these storms under the severe threshold.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A carport was damaged by the strong wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front swept through the area giving way to scattered snow that mainly impacted eastern counties in the stronger moisture field from Edwards to Barber and points east into central and south central Kansas. Amounts were in the range from 1-4 inches with points westward remaining dry.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 1.0 was observed in Kinsley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 4.0 inches was observed at a location 1 mile west of Dillwyn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread storms across central Kansas packed a punch with several reports of high winds up to 80 mph and sporadic areas of damage on July 15th, 2020.  Heavy rains also prompted flood warnings for several counties with the one in Rice county lasting quite long due to flooding along Cow creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tractor trailers were blown off of Interstate 135 near exit 60.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front brings slow moving thunderstorms and heavy rain to extreme southern portions of south central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening of July 26. Thunderstorms developed between 3pm and 4pm CDT from southwest to northeast, generally along a line from Rooks County in north central Kansas, to Thayer County in south central Nebraska. Once thunderstorms developed, heavy rain quickly became the main concern, though a few non-severe wind gusts around 50 to 55 mph were reported across north central Kansas early on in the event, as well as an estimated wind gust near 60mph in Thayer County. The heavy rain threat was driven by several factors, including: weak mid and upper level winds which resulted in slow storm motion, training of thunderstorms over the same areas for several hours, and unusually high atmospheric moisture levels. In fact, precipitable water values were near 2 on this evening, which is near 3 standard deviations above normal and in the upper 90th percentile of climatology. Heavy rain rates of 1-2 per hour, or higher, were common under the strongest thunderstorm cores, especially between the hours of 4pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorms gradually decreased in intensity during the late evening as the persistent convection over the same areas and loss of daytime heating led to decreasing instability. The majority of the lingering light rain ended by midnight.||For south central Nebraska, the heavy rain was limited to primarily eastern Nuckolls County and all of Thayer County. Storm total rain amounts by the morning of July 27th of 3-4 inches were common, with an isolated maximum of 4-5 plus reported in the Hebron area. The highest reported rain amount was 5.50 measured at the fire station in Hebron and relayed by emergency management. The primary impacts from the heavy rain were flooded roads across Thayer County. This included numerous county roads along with Highway 5 north of Deshler and Highway 81 (which is a major four lane highway) between Belvidere and the Nebraska/Kansas state line. The flooding on Highway 81 may have contributed to a semi tractor trailer to lose control and drive into a ditch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24-hour total rainfall amount of 5.15 inches was recorded by a CoCoRaHS Observer located 1 mile east-northeast of Hebron.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front brings slow moving thunderstorms and heavy rain to extreme southern portions of south central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening of July 26. Thunderstorms developed between 3pm and 4pm CDT from southwest to northeast, generally along a line from Rooks County in north central Kansas, to Thayer County in south central Nebraska. Once thunderstorms developed, heavy rain quickly became the main concern, though a few non-severe wind gusts around 50 to 55 mph were reported across north central Kansas early on in the event. The heavy rain threat was driven by several factors, including: weak mid and upper level winds which resulted in slow storm motion, training of thunderstorms over the same areas for several hours, and unusually high atmospheric moisture levels. In fact, precipitable water values were near 2 on this evening, which is near 3 standard deviations above normal and in the upper 90th percentile of climatology. Heavy rain rates of 1-2 per hour, or higher, were common under the strongest thunderstorm cores, especially between the hours of 4pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorms gradually decreased in intensity during the late evening as the persistent convection over the same areas and loss of daytime heating led to decreasing instability. The majority of the lingering light rain ended by midnight.||Heavy rain occurred across most of north central Kansas, with the exception of northern Phillips County and northern Smith County. Storm total rain amounts by the morning of July 27th of 3-4.5 inches were common, with an isolated maximum of 6-7 reported in south central Osborne County. The highest reported rain amount was 6.72 measured by an NWS Cooperative Observer located 9 miles north-northeast of Natoma, KS. The primary impact from the heavy rain was water affecting county roads. Just north of Randall, KS, the flooding contributed to a car losing control and ending up in the ditch, with the driver needing to be rescued.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total rainfall amounts ranged from 4 to 7 inches across the area. The primary impact was water affecting county roads.

In fact, precipitable water values were near 2 on this evening, which is near 3 standard deviations above normal and in the upper 90th percentile of climatology. Heavy rain rates of 1-2 per hour, or higher, were common under the strongest thunderstorm cores, especially between the hours of 4pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorms gradually decreased in intensity during the late evening as the persistent convection over the same areas and loss of daytime heating led to decreasing instability. The majority of the lingering light rain ended by midnight.||Heavy rain occurred across most of north central Kansas, with the exception of northern Phillips County and northern Smith County. Storm total rain amounts by the morning of July 27th of 3-4.5 inches were common, with an isolated maximum of 6-7 reported in south central Osborne County. The highest reported rain amount was 6.72 measured by an NWS Cooperative Observer located 9 miles north-northeast of Natoma, KS. The primary impact from the heavy rain was water affecting county roads. Just north of Randall, KS, the flooding contributed to a car losing control and ending up in the ditch, with the driver needing to be rescued.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24-hour total rainfall amount of 6.72 inches was recorded by the NWS Cooperative Observer located 9 miles north-northeast of Natoma.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving upper low brings multiple rounds of thunderstorms, including locally heavy rain and a few severe thunderstorms, on July 29th. Low to mid level warm air advection ahead of a lead shortwave trough led to the development of scattered showers and thunderstorms roughly along a line from Hastings to Superior between 6-8am CDT. Locally heavy rain rates and slow moving thunderstorms led to areas of heavy rain across portions of Clay, Nuckolls, Fillmore and Thayer Counties during the mid to late morning hours. Soil conditions in these areas were already saturated due to previous heavy rain events over the recent days. Activity decreased in coverage and intensity around midday, and most areas were dry by 1pm CDT. Total rain amounts of 2-3 inches were common across these areas, which led to renewed flooding, particularly over Thayer County. The primary impact was water covering county roads and water flowing over Highway 136 west of Deshler. Conditions were favorable for heavy rain given the aforementioned slow storm motions, but also relatively high precipitable water values near 2.||Additional thunderstorm activity developed during the afternoon hours from central Nebraska into northwest Kansas. Initial individual and cellular thunderstorms grew upscale into several clusters during the late afternoon and into the evening. One such cluster moved through far western portions of the County Warning Area (CWA), mainly from Cozad down to Beaver City, between 6-8pm CDT. Some of this activity became severe and produced up to ping pong ball sized hail across Furnas County. As this activity weakened around 8pm CDT, new, mainly isolated, thunderstorms developed just to the NE over Phelps and Buffalo Counties between 8-9pm CDT. Up to penny size hail was reported with this activity over Phelps County. Yet another round of thunderstorms developed and organized into a mesoscale convective system (MCS) west of the area, then moved through areas southwest of a line from Lexington, Nebraska to Beloit, Kansas after 10pm CDT. This activity was strong, but remained non-severe, over south central Nebraska.

A strong cold front swept through the area giving way to scattered snow that mainly impacted eastern counties in the stronger moisture field from Edwards to Barber and points east into central and south central Kansas. Amounts were in the range from 1-4 inches with points westward remaining dry.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 2 inches was observed in St. John.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving upper low brings multiple rounds of thunderstorms, including a few severe thunderstorms with high wind, to north central Kansas from the late afternoon hours of July 29th into the early morning hours of July 30th. Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed during the mid to late morning hours, but this activity remained weak and heavy rain remained off to the north across south central Nebraska. New thunderstorms developed from central Nebraska into northwest Kansas during the late afternoon and early evening hours as instability increased. Activity grew upscale into thunderstorms clusters and moved east/southeast during the evening hours. One such cluster moved through Philips and Rooks Counties between 6-8pm CDT, but remained sub-severe. Additional thunderstorms developed and organized into a mesoscale convective system (MCS) west of the area during the late evening hours, then moved into Phillips and Rooks Counties around midnight. A portion of the line began to develop a bow between midnight and 1am which produced a swath of severe winds from Phillips and Rook Counties southeast into Osborne County. The strongest wind gust was 72mph as measured by a mesonet station 9 miles north-northeast of Codell. It is not known what, if any, damage occurred as a result of the severe winds. Thunderstorms weakened by 3am and ended by dawn.||Severe weather activity was supported by moderate to strong instability, but the limiting factor to more widespread severe weather was weak effective shear of only 30 knots. Climatologically speaking, weak shear is typically the limiting factor during the mid to late summer months.
A wind gust of 62 mph was measured as a one hour report for a RAWS site at Scottsbluff National Monument on the afternoon of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Site at Scottsbluff National Monument measured the reported wind gust in an one hour observation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An initially unimpressive thunderstorm complex over northeast Nebraska rapidly intensified during the morning of August 10, 2020. After a few sporadic early morning damage reports, the intensifying storms began to more readily produce damaging winds in excess of 50 kts around 1340Z. Those damaging winds increased in coverage and intensity as the storms moved east into Iowa. The portion of the thunderstorm complex that moved through the NWS Omaha forecast area marked the approximate beginning of an intense derecho that tracked across portions of Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan, and Ohio. Within the NWS Omaha forecast area, there were more than 20 local storm reports of wind damage and measured severe wind gusts, including more than 50,000 power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public personal weather station measured a wind gust of 54 kts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds developed behind a cold front during the late morning hours into the afternoon hours on November 14th, 2020. Northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to around 60 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The North Platte ASOS recorded a peak wind gust of 62 mph at 343 pm CST. Northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph sustained with gusts as high as 62 mph were common across Lincoln County between 1 pm until 5 pm CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorm developed in the northern Nebraska panhandle the afternoon of 2 July 2020. This supercell produced very large hail and a tornado touched down near Marsland Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree damage, center pivot damage and three steel utility poles down. A NWS storm survey determined a 3.4 mile path beginning 5.8 miles east of Marsland Nebraska, ending 2.8 miles east-northeast of Marsland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm in Gage County produced damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported water over the road at current location and that other county roads in the area are flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of storms developed near south central South Dakota and tracked southeast producing wind damage with gusts over 60 mph in Madison, Stanton, and Cuming counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Norfolk Airport measured a wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of storms developed near south central South Dakota and tracked southeast producing wind damage with gusts over 60 mph in Madison, Stanton, and Cuming counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported a large tree branch (4 to 5 inches in diameter) down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe wind gusts occurred with a line of thunderstorms across portions of south central Nebraska and north central Kansas on the evening of July 2nd. Fairly typical summertime weather pattern occurred on this day in which scattered thunderstorms developed over the High Plains during the late afternoon, posing a tornado and large hail threat, then organized into a quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) as they shifted eastward through the evening into an increasing moist, and unstable environment. As is often the case with QLCS events in this part of the country during this time of year, severe wind gusts were the primary threat. Thunderstorm mergers over extreme southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas promoted the development of a significant pool of cold air which caused a segment of thunderstorms, within the broader line of thunderstorms, to quickly accelerate eastward into western portions of the County Warning Area (CWA) between 7-8pm CDT. By the time this activity arrived it already had a history of producing widespread 60-70mph wind gusts, and even isolated 70-80+mph wind gusts in the vicinity of Hill City, Kansas. The bowing line of thunderstorms continued to produce a swath of severe winds as it moved through the southern half (or so) of the CWA through the late evening hours. For south central Nebraska, severe reports were confined to areas mainly along and south of Highway 6 in Furnas and Harlan Counties, though a Cooperative Observer in Gosper County estimated up to 70mph wind gusts. Damage to trees and power lines were the main impacts of the severe wind. The strongest thunderstorm cores, on the leading edge of the QLCS, exited the area to the southeast by around midnight. Trailing stratiform rain lingered for a couple more hours.||As mentioned above, the meteorological conditions were quite typical for this area for early July. A warm and moist air mass and steep mid level lapse rates supported very strong instability (MLCAPE 4000-5000 J/kg) across a large portion of the Central Plains. A broad upper level ridge axis was in place from the southern Plains into the Upper Mississippi River Valley, resulting in weak southwesterly flow aloft. Because of the upper ridging, deep layer wind shear was weak at less than 30 knots, with much of the shear owing to veering of wind direction in the low to mid levels. This indicates that primarily mesoscale features such as an MCV and a strong cold pool were the main factors that supported severe wind in this event, and not synoptic scale features. Downdraft CAPE values in excess of 1500 J/kg were indicative of the strong potential for cool pool development.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 70 MPH. A tree approximately 10 inches in diameter was snapped.

Fairly typical summertime weather pattern occurred on this day in which scattered thunderstorms developed over the High Plains during the late afternoon, posing a tornado and large hail threat, then organized into a quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) as they shifted eastward through the evening into an increasing moist, and unstable environment. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early morning complex of storms moved across south central Kansas producing sporadic severe weather on July 10th, 2020. The main issue was very heavy rain.  Most locations were between 2 and 3 inches.  However, one report of 4.5 inches was noted in Kingman county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported the gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving storms developed early 7/2 and caused flash flooding in Lyon County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of flood waters flowing over Road 150 in the 900 to 1000 block area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong storms worked through north-central KS late 7/2 into 7/3 producing some strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated 60 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Damaging wind was reported with one storms associated with a morning MCV on 7/15.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small chicken coop was blown over along with a small playground set.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extensive line of thunderstorms brought widespread severe wind to much of south central Nebraska and portions of north central Kansas on this date. This event will likely go down as the most widespread severe weather event of the spring and summer of 2020 for the Hastings County Warning Area (CWA). Thunderstorms developed along a cold front across north central Nebraska, and also within a zone of low level upslope flow over western Nebraska and northeast Colorado, during the early evening hours of July 8th. Both areas of development initially contained line segments and embedded supercells, posing risks for all severe hazards, but quickly organized into two separate lines of convection, or quasi linear convective systems (QLCSs). By 9pm CDT, one line extended roughly west to east from Thedford, NE to O'Neill, NE and was moving southeast, while the other line extended roughly north to south from near Thedford, NE to just west of McCook, NE and was moving mainly east. Shortly thereafter, both lines began to merge together into one coherent line and produced several instances of 60-75 mph wind gusts and isolated severe hail north/northwest of the CWA. Thunderstorms increased in organization into a bow echo over Furnas and Gosper Counties in Nebraska, then entered far western/northwestern portions of north central Kansas between 10:30-11pm CDT. By 11pm CDT, the QLCS had taken on an S shape, slanting southwest to northeast. The greatest concentration of severe wind reports occurred north of the state line, however, several severe wind reports were also reported roughly along and north of Highway 36 between 11pm CDT on July 8th and 1am CDT on July 9th as forward speed increased dramatically. Peak wind gusts across north central Kansas generally remained 60-65mph. The only known damage was to a roof of a mobile home in Mitchell County, though at least minor tree and crop damage likely occurred across at least portions of the area as well. The leading edge of the QLCS, and associated peak wind threat, shifted east and southeast of the CWA by 1AM CDT, though lingering stratiform rain as well as a northwest to southeast band of thunderstorms near the state line continued for a few more hours. Severe hail associated with this activity remained just north of the state line, over Furnas County, where regenerating thunderstorms were most intense.||Meteorologically speaking, this severe wind event was driven largely by a cold front interacting with a strongly unstable airmass due to steep mid level lapse rates, strong heating, and moist boundary layer. Initially cellular activity quickly grew upscale into line segments owing to the linear forcing along the cold front and generally outflow dominated activity, with peak DCAPE values in excess of 1500 J/kg. The primary shortwave trough responsible for the cold front remained well north of the area, near the Montana/Canadian border, but several weak perturbations moving west to east over the cold front likely aided in thunderstorm development as well. A distinct mesoscale convective vortex, modest deep layer shear of 30-35 knots, and an intensifying southerly low level jet up to 45 knots sustained the severe convection well past sunset. Finally, it's worth noting that an impressive surface pressure rise/fall couplet of at least 3mb/2hr accompanied the QLCS across the CWA between 05Z and 07Z.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 65 MPH caused roof damage to a mobile home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms with damaging winds affected areas along Interstate 80 during the early morning hours of July 10th. Thunderstorms initially developed over the western Sandhills in central Nebraska during the late afternoon and early evening hours of July 9th. Two supercells merged northwest of North Platte, which resulted in one, forward moving supercell that transitioned to produce intense winds. 80-90mph winds were noted in the North Platte area, including an 87mph gust measured at the North Platte Airport. This activity continued to produce intense damaging wind as it moved southeastward into western Dawson County around 1am CDT on July 10th. The most intense winds occurred in the Cozad area with measured gusts up to 75mph resulting in widespread, significant tree damage in addition to building, power pole, and crop damage. Also, a semi tractor trailer was overturned on Interstate 80 west of Cozad. Another overturned semi tractor trailer was reported just west of Lexington. No injuries or fatalities were reported. Damage in Lexington was not as intense and limited to mainly tree damage with a measured gust at the Lexington Airport of 59mph, respectively. Thunderstorms continued to weaken as they shifted east, with only sporadic, minor tree damage noted in Kearney around 2am CDT. Thunderstorms dissipated to weak showers by 3am CDT.||Overall, it appears that this thunderstorm activity overachieved its meteorological environment, at least thermodynamically. The main instability axis of moderate MLCAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg was located primarily across the western High Plains, with generally less than 1000 J/kg of MLCAPE noted across western portions of the Hastings CWA. Instability quickly decreased with eastern extent, which likely led to the rapid decrease in thunderstorm intensity between Lexington and Kearney. However, what was lacking in the thermodynamic environment was likely compensated for kinematically as deep layer shear was impressive at 50-60 kt owing to significant veering of winds from southeast near to surface to west-northwest in the mid levels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 65 MPH caused an overturned semi trailer near Interstate 80 mile marker 218. This overturned trailer blocked Interstate 80 traffic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms with damaging winds affected areas along Interstate 80 during the early morning hours of July 10th. Thunderstorms initially developed over the western Sandhills in central Nebraska during the late afternoon and early evening hours of July 9th. Two supercells merged northwest of North Platte, which resulted in one, forward moving supercell that transitioned to produce intense winds. 80-90mph winds were noted in the North Platte area, including an 87mph gust measured at the North Platte Airport. This activity continued to produce intense damaging wind as it moved southeastward into western Dawson County around 1am CDT on July 10th. The most intense winds occurred in the Cozad area with measured gusts up to 75mph resulting in widespread, significant tree damage in addition to building, power pole, and crop damage. Also, a semi tractor trailer was overturned on Interstate 80 west of Cozad. Another overturned semi tractor trailer was reported just west of Lexington. No injuries or fatalities were reported. Damage in Lexington was not as intense and limited to mainly tree damage with a measured gust at the Lexington Airport of 59mph, respectively. Thunderstorms continued to weaken as they shifted east, with only sporadic, minor tree damage noted in Kearney around 2am CDT. Thunderstorms dissipated to weak showers by 3am CDT.||Overall, it appears that this thunderstorm activity overachieved its meteorological environment, at least thermodynamically. The main instability axis of moderate MLCAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg was located primarily across the western High Plains, with generally less than 1000 J/kg of MLCAPE noted across western portions of the Hastings CWA. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management estimated wind gusts to be at least 70 MPH, a mesonet station located 1 mile north-northeast of Cozad measured a peak gust of 75 MPH at 1:18 AM CDT. Damage in and near Cozad was reported, including roof, outbuilding, tree and crop damage. The town square gazebo was pushed over to a 45 degree angle. Power outages were also reported in the area.

Thunderstorms continued to weaken as they shifted east, with only sporadic, minor tree damage noted in Kearney around 2am CDT. Thunderstorms dissipated to weak showers by 3am CDT.||Overall, it appears that this thunderstorm activity overachieved its meteorological environment, at least thermodynamically. The main instability axis of moderate MLCAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg was located primarily across the western High Plains, with generally less than 1000 J/kg of MLCAPE noted across western portions of the Hastings CWA. Instability quickly decreased with eastern extent, which likely led to the rapid decrease in thunderstorm intensity between Lexington and Kearney. However, what was lacking in the thermodynamic environment was likely compensated for kinematically as deep layer shear was impressive at 50-60 kt owing to significant veering of winds from southeast near to surface to west-northwest in the mid levels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A metal outbuilding was damaged near Darr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms brought damaging wind gusts to portions of north central Kansas the evening of July 18th. Thunderstorms initially developed across northwest Kansas, just west of WFO Hastings CWA, between 5pm and 6pm CDT, along and ahead of a southeastward moving cold front. Conditions ahead of the front were very hot and humid, and a Heat Advisory was in effect for much of the daytime hours on the 18th. A few small clusters of thunderstorms within a broader corridor of convection ahead of the front became more organized between 6pm to 7pm CDT, with one such cluster becoming severe between Hoxie and Hill City. A wind gust of 72mph was reported just west of the area in Graham County just before 8pm CDT. This activity entered Rooks County around 8pm CDT, bringing damaging wind gusts near 60mph. This caused damage to a couple of campers at Webster State Park. This was the only known damage report from this activity within the Hastings CWA and thunderstorms decreased in intensity after 9pm due to stabilizing boundary layer and weak wind shear which allowed outflow to outrun the main convection.||The meteorological setup was ripe for localized damaging winds owing to strong instability (MLCAPE 3000-4000 J/kg), weak deep layer wind shear (effective shear 20-25kt), and a deeply mixed boundary layer resulting in downdraft CAPE (DCAPE) of 1300-1500 J/kg.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH. Lawn furniture was blown around 6 miles west-northwest of Webster State Park, while some minor camper damage was reported at Webster State Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front brings slow moving thunderstorms and heavy rain to extreme southern portions of south central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening of July 26. Thunderstorms developed between 3pm and 4pm CDT from southwest to northeast, generally along a line from Rooks County in north central Kansas, to Thayer County in south central Nebraska. Once thunderstorms developed, heavy rain quickly became the main concern, though a few non-severe wind gusts around 50 to 55 mph were reported across north central Kansas early on in the event, as well as an estimated wind gust near 60mph in Thayer County. The heavy rain threat was driven by several factors, including: weak mid and upper level winds which resulted in slow storm motion, training of thunderstorms over the same areas for several hours, and unusually high atmospheric moisture levels. In fact, precipitable water values were near 2 on this evening, which is near 3 standard deviations above normal and in the upper 90th percentile of climatology. Heavy rain rates of 1-2 per hour, or higher, were common under the strongest thunderstorm cores, especially between the hours of 4pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorms gradually decreased in intensity during the late evening as the persistent convection over the same areas and loss of daytime heating led to decreasing instability. The majority of the lingering light rain ended by midnight.||For south central Nebraska, the heavy rain was limited to primarily eastern Nuckolls County and all of Thayer County. Storm total rain amounts by the morning of July 27th of 3-4 inches were common, with an isolated maximum of 4-5 plus reported in the Hebron area. The highest reported rain amount was 5.50 measured at the fire station in Hebron and relayed by emergency management. The primary impacts from the heavy rain were flooded roads across Thayer County. This included numerous county roads along with Highway 5 north of Deshler and Highway 81 (which is a major four lane highway) between Belvidere and the Nebraska/Kansas state line. The flooding on Highway 81 may have contributed to a semi tractor trailer to lose control and drive into a ditch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total rainfall amounts ranged from 4 to 7 inches across the area. Numerous county roads were affected. The Department of Transportation reported water over Highway 5 north of Deshler and Highway 81 was closed between Belvidere and the state line due to water over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Limited precipitation in July and a continuation of hot temperatures, led to the initiation of severe drought conditions in portions of the eastern Nebraska Panhandle in late July. Severe drought conditions expanded into the Pine Ridge of northern Sheridan county, as well as portions of western Deuel and extreme southwestern Garden county. Severe drought conditions continued through the end of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) conditions developed in far northwest Sheridan County along the Pine Ridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms associated with an associated cold front moved through southeast Nebraska producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public made multiple reports of large tree limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms associated with an associated cold front moved through southeast Nebraska producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public estimated 60 mph winds in Beatrice and reported lights flickering in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms associated with an associated cold front moved through southeast Nebraska producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported tree down on the golf course.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms associated with an associated cold front moved through southeast Nebraska producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported lots of tree damage in Cook. 6 inch and greater tree branches down. Pictures were sent via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms associated with an associated cold front moved through southeast Nebraska producing damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rural carrier reported several locations with trees or large limbs down on or near roads south of Dawson and Humbuldt.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated hail, wind damage and flash flooding occurred in Lyon and Jefferson Counties with a cluster of thunderstorms that developed over central KS late on 7/20.
Isolated hail, wind damage and flash flooding occurred in Lyon and Jefferson Counties with a cluster of thunderstorms that developed over central KS late on 7/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust of 60 mph reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated hail, wind damage and flash flooding occurred in Lyon and Jefferson Counties with a cluster of thunderstorms that developed over central KS late on 7/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooded roadway at the 500 block of Walnut Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated hail, wind damage and flash flooding occurred in Lyon and Jefferson Counties with a cluster of thunderstorms that developed over central KS late on 7/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway covered with water at the 2000 block of Highway 99 just north of Emporia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed across extreme southeast Kansas before moving into southwest Missouri during the mid-afternoon and late afternoon hours as a very unstable airmass interacted with a stalled front. Severe straight-line winds caused damage to a couple barns near Baxter Springs in Cherokee County, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny sized hail was reported via MPing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An initially unimpressive thunderstorm complex over northeast Nebraska rapidly intensified during the morning of August 10, 2020. After a few sporadic early morning damage reports, the intensifying storms began to more readily produce damaging winds in excess of 50 kts around 1340Z. Those damaging winds increased in coverage and intensity as the storms moved east into Iowa. The portion of the thunderstorm complex that moved through the NWS Omaha forecast area marked the approximate beginning of an intense derecho that tracked across portions of Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan, and Ohio. Within the NWS Omaha forecast area, there were more than 20 local storm reports of wind damage and measured severe wind gusts, including more than 50,000 power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tekamah ASOS measured a wind of 59 kts.

After a few sporadic early morning damage reports, the intensifying storms began to more readily produce damaging winds in excess of 50 kts around 1340Z. Those damaging winds increased in coverage and intensity as the storms moved east into Iowa. The portion of the thunderstorm complex that moved through the NWS Omaha forecast area marked the approximate beginning of an intense derecho that tracked across portions of Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan, and Ohio. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Omaha Eppley Airfield ASOS measured a wind gust of 58 kts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front brings slow moving thunderstorms and heavy rain to extreme southern portions of south central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening of July 26. Thunderstorms developed between 3pm and 4pm CDT from southwest to northeast, generally along a line from Rooks County in north central Kansas, to Thayer County in south central Nebraska. Once thunderstorms developed, heavy rain quickly became the main concern, though a few non-severe wind gusts around 50 to 55 mph were reported across north central Kansas early on in the event. The heavy rain threat was driven by several factors, including: weak mid and upper level winds which resulted in slow storm motion, training of thunderstorms over the same areas for several hours, and unusually high atmospheric moisture levels. In fact, precipitable water values were near 2 on this evening, which is near 3 standard deviations above normal and in the upper 90th percentile of climatology. Heavy rain rates of 1-2 per hour, or higher, were common under the strongest thunderstorm cores, especially between the hours of 4pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorms gradually decreased in intensity during the late evening as the persistent convection over the same areas and loss of daytime heating led to decreasing instability. The majority of the lingering light rain ended by midnight.||Heavy rain occurred across most of north central Kansas, with the exception of northern Phillips County and northern Smith County. Storm total rain amounts by the morning of July 27th of 3-4.5 inches were common, with an isolated maximum of 6-7 reported in south central Osborne County. The highest reported rain amount was 6.72 measured by an NWS Cooperative Observer located 9 miles north-northeast of Natoma, KS. The primary impact from the heavy rain was water affecting county roads. Just north of Randall, KS, the flooding contributed to a car losing control and ending up in the ditch, with the driver needing to be rescued.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total rainfall amounts ranged from 4 to 7 inches across the area. Law enforcement reported that multiple roads were closed to running water. Just north of Randall, a car left the road and ended up in the ditch, with the driver needing rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving upper low brings multiple rounds of thunderstorms, including locally heavy rain and a few severe thunderstorms, on July 29th. Low to mid level warm air advection ahead of a lead shortwave trough led to the development of scattered showers and thunderstorms roughly along a line from Hastings to Superior between 6-8am CDT. Locally heavy rain rates and slow moving thunderstorms led to areas of heavy rain across portions of Clay, Nuckolls, Fillmore and Thayer Counties during the mid to late morning hours. Soil conditions in these areas were already saturated due to previous heavy rain events over the recent days. Activity decreased in coverage and intensity around midday, and most areas were dry by 1pm CDT. Total rain amounts of 2-3 inches were common across these areas, which led to renewed flooding, particularly over Thayer County. The primary impact was water covering county roads and water flowing over Highway 136 west of Deshler. Conditions were favorable for heavy rain given the aforementioned slow storm motions, but also relatively high precipitable water values near 2.||Additional thunderstorm activity developed during the afternoon hours from central Nebraska into northwest Kansas. Initial individual and cellular thunderstorms grew upscale into several clusters during the late afternoon and into the evening. One such cluster moved through far western portions of the County Warning Area (CWA), mainly from Cozad down to Beaver City, between 6-8pm CDT. Some of this activity became severe and produced up to ping pong ball sized hail across Furnas County. As this activity weakened around 8pm CDT, new, mainly isolated, thunderstorms developed just to the NE over Phelps and Buffalo Counties between 8-9pm CDT. Up to penny size hail was reported with this activity over Phelps County. Yet another round of thunderstorms developed and organized into a mesoscale convective system (MCS) west of the area, then moved through areas southwest of a line from Lexington, Nebraska to Beloit, Kansas after 10pm CDT. This activity was strong, but remained non-severe, over south central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts around 2 to 3 inches falling onto already wet soil resulted in flash flooding across the area. Rural county roads were covered and water was flowing over Highway 136 west of Deshler.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving upper low brings multiple rounds of thunderstorms, including a few severe thunderstorms with high wind, to north central Kansas from the late afternoon hours of July 29th into the early morning hours of July 30th. Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed during the mid to late morning hours, but this activity remained weak and heavy rain remained off to the north across south central Nebraska. New thunderstorms developed from central Nebraska into northwest Kansas during the late afternoon and early evening hours as instability increased. Activity grew upscale into thunderstorms clusters and moved east/southeast during the evening hours. One such cluster moved through Philips and Rooks Counties between 6-8pm CDT, but remained sub-severe. Additional thunderstorms developed and organized into a mesoscale convective system (MCS) west of the area during the late evening hours, then moved into Phillips and Rooks Counties around midnight. A portion of the line began to develop a bow between midnight and 1am which produced a swath of severe winds from Phillips and Rook Counties southeast into Osborne County. The strongest wind gust was 72mph as measured by a mesonet station 9 miles north-northeast of Codell. It is not known what, if any, damage occurred as a result of the severe winds. Thunderstorms weakened by 3am and ended by dawn.||Severe weather activity was supported by moderate to strong instability, but the limiting factor to more widespread severe weather was weak effective shear of only 30 knots. Climatologically speaking, weak shear is typically the limiting factor during the mid to late summer months.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 72 MPH wind gust was recorded by a mesonet station located 9 miles north-northeast of Codell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of severe weather affected portions of south central Nebraska and north central Kansas the evening of July 10th into the early morning hours of July 11th. For the first round, thunderstorms initially formed near the South Dakota and Nebraska border during the early afternoon hours, then shifted southeast into central Nebraska and eventually the northwest portions of the GID CWA during the late afternoon and early evening. Most of the severe reports were associated with an intense supercell on the southwestern flank of a line of thunderstorms. This supercell tracked from just south of Valentine to Broken Bow before it entered the local area in Buffalo and Sherman Counties around 5:30PM CDT. Multiple reports of 50-60mph wind gusts were received, along with 5 ft tall corn being blown over in northern Buffalo County. This thunderstorm continued southeast and impacted Kearney with 60-70mph winds, including a 61mph gust at the Kearney Airport. Additional severe wind reports, and even some quarter to half dollar size hail, occurred in Kearney County before the system weakened as it neared the state line during the late evening. These thunderstorms were supported by MLCAPE values of 2000-3000 J/kg, steep mid level lapse rates, and very strong effective shear of 50-60kt. ||The next round of thunderstorms brought high winds to central and northern portions of the area between 11PM CDT on the 10th, and 1AM CDT on the 11th. This round of severe weather actually stemmed from thunderstorms that developed well northwest of the area, across southeast Montana and northeast Wyoming, during the afternoon hours of July 10th. Weakening had been noted around midnight as the leading edge shifted into the northwest CWA, likely impacted by the remnant cool, drier outflow from the first wave resulting in decreasing surface based instability and increasing inhibition. However, a mesohigh quickly developed over north central Nebraska, which resulted in a rapidly increasing low level pressure gradient force and strong pressure rises. In fact, pressure rises on the order of 8-9mb/2 hr were noted at both Ord and Grand Island ASOSs. The pressure rises allowed strong wind to develop, despite an overall weakening trend within the convection itself. Multiple reports of 55-65mph wind gusts occurred with this second round of activity, impacting areas from Ord to Hastings, including Grand Island, east to the York area. The strong winds resulted in numerous downed tree branches and power lines. The pressure gradient and wind gusts gradually relaxed after 1AM, and any additional gusts remained sub severe.||The next round of thunderstorms brought high winds to central and northern portions of the area between 11PM CDT on the 10th, and 1AM CDT on the 11th. This round of severe weather actually stemmed from thunderstorms that developed well northwest of the area, across southeast Montana and northeast Wyoming, during the afternoon hours of July 10th. Weakening had been noted around midnight as the leading edge shifted into the northwest CWA, likely impacted by the remnant cool, drier outflow from the first wave. However, a mesohigh quickly developed over north central Nebraska, which resulted in a rapidly increasing low level pressure gradient force and strong pressure rises. In fact, rises on the order of 8-9mb/2 hr were noted at both Ord and Grand Island ASOSs. The pressure rises allowed strong wind to develop, despite an overall weakening trend within the convection itself. Multiple reports of 55-65mph wind gusts occurred with this second round of activity, impacting areas from Ord to Hastings, including Grand Island, east to the York area. The strong winds resulted in numerous downed tree branches and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts in and around Kearney were estimated to be in the 60 to 70 MPH range. Wind gusts of 61 MPH were recorded by the Kearney Regional Airport AWOS and a mesonet station located 2 miles north-northeast of Kearney. Small tree branches were downed around town, and a large tree limb knocked down power lines and snapped a power pole near the Buffalo County Fairgrounds. Some minor shingle damage was also reported on the northwest side of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Limited precipitation in July and a continuation of hot temperatures, led to the initiation of severe drought conditions in portions of the eastern Nebraska Panhandle in late July. Severe drought conditions expanded into the Pine Ridge of northern Sheridan county, as well as portions of western Deuel and extreme southwestern Garden county. Severe drought conditions continued through the end of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) introduced to far southwest Garden County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Limited precipitation in July and a continuation of hot temperatures, led to the initiation of severe drought conditions in portions of the eastern Nebraska Panhandle in late July. Severe drought conditions expanded into the Pine Ridge of northern Sheridan county, as well as portions of western Deuel and extreme southwestern Garden county. Severe drought conditions continued through the end of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) conditions developed in western Deuel County including the Chappell area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought scattered thunderstorms, including a few severe thunderstorms with marginally severe wind gusts, to portions of south central Nebraska in the late evening hours of  July 13th. Thunderstorms initially developed along a cold front during the late afternoon hours from north central into southwest Nebraska. A segment of the broken line of thunderstorms strengthened over Lincoln County between 7pm and 9pm CDT, near North Platte, and accelerated eastward. This activity entered far western portions of the Hastings CWA around 9:30pm CDT, bringing marginally severe wind gusts to portions of Dawson and Gosper Counties. Additional severe thunderstorm warnings were issued further east to include all or portions of Phelps, Buffalo, and Kearney counties, but thunderstorms rapidly decreased in intensity between 10pm and 11pm CDT. In total, four severe wind reports were received with this initial activity. Several mesoscale convective vortices (MCVs) developed within the broader zone of convection as the cold front progressively shifted eastward across the Central Plains during the overnight hours. One such MCV strengthened over south central Nebraska such that a wake low developed on the backside of departing stratiform precipitation which produced strong to marginally severe wind gusts around the Hastings, NE vicinity between 1am and 2am CDT on July 14th. This prompted the issuance of a short fused High Wind Warning. However, the duration and coverage of severe winds caused by the wake low was relatively limited, as wind gusts east of Adams County remained just below severe levels in the 50-55 mph range.||Severe thunderstorm development on this day was supported by a cold front interacting with a warm, humid air mass and strong instability (MLCAPE of 3000-4000 J/kg). However, limited deep layer shear to around 30 knots or less along with warm mid level temperatures and increasing convective inhibition after sunset likely prevented thunderstorms from maintaining their intensity deep into the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH in Farnam.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds developed behind a cold front during the late morning hours into the afternoon hours on November 14th, 2020. Northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to around 60 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The nearby Ogallala AWOS recorded a peak wind gust of 59 mph at 115 pm MST. Northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph sustained with gusts as high as 59 mph were common across Perkins County between 11 am until 3 pm MST. The strong winds also caused areas of blowing dust with some reduced visibility below 5 miles at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered storms produced a couple of severe reports and led to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported estimated wind gusts of 60 mph.
