EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple strong to severe thunderstorms moved across the eastern portion of the Panhandle producing hailstones up to one inch.

Severe thunderstorms moved across the northern half of the Nebraska Panhandle producing severe winds in excess of 55 knots, hail stones up to tennis balls, and a brief landspout. The landspout occurred over the open country so much details to discern proper rating, length and width are unavailable to properly address.

A mid-level short wave came off of the Rocky Mountains out over the central Plains. This led to a surface low developing over Kansas. In front of that surface low, warm moist air was advected north. Isentropic upglide and led to an overrunning precipitation event that led to some high snowfall totals in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. It was the #5 (5.4 inches) and #4 (4.5 inches) highest April snowfall events for Omaha and Lincoln respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 6 inches of snow and still snowing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm developed along a boundary in Greeley County Kansas. As is all to typical in the High Plains, a couple landspout tornadoes were able to form. The landspouts last a few minutes and traversed a relatively small area. No know damage was reported with these tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief landspout reported. Tornado lasted about 6 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm developed along a boundary in Greeley County Kansas. As is all to typical in the High Plains, a couple landspout tornadoes were able to form. The landspouts last a few minutes and traversed a relatively small area. No know damage was reported with these tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Greeley county dispatch reported an ongoing tornado. Officer reported the tornado as becoming rain-wrapped and widening at the base. According to dispatch, the tornado dissipated around 3 minutes later.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed along the CO/KS border which traveled southeast during the afternoon hours. The thunderstorms yielded hail up to ping pong ball sized as well as a 64 mph wind gust due to a heat burst event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station reported a 64 mph highwind gust. This is a heat burst event as relative humidity dropped from 66% to 17% and temperature increased briefly to 91F from 83F at time of wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across areas of Northwest Kansas during the morning of October 25th followed by snow during the evening into the afternoon of October 26th. This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  Up to six inches of snow was reported, with the highest snow reported in Sherman County.  Ice accumulations of up to 3/8 were reported, with the highest amounts in Wallace County on tree branches.  Accidents were reported in Greely, Wichita, Sherman, Cheyenne, Norton, and Thomas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A semi-truck was reported to jack-knife at US-283 & Rd. B near the NE/KS state line at 8:19 MST on Oct 26th due to hazardous driving conditions because of freezing rain and snow. No injuries were reported. A report of 4 inches of total snowfall in Norton, KS was received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of Severe thunderstorms moved across western Nebraska through the Sandhills, southwest and into north central Nebraska during the evening and overnight hours. Thunderstorms brought damaging winds and hail as they moved eastward.

Freezing rain occurred across areas of Northwest Kansas during the morning of October 25th followed by snow during the evening into the afternoon of October 26th. This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  Up to six inches of snow was reported, with the highest snow reported in Sherman County.  Ice accumulations of up to 3/8 were reported, with the highest amounts in Wallace County on tree branches.  Accidents were reported in Greely, Wichita, Sherman, Cheyenne, Norton, and Thomas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm snowfall total amounts ranged from 4 inches outside the Goodland, KS to 6 inches within the Goodland, KS city limits.||Four vehicle accidents occurred within Sherman county during Oct. 25th and October 26th due to hazardous driving conditions caused by freezing rain and snow. One vehicle rolled over at 5:00 MST on 10/25. A second vehicle rolled over at 13:50 MST on 10/25. There was a third vehicle accident that caused an injury at 14:00 MST on 10/25. A fourth vehicle slid off a road at 9:30 MST on 10/26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across areas of Northwest Kansas during the morning of October 25th followed by snow during the evening into the afternoon of October 26th. This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  Up to six inches of snow was reported, with the highest snow reported in Sherman County.  Ice accumulations of up to 3/8 were reported, with the highest amounts in Wallace County on tree branches.  Accidents were reported in Greely, Wichita, Sherman, Cheyenne, Norton, and Thomas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Operator passed that there were vehicle accidents due to hazardous driving conditions due to freezing rain and snow. On Oct. 25th: a vehicle slide-off was reported at I-70 mile marker 27 at 7:34 CST. On Oct. 26th: a vehicle slide-off was reported at I-70 mile marker 49 at 7:44 CST, a one-vehicle accident in Colby, KS at 11:49 CST, and a one-vehicle accident with an injury at I-70 mile marker 64 at 11:50 CST. Reported snowfall total amounts in Thomas County ranged from 3 to 5.1 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across areas of Northwest Kansas during the morning of October 25th followed by snow during the evening into the afternoon of October 26th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received of a vehicle accident on a K-27 bridge north of Tribune, KS due to black ice on the road caused by freezing rain. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds, low relative humidity levels and dry vegetation led to an extreme fire danger. Several grass fires were reported during the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rapidly moving grass fire near 168th and Buffalo Rd lead to an evacuation of the Meadow Oaks neighborhood (46 Homes). Buffalo Rd was also closed for a period of time. The fire was under control by 3:30 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across areas of Northwest Kansas during the morning of October 25th followed by snow during the evening into the afternoon of October 26th. This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  Up to six inches of snow was reported, with the highest snow reported in Sherman County.  Ice accumulations of up to 3/8 were reported, with the highest amounts in Wallace County on tree branches.  Accidents were reported in Greely, Wichita, Sherman, Cheyenne, Norton, and Thomas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow fall reports of 6-7 inches occurred in Yuma County, far southern Dundy, and central Sherman County. Based on proximity these amounts should have also occurred in Cheyenne County. A vehicle rollover due to hazardous driving conditions caused by freezing rain and snow was reported at the intersection of US-36 and Rd. 33 at 13:46 CST on Oct. 25th. No injuries were reported in this accident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across areas of Northwest Kansas during the morning of October 25th followed by snow during the evening into the afternoon of October 26th. This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  Up to six inches of snow was reported, with the highest snow reported in Sherman County.  Ice accumulations of up to 3/8 were reported, with the highest amounts in Wallace County on tree branches.  Accidents were reported in Greely, Wichita, Sherman, Cheyenne, Norton, and Thomas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported of four incidents of vehicles sliding off on KS-25 between 6:30 and 8:30 CST on Oct. 25th due to hazardous driving conditions due to freezing rain. One vehicle slid off the road at mile marker 123. Three vehicles including one KSDOT truck slid off between mile markers 114 and 116. One injury was reported from these incidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across areas of Southwest Nebraska during the morning of October 25th, followed by snow during the evening and lasting into the afternoon of October 26th. This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  The highest snowfall amounts occurred in far southern Dundy County where six inches was reported along Highway 34.  Snow amounts declined to the east, with only an inch occurring in Red Willow County.   There were no reports of ice accumulations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall total amounts in Dundy County ranged from 2.8 inches to 6 inches. 6 inches was reported 3.7 miles WNW of Benkelman, NE.

This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  Up to six inches of snow was reported, with the highest snow reported in Sherman County.  Ice accumulations of up to 3/8 were reported, with the highest amounts in Wallace County on tree branches.  Accidents were reported in Greely, Wichita, Sherman, Cheyenne, Norton, and Thomas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wallace County saw freezing rain starting early Oct. 25th that transitioned to snow going into Oct. 26th. Freezing rain caused reports of an icy glaze on the roads with a localized report of 3/8ths of an inch of ice on tree branches during Oct. 25th. Snowfall totals ranged from 2-5 inches at the end of the event with the maximum seen in Wallace, KS. No vehicle accidents were reported due to the driving conditions during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across areas of Southwest Nebraska during the morning of October 25th, followed by snow during the evening and lasting into the afternoon of October 26th. This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  The highest snowfall amounts occurred in far southern Dundy County where six inches was reported along Highway 34.  Snow amounts declined to the east, with only an inch occurring in Red Willow County.   There were no reports of ice accumulations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five vehicle accidents were reported due to hazardous driving conditions due to freezing rain and snow near the NE towns of Bartley, Indianola, and McCook during Oct. 25th and Oct.26. No injuries were reported. 3.5 inches of total snowfall was reported 4 miles S of Bartley, NE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across areas of Southwest Nebraska during the morning of October 25th, followed by snow during the evening and lasting into the afternoon of October 26th. This led to vehicle accidents during this time.  The highest snowfall amounts occurred in far southern Dundy County where six inches was reported along Highway 34.  Snow amounts declined to the east, with only an inch occurring in Red Willow County.   There were no reports of ice accumulations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A semi truck was reported to jack-knife on Hwy 25 near Trenton, NE overnight on Oct. 25th due to hazardous driving conditions caused by freezing rain and snow. A snow plow stopped to help the truck driver and the plow was hit by a skidding vehicle.  The local fire department was called to help get one of the vehicles back on the road. No injuries were reported in the accident. Culbertson, NE reported 2 inches of total snowfall from the event.

A mid April severe/winter storm system came through Nebraska over the weekend on April 11 and 12. Before the blast of cold air, a surge of warm, moist air in front of a rapidly strengthening low led to severe weather across southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. 3 inch hail was reported near Murray, IA. The next day a cold front moved through the area and the primary precipitation type was snow. A strong pressure gradient led to strong winds with a 58 MPH the max wind gust reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust measured at TQE was 58 mph at 12:37 CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought strong northwesterly wind gusts during the late afternoon on November 14th. A strong low pressure system across southern Canada forced a cold front through south central Nebraska during the late afternoon hours. Strong northwest wind gusts accompanied the passage of the front, particularly across the western third of the County Warning Area (CWA), where a few gusts of 55 to 65 mph were measured. There was no known damage or impacts from the high wind. The severe wind gusts were supported by intense pressure rises on the order of 4-5mb per 2 hours. The arrival time of the front during or just after peak mixing was also a contributing factor. Peak wind gusts further east were weaker, but still strong, at speeds of 50 to 55 mph, as far east as Highway 281. Peak wind gusts remained less than 50mph east of Highway 281 as the 2hr pressure rises decreased to 2-3 mb.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 62 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 2 miles north-northwest of Gothenburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought strong northwesterly wind gusts during the late afternoon on November 14th. A strong low pressure system across southern Canada forced a cold front through south central Nebraska during the late afternoon hours. Strong northwest wind gusts accompanied the passage of the front, particularly across the western third of the County Warning Area (CWA), where a few gusts of 55 to 65 mph were measured. There was no known damage or impacts from the high wind. The severe wind gusts were supported by intense pressure rises on the order of 4-5mb per 2 hours. The arrival time of the front during or just after peak mixing was also a contributing factor. Peak wind gusts further east were weaker, but still strong, at speeds of 50 to 55 mph, as far east as Highway 281. Peak wind gusts remained less than 50mph east of Highway 281 as the 2hr pressure rises decreased to 2-3 mb.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 59 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 2 miles north-northeast of Norman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Logan County producing high winds with gusts ranging from 55 to 58 mph. The peak 58 mph gust was observed via the AWOS station near Oakley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lack of significant precipitation as the agricultural season ended maintained severe drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions remained severe (D2) through November. Crop damage is an estimate from insured losses. Information provided by the United States Department of Agriculture.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and plentiful moisture combined to produce a mix of wintery weather and heavy rain across south central Nebraska on November 9th into the 10th. Strong southerly wind gusts from the previous day (see November 8th Storm Data entry) continued into the early morning hours of November 9th, which allowed for copious amounts of atmospheric moisture to advect into the region ahead of a cold front. The cold front moved through the area from northwest to southeast during the morning and afternoon hours, with little in the way of precipitation. The front slowed down by late afternoon as surface low pressure organized over the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles, and the cold front eventually stalled out from central Kansas to central Iowa, just southeast of the NWS Hastings County Warning Area (CWA). This resulted in a sharp temperature gradient at the surface across the area, with cold air in the 20s across northwest portions of the CWA, 30s to low 40s across the far southeast CWA, and the surface freezing line from north central Kansas to east central Nebraska. Later during the evening hours, showers and even weak thunderstorms blossomed as moisture and weak instability interacted with the stalled cold front and shallow low level cold air mass. This set the stage for a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain across south central Nebraska during the evening hours of November 9th. Rain rates were impressive by November standards, and with surface temperatures below freezing, ice accretion began quickly. The greatest ice accretion occurred from around 8pm on the 9th until 2am on the 10th before mid level dry air was advected in from the southwest. The system was not done causing wintry weather across the area, however, as the surface and upper level low pressure ejected northeast from the southern High Plains into the Lower MO Valley and wrap around moisture brought a period of light to moderate snow during the morning hours of the 10, mainly after 4am. Several inches of snow fell across areas mainly north of Interstate 80, with the highest amounts of 4 to 6 inches observed in Greeley County. Only lingering light snow and flurries continued into the afternoon hours of the 10th.||Impacts from the ice were widespread from Webster and Nuckolls Counties northeast to Nance and Polk Counties, particularly in terms of tree damage, where ice accretion of at least one quarter of an inch was observed. Within the broader zone of ice damage, a smaller swath around 30-40 miles wide of more severe impacts appears to have occurred from Adams and Clay Counties northeast to portions of York and Polk Counties. This is where large tree limbs (10 to 15 inches in diameter) were snapped and where power outages were most common and long-lasting, some in excess of 24 hours (mainly rural areas). Also, some of the large tree limbs fell onto roadways and further complicated already hazardous travel conditions. A Cooperative Observer just northeast of Shelby, NE (in Polk County) reported ice accumulation as high as one half inch. School and business closures were numerous not only in the areas affected by ice, but also further north where snow was more prevalent. Meteorologically speaking, this event was impressive due to very high amounts of moisture, and even some instability, that overlapped with near or below freezing temperatures at the surface. Precipitable water values (PWATs) were as high as 1.0 to 1.2 inches, again, anomalously high for November. While this event was certainly towards the higher end of recent ice events, the area was fortunate it wasnt worse for several reasons: 1) Rain rates, while impressive, were actually too high for optimal and efficient ice accretion 2) surface temperatures were generally one to two degrees too warm for optimal ice accretion 3) Surface winds were relatively light and 4) duration of ice accretion was limited to around 6 hrs. We can say with relatively high confidence that if even one of the above factors was worse, this event couldve been much more severe. Finally, it's worth noting that for many, this was the most significant precipitation event in around two months, as many areas along and east of Highway 281 received 0.75 to 1 or more of moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts of 1 to 3 inches fell across the county, with the highest amounts across far eastern portions of the county. A light glaze of ice from freezing rain and freezing drizzle occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and plentiful moisture combined to produce a mix of wintery weather and heavy rain across south central Nebraska on November 9th into the 10th. Strong southerly wind gusts from the previous day (see November 8th Storm Data entry) continued into the early morning hours of November 9th, which allowed for copious amounts of atmospheric moisture to advect into the region ahead of a cold front. The cold front moved through the area from northwest to southeast during the morning and afternoon hours, with little in the way of precipitation. The front slowed down by late afternoon as surface low pressure organized over the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles, and the cold front eventually stalled out from central Kansas to central Iowa, just southeast of the NWS Hastings County Warning Area (CWA). This resulted in a sharp temperature gradient at the surface across the area, with cold air in the 20s across northwest portions of the CWA, 30s to low 40s across the far southeast CWA, and the surface freezing line from north central Kansas to east central Nebraska. Later during the evening hours, showers and even weak thunderstorms blossomed as moisture and weak instability interacted with the stalled cold front and shallow low level cold air mass. This set the stage for a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain across south central Nebraska during the evening hours of November 9th. Rain rates were impressive by November standards, and with surface temperatures below freezing, ice accretion began quickly. The greatest ice accretion occurred from around 8pm on the 9th until 2am on the 10th before mid level dry air was advected in from the southwest. The system was not done causing wintry weather across the area, however, as the surface and upper level low pressure ejected northeast from the southern High Plains into the Lower MO Valley and wrap around moisture brought a period of light to moderate snow during the morning hours of the 10, mainly after 4am. Several inches of snow fell across areas mainly north of Interstate 80, with the highest amounts of 4 to 6 inches observed in Greeley County. Only lingering light snow and flurries continued into the afternoon hours of the 10th.||Impacts from the ice were widespread from Webster and Nuckolls Counties northeast to Nance and Polk Counties, particularly in terms of tree damage, where ice accretion of at least one quarter of an inch was observed. Within the broader zone of ice damage, a smaller swath around 30-40 miles wide of more severe impacts appears to have occurred from Adams and Clay Counties northeast to portions of York and Polk Counties. This is where large tree limbs (10 to 15 inches in diameter) were snapped and where power outages were most common and long-lasting, some in excess of 24 hours (mainly rural areas). Also, some of the large tree limbs fell onto roadways and further complicated already hazardous travel conditions. A Cooperative Observer just northeast of Shelby, NE (in Polk County) reported ice accumulation as high as one half inch. School and business closures were numerous not only in the areas affected by ice, but also further north where snow was more prevalent. Meteorologically speaking, this event was impressive due to very high amounts of moisture, and even some instability, that overlapped with near or below freezing temperatures at the surface. Precipitable water values (PWATs) were as high as 1.0 to 1.2 inches, again, anomalously high for November. While this event was certainly towards the higher end of recent ice events, the area was fortunate it wasnt worse for several reasons: 1) Rain rates, while impressive, were actually too high for optimal and efficient ice accretion 2) surface temperatures were generally one to two degrees too warm for optimal ice accretion 3) Surface winds were relatively light and 4) duration of ice accretion was limited to around 6 hrs. We can say with relatively high confidence that if even one of the above factors was worse, this event couldve been much more severe. Finally, it's worth noting that for many, this was the most significant precipitation event in around two months, as many areas along and east of Highway 281 received 0.75 to 1 or more of moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts of 1 to 3 inches fell across the county, with the highest amounts across far eastern portions of the county. A light glaze of ice from freezing rain and freezing drizzle occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the first week of November 2020, and for the first time since 2015, a small portion of this six-county North Central Kansas area found itself in D2 Severe Drought per the U.S. Drought Monitor (USDM). Specifically, D2 was introduced to northern portions of Phillips and Smith counties along with the extreme northwest corner of Jewell County on the Nov. 3rd USDM issuance, with a slight southward expansion later in the month including a bit more of these counties. In addition, the Nov. 24th USDM technically introduced D3 Extreme Drought to the far northwest corner of Phillips County, marking the first instance of D3 within North Central Kansas since 2014. Outside of the fairly limited D2/D3 areas, the remainder of (and the majority of) the six-county area spent November in D1 Moderate Drought. ||Within a larger context, this autumn introduction of D2/D3 signaled a relatively-rapid decline in moisture conditions within North Central Kansas, as the entire six-county area had been void of all drought categories (including D0 Abnormally Dry) as recently as most of July and all of August (before D0/D1 started creeping in during September-October). In fact, July was notably wet across the vast majority of the area as most places tallied 5-10+ inches of rain (except for northwestern Phillips County which saw a bit less). But starting in August and peaking in October, the proverbial faucet really shut off, allowing drought to enter the picture. In fact, most of the area received no more than 5-10 percent-of-normal precipitation in October (including merely 0.05 at Smith Center and 0.09 at Phillipsburg). From a longer-duration perspective covering the four-month-stretch from August-November, a few of the very-driest NWS observer precipitation totals within/near the current D2/D3 area included 1.83 at Logan (driest on record), 1.88 at Phillipsburg (driest on record) and 2.59 in Smith Center (3rd-driest on record). Farther south and east within North Central Kansas, drought classification remained no worse than D1 during November, as much of especially Jewell, Osborne and Mitchell counties received slightly above normal monthly precipitation of 1.50-2.00+ inches. Given that the current North Central Kansas drought situation materialized fairly rapidly during the late summer/fall months and that the preceding few years had been rather wet, there were no known widespread/serious 2020 drought impacts within the local area through November.

During November, 18 of the 24 counties in South Central Nebraska were completely-or-partially included in D2-or-worse drought, per weekly issuances of the U.S. Drought Monitor. For much of the western half of the area (especially west of a Greeley-Minden-Franklin line), November marked at least the fourth-consecutive month of below normal precipitation, prompting the return of D3 Extreme Drought to portions of South Central Nebraska for the first time since 2013. Meanwhile, for roughly the eastern half of the area, November precipitation trends were more encouraging as most places registered slightly wetter-than-normal for the month (totals commonly 1.50-2.00 inches). Of note, November finally broke a five-month streak of below normal precipitation at Hastings that had lasted from June-October. Although drought categories did not explicitly improve in the eastern half of the area, they at least remained status quo, stemming a gradual-worsening trend that had defined the preceding few months. ||Breaking things down in more detail and focusing on specific drought categories: Clearly the most newsworthy November note was the late-month introduction of D3 to all of of Furnas/Gosper counties, along with adjacent portions of Dawson/Phelps/Harlan/far southwestern Buffalo (total of six affected counties). Within much of this area, November precipitation totals were incredibly meager, including as little as 0.04 at Wilsonville and 0.07 south of Elwood. However, the introduction of D3 was ultimately driven by slightly-longer term precipitation deficits, as several official NWS stations in the D3 area endured one of their driest August-November stretches on record, including record-driest at Elwood 8S (1.47) and Canaday Steam Plant/Lexington 6SSE (1.07). Slightly east of the official D3 area, Minden also notched its driest-on-record Aug.-Nov. with only 2.30. In addition to the six counties included in D3 by month's end, all-or-some of 12 other counties west of the Highway 81 corridor remained in D2 Severe Drought throughout the month. Meanwhile, the rest of South Central Nebraska remained in (or was newly-assigned) D1 Moderate Drought during November. Temperature-wise, although not as big of a drought-factor as it would have been during the growing season, November was certainly a warm one with most local stations averaging 5-7 degrees F above normal (among the Top-10 warmest-on-record at many of them).

During November, 18 of the 24 counties in South Central Nebraska were completely-or-partially included in D2-or-worse drought, per weekly issuances of the U.S. Drought Monitor. For much of the western half of the area (especially west of a Greeley-Minden-Franklin line), November marked at least the fourth-consecutive month of below normal precipitation, prompting the return of D3 Extreme Drought to portions of South Central Nebraska for the first time since 2013. Meanwhile, for roughly the eastern half of the area, November precipitation trends were more encouraging as most places registered slightly wetter-than-normal for the month (totals commonly 1.50-2.00 inches). Of note, November finally broke a five-month streak of below normal precipitation at Hastings that had lasted from June-October. Although drought categories did not explicitly improve in the eastern half of the area, they at least remained status quo, stemming a gradual-worsening trend that had defined the preceding few months. ||Breaking things down in more detail and focusing on specific drought categories: Clearly the most newsworthy November note was the late-month introduction of D3 to all of of Furnas/Gosper counties, along with adjacent portions of Dawson/Phelps/Harlan/far southwestern Buffalo (total of six affected counties). Within much of this area, November precipitation totals were incredibly meager, including as little as 0.04 at Wilsonville and 0.07 south of Elwood. However, the introduction of D3 was ultimately driven by slightly-longer term precipitation deficits, as several official NWS stations in the D3 area endured one of their driest August-November stretches on record, including record-driest at Elwood 8S (1.47) and Canaday Steam Plant/Lexington 6SSE (1.07). Slightly east of the official D3 area, Minden also notched its driest-on-record Aug.-Nov. with only 2.30. In addition to the six counties included in D3 by month's end, all-or-some of 12 other counties west of the Highway 81 corridor remained in D2 Severe Drought throughout the month. Meanwhile, the rest of South Central Nebraska remained in (or was newly-assigned) D1 Moderate Drought during November. Temperature-wise, although not as big of a drought-factor as it would have been during the growing season, November was certainly a warm one with most local stations averaging 5-7 degrees F above normal (among the Top-10 warmest-on-record at many of them).

A lack of significant precipitation as the agricultural season ended maintained severe drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions remained severe (D2) through November.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unusual warmth with a week of temperatures mainly in the 70s (even 50s and 60s on November 9 less than a day before this storm) was brought to an abrupt end as a deep trough of low pressure moved out of Rockies and into the Plains. An intense lower- to mid-level frontal zone oozed eastward as a strong jet lifted out across the Plains on November 10, initiating widespread precipitation. Shallow cooling lingered during the late night and early morning hours and led to a period of freezing rain which accumulated from a tenth to a quarter inch, before changing to snow. Snow amounts ranged from 3 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain overnight and through the morning resulted in ice accumulation of a quarter inch, especially on elevated surfaces, including powerlines. Brief power outages were reported. Snowfall developed later morning and through the afternoon, and accumulated to 3.0 inches at Emerson. Slick roadways resulted in several accidents. Two separate accidents resulted in (indirect) fatalities along State Highway 35 northeast of Emerson.  The first occurred around 0640CST when a semi truck ran off the highway and struck a creek bank, killing the driver.  The second fatal accident occurred shortly after 1500CST when a jackknifing semi trailer collided with the tractor of a second semi on a curve. Property damage costs are rough estimates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercells developed along an outflow boundary in NW Kansas and moved south across I-70. These storms produced up to half-dollar sized hail in Gove County, as well as 60 mph thunderstorm wind gusts and up to penny sized hail in Logan County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports from social media and Logan County Emergency Manager of small hail ranging from peas to penny in size that fell for a duration of approximately 10 minutes in the town of Oakley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two lines of thunderstorms formed along boundaries in eastern Colorado and then merged into a cluster in Yuma County, Colorado. The cluster entered into northwest Kansas in the early evening hours producing thunderstorm wind gusts up to 60 MPH in Cheyenne and Rawlins County. The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public reported sporadic dime to penny sized hail that fell for a duration of 20 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two lines of thunderstorms formed along boundaries in eastern Colorado and then merged into a cluster in Yuma County, Colorado. The cluster entered into northwest Kansas in the early evening hours producing thunderstorm wind gusts up to 60 MPH in Cheyenne and Rawlins County. The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public reported via social media an estimated 60 mph wind gust associated with the outflow from a cluster of thunderstorms moving east across Cheyenne County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two lines of thunderstorms formed along boundaries in eastern Colorado and then merged into a cluster in Yuma County, Colorado. The cluster entered into northwest Kansas in the early evening hours producing thunderstorm wind gusts up to 60 MPH in Cheyenne and Rawlins County. The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public reported an estimated 60 mph wind gust associated with an outflow boundary entering Rawlins County ahead of a cluster of thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing dust associated with a strong cold front caused reduced visibilities of less than one hundred yards on Highway 83 in southern Decatur County. The nearby mesonet stations were observing gusts between 40-50 mph around the time of the report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Gove County producing high wind sustained at 30 to 55 mph with gusts from 59 to 62 mph for a duration of 15 minutes. The wind gusts were measured via a mesonet station near I-70 in the northeast corner of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Logan County Emergency Manager reported blowing dust associated with a strong cold front from Oakley to Russell Springs. Visibility ranged from one mile to zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unusual warmth with a week of temperatures mainly in the 70s (even 50s and 60s on November 9 less than a day before this storm) was brought to an abrupt end as a deep trough of low pressure moved out of Rockies and into the Plains. An intense lower- to mid-level frontal zone oozed eastward as a strong jet lifted out across the Plains on November 10, initiating widespread precipitation. Shallow cooling lingered during the late night and early morning hours and led to a period of freezing rain which accumulated from a tenth to a quarter inch, before changing to snow. Snow amounts ranged from 3 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, briefly mixed with sleet or freezing drizzle during the morning, became heavy at times between 1000-1400CST.  Accumulations reached 6.0 inches at Concord, 5.6 inches 2 miles northwest of Ponca, and 5.4 inches at Newcastle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two lines of thunderstorms formed along boundaries in eastern Colorado and then merged into a cluster in Yuma County, Colorado. The cluster entered into northwest Kansas in the early evening hours producing thunderstorm wind gusts up to 60 MPH in Cheyenne and Rawlins County. The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public reported an estimated 60 mph wind gust associated with the outflow boundary of a thunderstorm cluster moving east across northwest Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two lines of thunderstorms formed along boundaries in eastern Colorado and then merged into a cluster in Yuma County, Colorado. The cluster entered into southwest Nebraska in the early evening hours producing thunderstorm wind gusts up to 60 MPH and up to half-dollar sized hail in Dundy County.  As the storms progressed east, they also produced up to penny sized hail in Hitchcock County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported quarter to half-dollar sized hail.

Northwest flow aloft with marginal severe risk associated with a frontal boundary moving southeastward bordering up to the Oklahoma state line. A few rogue thunderstorms made their way across some of the southern counties and with enough instability, small hail and heavy rain fell with a few quarters being the largest observed.

With continued dry conditions in September, severe and extreme drought conditions expanded across the eastern Nebraska Panhandle and portions of the western Sandhills and southwestern Nebraska in September. Extreme drought conditions expanded into the western third of Garden and extreme southwestern portions of Sheridan and extreme northwestern portions of Deuel county by the end of September. East of this area to a line from Gordon, to Arthur, to North Platte and Maywood, severe drought conditions had developed by the end of month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of September, severe drought (D2) conditions, expanded to all of Sheridan County. In addition, locations in extreme southwestern Sheridan county were experiencing extreme drought (D3) conditions by the end of September.  The cooperative station at Gordon 6N reported 0.71 inches of rainfall for the month. This was 0.92 inches below the normal of 1.63 inches. The cooperative station at Ellsworth 2W reported 0.60 inches of rain which was 1.00 inches below the normal of 1.60 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry conditions in August along with above normal temperatures, led to the expansion of severe drought conditions. Locations in northern Sheridan, Garden, Deuel and western Keith county were in severe drought conditions by the end of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) conditions expanded to include all of the Pine Ridge area of northern Sheridan county by the end of August. Precipitation received at the Cooperative Station Gordon 6N received 0.50 inches of rainfall for August which was well below the normal of 1.64 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry conditions in August along with above normal temperatures, led to the expansion of severe drought conditions. Locations in northern Sheridan, Garden, Deuel and western Keith county were in severe drought conditions by the end of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) conditions expanded from far southwestern Garden county to include all of Garden county by the end of month of August. The Cooperative Station at Lisco reported 0.00 inches of precipitation for August which was 1.98 inches below the normal of 1.98 inches. Oshkosh reported 0.21 inches of rainfall which was well below the normal of 1.96 inches. Oshkosh 8SW reported 0.61 inches which was well below the normal of 2.40 inches. The Cooperative Station at Crescent Lakes NWR, 20 miles north of Oshkosh reported only 0.08 inches of rainfall which was well below the normal of 2.18 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry conditions in August along with above normal temperatures, led to the expansion of severe drought conditions. Locations in northern Sheridan, Garden, Deuel and western Keith county were in severe drought conditions by the end of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) conditions expanded from western Deuel county at the beginning of August, to all of Deuel county by the end of the month. The Cooperative Station at Chappell reported only 0.70 inches of rainfall for the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry conditions in August along with above normal temperatures, led to the expansion of severe drought conditions. Locations in northern Sheridan, Garden, Deuel and western Keith county were in severe drought conditions by the end of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) conditions began across southwestern Keith county on August 11th and expanded slightly into northwestern Keith county by the end of the month. At Ogallala, only 0.02 inches of precipitation was recorded for the month. This was well below the normal of 2.29 inches. The Cooperative Station at Kingsley Dam reported 0.30 inches of rain for the month. This was well below the normal of 1.88 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station near Leoti observed a high wind gust of 62 mph as a strong cold front passed over. The station lost power after the observation. The strong winds lifted dirt into the air and caused reduced visibility less than one-quarter mile in the town of Leoti.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A linear cluster of storms moved east into northwest Kansas from Yuma County and merged into one large line with clusters in Cheyenne County, Colorado and southwest Nebraska. These storms produced up to 60 mph thunderstorm wind gusts and various sized hail up to two inches in diameter.

A linear cluster of storms moved east into northwest Kansas from Yuma County and merged into one large line with clusters in Cheyenne County, Colorado and southwest Nebraska. These storms produced up to 60 mph thunderstorm wind gusts and various sized hail up to two inches in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of various sized hail from nickel to hen egg in size that fell for a duration of approximately seven minutes in downtown Sharon Springs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 41 mph reported by KGLD ASOS 1 mile north-northeast of Goodland, KS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and plentiful moisture combined to produce a mix of wintery weather and heavy rain across south central Nebraska on November 9th into the 10th. Strong southerly wind gusts from the previous day (see November 8th Storm Data entry) continued into the early morning hours of November 9th, which allowed for copious amounts of atmospheric moisture to advect into the region ahead of a cold front. The cold front moved through the area from northwest to southeast during the morning and afternoon hours, with little in the way of precipitation. The front slowed down by late afternoon as surface low pressure organized over the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles, and the cold front eventually stalled out from central Kansas to central Iowa, just southeast of the NWS Hastings County Warning Area (CWA). This resulted in a sharp temperature gradient at the surface across the area, with cold air in the 20s across northwest portions of the CWA, 30s to low 40s across the far southeast CWA, and the surface freezing line from north central Kansas to east central Nebraska. Later during the evening hours, showers and even weak thunderstorms blossomed as moisture and weak instability interacted with the stalled cold front and shallow low level cold air mass. This set the stage for a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain across south central Nebraska during the evening hours of November 9th. Rain rates were impressive by November standards, and with surface temperatures below freezing, ice accretion began quickly. The greatest ice accretion occurred from around 8pm on the 9th until 2am on the 10th before mid level dry air was advected in from the southwest. The system was not done causing wintry weather across the area, however, as the surface and upper level low pressure ejected northeast from the southern High Plains into the Lower MO Valley and wrap around moisture brought a period of light to moderate snow during the morning hours of the 10, mainly after 4am. Several inches of snow fell across areas mainly north of Interstate 80, with the highest amounts of 4 to 6 inches observed in Greeley County. Only lingering light snow and flurries continued into the afternoon hours of the 10th.||Impacts from the ice were widespread from Webster and Nuckolls Counties northeast to Nance and Polk Counties, particularly in terms of tree damage, where ice accretion of at least one quarter of an inch was observed. Within the broader zone of ice damage, a smaller swath around 30-40 miles wide of more severe impacts appears to have occurred from Adams and Clay Counties northeast to portions of York and Polk Counties. This is where large tree limbs (10 to 15 inches in diameter) were snapped and where power outages were most common and long-lasting, some in excess of 24 hours (mainly rural areas). Also, some of the large tree limbs fell onto roadways and further complicated already hazardous travel conditions. A Cooperative Observer just northeast of Shelby, NE (in Polk County) reported ice accumulation as high as one half inch. School and business closures were numerous not only in the areas affected by ice, but also further north where snow was more prevalent. Meteorologically speaking, this event was impressive due to very high amounts of moisture, and even some instability, that overlapped with near or below freezing temperatures at the surface. Precipitable water values (PWATs) were as high as 1.0 to 1.2 inches, again, anomalously high for November. While this event was certainly towards the higher end of recent ice events, the area was fortunate it wasnt worse for several reasons: 1) Rain rates, while impressive, were actually too high for optimal and efficient ice accretion 2) surface temperatures were generally one to two degrees too warm for optimal ice accretion 3) Surface winds were relatively light and 4) duration of ice accretion was limited to around 6 hrs. We can say with relatively high confidence that if even one of the above factors was worse, this event couldve been much more severe. Finally, it's worth noting that for many, this was the most significant precipitation event in around two months, as many areas along and east of Highway 281 received 0.75 to 1 or more of moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and freezing drizzle resulted in a coating of ice at least one-quarter inch thick. Travel was hazardous, and numerous tree limbs were downed. Power lines were also affected, causing power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and freezing drizzle resulted in a coating of ice at least one-quarter inch thick. Travel was hazardous, and numerous tree limbs were downed. Power lines were also affected, causing power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and plentiful moisture combined to produce a mix of wintery weather and heavy rain across south central Nebraska on November 9th into the 10th. Strong southerly wind gusts from the previous day (see November 8th Storm Data entry) continued into the early morning hours of November 9th, which allowed for copious amounts of atmospheric moisture to advect into the region ahead of a cold front. The cold front moved through the area from northwest to southeast during the morning and afternoon hours, with little in the way of precipitation. The front slowed down by late afternoon as surface low pressure organized over the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles, and the cold front eventually stalled out from central Kansas to central Iowa, just southeast of the NWS Hastings County Warning Area (CWA). This resulted in a sharp temperature gradient at the surface across the area, with cold air in the 20s across northwest portions of the CWA, 30s to low 40s across the far southeast CWA, and the surface freezing line from north central Kansas to east central Nebraska. Later during the evening hours, showers and even weak thunderstorms blossomed as moisture and weak instability interacted with the stalled cold front and shallow low level cold air mass. This set the stage for a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain across south central Nebraska during the evening hours of November 9th. Rain rates were impressive by November standards, and with surface temperatures below freezing, ice accretion began quickly. The greatest ice accretion occurred from around 8pm on the 9th until 2am on the 10th before mid level dry air was advected in from the southwest. The system was not done causing wintry weather across the area, however, as the surface and upper level low pressure ejected northeast from the southern High Plains into the Lower MO Valley and wrap around moisture brought a period of light to moderate snow during the morning hours of the 10, mainly after 4am. Several inches of snow fell across areas mainly north of Interstate 80, with the highest amounts of 4 to 6 inches observed in Greeley County. Only lingering light snow and flurries continued into the afternoon hours of the 10th.||Impacts from the ice were widespread from Webster and Nuckolls Counties northeast to Nance and Polk Counties, particularly in terms of tree damage, where ice accretion of at least one quarter of an inch was observed. Within the broader zone of ice damage, a smaller swath around 30-40 miles wide of more severe impacts appears to have occurred from Adams and Clay Counties northeast to portions of York and Polk Counties. This is where large tree limbs (10 to 15 inches in diameter) were snapped and where power outages were most common and long-lasting, some in excess of 24 hours (mainly rural areas). Also, some of the large tree limbs fell onto roadways and further complicated already hazardous travel conditions. A Cooperative Observer just northeast of Shelby, NE (in Polk County) reported ice accumulation as high as one half inch. School and business closures were numerous not only in the areas affected by ice, but also further north where snow was more prevalent. Meteorologically speaking, this event was impressive due to very high amounts of moisture, and even some instability, that overlapped with near or below freezing temperatures at the surface. Precipitable water values (PWATs) were as high as 1.0 to 1.2 inches, again, anomalously high for November. While this event was certainly towards the higher end of recent ice events, the area was fortunate it wasnt worse for several reasons: 1) Rain rates, while impressive, were actually too high for optimal and efficient ice accretion 2) surface temperatures were generally one to two degrees too warm for optimal ice accretion 3) Surface winds were relatively light and 4) duration of ice accretion was limited to around 6 hrs. We can say with relatively high confidence that if even one of the above factors was worse, this event couldve been much more severe. Finally, it's worth noting that for many, this was the most significant precipitation event in around two months, as many areas along and east of Highway 281 received 0.75 to 1 or more of moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and freezing drizzle resulted in a coating of ice at least one-quarter inch thick. Travel was hazardous, and numerous tree limbs were downed. Power lines were also affected, causing power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A linear cluster of storms moved east into northwest Kansas from Yuma County and merged into one large line with clusters in Cheyenne County, Colorado and southwest Nebraska on August 11th. As the main line continued across northwest Kansas and southwest Nebraska, more convection developed throughout the evening and into the early morning hours of August 12th producing 59 mph thunderstorm wind gusts in the city of McCook in Red Willow County.

Far south central Kansas was hammered with large hail in a few locations overnight on August the 12th into the early morning of August the 13th.  It is likely more hail occurred with this small line of storms, however, the hour in which it moved across the area hampered reports from the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Time estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Far south central Kansas was hammered with large hail in a few locations overnight on August the 12th into the early morning of August the 13th.  It is likely more hail occurred with this small line of storms, however, the hour in which it moved across the area hampered reports from the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Relayed via county Emergency Manager.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Far south central Kansas was hammered with large hail in a few locations overnight on August the 12th into the early morning of August the 13th.  It is likely more hail occurred with this small line of storms, however, the hour in which it moved across the area hampered reports from the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public report was relayed via KSN TV.  The report was based on a picture submitted via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved across the Sandhills into Southwest Nebraska the evening of August 5, 2020. A few isolated thunderstorms became severe with hail the main threat.

One cluster of thunderstorms moved eastward from the Nebraska Panhandle into western Nebraska through the northern Sandhills. The second cluster of storms moved eastward from northern Colorado into southern Nebraska. Storms produced severe hail and damaging winds.

One cluster of thunderstorms moved eastward from the Nebraska Panhandle into western Nebraska through the northern Sandhills. The second cluster of storms moved eastward from northern Colorado into southern Nebraska. Storms produced severe hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained Spotter reported strong winds of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One cluster of thunderstorms moved eastward from the Nebraska Panhandle into western Nebraska through the northern Sandhills. The second cluster of storms moved eastward from northern Colorado into southern Nebraska. Storms produced severe hail and damaging winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of a 64 mph wind gust from the ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense cluster of severe thunderstorms developed along Interstate 44 from Mount Vernon to far southeast Kansas as a southward moving outflow boundary interacted with a very unstable air mass. The storms produced hail up to the size of tennis balls as they moved southwestward into Cherokee County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail was reported.

The storms produced hail up to the size of tennis balls as they moved southwestward into Cherokee County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A picture of hail to the size of tennis balls was received via social media from a rural part of the county. Minor roof and vehicle damage occurred to the farm stead where the hail occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail from half dollar to golf balls in size was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An MCS moved across the region producing widespread severe thunderstorm wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several power lines were reported down on south Ozark Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the month the drought status worsened for Greeley County from D2 Severe to D3 Extreme Drought.  Wallace County remained unchanged with the southern half of the county in D2 Drought.  Total precipitation for these counties ranged from 0.76 to 2.66, with the higher amounts over Greeley County.  Average precipitation for these counties ranged from 0.02 to 1.45.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total precipitation received for the month ranged from 1.40 to 2.66.  The normal precipitation for August ranges from 2.00 to 3.00.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance aloft in northwest flow was enough to produce isolated thunderstorms. One thunderstorm briefly became severe in the vicinity of Dighton.  An apparent microburst produced damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A building was heavily damaged from an apparent microburst.  Blowing gravel broke out the windows of a vehicle and injured the occupant of the vehicle.  There were also power poles blown down in this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northwest flow upper level shortwave moved across the CWA into the late evening and early overnight hours with large hail over an inch and up to 1.75 inches reported initially during daylight hours, before becoming a wind driven event after sunset seeing gusts up to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several tree branches were broken by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northwest flow upper level shortwave moved across the CWA late evening and into the overnight hours once again with large hail the initial threat seeing sizes up to 3-4 inches. Several apparent gustnadoes were incorrectly identified as tornadoes based on video evidence.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged from pea to ping ball sized.

A severe storm moved eastward across portions of central KS on August 14th, producing wind gusts into the lower 70 mph range and also some low end severe sized hail. The storm paralleled Interstate 70 extending to the north and south about 25 miles each way.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe storm moved eastward across portions of central KS on August 14th, producing wind gusts into the lower 70 mph range and also some low end severe sized hail. The storm paralleled Interstate 70 extending to the north and south about 25 miles each way.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The sustained severe winds were measured wind gust at KRSL, Russell Municipal Airport. The initial gust began at 63 mph at 21 minutes after the hour and then increased to 67 mph shortly thereafter.  The severe gusty winds continued for several minutes before peaking at 72 mph at 10:41 then decreasing as the storm moved east.  Numerous 1 foot in diameter tree limbs were blown down across the community of Russell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon scattered thunderstorms, along with a line of severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds over southern and southeast Kansas, on August 10th, 2020.
An MCS moved across the region producing widespread severe thunderstorm wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous tree limbs were down on homes and power lines across town. At least a dozen power lines were down along with four power poles pushed over. Several large trees were uprooted. Roof damage occurred to several homes. No injuries were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows were broke out several vehicles.

During October the drought status for Greeley and Wallace counties remained unchanged for the most part.  There was a small expansion of the D2 Severe and D3 Extreme Drought area for Wallace County.  Observed precipitation ranged from a tenth to a quarter of an inch.  Normal precipitation ranged from one to one and a half inches.  This is a departure of up to two inches below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed precipitation for the month ranged from a tenth to a quarter of an inch. Normal precipitation amounts ranged from one to one and a half inches. This is a departure of one to two inches from normal. D3 Extreme Drought encompassed the west half of the county with D2 Severe Drought covering the east half.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During October the drought status for Greeley and Wallace counties remained unchanged for the most part.  There was a small expansion of the D2 Severe and D3 Extreme Drought area for Wallace County.  Observed precipitation ranged from a tenth to a quarter of an inch.  Normal precipitation ranged from one to one and a half inches.  This is a departure of up to two inches below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed precipitation for the month ranged from a quarter to half an inch. Normal precipitation amounts ranged from one to one and a half inches. This is a departure of half an inch to an inch from normal. D3 Severe Drought encompassed roughly the southwestern quarter of the county, with D2 Severe Drought extending slightly further east in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. These cells produced various sized hail up to tennis ball in size and up to 60 mph thunderstorm wind gusts across Red Willow, Hitchcock, and Dundy counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball sized hail reportedly fell at the location for a duration of 5 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moved across the CWA with a surface boundary draped across the area. Initial threat was large hail but later formed into a cluster of storms producing wind damage and severe gusts around 60 mph.

A shortwave trough moved across the CWA with a surface boundary draped across the area. Initial threat was large hail but later formed into a cluster of storms producing wind damage and severe gusts around 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Siding damage was done to a barn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moved across the CWA with a surface boundary draped across the area. Initial threat was large hail but later formed into a cluster of storms producing wind damage and severe gusts around 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power poles were blown down by the high wind.

During October D2 Severe Drought expanded dramatically in coverage from two to six counties. Observed precipitation amounts ranged from a tenth to a half inch. Normal precipitation amounts ranged from a half inch to two inches. This is a departure of up to two inches from normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed precipitation for the month ranged from a quarter to half an inch. Normal precipitation amounts ranged from one to two inches. This is a departure of half an inch to two inches from normal.  D2 Severe Drought covered the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds associated with a strong cold front lifted dirt and corn leaves into the air. The blowing dust caused reduced visibilities between one-quarter mile to near-zero on Old Highway 40 between Grainfield and Grinnell. Nearby stations have missing observations, so the wind gusts are unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As a strong cold front moved southeast across Norton County, dirt was lifted in the air. The blowing dust caused reduced visibilities from fifty to ten yards near the town of Norton. The Norton AWOS station has missing observations during this time and nearby stations are measuring near zero winds, so the actual wind speeds to cause the blowing dust is unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During October D2 Severe Drought expanded dramatically in coverage from two to six counties. Observed precipitation amounts ranged from a tenth to a half inch. Normal precipitation amounts ranged from a half inch to two inches. This is a departure of up to two inches from normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed precipitation for the month ranged from a quarter to half an inch.  Normal precipitation amounts ranged from one and a half to two inches. This is a departure of one to two inches from normal.  D2 Severe Drought encompassed the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During October drought conditions for Sherman County worsened.  The drought status changed from D1 Moderate Drought to D2 Severe Drought covering most of the county.  Observed precipitation ranged from a quarter to half an inch.  Normal precipitation ranged from one to one and a half inches.  This resulted in a departure from normal of half to two inches.

During October D2 Severe Drought expanded dramatically in coverage from two to six counties. Observed precipitation amounts ranged from a tenth to a half inch. Normal precipitation amounts ranged from a half inch to two inches. This is a departure of up to two inches from normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed precipitation for the month ranged from a tenth to a quarter of an inch. Normal precipitation amounts ranged from a half to one and a half inches. This is a departure of one to two inches from normal. D2 Severe Drought encompassed the northwest half of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought strong northwesterly wind gusts during the late afternoon on November 14th. A strong low pressure system across southern Canada forced a cold front through south central Nebraska during the late afternoon hours. Strong northwest wind gusts accompanied the passage of the front, particularly across the western third of the County Warning Area (CWA), where a few gusts of 55 to 65 mph were measured. There was no known damage or impacts from the high wind. The severe wind gusts were supported by intense pressure rises on the order of 4-5mb per 2 hours. The arrival time of the front during or just after peak mixing was also a contributing factor. Peak wind gusts further east were weaker, but still strong, at speeds of 50 to 55 mph, as far east as Highway 281. Peak wind gusts remained less than 50mph east of Highway 281 as the 2hr pressure rises decreased to 2-3 mb.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 59 MPH was measured by the Ord Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought strong northwesterly wind gusts during the late afternoon on November 14th. A strong low pressure system across southern Canada forced a cold front through north central Kansas during the late afternoon hours. Strong northwest wind gusts accompanied the passage of the front, particularly across the western third of the County Warning Area (CWA). A peak wind gust of 63 mph was measured in Phillips County, KS, but there was no known damage or impacts from the high wind. The severe wind gust was supported by intense pressure rises on the order of 4-5mb per 2 hours. The arrival time of the front during or just after peak mixing was also a contributing factor. Peak wind gusts further east were weaker, but still strong, at speeds of 50 to 55 mph, as far east as Highway 281. Peak wind gusts remained less than 50mph east of Highway 281 as the 2hr pressure rises decreased to 2-3 mb.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 63 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 1 mile west of Logan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved slowly southeast across Graham County producing wind gusts ranging from 58 to 81 mph. The high winds lifted dust high into the air, which caused reduced visibilities as low as two hundred to one hundred yards in Hill City. These reduced visibilities caused one accident on Highway 283. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and plentiful moisture combined to produce a mix of wintery weather and heavy rain across south central Nebraska on November 9th into the 10th. Strong southerly wind gusts from the previous day (see November 8th Storm Data entry) continued into the early morning hours of November 9th, which allowed for copious amounts of atmospheric moisture to advect into the region ahead of a cold front. The cold front moved through the area from northwest to southeast during the morning and afternoon hours, with little in the way of precipitation. The front slowed down by late afternoon as surface low pressure organized over the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles, and the cold front eventually stalled out from central Kansas to central Iowa, just southeast of the NWS Hastings County Warning Area (CWA). This resulted in a sharp temperature gradient at the surface across the area, with cold air in the 20s across northwest portions of the CWA, 30s to low 40s across the far southeast CWA, and the surface freezing line from north central Kansas to east central Nebraska. Later during the evening hours, showers and even weak thunderstorms blossomed as moisture and weak instability interacted with the stalled cold front and shallow low level cold air mass. This set the stage for a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain across south central Nebraska during the evening hours of November 9th. Rain rates were impressive by November standards, and with surface temperatures below freezing, ice accretion began quickly. The greatest ice accretion occurred from around 8pm on the 9th until 2am on the 10th before mid level dry air was advected in from the southwest. The system was not done causing wintry weather across the area, however, as the surface and upper level low pressure ejected northeast from the southern High Plains into the Lower MO Valley and wrap around moisture brought a period of light to moderate snow during the morning hours of the 10, mainly after 4am. Several inches of snow fell across areas mainly north of Interstate 80, with the highest amounts of 4 to 6 inches observed in Greeley County. Only lingering light snow and flurries continued into the afternoon hours of the 10th.||Impacts from the ice were widespread from Webster and Nuckolls Counties northeast to Nance and Polk Counties, particularly in terms of tree damage, where ice accretion of at least one quarter of an inch was observed. Within the broader zone of ice damage, a smaller swath around 30-40 miles wide of more severe impacts appears to have occurred from Adams and Clay Counties northeast to portions of York and Polk Counties. This is where large tree limbs (10 to 15 inches in diameter) were snapped and where power outages were most common and long-lasting, some in excess of 24 hours (mainly rural areas). Also, some of the large tree limbs fell onto roadways and further complicated already hazardous travel conditions. A Cooperative Observer just northeast of Shelby, NE (in Polk County) reported ice accumulation as high as one half inch. School and business closures were numerous not only in the areas affected by ice, but also further north where snow was more prevalent. Meteorologically speaking, this event was impressive due to very high amounts of moisture, and even some instability, that overlapped with near or below freezing temperatures at the surface. Precipitable water values (PWATs) were as high as 1.0 to 1.2 inches, again, anomalously high for November. While this event was certainly towards the higher end of recent ice events, the area was fortunate it wasnt worse for several reasons: 1) Rain rates, while impressive, were actually too high for optimal and efficient ice accretion 2) surface temperatures were generally one to two degrees too warm for optimal ice accretion 3) Surface winds were relatively light and 4) duration of ice accretion was limited to around 6 hrs. We can say with relatively high confidence that if even one of the above factors was worse, this event couldve been much more severe. Finally, it's worth noting that for many, this was the most significant precipitation event in around two months, as many areas along and east of Highway 281 received 0.75 to 1 or more of moisture.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and freezing drizzle resulted in a coating of ice at least one-quarter inch thick. Travel was hazardous, and numerous tree limbs were downed. Power lines were also affected, causing power outages. A cooperative observer located 3 miles northeast of Shelby reported ice accumulation closer to one-half inch, with tree limbs as large as 15 inches in diameter brought down.
