EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms moved through north central and southeast Kansas during the overnight and morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Official NWS observation measurement.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported quarter sized hail at the location that fell for a duration of 20 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Caller reported quarter sized hail that broke a window at the residence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports received from trained spotters of various sized hail in Wheeler ranging from pea to quarter in size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Caller reported estimated 60-70 mph wind gusts associated with a strong thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter observed an estimated 60 mph wind gust associated with an approaching thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Non-thunderstorm high winds associated with a passing cold front occurred in southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours of November 14th, 2020. The maximum sustained wind speed recorded was 43 mph and the maximum wind gust speed recorded was 62 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds were seen across Dundy county based high winds observed in the surrounding counties. Event time and wind speed estimate were based on observations from these surrounding counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms moved through north central and southeast Kansas during the overnight and morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread tree and power line damage in a narrow corridor from Saint Paul to the Crawford County line. There was damage to an outbuilding noted as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms moved through north central and southeast Kansas during the overnight and morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of tree and power line damage in the county including Galesburg, Erie and Saint Paul.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported thunderstorm wind damage associated with an estimated 70 mph gust from the core of a strong thunderstorm. The wind snapped several 1.25-1.5 inch live tree branches from trees and peeled tin off the roof of an old granary building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KKSSAINT6 mesonet observed a 60 mph wind gust associated with the approaching core of a strong thunderstorm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off-duty NWS employee reported strong thunderstorm wind gusts increasing from 60 mph to 70 mph over a duration of 6 minutes. Pea size hail was also reported at the location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Caller reported estimated 50-60 mph wind gusts associated with the core of a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early season winter storm impacted the region on the 8th and 9th bringing in mixed precipitation and accumulating snowfall. In addition in the wake of the precipitation, hard freezing temperatures brought an end to the growing season with many locations dropping overnight temperatures into the middle 20s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer located in Harrison measured a total storm snowfall of 7.7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During November, 18 of the 24 counties in South Central Nebraska were completely-or-partially included in D2-or-worse drought, per weekly issuances of the U.S. Drought Monitor. For much of the western half of the area (especially west of a Greeley-Minden-Franklin line), November marked at least the fourth-consecutive month of below normal precipitation, prompting the return of D3 Extreme Drought to portions of South Central Nebraska for the first time since 2013. Meanwhile, for roughly the eastern half of the area, November precipitation trends were more encouraging as most places registered slightly wetter-than-normal for the month (totals commonly 1.50-2.00 inches). Of note, November finally broke a five-month streak of below normal precipitation at Hastings that had lasted from June-October. Although drought categories did not explicitly improve in the eastern half of the area, they at least remained status quo, stemming a gradual-worsening trend that had defined the preceding few months. ||Breaking things down in more detail and focusing on specific drought categories: Clearly the most newsworthy November note was the late-month introduction of D3 to all of of Furnas/Gosper counties, along with adjacent portions of Dawson/Phelps/Harlan/far southwestern Buffalo (total of six affected counties). Within much of this area, November precipitation totals were incredibly meager, including as little as 0.04 at Wilsonville and 0.07 south of Elwood. However, the introduction of D3 was ultimately driven by slightly-longer term precipitation deficits, as several official NWS stations in the D3 area endured one of their driest August-November stretches on record, including record-driest at Elwood 8S (1.47) and Canaday Steam Plant/Lexington 6SSE (1.07). Slightly east of the official D3 area, Minden also notched its driest-on-record Aug.-Nov. with only 2.30. In addition to the six counties included in D3 by month's end, all-or-some of 12 other counties west of the Highway 81 corridor remained in D2 Severe Drought throughout the month. Meanwhile, the rest of South Central Nebraska remained in (or was newly-assigned) D1 Moderate Drought during November. Temperature-wise, although not as big of a drought-factor as it would have been during the growing season, November was certainly a warm one with most local stations averaging 5-7 degrees F above normal (among the Top-10 warmest-on-record at many of them).

Of note, November finally broke a five-month streak of below normal precipitation at Hastings that had lasted from June-October. Although drought categories did not explicitly improve in the eastern half of the area, they at least remained status quo, stemming a gradual-worsening trend that had defined the preceding few months. ||Breaking things down in more detail and focusing on specific drought categories: Clearly the most newsworthy November note was the late-month introduction of D3 to all of of Furnas/Gosper counties, along with adjacent portions of Dawson/Phelps/Harlan/far southwestern Buffalo (total of six affected counties). Within much of this area, November precipitation totals were incredibly meager, including as little as 0.04 at Wilsonville and 0.07 south of Elwood. However, the introduction of D3 was ultimately driven by slightly-longer term precipitation deficits, as several official NWS stations in the D3 area endured one of their driest August-November stretches on record, including record-driest at Elwood 8S (1.47) and Canaday Steam Plant/Lexington 6SSE (1.07). Slightly east of the official D3 area, Minden also notched its driest-on-record Aug.-Nov. with only 2.30. In addition to the six counties included in D3 by month's end, all-or-some of 12 other counties west of the Highway 81 corridor remained in D2 Severe Drought throughout the month. Meanwhile, the rest of South Central Nebraska remained in (or was newly-assigned) D1 Moderate Drought during November. Temperature-wise, although not as big of a drought-factor as it would have been during the growing season, November was certainly a warm one with most local stations averaging 5-7 degrees F above normal (among the Top-10 warmest-on-record at many of them).

During November, 18 of the 24 counties in South Central Nebraska were completely-or-partially included in D2-or-worse drought, per weekly issuances of the U.S. Drought Monitor. For much of the western half of the area (especially west of a Greeley-Minden-Franklin line), November marked at least the fourth-consecutive month of below normal precipitation, prompting the return of D3 Extreme Drought to portions of South Central Nebraska for the first time since 2013. Meanwhile, for roughly the eastern half of the area, November precipitation trends were more encouraging as most places registered slightly wetter-than-normal for the month (totals commonly 1.50-2.00 inches). Of note, November finally broke a five-month streak of below normal precipitation at Hastings that had lasted from June-October. Isolated thunderstorms developed along the CO/KS border which traveled southeast during the afternoon hours. The thunderstorms yielded hail up to ping pong ball sized as well as a 64 mph wind gust due to a heat burst event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel sized hail reported at location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off-duty NWS employee reported a large maple tree limb roughly 10-12 inches in diameter snapped off the tree in a city park. At the estimated time of the branch snapping off, the KGLD ASOS station on north side of town measured a 62 mph gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The KGLD ASOS station recorded a 62 mph wind gusts with a duration of 3 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received via Facebook of a chimney blown off an old house. Wind gusts are estimated to be 80 mph and associated with an outflow boundary ahead of a linear cluster of thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple clusters of supercells developed in southwest Nebraska and moved south across the Nebraska-Kansas border. As the storms moved into northwest Kansas, they merged into one large cluster that produced strong damaging winds up to 70 mph from the Kansas-Nebraska border to Wichita County and up to quarter sized hail in Cheyenne County.

During the morning hours, multiple outflow boundaries moved across northwest Kansas. Several weak showers and thunderstorms formed south of I-70 along a few of the boundaries. Along another outflow boundary, high winds up to 62 mph were recorded in Sherman and Thomas counties. An increase of approximately ten degrees in temperature occurred within five minutes of the wind report due to the mixing of warmer temperatures above ground down to the surface along the boundaries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Kansas mesonet station recorded a wind gust of 62 mph. Five minutes prior to the wind observation, at 07:35 am MST, the station recorded a rise in temperature from 72 degrees to 82 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the morning hours, multiple outflow boundaries moved across northwest Kansas. Several weak showers and thunderstorms formed south of I-70 along a few of the boundaries. Along another outflow boundary, high winds up to 62 mph were recorded in Sherman and Thomas counties. An increase of approximately ten degrees in temperature occurred within five minutes of the wind report due to the mixing of warmer temperatures above ground down to the surface along the boundaries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KKSCOLBY28 mesonet station recorded a 58 mph wind gust associate with an outflow boundary moving across Logan and Thomas counties. Also observed with this station was an increase in temperature from 76 degrees at 10:24 am CST to 91 degrees at 10:54 am, which was followed by a steady decrease in temperature to 77 degrees at 11:34 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Wallace county producing strong winds ranging from 58 to 60 mph. The peak wind gust of 60 mph was observed by a mesonet near the town of Wallace.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Thomas County producing high winds sustained at 40 to 55 mph for one hour and fifteen minutes with gusts varying from 57 to 63 mph. Two separate mesonet stations, one near Brewster and another on the east side of Colby recorded a peak gust of 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought strong northwesterly wind gusts during the late afternoon on November 14th. A strong low pressure system across southern Canada forced a cold front through south central Nebraska during the late afternoon hours. Strong northwest wind gusts accompanied the passage of the front, particularly across the western third of the County Warning Area (CWA), where a few gusts of 55 to 65 mph were measured. There was no known damage or impacts from the high wind. The severe wind gusts were supported by intense pressure rises on the order of 4-5mb per 2 hours. The arrival time of the front during or just after peak mixing was also a contributing factor. Peak wind gusts further east were weaker, but still strong, at speeds of 50 to 55 mph, as far east as Highway 281. Peak wind gusts remained less than 50mph east of Highway 281 as the 2hr pressure rises decreased to 2-3 mb.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 63 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 1 mile north-northeast of Cozad.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensity as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to quarter sized hail, up to 74 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.1 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail from penny to quarter sized fell for a minimum duration of 3 minutes at the location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.

Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that developed into a line as it moved through northwest Kansas. The storms produced up to golf ball sized hail and wind gusts near 70 mph that produced brown out conditions and snapped numerous tree limbs in Logan, Thomas, Gove, and Sheridan counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported hail ranging from quarters to golf ball in size covering the ground enough to appear white. At a nearby residence, hail ranging from quarters to golf ball in size broke several windows.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Evening thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front in Northwestern Kansas. These thunderstorms yielded damaging wind gusts up to 100 mph and pea size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station at location recorded a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust at start time and a 58 mph thunderstorm wind gust at end time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Evening thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front in Northwestern Kansas. These thunderstorms yielded damaging wind gusts up to 100 mph and pea size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KHLC ASOS recorded 61 mph thunderstorm wind gusts at start and end times at location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving eastward through southwestern Nebraska. These thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts with speeds up to 74 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KMCK ASOS reported a 63 mph wind gust at location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving eastward through southwestern Nebraska. These thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts with speeds up to 74 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a tree limb down that was roughly 3 car lengths in length. Speed estimated based on damage indicator.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Precipitation continued well-below normal across northeast Nebraska, varying from 25 to 50 percent of normal. Temperatures were mainly near to slightly below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) started the month with continued very warm and dry conditions. Drought conditions were alleviated somewhat by mid-month by rainfall which brought 1.90 inches at Emerson and 1.60 inches at Sioux City between September 8-12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong gradient winds ahead of a cold front produced very gusty conditions across the central and northern sections of the state.  A 60 mph wind gust was reported at Salina and Hutchinson Municipal Airport.  A wind gust to 58 mph was noted at the Russell Municipal Airport, 55 mph at Kingman, 53 mph at both Strother Field in Winfield and Wichita. A 52 mph wind gust occurred near Canton and a 51 mph gust was reported near New Cambria.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Official NWS measurement.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across Kansas producing strong winds at many locations.  The strongest was recorded at Russell with a gust of 58 mph.  Other wind gusts were 51 mph near Canton and McPherson, 49 mph at Hutchinson and Jabara airports, and 48 mph at Great Bend, Kingman, and Ellsworth.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Official NWS measurement at Russell Municipal Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Citizen observed an estimated wind gust of 60 mph in the core of a thundestorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds continued to gust for 29 minutes after the initial 88 mph gust at 8:09 pm CDT with a measured gust of 60 mph at 8:38 pm CDT.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: As a strong cold front moved southeast across Norton County, dirt was lifted in the air. The blowing dust caused reduced visibilities from fifty to ten yards near the town of Norton. The Norton AWOS station has missing observations during this time and nearby stations are measuring near zero winds, so the actual wind speeds to cause the blowing dust is unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A supercell in an environment full of moisture and wind shear produced hail up to golf ball sized in Wichita County near Leoti.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff and citizens on social media reported various sized hail from quarter to half dollar falling in the town of Leoti.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed along the dry line in central Colorado increasing in coverage as they moved east. The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas. The storms produced up to 79 mph wind gusts in Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties. The 79 mph gust in Red Willow County caused snapped a power pole and downed various sized of tree limbs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported tree limbs of various sizes down along with a snapped power pole in northern McCook. The damage occurred near the time of a measured 79 mph wind gust at the McCook ASOS station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported three wooden power poles down due to strong wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms developed in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon and evening hours of July 29th. These thunderstorms produced hail up to half dollar size along with damaging wind gusts up to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of quarter to half dollar size hail received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported numerous live tree limbs and power lines down causing power outages. Four tank batteries for oil were blown over and an additional oil battery south of Hill City caught on fire. A power pole was also knocked down. The Hill City ASOS observed a 93 mph wind gust at the time the damage occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought status for these two counties improved slightly by the end of the month due to heavy rainfall occurring.  The higher rainfall amounts occurred over the eastern part of these counties.  Precipitation for the month ranged from 1.50 to 5.11, which was 1.43 below normal to 2.29 above normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wichita County improved from D2 over the southwest half of the county and D1 elsewhere, to all of the county being in D1 by the end of the month.  Rainfall for the month ranged from 2.48 to 5.11.  This was roughly 2.29 above normal.

During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving eastward through northwestern Kansas. Thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts including a downburst event near St. Francis, KS producing damaging wind gusts up to 81 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station reported a wind gust of 80 mph at location at start time. Public report received at end time of tree blown down and car window broken due to thunderstorm wind gust at location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving eastward through northwestern Kansas. Thunderstorms produced strong wind gusts including a downburst event near St. Francis, KS producing damaging wind gusts up to 81 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received of roof damage by a thunderstorm wind gust. Speed based on damage indicator and time based on nearby Mesonet station reports and radar imagery.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An elevated thunderstorm developed on the combined boundary of a cold front and outflow from earlier night convection. A strong updraft congealed and resulted in spotty large hail from northeast Nebraska into northwest Iowa.

A round of severe thunderstorms moved west to east across south central and southeast Kansas in the evening hours of November 24th. There were reports of 60 mph winds in multiple locations as well as quarter to ping pong ball sized hail in few spots.

A round of severe thunderstorms moved west to east across south central and southeast Kansas in the evening hours of November 24th. There were reports of 60 mph winds in multiple locations as well as quarter to ping pong ball sized hail in few spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground and was accompanied by 60 mph winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was accompanied by 60 mph winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With continued dry conditions in September, severe and extreme drought conditions expanded across the eastern Nebraska Panhandle and portions of the western Sandhills and southwestern Nebraska in September. Extreme drought conditions expanded into the western third of Garden and extreme southwestern portions of Sheridan and extreme northwestern portions of Deuel county by the end of September. East of this area to a line from Gordon, to Arthur, to North Platte and Maywood, severe drought conditions had developed by the end of month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of September, severe drought (D2) conditions, expanded into all of Perkins County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms developed in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon and evening hours of July 29th. These thunderstorms produced hail up to half dollar size along with damaging wind gusts up to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received via social media of quarter to half dollar size hail. Hail had covered the ground white.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received of nickle size hail at location.

Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station CW6099 measured a 59 mph wind gust associated with thunderstorm outflow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet measured a 62 mph wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of severe thunderstorms moved west to east across south central and southeast Kansas in the evening hours of November 24th. There were reports of 60 mph winds in multiple locations as well as quarter to ping pong ball sized hail in few spots.

A round of severe thunderstorms moved west to east across south central and southeast Kansas in the evening hours of November 24th. There were reports of 60 mph winds in multiple locations as well as quarter to ping pong ball sized hail in few spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were downed due to high winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: AccuWeather meteorologist measured 59 mph at the intersection of Central and West streets.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were accompanied by quarter sized hail which covered the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of severe thunderstorms moved west to east across south central and southeast Kansas in the evening hours of November 24th. There were reports of 60 mph winds in multiple locations as well as quarter to ping pong ball sized hail in few spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was accompanied by half dollar sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Portions of north central and south central Kansas received snow in the wee hours of the morning with a range from an inch to over five inches; this was on the back side of a system that had brought severe thunderstorms during the evening of the 24th. The highest value was reported in Ellsworth County near Lorraine.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of 5.5 inches of snow fell one mile south of Lorraine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although most of South Central Nebraska experienced a dry August-September, September marked the fourth consecutive month of below normal rainfall within a relatively-focused zone through the heart of the 24-county area. As a result, the U.S. Drought Monitor gradually expanded the coverage of D2 Severe Drought over the course of the month. As September opened, D2 drought was already assigned to much of Kearney/Adams counties, and adjacent smaller portions of Buffalo, Hall and Clay counties. On the 8th, D2 expanded slightly to also include small portions of Phelps, Franklin and Webster counties. Finally, one more small expansion of D2 on the 22nd brought northeastern Harlan County into the mix as well, making for a total of nine counties at least partially included in Severe Drought for at least some portion of the month. Outside of the worst-off D2 area, both D1 Moderate Drought and D0 Abnormally Dry also expanded across much of South Central Nebraska during September. Of all 24 local counties, only the majority of Thayer County managed to remain void of all drought categories (including D0) through the month. ||Digging deeper into September rainfall, although the month was not as acutely dry as August, the majority of the area was again below-average, with most places tallying between 30-80 percent of normal. In general, the overall-driest official NWS totals focused within northern/western counties, including 0.57 at Ord airport, 0.66 eight miles south of Elwood and 0.67 at Miller. On the opposite end of the spectrum, parts of Thayer County featured the only legitimate above normal amounts in South Central Nebraska, including as much as 3.45 at Hebron. Over the longer-term four-month period from June-September, some of the driest portions of the area only received 4-6 of rain (generally 35-45 percent of normal). This included only 4.92 at Minden (2nd-driest on record), 4.97 at Kearney airport (5th-driest), 5.58 in St. Paul (4th-driest) and 5.66 at Hastings airport (outright-driest). Fortunately, hot temperatures were not a major factor contributing to drought stress for the majority of September, as most of the area observed monthly departures from near-normal to 2 degrees cooler-than-normal. However, a notable exception was the week of the 20th-26th, during which every day saw highs into at least the 80s (and even a few 90s). Although there were no widespread/major drought impacts noted within South Central Nebraska during September, pastures and dryland crops exhibited continued stress as the growing season drew to a close, and some area rivers/streams reported below normal stream flows (including the Little Blue River).

Strong winds across much of the area. A couple of locations gusted to speeds right around 50 mph.  Many other locations in central and south-central KS experienced wind gusts between 40 to 45 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Official measuring equipment recorded the gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds across much of the area. A couple of locations gusted to speeds right around 50 mph.  Many other locations in central and south-central KS experienced wind gusts between 40 to 45 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Official measuring equipment recorded the gusts at multiple locations across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of high atmospheric moisture, and a nearly stationary south    |to north orientated boundary, and southwest winds, generated several rounds of    |showers/embedded storms on September 8th, 2020.  The heavy rainfall produced some flooding across southeast Kansas with 2 to 5 inches of rainfall reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding occurred in Coffeyville, Kansas where rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches were reports. At least one vehicle stalled in the water from the flooding.  The 24-hour rainfall report i2 miles east of Coffeyville was 3.41 inches and the amount recorded at the airport was 2.52 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of high atmospheric moisture, and a nearly stationary south    |to north orientated boundary, and southwest winds, generated several rounds of    |showers/embedded storms on September 8th, 2020.  The heavy rainfall produced some flooding across southeast Kansas with 2 to 5 inches of rainfall reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement dispatch reported flooded roads in the county. the most notable flooding occurred at the Highway 59 and Highway 160 intersection south of Parsons, Kansas. The 24-hour rainfall report in Altamont was 4.8 inches. This was the highest value recorded for the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms developed in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon and evening hours of July 29th. These thunderstorms produced hail up to half dollar size along with damaging wind gusts up to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station reported a 65 mph thunderstorm wind gust at location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.

Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Citizen reported quarter sized hail that stripped corn crop of all its leaves.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Citizen reported hail ranging from dime to quarter in size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed along the dry line in central Colorado increasing in coverage as they moved east. The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas. The storms produced up to 79 mph wind gusts in Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties. The 79 mph gust in Red Willow County caused snapped a power pole and downed various sized of tree limbs.

Lift associated with a jet streak across southern North Dakota interacted with an unstable and weakly capped environment with 30 to 40 knots of deep-layer shear to produce a couple of smaller clusters of thunderstorms with large hail and damaging wind during the evening and overnight which progressed east and southeast across southeast South Dakota into northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail accompanied by estimated wind gusts up to 50 mph. Crop damage is an estimate from insured losses. Information provided by the United States Department of Agriculture.

During the month the drought status for Greeley and Wallace counties remained unchanged.  The south half of Wallace County was in D2 Severe Drought.  Greeley County had D2 Severe Drought in the east half, with D3 Extreme Drought over the west half of the county.  Monthly precipitation ranged from 0.5 to 1 for both counties, which is up to 1 below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation for the month ranged from 0.5 to 1.  This was up to 0.5 below normal for the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning of the 9th, light snow developed over Northwest Kansas. Snowfall amounts were less than an inch across Cheyenne and Sherman counties.  The snow changed to rain during the morning before ending. This snow event broke the record for the earliest snowfall of the season with the prior records being the 20th or 21st of September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on snowfall reports from surrounding counties, believe that snowfall occurred in Cheyenne County even though there are no reports of snow.  Any snow reports would be less than an inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning of the 9th, light snow developed over Northwest Kansas. Snowfall amounts were less than an inch across Cheyenne and Sherman counties.  The snow changed to rain during the morning before ending. This snow event broke the record for the earliest snowfall of the season with the prior records being the 20th or 21st of September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall reports across the county were less than an inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Near normal to below normal precipitation amounts occurred for Northwest Kansas during November. Precipitation amounts ranged from 0-0.50. Normal precipitation amounts for November range from 0.50-1. The D2 Severe Drought level expanded slightly further east. However the D3 Extreme Drought expanded east to include most of Northwest Kansas by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed precipitation for the month ranged from 0-0.10, which was 0.5-1 below normal. Normal precipitation amounts are 0.50-1. Key impacts: vegetation more favorable for rapid fire growth, little to no soil moisture, the ground is more favorable for blowing dust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Observed precipitation for the month ranged from 0-0.25, which was 0.5-1 below normal. Normal precipitation amounts are 0.50-1.   The continued below normal precipitation caused D2 Severe Drought level to occur for Sheridan County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county entered D2 Severe Drought.  Key impacts: vegetation more favorable for rapid fire growth, little to no soil moisture, the ground is more favorable for blowing dust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms developed along the dry line in central Colorado increasing in coverage as they moved east. The cells merged into clusters along a line as they entered southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas. The storms produced up to 79 mph wind gusts in Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties. The 79 mph gust in Red Willow County caused snapped a power pole and downed various sized of tree limbs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports received from Dundy County dispatch and the public for estimated wind gusts of 60 mph associated with a strong thunderstorm.

Isolated showers and thunderstorms developed during the evening hours in eastern Colorado which moved eastward into northwest Kansas. As the storms moved across the Thomas County, an estimated 70 mph wind gust blew over two semi trucks 4 miles apart on I-70.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thomas County reported a semi truck blown over at mile marker 60 on I-70 due to strong winds. No other vehicles were impacted. No injuries to driver or other vehicles involved.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lift associated with a jet streak across southern North Dakota interacted with an unstable and weakly capped environment with 30 to 40 knots of deep-layer shear to produce a couple of smaller clusters of thunderstorms with large hail and damaging wind during the evening and overnight which progressed east and southeast across southeast South Dakota into northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds which took down moderate-sized branches were accompanied by pea sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lift associated with a jet streak across southern North Dakota interacted with an unstable and weakly capped environment with 30 to 40 knots of deep-layer shear to produce a couple of smaller clusters of thunderstorms with large hail and damaging wind during the evening and overnight which progressed east and southeast across southeast South Dakota into northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust of 67 mph was measured by a personal weather station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lift associated with a jet streak across southern North Dakota interacted with an unstable and weakly capped environment with 30 to 40 knots of deep-layer shear to produce a couple of smaller clusters of thunderstorms with large hail and damaging wind during the evening and overnight which progressed east and southeast across southeast South Dakota into northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 65 mph were measured by a personal weather station. Dime-size hail accompanied the strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought status for these two counties improved slightly by the end of the month due to heavy rainfall occurring.  The higher rainfall amounts occurred over the eastern part of these counties.  Precipitation for the month ranged from 1.50 to 5.11, which was 1.43 below normal to 2.29 above normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Greeley County changed from D3 in the southwest part of the county to D3 across the western half with D2 elsewhere, to all of the county being in D2 Drought by the end of the month.  Precipitation for the month ranged from 1.50 to 4.29.  The precipitation ranged from 1.43 below normal to 1.52 above normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of high atmospheric moisture, and a nearly stationary south    |to north orientated boundary, and southwest winds, generated several rounds of    |showers/embedded storms on September 8th, 2020.  The heavy rainfall produced some flooding across southeast Kansas with 2 to 5 inches of rainfall reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 24-hour rainfall amount reported was 4.5 inches. This report was received via Facebook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that developed into a line as it moved through northwest Kansas. The storms produced up to golf ball sized hail and wind gusts near 70 mph that produced brown out conditions and snapped numerous tree limbs in Logan, Thomas, Gove, and Sheridan counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported patches of blowing dust with brown out conditions just north of Oakley due to the leading edge of an outflow boundary producing strong wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved south into Northwest Kansas during the evening.  Wind gusts up to 60 MPH were recorded as the storms moved through, with the strongest gust occurring near St. Francis.  Hail up to two inches in diameter fell with these storms, with the largest hail reported near Herndon.  As the storms moved south their intensity declined.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter estimated the wind gusts to be 50-60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in southwestern Nebraska and traveled south-southeast toward the NE/KS border. Thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that caused damage to trees in Bartley, NE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported numerous tree limbs down due to straight line winds at location. Spotter also reported pea to dime size hail. Speed estimated by storm damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening a line of thunderstorms moved south into Southwest Nebraska.  As the storms moved through they produced hail up to ping-pong ball size, estimated wind gusts up to 60 MPH, and started an oil supply tank on fire near Trenton from a lightning strike.  Part of this line of storms moved slow enough to cause flash flooding near Parks in Rock Creek, washing part of the road and small bridge out.
Evening thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front in Northwestern Kansas. These thunderstorms yielded damaging wind gusts up to 100 mph and pea size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received of 5 power poles broken on the NW side of town due to thunderstorm wind gusts. Time is radar estimated and estimated wind gust speed is based on storm damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Evening thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front in Northwestern Kansas. These thunderstorms yielded damaging wind gusts up to 100 mph and pea size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station recorded a 63 mph thunderstorm wind gust at location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Evening thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front in Northwestern Kansas. These thunderstorms yielded damaging wind gusts up to 100 mph and pea size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station recorded a 67 mph thunderstorm wind gust at location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Evening thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front in Northwestern Kansas. These thunderstorms yielded damaging wind gusts up to 100 mph and pea size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received via social media of a personal weather station recording a peak wind gust of 67 mph. Time is radar estimated. Report also mentioned power lines down on the ground nearby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail fell for a duration of 5 minutes at the location. The hail and severe wind damaged two windows at the residence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS station KGLD measured a 61 mph wind gust from the core of a thunderstorm passing over the site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds affected portions of south central Nebraska during the late morning and early afternoon hours on Sunday, November 8th. Peak wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph were observed by airport ASOS/AWOS stations as well as various mesonet stations between roughly 9am and 2pm CST. The primary areas affected were east of Highway 183. No significant damage was reported as a result of these strong winds.||The strong southerly winds occurred within a broad warm sector of an intense low pressure system tracking from the northern Rockies into the northern Plains. An anomalously strong low level jet developed over the Central Plains during the night of November 7th into the early morning hours of November 8th, in response to an increasing pressure gradient, and peaked at a magnitude of 60 to 70kt. Boundary layer mixing depth increased after sunrise on the morning of November 8th and managed to tap into the bottom of this low level jet, with the result being several hours of severe southerly synoptic winds being mixed down to the surface.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH, based on neighboring observations, occurred during the late morning through early afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A supercell in an environment full of moisture and wind shear produced hail up to golf ball sized in Wichita County near Leoti.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms became stationary over Dundy County during the evening of the 23rd.  The storm activity spread to the south and west through the rest of the 23rd into the 24th before ending from west to east.  When the rainfall ended, over nine inches of rain had occurred roughly along CR 709, with lesser amounts to the north and south.  Roads were washed out in many places, and the AM Track train was stranded at Haigler due to the tracks being washed out somewhere between Haigler and Parks.  Highway 34 was closed from Benkelman to Highway 385 in Yuma County Colorado due to flooding. The Republican River at Benkelman reached a peak height of almost nine and a half feet. |The flood waters extended east into Hitchcock County, where the river gauge at Stratton measured a stage just below the record stage of 11 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from prolonged heavy rainfall in Dundy County caused the Republican River to surpass flood stage in the western part of Hitchcock County, from the county line to Stratton. The flood waters did not cause any damage to buildings, roads, or bridges along the river channel. In addition, the river stage at Stratton was just under 11 feet, which is just below the record stage for the site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of stationary thunderstorms producing heavy rainfall over Dundy County Nebraska expanded south into Cheyenne County.  Rainfall amounts of over eight inches fell, with the highest amounts of rain occurring near the Nebraska border.  Multiple roads had sections washed out, some as deep as 10 ft or so.  Some farms in the northern part of the county were stranded due to all the roads leading out being washed out.  Water in the Republican River was running so fast and deep that trees were snapping.  One bridge in the county was damaged and another was washed out from the flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the road damage from flooding occurred north of CR S, with the damage becoming more severe toward the Nebraska border.  One bridge was partially damaged east of Highway 27 near CR Z.  Another bridge was washed out at River Road and RS 115.  A culvert was washed out on CR 19 between CR AA and CR BB.  Near CR BB and CR 17 a barb wire fence was washed onto the road.  Near CR 15 and CR V flood waters had washed a large tree onto the road.  Near CR 2 the Republican River was out of its banks.  Hackberry Creek was also flooding where it joined with the Republican River.  Damage from the flooding is unknown due to the unknown number of sections of road washed out and the unknown acres of crop land flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Live tree 1 foot in diameter and 25 feet long knocked down by winds measured a few miles east at 65 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Norton County producing high winds. At the time of frontal passage, many mesonet stations and the AWOS have inaccurate or missing observations. The first observation reported by the Norton AWOS was at 7:55 pm CDT with a gust of 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southerly winds affected portions of south central Nebraska during the late morning and early afternoon hours on Sunday, November 8th. Peak wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph were observed by airport ASOS/AWOS stations as well as various mesonet stations between roughly 9am and 2pm CST. The primary areas affected were east of Highway 183. No significant damage was reported as a result of these strong winds.||The strong southerly winds occurred within a broad warm sector of an intense low pressure system tracking from the northern Rockies into the northern Plains. An anomalously strong low level jet developed over the Central Plains during the night of November 7th into the early morning hours of November 8th, in response to an increasing pressure gradient, and peaked at a magnitude of 60 to 70kt. Boundary layer mixing depth increased after sunrise on the morning of November 8th and managed to tap into the bottom of this low level jet, with the result being several hours of severe southerly synoptic winds being mixed down to the surface.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH, based on neighboring observations, occurred during the late morning through early afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon, isolated thunderstorms developed and moved south along multiple outlfow boundaries in northwest Kansas. As a storm moved through Wallace County, it strengthened to produce up to penny sized hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter observed dime to penny sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms became stationary over Dundy County during the evening of the 23rd.  The storm activity spread to the south and west through the rest of the 23rd into the 24th before ending from west to east.  When the rainfall ended, over nine inches of rain had occurred roughly along CR 709, with lesser amounts to the north and south.  Roads were washed out in many places, and the AM Track train was stranded at Haigler due to the tracks being washed out somewhere between Haigler and Parks.  Highway 34 was closed from Benkelman to Highway 385 in Yuma County Colorado due to flooding. The Republican River at Benkelman reached a peak height of almost nine and a half feet. |The flood waters extended east into Hitchcock County, where the river gauge at Stratton measured a stage just below the record stage of 11 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from prolonged heavy rainfall in Dundy County caused the Republican River to surpass flood stage in the western part of Hitchcock County, from the county line to Stratton.  The flood waters did not cause any damage to buildings, roads, or bridges along the river channel.  In addition, the river stage at Stratton was just under 11 feet, which is just below the record stage for the site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening a line of thunderstorms moved south into Southwest Nebraska.  As the storms moved through they produced hail up to ping-pong ball size, estimated wind gusts up to 60 MPH, and started an oil supply tank on fire near Trenton from a lightning strike.  Part of this line of storms moved slow enough to cause flash flooding near Parks in Rock Creek, washing part of the road and small bridge out.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 50-60 MPH occurred with hail up to quarter size.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 60 MPH were estimated at this location.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small bridge in the Rock Creek channel near Rock Creek Lake, and part of a road, were washed away due to the prolonged rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported a 5 inch diameter tree limb blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mature pine tree was reported to be blown over.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Citizen reported two double pane windows on the west side of a single family residence were blown out due to strong winds and 1 inch hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms initiated along a dry line in central Colorado moving east and forming a cluster of supercells that moved through Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties along the Kansas and Nebraska border. The storms produced up to tennis ball sized hail and wind gusts up to 91 mph that blew out windows and garage doors, caused power poles to lean, power outages, and blew down trees along with various sizes of branches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported power outages in Stratton, Culbertson, Trenton, and Palisade.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Supercell thunderstorms formed over the Colorado High Plains increasing in coverage to form a line and intensified as they moved east into Kansas and Nebraska. In Kansas, the storms produced up to ping pong ball sized hail, up to 93 mph wind gusts, and up to 1.5 inches of rain. During the event, several power poles were reported down in Cheyenne, Logan, Thomas, and Graham counties. Five oil tank batteries in Graham County and a central pivot irrigation system in Thomas County were also damaged.

A cluster of thunderstorms became stationary over Dundy County during the evening of the 23rd.  The storm activity spread to the south and west through the rest of the 23rd into the 24th before ending from west to east.  When the rainfall ended, over nine inches of rain had occurred roughly along CR 709, with lesser amounts to the north and south.  Roads were washed out in many places, and the AM Track train was stranded at Haigler due to the tracks being washed out somewhere between Haigler and Parks.  Highway 34 was closed from Benkelman to Highway 385 in Yuma County Colorado due to flooding. The Republican River at Benkelman reached a peak height of almost nine and a half feet. |The flood waters extended east into Hitchcock County, where the river gauge at Stratton measured a stage just below the record stage of 11 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads across the flooded part of the county were washed out.  Notable road closures include Highway 34 closed from Benkelman to Highway 385 at Wray, River Road closed from Parks to Doane, and Avenue 328 closed due to four feet of water over the road.  The flood waters also washed out part of the railroad between Parks and Haigler, stranding the train in Haigler.  The Republican River at Benkelman reached a peak height of almost nine and a half feet.  The record stage height is just over 13 feet.||Total damage for this event (both flash flood and flood) totaled between $100,000 and $108,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small line of thunderstorms developed over northwest Kansas and moved north into southwest Nebraska. The storms produced up to 60 mph wind gusts and quarter sized hail in Rawlins County.
A small line of thunderstorms developed over northwest Kansas and moved north into southwest Nebraska. The storms produced up to 60 mph wind gusts and quarter sized hail in Rawlins County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports received of pea to quarter sized hail in McDonald. A picture was submitted via social media of a large accumulation of hail against a structure. The hail fell for an approximate duration of five minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small line of thunderstorms developed over northwest Kansas and moved north into southwest Nebraska. The storms produced up to 60 mph wind gusts and quarter sized hail in Rawlins County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported an estimated 60 mph wind gust associated with a strong thunderstorm over the town of McDonald.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms developed and produced large hail and strong wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter estimated wind at about 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the area bringing with it light snow fall and winds gusting up to 60 mph. Blizzard conditions were observed much of the area. Many other locations not in the blizzard warning, experience near blizzard conditions and had impacts warranting a Winter Storm warning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Personal weather station measured peak wind of 50 mph. Light snow combined with strong winds led to a reduction of visibility and winter weather impacts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: AWOS measured a peak wind gust of 56 mph and visibilities of 0.25 miles. Light snow combined with strong winds led to a reduction of visibility and winter weather impacts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chadron Municipal Airport ASOS station KCDR reported wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although it only impacted a small percentage of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, the large and intense supercell storm that marched south-southwestward for over 90 miles through several eastern counties on this Friday afternoon/early evening was likely the local area's most noteworthy individual storm of the 2020 convective season. In addition to dropping three fairly brief EF-0 tornadoes in southeastern Hamilton and northeastern Clay counties, its main calling card was large hail, with several reports of golf ball to slightly larger than baseball size stones in Clay/Nuckolls counties, and smaller hail to around quarter size as far north as Osceola. Interestingly, damaging winds were not a major player, with no ground-truth gusts in excess of 50 MPH. Focusing on specific storm reports, and starting with the three EF-0 tornadoes, they all occurred between 5-6 p.m. CDT, touching down briefly along a roughly 15-mile long corridor from near Interstate 80 a few miles south of Hampton, down to the Saronville area. Per storm surveys, the first two tornadoes were each on the ground for roughly 2 miles. While the majority of minor damage was confined to crops and trees, a lean-to shed was destroyed and a pivot overturned. As for the hail, the largest reported was 3 diameter between Clay Center and Harvard, but towns including Sutton and Nelson endured stones to at least tennis ball size. Flooding was not much of an issue, as the storm was progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch. ||Breaking down the meteorological background and event timing, this was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for South Central Nebraska, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C providing a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the afternoon. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding formidable mixed-layer CAPE around 4000 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection. As for what actually transpired, the main show was preceded by a broken line of non-severe, likely elevated storms that passed primarily through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 between 12:30-3:30 p.m. CDT. About the time this innocuous early afternoon activity was departing the local area to the southeast, a broken line of true, surface-based storms got going along the front in northeast Nebraska, with the southwestern-most cell building down into the far northeast corner of South Central Nebraska (eastern Nance/northeast Merrick/northern Polk counties) between 3-4 p.m. CDT. Within an hour thereafter, this tail end Charlie storm rapidly grew into a full-blown supercell over Polk/northern York counties, producing its first marginally-severe hail reports. During the following two hours (5-7 p.m. CDT), the storm anchored itself firmly to the surface front, with new updraft generation along its western edge promoting more of a southwestward propagation and causing it to grow larger in both intensity/size, becoming more of a supercell cluster. It was during this time that the brief tornadoes occurred along the storm's far western flank, likely driven by pronounced low-level vorticity stretching along the surface front. While the sporadic tornado touchdowns were brief, the storm continued to be a prolific hail-producer as it gradually exited the local area out of Nuckolls County into northern Kansas between 7-8 p.m. CDT, ending all South Central Nebraska convection for the night.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite near normal precipitation occurring in Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties, the D3 Extreme Drought status continued.  Precipitation amounts ranged from 0.25 to 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation across the county ranged from 0.50 to 1.  Normal precipitation ranged from 0.25 to 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite near normal precipitation occurring in Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties, the D3 Extreme Drought status continued.  Precipitation amounts ranged from 0.25 to 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation across the county ranged from 0.25 to 1.  Normal precipitation ranged from 0.25 to 0.50.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite near normal precipitation occurring in Dundy, Hitchcock, and Red Willow counties, the D3 Extreme Drought status continued.  Precipitation amounts ranged from 0.25 to 1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation across the county ranged from 0.25 to 0.50.  Normal precipitation ranged from 0.25 to 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening, and through following morning, multiple bands of moderate to heavy snowfall rates moved north over parts of Southwest Nebraska. Up to six inches of snow was reported from these bands in Dundy County, with a small portion extending into western Hitchcock County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the county ranged from a couple inches in the northwest corner to six inches in the Benkelman area.  Key words:  heavy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On this late Sunday afternoon and evening, several scattered, strong to severe storms advanced southward across various portions of South Central Nebraska, prompting many accounts of large hail and a few damaging wind gusts. While most hail was in the quarter to golf ball size range, larger stones of 2-3 diameter fell in the Chapman and Marquette areas of Merrick/Hamilton counties. Ping pong to golf ball size hail occurred in or near the following communities/locations: Fullerton, Amherst, Orleans, Harlan County Lake, Naponee and Deweese. In the Tri Cities, only Grand Island saw severe weather, as two rounds of quarter to half dollar size hail moved through, one mainly affecting the north side of town (including the airport) around 6 p.m. CDT, and another about an hour later that clipped more of the city. As for thunderstorm winds, the vast majority of gusts captured by area sensors were non-severe (generally 40-50 MPH), but there were two reports estimated around 60 MPH, one near Hampton and another at Hebron, where a few large trees were downed and a store front sustained minor damage. Given fairly progressive storm motions, rainfall totals in most affected areas were less than 1 inch during the afternoon/evening. However, combined with localized heavy rain that fell during a separate round of early morning/non-severe activity, portions of mainly eastern Clay County registered over 3 for the day (including NWS coop observer total of 3.33 six miles east-southeast of Clay Center). As a result, the later-day storms prompted some isolated flash flooding, as School Creek overtopped the paved spur road south of Saronville. ||This event was characterized by truly scattered, hit-or-miss convection, as afternoon heating and subtle convergence along/ahead of a weak cold front sagging southward into the region prompted several strong to severe storms, mainly in the form of multicells/multicell clusters, but also a few brief supercells. Nearly every county in the 24-county area observed at least a touch of thunderstorm activity. That being said, the majority of ground-truth reports concentrated in two primary areas: 1) parts of Hall/Hamilton/Merrick counties...2) a swath from eastern Furnas to far southwestern Franklin counties. A few of the first severe storms of the event flared up over Furnas/Buffalo counties between 430-530 p.m. CDT, and the final severe storm of the evening was centered over the Nuckolls County area before weakening around 9 p.m. CDT. Thereafter, a smattering of strong storms lingered within counties south of Interstate 80 through around 10:30 pm. CDT before all convection ended for the night. In total, 19 Severe Thunderstorm Warnings were issued within South Central Nebraska over the course of over four hours. Digging deeper into the meteorological setup, it's worth noting that this event exceeded forecast expectations, especially in terms of the number of severe storms. This was due in part to greater-than-expected convective instability, as afternoon surface dewpoints soared into the upper 60s-low 70 F,  promoting significant mixed-layer CAPE of at least 3000-4000 J/kg. In tandem with deep layer wind shear around 35 knots, this CAPE/shear combo proved plenty sufficient for robust convection. In the mid-upper levels, a pronounced north-northwest flow regime resided over the Central Plains, within the interface between a stout western United States ridge and a broad eastern trough.

Arguably the most noteworthy individual thunderstorm of the 2020 convective season within this six-county North Central Kansas area rolled southward across portions of Jewell, Mitchell and mainly eastern Osborne counties on this Friday evening, highlighted by several reports of large to very large hail. Of the counties impacted by this supercell, Jewell was hardest-hit, as copious amounts of tennis ball to softball size hail stones crashed down onto areas in and near the communities of Mankato and Jewell, causing extensive damage to homes, vehicles and area crops. The hail size toned down somewhat farther south into Mitchell and Osborne counties, where limited reports included ping pong ball size stones in Cawker City and golf ball size south of Osborne. Although damaging winds were not a major player during this event, several mesonets clocked gusts of at least 40-50 MPH, and a Kansas Mesonet site near Jewell reached severe-criteria with 65 MPH. Flooding was not much of an issue, with convection staying progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch.||Breaking down event timing and meteorological background, this giant storm invaded northern Jewell County between 7-8 pm. CDT, having already propagated south-southwestward for roughly 90 miles since its inception in east central Nebraska about three hours prior. As it drifted southward into Mitchell County between 8-9 p.m. CDT it started merging with a much smaller, separate storm that had flared up over central Osborne County. Finally, between 9-10 p.m. CDT, the now-merged supercell cluster continued southward while exiting the local area into central Kansas, ending all local storms for the night. This was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for North Central Kansas, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C promoting a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the evening. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding impressive mixed-layer CAPE up to around 4500 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 65 MPH was measured by a Kansas Mesonet site located 3 miles west-northwest of Jewell.

The hail size toned down somewhat farther south into Mitchell and Osborne counties, where limited reports included ping pong ball size stones in Cawker City and golf ball size south of Osborne. Although damaging winds were not a major player during this event, several mesonets clocked gusts of at least 40-50 MPH, and a Kansas Mesonet site near Jewell reached severe-criteria with 65 MPH. Flooding was not much of an issue, with convection staying progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch.||Breaking down event timing and meteorological background, this giant storm invaded northern Jewell County between 7-8 pm. CDT, having already propagated south-southwestward for roughly 90 miles since its inception in east central Nebraska about three hours prior. As it drifted southward into Mitchell County between 8-9 p.m. CDT it started merging with a much smaller, separate storm that had flared up over central Osborne County. Finally, between 9-10 p.m. CDT, the now-merged supercell cluster continued southward while exiting the local area into central Kansas, ending all local storms for the night. This was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for North Central Kansas, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C promoting a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the evening. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding impressive mixed-layer CAPE up to around 4500 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection.

A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Rawlins County producing strong to high wind gusts ranging from 40 mph to 64 mph. The high winds lifted dirt into the air, which reduced visibility to less than four blocks in the town of Atwood.

These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage.
