No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Graham County producing high winds sustained at 40 to 69 mph with gusts ranging from 58 to 81 mph. The Hill City ASOS station recorded a 66 mph peak gust. A mesonet station northeast of Bogue recorded a peak gust of 81 mph. During the event, Graham County Dispatch reported the high winds downed power lines which sparked a few sporadic fires around the county and cut power to the ASOS station after the 7:40 pm CDT observation. A more notable fire on south and southeast of Nicodemus due to the embers from a trash burning fire catching the grass on fire. No injuries or structural damage was reported from the fires. The high winds also lifted dirt into the air which caused reduced visibilities in Hill City of one hundred to two hundred yards. At 7:21 pm CDT, a car accident occurred due south of Hill City on Highway 283 due to the reduced visibilities. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system caused high winds across north central and southwest Nebraska. Northwest winds were frequently sustained at 30 to 40 mph with gusts to around 60 mph at times. The high winds began during the evening hours on December 22nd, and continued during the overnight hours into the afternoon hours on December 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds of 30 to 50 mph with gusts up to 71 mph occurred across Lincoln County during the morning into the early afternoon hours. A mesonet site 4 miles north of North Platte recorded a peak wind gust of 71 mph at 1115 am CST. The North Platte ASOS also recorded a peak wind gust of 67 mph at 1153 am CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On this late Sunday afternoon and evening, several scattered, strong to severe storms advanced southward across various portions of South Central Nebraska, prompting many accounts of large hail and a few damaging wind gusts. While most hail was in the quarter to golf ball size range, larger stones of 2-3 diameter fell in the Chapman and Marquette areas of Merrick/Hamilton counties. Ping pong to golf ball size hail occurred in or near the following communities/locations: Fullerton, Amherst, Orleans, Harlan County Lake, Naponee and Deweese. In the Tri Cities, only Grand Island saw severe weather, as two rounds of quarter to half dollar size hail moved through, one mainly affecting the north side of town (including the airport) around 6 p.m. CDT, and another about an hour later that clipped more of the city. As for thunderstorm winds, the vast majority of gusts captured by area sensors were non-severe (generally 40-50 MPH), but there were two reports estimated around 60 MPH, one near Hampton and another at Hebron, where a few large trees were downed and a store front sustained minor damage. Given fairly progressive storm motions, rainfall totals in most affected areas were less than 1 inch during the afternoon/evening. However, combined with localized heavy rain that fell during a separate round of early morning/non-severe activity, portions of mainly eastern Clay County registered over 3 for the day (including NWS coop observer total of 3.33 six miles east-southeast of Clay Center). As a result, the later-day storms prompted some isolated flash flooding, as School Creek overtopped the paved spur road south of Saronville. ||This event was characterized by truly scattered, hit-or-miss convection, as afternoon heating and subtle convergence along/ahead of a weak cold front sagging southward into the region prompted several strong to severe storms, mainly in the form of multicells/multicell clusters, but also a few brief supercells. Nearly every county in the 24-county area observed at least a touch of thunderstorm activity. That being said, the majority of ground-truth reports concentrated in two primary areas: 1) parts of Hall/Hamilton/Merrick counties...2) a swath from eastern Furnas to far southwestern Franklin counties. A few of the first severe storms of the event flared up over Furnas/Buffalo counties between 430-530 p.m. CDT, and the final severe storm of the evening was centered over the Nuckolls County area before weakening around 9 p.m. CDT. Thereafter, a smattering of strong storms lingered within counties south of Interstate 80 through around 10:30 pm. CDT before all convection ended for the night. In total, 19 Severe Thunderstorm Warnings were issued within South Central Nebraska over the course of over four hours. Digging deeper into the meteorological setup, it's worth noting that this event exceeded forecast expectations, especially in terms of the number of severe storms. This was due in part to greater-than-expected convective instability, as afternoon surface dewpoints soared into the upper 60s-low 70 F,  promoting significant mixed-layer CAPE of at least 3000-4000 J/kg. In tandem with deep layer wind shear around 35 knots, this CAPE/shear combo proved plenty sufficient for robust convection. In the mid-upper levels, a pronounced north-northwest flow regime resided over the Central Plains, within the interface between a stout western United States ridge and a broad eastern trough.

Mainly between midnight and 4 a.m. CDT on this early Thursday morning, scattered strong-to-briefly-severe thunderstorms rumbled along a narrow corridor of South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast, primarily affecting these counties: Dawson, Buffalo, Hall, Adams, Clay, Fillmore and Thayer. Although radar data suggested that spotty hail to at least nickel size likely occurred within various counties, ground-truth verification was quite limited, consisting of only a few reports of penny to quarter size stones in Hastings around 1:30 a.m. CDT, followed a short time later by the only severe-criteria report of the event: golf ball size hail at Inland in western Clay County. A few hours later (around 4 a.m. CDT), the final strong local storms of the morning dissipated over eastern Fillmore/Thayer counties. There were no reports of strong/severe wind gusts. ||This somewhat-unexpected nocturnal convection (at least in terms of intensity) initiated in the local area over Dawson County shortly before midnight CDT, roughly 50 miles east of a small cluster of strong storms already ongoing off to the west, and roughly 75-100 miles north of the centroid of a small mesoscale convective system (MCS) sliding across northern Kansas (in fact the local storms appeared to be a northward-displaced offshoot of the Kansas MCS). Whether or not the local convection was directly tied to the activity farther south, mesoscale analysis revealed that it was likely sparked by a subtle ribbon of low-mid level warm air/moisture advection within a weak southwesterly low level jet axis (winds at 850 millibars less than 25 knots). Convective parameters were at least marginally-supportive of sporadic intense updrafts, featuring around 1500 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and up to around 30 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

Arguably the most noteworthy individual thunderstorm of the 2020 convective season within this six-county North Central Kansas area rolled southward across portions of Jewell, Mitchell and mainly eastern Osborne counties on this Friday evening, highlighted by several reports of large to very large hail. Of the counties impacted by this supercell, Jewell was hardest-hit, as copious amounts of tennis ball to softball size hail stones crashed down onto areas in and near the communities of Mankato and Jewell, causing extensive damage to homes, vehicles and area crops. The hail size toned down somewhat farther south into Mitchell and Osborne counties, where limited reports included ping pong ball size stones in Cawker City and golf ball size south of Osborne. Although damaging winds were not a major player during this event, several mesonets clocked gusts of at least 40-50 MPH, and a Kansas Mesonet site near Jewell reached severe-criteria with 65 MPH. Flooding was not much of an issue, with convection staying progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch.||Breaking down event timing and meteorological background, this giant storm invaded northern Jewell County between 7-8 pm. CDT, having already propagated south-southwestward for roughly 90 miles since its inception in east central Nebraska about three hours prior. As it drifted southward into Mitchell County between 8-9 p.m. CDT it started merging with a much smaller, separate storm that had flared up over central Osborne County. Finally, between 9-10 p.m. CDT, the now-merged supercell cluster continued southward while exiting the local area into central Kansas, ending all local storms for the night. This was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for North Central Kansas, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C promoting a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the evening. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding impressive mixed-layer CAPE up to around 4500 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long-lived supercell produced a substantial swath of very large hail in the Mankato and Jewell areas, with large hail produced for a significant amount of time. A public report of golf ball size hail was received at 7:45 p.m. CDT in Mankato. By 7:50 p.m. CDT, the hail size in Mankato reached a measured diameter of 4 inches, with tennis ball size hail still falling in town at 8:10 p.m. CDT. At 8:13 p.m. CDT, golf ball size hail was reported about 3 miles northwest of Randall. At 8:15 p.m. CDT, 4 inch diameter hail was reported 2 miles north of Jewell, with baseball size hail in Jewell. Significant hail damage to homes, vehicles and crops occurred in the area. As just one example, local media reported that the Jewell County EMS Director's vehicle incurred major hail damage, including a shattered windshield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although it only impacted a small percentage of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, the large and intense supercell storm that marched south-southwestward for over 90 miles through several eastern counties on this Friday afternoon/early evening was likely the local area's most noteworthy individual storm of the 2020 convective season. In addition to dropping three fairly brief EF-0 tornadoes in southeastern Hamilton and northeastern Clay counties, its main calling card was large hail, with several reports of golf ball to slightly larger than baseball size stones in Clay/Nuckolls counties, and smaller hail to around quarter size as far north as Osceola. Interestingly, damaging winds were not a major player, with no ground-truth gusts in excess of 50 MPH. Focusing on specific storm reports, and starting with the three EF-0 tornadoes, they all occurred between 5-6 p.m. CDT, touching down briefly along a roughly 15-mile long corridor from near Interstate 80 a few miles south of Hampton, down to the Saronville area. Per storm surveys, the first two tornadoes were each on the ground for roughly 2 miles. While the majority of minor damage was confined to crops and trees, a lean-to shed was destroyed and a pivot overturned. As for the hail, the largest reported was 3 diameter between Clay Center and Harvard, but towns including Sutton and Nelson endured stones to at least tennis ball size. Flooding was not much of an issue, as the storm was progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch. ||Breaking down the meteorological background and event timing, this was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for South Central Nebraska, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C providing a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the afternoon. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding formidable mixed-layer CAPE around 4000 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection. As for what actually transpired, the main show was preceded by a broken line of non-severe, likely elevated storms that passed primarily through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 between 12:30-3:30 p.m. CDT. About the time this innocuous early afternoon activity was departing the local area to the southeast, a broken line of true, surface-based storms got going along the front in northeast Nebraska, with the southwestern-most cell building down into the far northeast corner of South Central Nebraska (eastern Nance/northeast Merrick/northern Polk counties) between 3-4 p.m. CDT. Within an hour thereafter, this tail end Charlie storm rapidly grew into a full-blown supercell over Polk/northern York counties, producing its first marginally-severe hail reports. During the following two hours (5-7 p.m. CDT), the storm anchored itself firmly to the surface front, with new updraft generation along its western edge promoting more of a southwestward propagation and causing it to grow larger in both intensity/size, becoming more of a supercell cluster. It was during this time that the brief tornadoes occurred along the storm's far western flank, likely driven by pronounced low-level vorticity stretching along the surface front. While the sporadic tornado touchdowns were brief, the storm continued to be a prolific hail-producer as it gradually exited the local area out of Nuckolls County into northern Kansas between 7-8 p.m. CDT, ending all South Central Nebraska convection for the night.

A powerful storm system caused high winds across north central and southwest Nebraska. Northwest winds were frequently sustained at 30 to 40 mph with gusts to around 60 mph at times. The high winds began during the evening hours on December 22nd, and continued during the overnight hours into the afternoon hours on December 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds of 30 to 50 mph with gusts up to 71 mph occurred across Logan County during the morning into the early afternoon hours. A nearby mesonet site 4 miles north of North Platte recorded a peak wind gust of 71 mph at 1115 am CST. The nearby North Platte ASOS also recorded a peak wind gust of 67 mph at 11153 am MST.

A nearby mesonet site 4 miles north of North Platte recorded a peak wind gust of 71 mph at 1115 am CST. The nearby North Platte ASOS also recorded a peak wind gust of 67 mph at 11153 am MST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system caused high winds across north central and southwest Nebraska. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds of 40 mph sustained were recorded at the Ogallala AWOS between 930 am and 11 am MST. A peak wind gust during this time was 56 mph. Winds of this magnitude were common across Keith County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system caused high winds across north central and southwest Nebraska. Northwest winds were frequently sustained at 30 to 40 mph with gusts to around 60 mph at times. The high winds began during the evening hours on December 22nd, and continued during the overnight hours into the afternoon hours on December 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds of 40 mph sustained were recorded at the nearby Sidney ASOS between 430 am and 1030 am MST.  A peak wind gust during this time was 67 mph. Winds of this magnitude were common across Deuel County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions remained unchanged across western and north central Nebraska in December. Precipitation was below normal in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle and portions of far southwestern Nebraska. Across the northern Sandhills from eastern Cherry county into Holt county, precipitation for the month was running 50 to 90 percent of normal. Across the central and southern Sandhills, including Lincoln and Keith counties, precipitation was 100 to 150 percent of normal. For the year ending in December, Broken Bow, North Platte, Valentine and Imperial, ran precipitation deficits of: -3.33, -5.48, -1.94, and -9.36 inches respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of December, extreme (D3) drought conditions remained present over far southern Keith County. Over the remainder of the county, severe (D2) drought conditions persisted through December. The cooperative observer at Kingsley Dam reported 0.58 inches of precipitation in December. This was 0.12 inches above the normal of 0.46 inches. The cooperative station at Ogallala reported 0.69 inches and was 0.30 inches above the normal of 0.39 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of December, drought severity remained unchanged across Arthur county. Severe (D2) drought conditions were present over the western half of the county. The cooperative station at Arthur reported 0.41 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.08 inches above the normal of 0.33 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms associated with a cold front moved through eastern Nebraska. It produced large hail early on and strong winds late in the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Personal weather station measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report via social media reported tree damage and power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low tracked across the Texas panhandle into northwestern Oklahoma that produced snow on the backside across southern counties of the CWA along the border. Reports up to a foot in the warning areas of Meade to Barber County with lesser amounts for the next tier of counties west and north of this line. Coupled with strong north winds gusting up to 30-40 mph, substantial impacts in the warning and advisory areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inches of snow was observed in Plains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On this late Sunday afternoon and evening, several scattered, strong to severe storms advanced southward across various portions of South Central Nebraska, prompting many accounts of large hail and a few damaging wind gusts. While most hail was in the quarter to golf ball size range, larger stones of 2-3 diameter fell in the Chapman and Marquette areas of Merrick/Hamilton counties. Ping pong to golf ball size hail occurred in or near the following communities/locations: Fullerton, Amherst, Orleans, Harlan County Lake, Naponee and Deweese. In the Tri Cities, only Grand Island saw severe weather, as two rounds of quarter to half dollar size hail moved through, one mainly affecting the north side of town (including the airport) around 6 p.m. CDT, and another about an hour later that clipped more of the city. As for thunderstorm winds, the vast majority of gusts captured by area sensors were non-severe (generally 40-50 MPH), but there were two reports estimated around 60 MPH, one near Hampton and another at Hebron, where a few large trees were downed and a store front sustained minor damage. Given fairly progressive storm motions, rainfall totals in most affected areas were less than 1 inch during the afternoon/evening. However, combined with localized heavy rain that fell during a separate round of early morning/non-severe activity, portions of mainly eastern Clay County registered over 3 for the day (including NWS coop observer total of 3.33 six miles east-southeast of Clay Center). As a result, the later-day storms prompted some isolated flash flooding, as School Creek overtopped the paved spur road south of Saronville. ||This event was characterized by truly scattered, hit-or-miss convection, as afternoon heating and subtle convergence along/ahead of a weak cold front sagging southward into the region prompted several strong to severe storms, mainly in the form of multicells/multicell clusters, but also a few brief supercells. Nearly every county in the 24-county area observed at least a touch of thunderstorm activity. That being said, the majority of ground-truth reports concentrated in two primary areas: 1) parts of Hall/Hamilton/Merrick counties...2) a swath from eastern Furnas to far southwestern Franklin counties. A few of the first severe storms of the event flared up over Furnas/Buffalo counties between 430-530 p.m. CDT, and the final severe storm of the evening was centered over the Nuckolls County area before weakening around 9 p.m. CDT. Thereafter, a smattering of strong storms lingered within counties south of Interstate 80 through around 10:30 pm. CDT before all convection ended for the night. In total, 19 Severe Thunderstorm Warnings were issued within South Central Nebraska over the course of over four hours. Digging deeper into the meteorological setup, it's worth noting that this event exceeded forecast expectations, especially in terms of the number of severe storms. This was due in part to greater-than-expected convective instability, as afternoon surface dewpoints soared into the upper 60s-low 70 F,  promoting significant mixed-layer CAPE of at least 3000-4000 J/kg. In tandem with deep layer wind shear around 35 knots, this CAPE/shear combo proved plenty sufficient for robust convection. In the mid-upper levels, a pronounced north-northwest flow regime resided over the Central Plains, within the interface between a stout western United States ridge and a broad eastern trough.

Ping pong to golf ball size hail occurred in or near the following communities/locations: Fullerton, Amherst, Orleans, Harlan County Lake, Naponee and Deweese. In the Tri Cities, only Grand Island saw severe weather, as two rounds of quarter to half dollar size hail moved through, one mainly affecting the north side of town (including the airport) around 6 p.m. CDT, and another about an hour later that clipped more of the city. As for thunderstorm winds, the vast majority of gusts captured by area sensors were non-severe (generally 40-50 MPH), but there were two reports estimated around 60 MPH, one near Hampton and another at Hebron, where a few large trees were downed and a store front sustained minor damage. Given fairly progressive storm motions, rainfall totals in most affected areas were less than 1 inch during the afternoon/evening. However, combined with localized heavy rain that fell during a separate round of early morning/non-severe activity, portions of mainly eastern Clay County registered over 3 for the day (including NWS coop observer total of 3.33 six miles east-southeast of Clay Center). As a result, the later-day storms prompted some isolated flash flooding, as School Creek overtopped the paved spur road south of Saronville. ||This event was characterized by truly scattered, hit-or-miss convection, as afternoon heating and subtle convergence along/ahead of a weak cold front sagging southward into the region prompted several strong to severe storms, mainly in the form of multicells/multicell clusters, but also a few brief supercells. Nearly every county in the 24-county area observed at least a touch of thunderstorm activity. That being said, the majority of ground-truth reports concentrated in two primary areas: 1) parts of Hall/Hamilton/Merrick counties...2) a swath from eastern Furnas to far southwestern Franklin counties. A few of the first severe storms of the event flared up over Furnas/Buffalo counties between 430-530 p.m. CDT, and the final severe storm of the evening was centered over the Nuckolls County area before weakening around 9 p.m. CDT. Thereafter, a smattering of strong storms lingered within counties south of Interstate 80 through around 10:30 pm. CDT before all convection ended for the night. In total, 19 Severe Thunderstorm Warnings were issued within South Central Nebraska over the course of over four hours. Digging deeper into the meteorological setup, it's worth noting that this event exceeded forecast expectations, especially in terms of the number of severe storms. This was due in part to greater-than-expected convective instability, as afternoon surface dewpoints soared into the upper 60s-low 70 F,  promoting significant mixed-layer CAPE of at least 3000-4000 J/kg. In tandem with deep layer wind shear around 35 knots, this CAPE/shear combo proved plenty sufficient for robust convection. In the mid-upper levels, a pronounced north-northwest flow regime resided over the Central Plains, within the interface between a stout western United States ridge and a broad eastern trough.

A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Greeley county producing high winds ranging from 40 mph to 60 mph. The peak gust of 60 mph was observed north of the town of Tribune. These high winds lifted dirt into the air at least one thousand feet above ground and reduced visibilities between one-quarter mile near Horace to two blocks in Tribune.

No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As a strong cold front moved across Sherman County, strong winds ranging from 27 to 80 mph caused dirt to be lifted into the air. The blowing dust reduced visibilities between one mile to a couple hundred yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe storms move across the area producing isolated severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to quarter sized hail was reported by the Emergency Manager.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low tracked across the Texas panhandle into northwestern Oklahoma that produced snow on the backside across southern counties of the CWA along the border. Reports up to a foot in the warning areas of Meade to Barber County with lesser amounts for the next tier of counties west and north of this line. Coupled with strong north winds gusting up to 30-40 mph, substantial impacts in the warning and advisory areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to six inches of snow was observed near Centerview.

Coupled with strong north winds gusting up to 30-40 mph, substantial impacts in the warning and advisory areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to six inches of snow was observed near Centerview.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low again tracked across the Texas and Oklahoma panhandles, allowing for several inches of snow across much of the southern half of the CWA with highest reports near the Oklahoma state line. Broad banding of snow with the 700mb trough stretched across Seward to Clark Counties to include Meade, where the highest amounts fell up to 12-14 inches. Couple with the weak upslope easterly flow near the surface, this helped to aid in the widespread snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 9 inches was observed at a location 12 miles NW of Englewood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter weather system impacted the area bringing wide swaths of 5 to 7 inches of snow. Farther to the south, ice accumulated on top of the snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported 2.0 inches of snow with 1 inch of sleet on top of that and freezing rain accumulations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter weather system impacted the area bringing wide swaths of 5 to 7 inches of snow. Farther to the south, ice accumulated on top of the snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 7.2 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter weather system impacted the area bringing wide swaths of 5 to 7 inches of snow. Farther to the south, ice accumulated on top of the snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS report of 7.6 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter weather system impacted the area bringing wide swaths of 5 to 7 inches of snow. Farther to the south, ice accumulated on top of the snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported of 7.8 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter weather system impacted the area bringing wide swaths of 5 to 7 inches of snow. Farther to the south, ice accumulated on top of the snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS report of 8.0 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system caused blizzard conditions and high winds across portions of north central and central Nebraska. Northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph gusting to 60 mph combined with snow to create blizzard conditions during the early morning through the early afternoon hours. Visibility was reduced to near zero at times and caused numerous road closures. Snowfall amounts ranged from 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph gusting to 60 mph combined with snow to create blizzard conditions during the early morning through the early afternoon hours across Keya Paha County. Visibility was reduced to near zero at times. Snowfall amounts ranged around 2 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system caused blizzard conditions and high winds across portions of north central and central Nebraska. Northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph gusting to 60 mph combined with snow to create blizzard conditions during the early morning through the early afternoon hours. Visibility was reduced to near zero at times and caused numerous road closures. Snowfall amounts ranged from 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph gusting to 60 mph combined with snow to create blizzard conditions during the early morning through the early afternoon hours across Brown County. Visibility was reduced to near zero at times causing road closures. Snowfall amounts ranged from 2 to 3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On this late Sunday afternoon and evening, several scattered, strong to severe storms advanced southward across various portions of South Central Nebraska, prompting many accounts of large hail and a few damaging wind gusts. While most hail was in the quarter to golf ball size range, larger stones of 2-3 diameter fell in the Chapman and Marquette areas of Merrick/Hamilton counties. Ping pong to golf ball size hail occurred in or near the following communities/locations: Fullerton, Amherst, Orleans, Harlan County Lake, Naponee and Deweese. In the Tri Cities, only Grand Island saw severe weather, as two rounds of quarter to half dollar size hail moved through, one mainly affecting the north side of town (including the airport) around 6 p.m. CDT, and another about an hour later that clipped more of the city. As for thunderstorm winds, the vast majority of gusts captured by area sensors were non-severe (generally 40-50 MPH), but there were two reports estimated around 60 MPH, one near Hampton and another at Hebron, where a few large trees were downed and a store front sustained minor damage. Given fairly progressive storm motions, rainfall totals in most affected areas were less than 1 inch during the afternoon/evening. However, combined with localized heavy rain that fell during a separate round of early morning/non-severe activity, portions of mainly eastern Clay County registered over 3 for the day (including NWS coop observer total of 3.33 six miles east-southeast of Clay Center). As a result, the later-day storms prompted some isolated flash flooding, as School Creek overtopped the paved spur road south of Saronville. ||This event was characterized by truly scattered, hit-or-miss convection, as afternoon heating and subtle convergence along/ahead of a weak cold front sagging southward into the region prompted several strong to severe storms, mainly in the form of multicells/multicell clusters, but also a few brief supercells. Nearly every county in the 24-county area observed at least a touch of thunderstorm activity. That being said, the majority of ground-truth reports concentrated in two primary areas: 1) parts of Hall/Hamilton/Merrick counties...2) a swath from eastern Furnas to far southwestern Franklin counties. A few of the first severe storms of the event flared up over Furnas/Buffalo counties between 430-530 p.m. CDT, and the final severe storm of the evening was centered over the Nuckolls County area before weakening around 9 p.m. CDT. Thereafter, a smattering of strong storms lingered within counties south of Interstate 80 through around 10:30 pm. CDT before all convection ended for the night. In total, 19 Severe Thunderstorm Warnings were issued within South Central Nebraska over the course of over four hours. Digging deeper into the meteorological setup, it's worth noting that this event exceeded forecast expectations, especially in terms of the number of severe storms. This was due in part to greater-than-expected convective instability, as afternoon surface dewpoints soared into the upper 60s-low 70 F,  promoting significant mixed-layer CAPE of at least 3000-4000 J/kg. In tandem with deep layer wind shear around 35 knots, this CAPE/shear combo proved plenty sufficient for robust convection. In the mid-upper levels, a pronounced north-northwest flow regime resided over the Central Plains, within the interface between a stout western United States ridge and a broad eastern trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH downed two large trees and damaged one store front.

For several hours on this late Sunday afternoon and evening, a handful of strong to severe storms advanced southward across portions of this six-county North Central Kansas area, yielding a few reports of marginally-severe hail up to quarter size mainly in portions of Jewell, Smith and Osborne counties. There were no significant ground-truth reports of thunderstorm winds, and all gusts captured by reliable area sensors came in under 50 MPH. ||This event consisted of isolated to scattered, hit-or-miss convection, as afternoon heating and subtle convergence near a weak cold front sagging southward across southern Nebraska prompted the development of several multicell storms/clusters. Locally, the first strong storm of the afternoon flared up between 3-4 p.m. CDT in southern Rooks County but fizzled quickly (no known reports). Then, between 530-630 p.m. CDT, a verified large-hailer over extreme southern Nebraska nearly brushed into northern Phillips County but weakened before doing so. Between 7-9 p.m. CDT strong to marginally-severe storms roamed mainly parts of Rooks/Smith/Jewell counties (hail reports from the Lebanon and Esbon areas). After this, it briefly appeared that the severe storm threat was over for the night, but around 10 p.m. CDT one last gasp of vigorous convection bubbled up near the Osborne/Mitchell County line, producing nickel to quarter size hail between Downs and Tipton before weakening. All activity departed south of the local area by 1130 p.m. CDT. In the end, the majority of regional severe weather concentrated at least slightly west, east and especially north of the local area. Nonetheless, this was a fairly potent setup for healthy storms in North Central Kansas, as afternoon surface dewpoints climbed into the mid 60s-low 70 F during the afternoon, promoting significant mixed-layer CAPE of at least 2000-4000 J/kg. In tandem with deep layer wind shear around 35 knots, this CAPE/shear combo proved plenty sufficient for robust convection. In the mid-upper levels, a pronounced north-northwest flow regime resided over the Central Plains, within the interface between a stout western United States ridge and a broad eastern trough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the late evening of Sunday the 30th and the pre-dawn hours of Monday the 31st, a cluster of strong thunderstorms tracked across mainly the northeastern one-third of South Central Nebraska (primarily northeast of an Ord-York line), producing slightly-sub-severe hail, gusty winds and brief heavy rain. Early in the event (12-1230 a.m. CDT), a few hail reports flirted with severe criteria, including nickel size stones in North Loup and dime size in Ord. All known wind gusts from area sensors registered under 50 MPH. ||Breaking down event timing, it's worth noting that north-northwest local counties had already dodged a possible severe storm threat earlier in the evening, as a broken line of strong to severe storms approaching from central/north central Nebraska fizzled out shortly before reaching the Valley County area around nightfall. A few hours later and shortly before midnight CDT, a few briefly-isolated strong storms rapidly flared up over Valley/Greeley counties, with the western one dropping the aforementioned dime-nickel size hail. Already by 1230 a.m. CDT these cells had merged into a small cluster, and although radar signatures suggested possible severe hail and/or wind across southern Greeley/far northern Howard counties, there were no verifying reports. All convection departed South Central Nebraska out of Polk/York counties between 3-4 a.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, this overnight event was fairly strongly-forced, as the southern edge of a potent shortwave trough swept through the Dakotas and far northern Nebraska. At the surface, storms initiated near/along an associated strong surface cold front sweeping through South Central Nebraska, its nocturnal passage marked by 25-40 MPH northerly gusts. Around the time of the hail in Valley County, the mesoscale environment featured at least 1500 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

A couple of strong (one briefly severe) thunderstorms infiltrated the far western and northern fringes of South Central Nebraska for a short time on this Tuesday evening, with one of them yielding a lone marginally-severe wind report in Furnas County. This storm entered the county from the west around 9 p.m. CDT as part of a north-south oriented, broken line of convection that initiated hours earlier in northeast Colorado. As the storm tracked along Highway 6/34, a county deputy estimated 60 MPH gusts near Holbrook. Shortly thereafter the storm weakened, and had all but dissipated before reaching Phelps County around 10 p.m. CDT. About an hour later, a completely separate storm (part of a complex that had been drifting across northwestern Nebraska for several hours) entered Valley County from the west-northwest. Although radar briefly suggested it might have reached severe levels, the only known report consisted of pea size hail near Elyria. Like the other storm, this one also weakened considerably within an hour of entering the local area, and there was no additional strong convection  within South Central Nebraska the remainder of the night. In the mid-upper levels, this was a typical summer setup for scattered, loosely-organized convection to survive eastward into the local area off the High Plains during the evening, as weak/low-amplitude disturbances meandered through the prevailing quasi-zonal flow. Post-sunset mesoscale parameters over South Central Nebraska were only marginally-supportive of strong to severe storms, featuring around 1500 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE but no more than 25-30 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Officer reported wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH while driving between Cambridge and Arapahoe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions remained unchanged across western and north central Nebraska in December. Precipitation was below normal in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle and portions of far southwestern Nebraska. Across the northern Sandhills from eastern Cherry county into Holt county, precipitation for the month was running 50 to 90 percent of normal. Across the central and southern Sandhills, including Lincoln and Keith counties, precipitation was 100 to 150 percent of normal. For the year ending in December, Broken Bow, North Platte, Valentine and Imperial, ran precipitation deficits of: -3.33, -5.48, -1.94, and -9.36 inches respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of December, extreme (D3) drought conditions remained unchanged across all of Hayes County. The cooperative station at Hayes Center reported 0.41 inches of precipitation for December. This was 0.12 inches below the normal of 0.53 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Broad warm advection developed early on December 29 as a strong trough aloft sheared northeast through the central and northern Plains. A period of strong frontogenesis shifted northeast, accompanied by a deep dendritic layer which produced snowfall rates up to an inch per hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to briefly heavy snowfall totaled 6.3 inches at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong front moved southeast across Sherman County producing winds with gusts between 55-80 mph. In northern Sherman County, up to 70 mph wind gusts were observed for a duration of one hour and 50 minutes. These strong winds snapped an 8 inch diameter tree limb off a fruit tree and another tree to fall, which crushed a fence, in Goodland. The Goodland ASOS observed a peak gust of 66 mph during the event. The high winds also caused blowing dust to occur, which reduced visibilities between one mile to a few hundred yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds developed behind a cold front during the late morning hours into the afternoon hours on November 14th, 2020. Northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to around 60 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The nearby Imperial ASOS recorded a peak wind gust of 64 mph at 256 pm CST. Northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph sustained with gusts as high as 64 mph were common across Hayes County between 12 pm until 5 pm CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds developed behind a cold front during the late morning hours into the afternoon hours on November 14th, 2020. Northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to around 60 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The nearby McCook ASOS recorded a peak wind gust of 62 mph at 353 pm CST. Northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph sustained with gusts as high as 62 mph were common across Frontier County between 1 pm until 5 pm CST. Areas of blowing dust also occurred with visibilities as low as 3 miles at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although it only impacted a small percentage of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, the large and intense supercell storm that marched south-southwestward for over 90 miles through several eastern counties on this Friday afternoon/early evening was likely the local area's most noteworthy individual storm of the 2020 convective season. In addition to dropping three fairly brief EF-0 tornadoes in southeastern Hamilton and northeastern Clay counties, its main calling card was large hail, with several reports of golf ball to slightly larger than baseball size stones in Clay/Nuckolls counties, and smaller hail to around quarter size as far north as Osceola. Interestingly, damaging winds were not a major player, with no ground-truth gusts in excess of 50 MPH. Focusing on specific storm reports, and starting with the three EF-0 tornadoes, they all occurred between 5-6 p.m. CDT, touching down briefly along a roughly 15-mile long corridor from near Interstate 80 a few miles south of Hampton, down to the Saronville area. Per storm surveys, the first two tornadoes were each on the ground for roughly 2 miles. While the majority of minor damage was confined to crops and trees, a lean-to shed was destroyed and a pivot overturned. As for the hail, the largest reported was 3 diameter between Clay Center and Harvard, but towns including Sutton and Nelson endured stones to at least tennis ball size. Flooding was not much of an issue, as the storm was progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch. ||Breaking down the meteorological background and event timing, this was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for South Central Nebraska, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C providing a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the afternoon. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding formidable mixed-layer CAPE around 4000 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection. As for what actually transpired, the main show was preceded by a broken line of non-severe, likely elevated storms that passed primarily through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 between 12:30-3:30 p.m. CDT. About the time this innocuous early afternoon activity was departing the local area to the southeast, a broken line of true, surface-based storms got going along the front in northeast Nebraska, with the southwestern-most cell building down into the far northeast corner of South Central Nebraska (eastern Nance/northeast Merrick/northern Polk counties) between 3-4 p.m. CDT. Within an hour thereafter, this tail end Charlie storm rapidly grew into a full-blown supercell over Polk/northern York counties, producing its first marginally-severe hail reports. During the following two hours (5-7 p.m. CDT), the storm anchored itself firmly to the surface front, with new updraft generation along its western edge promoting more of a southwestward propagation and causing it to grow larger in both intensity/size, becoming more of a supercell cluster. It was during this time that the brief tornadoes occurred along the storm's far western flank, likely driven by pronounced low-level vorticity stretching along the surface front. While the sporadic tornado touchdowns were brief, the storm continued to be a prolific hail-producer as it gradually exited the local area out of Nuckolls County into northern Kansas between 7-8 p.m. CDT, ending all South Central Nebraska convection for the night.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds were measured by ASOS and several other wind sensors for several hours across the county.  The highest peak gust was measured at 66 mph.  Reports of downed trees and power lines were also noted along with shingles being blown off of roofs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant wind storm developed and moved across the central and south central sections of Kansas.  Wind speeds were measured at many locations to be between 55 and 70 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds were measured by an AWOS wind sensor for several hours across the county.  The highest peak gust was measured at 59 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant wind storm developed and moved across the central and south central sections of Kansas.  Wind speeds were measured at many locations to be between 55 and 70 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds were measured by an AWOS wind sensor for several hours across the county.  The highest peak gust was measured at 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual October winter storm affected much of south central Kansas on October 26th and 27th. The event started during the early morning hours of Monday, October 26th as a mix of sleet and snow with a second round on Tuesday which consisted of mostly sleet and freezing rain. Locations across Cowley, Chautauqua, Elk and Montogomery counties saw the most significant ice accumulation. The towns of Winfield and especially Arkansas City were hit hard, with numerous reports of widespread power outages along with large trees down. ||Wichita set new snowfall records for both October 26th and 27th. The 1.3 inches on the 26th was the most snow Wichita has ever received that early.  The 1.6 inches from both days combined makes October 2020 the 2nd snowiest October on record for Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter mix prevailed across the county causing minor nuisances for travel.  The precipitation began as freezing drizzle then transitioned over to snow.  Snowfall amounts across the county varied between 1 to 2 inches.  Officially, the 1.3 inches on the 26th was the most snow Wichita had ever received this early in the season.  Secondly, the 1.6 inch storm total made this the 2nd snowiest month on record for the county.  Ice accumulations up to 0.15 inches were noted as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low again tracked across the Texas and Oklahoma panhandles, allowing for several inches of snow across much of the southern half of the CWA with highest reports near the Oklahoma state line. Broad banding of snow with the 700mb trough stretched across Seward to Clark Counties to include Meade, where the highest amounts fell up to 12-14 inches. Couple with the weak upslope easterly flow near the surface, this helped to aid in the widespread snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5 inches was reported in Bloom.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions remained unchanged across western and north central Nebraska in December. Precipitation was below normal in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle and portions of far southwestern Nebraska. Across the northern Sandhills from eastern Cherry county into Holt county, precipitation for the month was running 50 to 90 percent of normal. Across the central and southern Sandhills, including Lincoln and Keith counties, precipitation was 100 to 150 percent of normal. For the year ending in December, Broken Bow, North Platte, Valentine and Imperial, ran precipitation deficits of: -3.33, -5.48, -1.94, and -9.36 inches respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of December, extreme (D3) drought conditions remained over the southern half of Lincoln county. Along the Platte River Valley in central Lincoln county, severe (D2) drought conditions remained unchanged during December. The cooperative station at Wallace 2W reported 0.37 inches of precipitation for December. This was 0.03 inches below the normal of 0.40 inches. The cooperative station at Hershey 5SSE reported 0.44 inches of precipitation in December. This was 0.15 inches above the normal of 0.29 inches. At the North Platte Airport, 0.72 inches of precipitation fell which was 0.31 inches above the normal of 0.41 inches. At the cooperative station in Brady, 0.92 inches of precipitation fell.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme (D3) drought conditions remained unchanged during the month of December in Frontier County. The cooperative station at Curtis reported 0.66 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.21 inches above the normal of 0.45 inches. The cooperative station at Eustis 2NW reported 0.91 inches of precipitation in December. This was 0.25 inches above the normal of 0.66 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Non-thunderstorm high winds associated with a passing cold front occurred in southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours of November 14th, 2020. The maximum sustained wind speed recorded was 43 mph and the maximum wind gust speed recorded was 62 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds between 40-43 mph and wind gusts up to 62 mph were reported across the county. KMCK ASOS 2 miles east of McCook, NE reported the max wind gust of 62 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Non-thunderstorm high winds associated with a passing cold front occurred in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon hours of November 14th, 2020. The maximum sustained wind speed recorded was 43 mph and the maximum wind gust speed recorded was 65 mph. These high winds also caused reduced visibility down to a quarter mile due to blowing dust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported 1/4 visibility due to dust at 8 miles north-northwest of Monument Rocks land in KS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between 8-930 p.m. CDT on this Friday evening, a lone severe storm roamed south-southeastward across portions of Osborne County, prompting a few reports of hail up to ping pong ball size. This supercell initiated in north central Osborne County, with the first report of quarter size hail from within the city of Osborne around 8:30 pm. CDT. During the next hour the storm tracked south-southeast through rural portions of the county as hail size increased to 1.5 diameter, with one resident reporting destroyed rose blooms. Around 9:30 p.m. CDT the now-weakening cell exited the county (and this North Central Kansas area altogether). Although additional, more widespread convection developed into the area a few hours later, these later-night storms were not severe. This sunset severe storm fired up slightly behind a surface cold front slipping southward through the region, as weak low level convergence was able to locally overcome fairly strong capping (as evidenced by 700 millibar temperature around 12C). Despite the passing front, surface dewpoints still held up in the upper 60s F near the storm, promoting decent instability as the evening mesoscale environment featured 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 35 knots of deep-layer wind shear. In the mid-upper levels, broad west-northwest flow prevailed over northern Kansas.

Although it only impacted a small percentage of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, the large and intense supercell storm that marched south-southwestward for over 90 miles through several eastern counties on this Friday afternoon/early evening was likely the local area's most noteworthy individual storm of the 2020 convective season. In addition to dropping three fairly brief EF-0 tornadoes in southeastern Hamilton and northeastern Clay counties, its main calling card was large hail, with several reports of golf ball to slightly larger than baseball size stones in Clay/Nuckolls counties, and smaller hail to around quarter size as far north as Osceola. Interestingly, damaging winds were not a major player, with no ground-truth gusts in excess of 50 MPH. Focusing on specific storm reports, and starting with the three EF-0 tornadoes, they all occurred between 5-6 p.m. CDT, touching down briefly along a roughly 15-mile long corridor from near Interstate 80 a few miles south of Hampton, down to the Saronville area. Per storm surveys, the first two tornadoes were each on the ground for roughly 2 miles. While the majority of minor damage was confined to crops and trees, a lean-to shed was destroyed and a pivot overturned. As for the hail, the largest reported was 3 diameter between Clay Center and Harvard, but towns including Sutton and Nelson endured stones to at least tennis ball size. Flooding was not much of an issue, as the storm was progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch. ||Breaking down the meteorological background and event timing, this was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for South Central Nebraska, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C providing a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the afternoon. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding formidable mixed-layer CAPE around 4000 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection. As for what actually transpired, the main show was preceded by a broken line of non-severe, likely elevated storms that passed primarily through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 between 12:30-3:30 p.m. CDT. About the time this innocuous early afternoon activity was departing the local area to the southeast, a broken line of true, surface-based storms got going along the front in northeast Nebraska, with the southwestern-most cell building down into the far northeast corner of South Central Nebraska (eastern Nance/northeast Merrick/northern Polk counties) between 3-4 p.m. CDT. Within an hour thereafter, this tail end Charlie storm rapidly grew into a full-blown supercell over Polk/northern York counties, producing its first marginally-severe hail reports. During the following two hours (5-7 p.m. CDT), the storm anchored itself firmly to the surface front, with new updraft generation along its western edge promoting more of a southwestward propagation and causing it to grow larger in both intensity/size, becoming more of a supercell cluster. It was during this time that the brief tornadoes occurred along the storm's far western flank, likely driven by pronounced low-level vorticity stretching along the surface front. While the sporadic tornado touchdowns were brief, the storm continued to be a prolific hail-producer as it gradually exited the local area out of Nuckolls County into northern Kansas between 7-8 p.m. CDT, ending all South Central Nebraska convection for the night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor crop and tree damage occurred. Debris was found in nearby powerlines. An old lean-to shed was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mainly between midnight and 4 a.m. CDT on this early Thursday morning, scattered strong-to-briefly-severe thunderstorms rumbled along a narrow corridor of South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast, primarily affecting these counties: Dawson, Buffalo, Hall, Adams, Clay, Fillmore and Thayer. Although radar data suggested that spotty hail to at least nickel size likely occurred within various counties, ground-truth verification was quite limited, consisting of only a few reports of penny to quarter size stones in Hastings around 1:30 a.m. CDT, followed a short time later by the only severe-criteria report of the event: golf ball size hail at Inland in western Clay County. A few hours later (around 4 a.m. CDT), the final strong local storms of the morning dissipated over eastern Fillmore/Thayer counties. There were no reports of strong/severe wind gusts. ||This somewhat-unexpected nocturnal convection (at least in terms of intensity) initiated in the local area over Dawson County shortly before midnight CDT, roughly 50 miles east of a small cluster of strong storms already ongoing off to the west, and roughly 75-100 miles north of the centroid of a small mesoscale convective system (MCS) sliding across northern Kansas (in fact the local storms appeared to be a northward-displaced offshoot of the Kansas MCS). Whether or not the local convection was directly tied to the activity farther south, mesoscale analysis revealed that it was likely sparked by a subtle ribbon of low-mid level warm air/moisture advection within a weak southwesterly low level jet axis (winds at 850 millibars less than 25 knots). Convective parameters were at least marginally-supportive of sporadic intense updrafts, featuring around 1500 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and up to around 30 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 58 mph non-thunderstorm wind gust was reported at KSYF AWOS in Saint Francis, KS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although it only impacted a small percentage of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, the large and intense supercell storm that marched south-southwestward for over 90 miles through several eastern counties on this Friday afternoon/early evening was likely the local area's most noteworthy individual storm of the 2020 convective season. In addition to dropping three fairly brief EF-0 tornadoes in southeastern Hamilton and northeastern Clay counties, its main calling card was large hail, with several reports of golf ball to slightly larger than baseball size stones in Clay/Nuckolls counties, and smaller hail to around quarter size as far north as Osceola. Interestingly, damaging winds were not a major player, with no ground-truth gusts in excess of 50 MPH. Focusing on specific storm reports, and starting with the three EF-0 tornadoes, they all occurred between 5-6 p.m. CDT, touching down briefly along a roughly 15-mile long corridor from near Interstate 80 a few miles south of Hampton, down to the Saronville area. Per storm surveys, the first two tornadoes were each on the ground for roughly 2 miles. While the majority of minor damage was confined to crops and trees, a lean-to shed was destroyed and a pivot overturned. As for the hail, the largest reported was 3 diameter between Clay Center and Harvard, but towns including Sutton and Nelson endured stones to at least tennis ball size. Flooding was not much of an issue, as the storm was progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch. ||Breaking down the meteorological background and event timing, this was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for South Central Nebraska, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C providing a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the afternoon. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding formidable mixed-layer CAPE around 4000 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection. As for what actually transpired, the main show was preceded by a broken line of non-severe, likely elevated storms that passed primarily through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 between 12:30-3:30 p.m. CDT. About the time this innocuous early afternoon activity was departing the local area to the southeast, a broken line of true, surface-based storms got going along the front in northeast Nebraska, with the southwestern-most cell building down into the far northeast corner of South Central Nebraska (eastern Nance/northeast Merrick/northern Polk counties) between 3-4 p.m. CDT. Within an hour thereafter, this tail end Charlie storm rapidly grew into a full-blown supercell over Polk/northern York counties, producing its first marginally-severe hail reports. During the following two hours (5-7 p.m. CDT), the storm anchored itself firmly to the surface front, with new updraft generation along its western edge promoting more of a southwestward propagation and causing it to grow larger in both intensity/size, becoming more of a supercell cluster. It was during this time that the brief tornadoes occurred along the storm's far western flank, likely driven by pronounced low-level vorticity stretching along the surface front. While the sporadic tornado touchdowns were brief, the storm continued to be a prolific hail-producer as it gradually exited the local area out of Nuckolls County into northern Kansas between 7-8 p.m. CDT, ending all South Central Nebraska convection for the night.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving storms led to heavy rain and flash flooding in many places across southeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager reported more county roads being closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms tracked across southeast Nebraska producing damaging wind gusts and small hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported several large tree limbs down near Roca.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of storms moved across eastern Nebraska producing hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from mping of 1 inch tree limbs broken and shingles blown off of roof.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved north and produced a brief tornado and wind damage. A cold front quickly followed the warm front and let to several reports of 50+ mph non-thunderstorm winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A utility company reported hail up to the size of quarters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across eastern Nebraska and produced damaging winds, flash flooding, and a few hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 1 inch hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Non-thunderstorm high winds associated with a passing cold front occurred in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon hours of November 14th, 2020. The maximum sustained wind speed recorded was 43 mph and the maximum wind gust speed recorded was 65 mph. These high winds also caused reduced visibility down to a quarter mile due to blowing dust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 65 mph non-thunderstorm wind gust was reported at Mesonet station KKSHOXIE2 in Hoxie, KS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Non-thunderstorm high winds associated with a passing cold front occurred in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon hours of November 14th, 2020. The maximum sustained wind speed recorded was 43 mph and the maximum wind gust speed recorded was 65 mph. These high winds also caused reduced visibility down to a quarter mile due to blowing dust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 60 mph non-thunderstorm wind gust was reported at KOEL AWOS 2 miles east-southeast of Oakley, KS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Non-thunderstorm high winds associated with a passing cold front occurred in northwestern Kansas during the afternoon hours of November 14th, 2020. The maximum sustained wind speed recorded was 43 mph and the maximum wind gust speed recorded was 65 mph. These high winds also caused reduced visibility down to a quarter mile due to blowing dust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds were seen across Wallace county based on high winds observed in the surrounding counties. Event time and wind speed estimate were based on observations from these surrounding counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A confluent trough developed across the Northern Plains and locked in the cold air which had pushed southward and produced numerous record low maximum and minimum temperatures. As an extended period of warm advection and frontogenesis intensified during the afternoon of October 24, a broad area of snowfall developed, with periods of moderate to briefly heavy snowfall during the morning and early afternoon of October 25. Numerous snowfall records were established on October 24th and 25th to go along with the record cold temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled 3.9 inches inches at Concord and 3.0 inches at Newcastle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A confluent trough developed across the Northern Plains and locked in the cold air which had pushed southward and produced numerous record low maximum and minimum temperatures. As an extended period of warm advection and frontogenesis intensified during the afternoon of October 24, a broad area of snowfall developed, with periods of moderate to briefly heavy snowfall during the morning and early afternoon of October 25. Numerous snowfall records were established on October 24th and 25th to go along with the record cold temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled 3.3 inches at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual October winter storm affected much of south central Kansas on October 26th and 27th. The event started during the early morning hours of Monday, October 26th as a mix of sleet and snow with a second round on Tuesday which consisted of mostly sleet and freezing rain. Locations across Cowley, Chautauqua, Elk and Montogomery counties saw the most significant ice accumulation. The towns of Winfield and especially Arkansas City were hit hard, with numerous reports of widespread power outages along with large trees down. ||Wichita set new snowfall records for both October 26th and 27th. The 1.3 inches on the 26th was the most snow Wichita has ever received that early.  The 1.6 inches from both days combined makes October 2020 the 2nd snowiest October on record for Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were reported at many locations across the county.  The communities of Moline, Howard, and Grenola were hit the hardest.  Power outages were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual October winter storm affected much of south central Kansas on October 26th and 27th. The event started during the early morning hours of Monday, October 26th as a mix of sleet and snow with a second round on Tuesday which consisted of mostly sleet and freezing rain. Locations across Cowley, Chautauqua, Elk and Montogomery counties saw the most significant ice accumulation. The towns of Winfield and especially Arkansas City were hit hard, with numerous reports of widespread power outages along with large trees down. ||Wichita set new snowfall records for both October 26th and 27th. The 1.3 inches on the 26th was the most snow Wichita has ever received that early.  The 1.6 inches from both days combined makes October 2020 the 2nd snowiest October on record for Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mixture occurred across the county with it all beginning as rain and then switching over to snow.  The second round of weather also continued to be a wintry mix as ice was added to the mix this go round.  The temperatures hovered right at freezing making any one type of precipitation difficult. Snow amounts generally remained less than one inch and ice accumulations varied from a trace to 0.2 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm moved across southwest Kansas into northern Oklahoma during the late night on December, 2nd, 2020.  Cold air on the north side of the system, led to light snowfall amounts across most of south central Kansas.  Snowfall amounts were 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts were generally one to three inches across the county.  The Coop observer in Anthony reported 1.9 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm moved across southwest Kansas into northern Oklahoma during the late night on December, 2nd, 2020.  Cold air on the north side of the system, led to light snowfall amounts across most of south central Kansas.  Snowfall amounts were 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts generally ranged from three to five inches across the county, with the heaviest amounts in the western sections of the county.  The Coop observer in Zenda reported 5.5 inches, while the Coop observer in Kingman reported 3.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm moved across southwest Kansas into northern Oklahoma during the late night on December, 2nd, 2020.  Cold air on the north side of the system, led to light snowfall amounts across most of south central Kansas.  Snowfall amounts were 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts generally ranged from 1 to 3 inches across the county, with the heaviest amounts over the southwest portions of the county.   A CocoRahs observer near Langdon, Kansas, reported 3.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As a strong cold front moved across Graham County, high winds gusted between 59 to 81 mph. Around 7:13 pm CDT, Graham County dispatch received a report of an out of control trash burning fire that was burning fields near the historic town of Nicodemus. The fire was close enough to town that the entire town was evacuated for a few hours as thirty five firefighters and 15 trucks responded from multiple counties to stop the fire. The Graham County Fire Department reported the fire was 1.5 miles wide and 2 miles long. The fire occurred to the south and southeast of Nicodemus and extended south to K-18 and east to the Rooks County line. Around 9:30 pm CDT, dispatch reported the fire had moved into Rooks County and was mostly under control or out completely. No injuries or structural damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved southeast across Rawlins County producing strong to high wind gusts ranging from 40 mph to 64 mph. The high winds lifted dirt into the air. The blowing dust reduced visibility to less than four blocks in the town of Atwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong southeastward cold front produced high wind gusts ranging from 27 to 81 mph. These high winds lasted for various durations of time, ranging from six minutes to one hour and fifty minutes after frontal passage. The high winds produced blowing dust with visibilities reduced to between one mile to as low as 10 yards at times across northwest Kansas. The strong winds knocked a few power lines down in Graham County which sparked a few small fires around the county and were quickly put out. The strong winds also caused a manure fire in southern Logan County to get out of hand; however, it was contained without causing damage. The most notable fire caused with this event was a grass fire caused from the embers of a burning trash fire in Graham County, which caused town-wide evacuations of Nicodemus. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced strong winds up to 63 mph which caused dirt to lift into the air. The blowing dust reduced visibility between one-half to one-quarter mile near the town of Halford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual October winter storm affected much of south central Kansas on October 26th and 27th. The event started during the early morning hours of Monday, October 26th as a mix of sleet and snow with a second round on Tuesday which consisted of mostly sleet and freezing rain. Locations across Cowley, Chautauqua, Elk and Montogomery counties saw the most significant ice accumulation. The towns of Winfield and especially Arkansas City were hit hard, with numerous reports of widespread power outages along with large trees down. ||Wichita set new snowfall records for both October 26th and 27th. The 1.3 inches on the 26th was the most snow Wichita has ever received that early.  The 1.6 inches from both days combined makes October 2020 the 2nd snowiest October on record for Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix occurred across the county.  Snow amounts were generally less than 0.5 inches and ice accumulations up to 0.15 inches were reported.
