EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm moved across southwest Kansas into northern Oklahoma during the late night on December, 2nd, 2020.  Cold air on the north side of the system, led to light snowfall amounts across most of south central Kansas.  Snowfall amounts were 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts generally ranged from one to three inches across the county, with the heaviest amounts over western sections of the county.   NWS employees in Wichita, reported two to 2.4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm moved across southwest Kansas into northern Oklahoma during the late night on December, 2nd, 2020.  Cold air on the north side of the system, led to light snowfall amounts across most of south central Kansas.  Snowfall amounts were 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts generally were one to two inches of snow across the county.  A Coop observer in Belle Plaine reported 1.0 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm moved across southwest Kansas into northern Oklahoma during the late night on December, 2nd, 2020.  Cold air on the north side of the system, led to light snowfall amounts across most of south central Kansas.  Snowfall amounts were 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts generally ranged from one to two inches across the county.  A Coop observer in Elbing, Kansas, reported 1.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong system ejected eastward into the central part of the country just after Christmas. While the temperatures at the surface remained well below freezing, temperatures just off the surface remained warm enough to melt any ice that was produced in the cloud. Therefore, there was freezing rain that formed, generally along the HWY 36 corridor, producing numerous power outages and causing several vehicle accidents.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the day on December 29, a potent winter storm moved into the area. The precipitation started as primarily snow during the morning hours producing a couple inches of accumulation, but switched to freezing rain just before 10 am as warm air aloft moved over the area. Moderate, to at times heavy rain ensued through the rest of the morning and early to middle afternoon hours, before eventually moving out by the evening hours. The main impact from this storm was 10,000 to 20,000 without power in and around the area. Due to the rain rates, not all of the nearly 1 inch of liquid precipitation accreted on surfaces, but a quarter to half inch did accrete, causing a significant disruption to the power, and closing numerous roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to high winds occurred over portions of Cheyenne, Sheridan, and Graham counties as a trough moved slowly across eastern Colorado into western Kansas. A ridge over the eastern United States blocked the low from moving from the western half of the country, which allowed the winds to impact the area for a few hours each day. Something unusual with this event, was the strong winds that occurred during the night Saturday into early Sunday morning. The strong to high winds produced gusts up to 60 mph and helped spread wildfires in Wichita, Norton, and Cheyenne counties. The fires in Wichita and Cheyenne counties were small field fires that were quickly extinguished with no structural damage. The fire in Norton County prompted a State of Emergency and the Kansas Forest Service flew their tanker plane to assist ground units with extinguishing the fire. The grass fire was mainly over open grass and cattle fields; however, an unknown amount of cattle fencing and a cattle pen was burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire just west of the town of Norton prompted the Governor of Kansas to declare a State of Emergency. The fire was originally a ditch fire that strong southerly winds, gusting up to 42 mph, brought out of control.  Kansas Forest Service deployed their tanker airplane to assist the eight ground units responding to the fire. The fire was mainly over open grass and cattle fields; however, an unknown amount of cattle fencing and a cattle pen was burned. It took nearly 8.5 hours to completely extinguish the fire that burned an unknown amount of acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station in far east Cheyenne County observed a maximum wind gust of 59 mph over a total duration of approximately two and a half hours and sustained winds of 40-47 mph for a duration of one hour within that time frame.

The 1.3 inches on the 26th was the most snow Wichita has ever received that early.  The 1.6 inches from both days combined makes October 2020 the 2nd snowiest October on record for Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix occurred across the county.  Snow amounts were generally less than 2 inches and ice accumulations up to 0.1 inches were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts for a couple of southern KS counties were quite impressive with totals over 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of 3.67 inches of rain was reported for the previous 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter weather system impacted the area bringing wide swaths of 5 to 7 inches of snow. Farther to the south, ice accumulated on top of the snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 4.0 inches of rain and accumulating sleet and freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the area bringing with it light snow fall and winds gusting up to 60 mph. Blizzard conditions were observed much of the area. Many other locations not in the blizzard warning, experience near blizzard conditions and had impacts warranting a Winter Storm warning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observations from ASOS confirmed blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the final week of August 2020, and for the first time since January 2017, a small portion of South Central Nebraska was assigned D2 Severe Drought by the weekly U.S. Drought Monitor. Specifically, D2 was assigned to much of Kearney and far western Adams counties, a bullseye of dryness within larger areas of both D1 Moderate Drought and D0 Abnormally Dry conditions that had gradually expanded in coverage/evolved during the previous few months. This introduction of D2 drought marked a relatively-rapid decline in moisture conditions within South Central Nebraska, as the entire 24-county area began the spring season completely void of all drought categories (including D0), and D1 did not show up within Kearney/Adams counties until July. ||Going into more background detail: the first several months of 2020 started out void of all drought concerns, largely due to a notably-wet 2019. However, during the later spring and early summer, Abnormally Dry (D0) to localized Moderate Drought (D1) began showing up mainly near and south of the Nebraska-Kansas border, while a wet May kept drought at bay across most local Nebraska counties. But then, rainfall patterns became quite interesting and highly-variable during June-July. Over the course of these two months, most northern, western and particularly southern portions of South Central Nebraska received appreciable rainfall (especially during July), while in contrast, a handful of counties in the heart of the area (particularly Kearney/Adams and parts of surrounding) kept missing out on one rain event after another, allowing Moderate Drought (D1) to take hold. Finally, August came around and nearly the ENTIRE 24-county area was dealt well-below-normal rain (most areas only 10-40 percent of the monthly normal). This lack of August rain, in tandem with a notably-hot nine-day stretch centered from Aug. 20-28 (highs in the 90s each day), finally prompted the introduction of this localized Severe Drought (D2). Focusing specifically on the NWS cooperative observer at Minden (the only official NWS precipitation site within the D2 area), there was no sign of trouble as late as May, which was a notably-wet month with 7.91 inches of rain (3.36 above normal). However, the proverbial faucet shut off quite drastically thereafter, as the combined months of June-August only yielded 3.77...merely 34 percent of the normal of 10.99. Fortunately, hot temperatures were not a major contributing drought factor during this 3-month stretch in the heart of the agricultural growing season, as readings only averaged slightly above normal during this time (1.4 degrees above normal at Minden). Given that drought materialized fairly rapidly during the summer and that the first part of the year (and the entirety of the preceding few years) had been rather wet, there were no widespread/serious drought impacts reported in the local area through the end of August, although local Nebraska Extension did note some drought stress in pastures and dryland crops.

Strong to high winds occurred over portions of Cheyenne, Sheridan, and Graham counties as a trough moved slowly across eastern Colorado into western Kansas. A ridge over the eastern United States blocked the low from moving from the western half of the country, which allowed the winds to impact the area for a few hours each day. Something unusual with this event, was the strong winds that occurred during the night Saturday into early Sunday morning. The strong to high winds produced gusts up to 60 mph and helped spread wildfires in Wichita, Norton, and Cheyenne counties. The fires in Wichita and Cheyenne counties were small field fires that were quickly extinguished with no structural damage. The fire in Norton County prompted a State of Emergency and the Kansas Forest Service flew their tanker plane to assist ground units with extinguishing the fire. The grass fire was mainly over open grass and cattle fields; however, an unknown amount of cattle fencing and a cattle pen was burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station located south of Selden, Kansas recorded wind gusts of 58-59 mph over a ten minute period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although it only impacted a small percentage of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, the large and intense supercell storm that marched south-southwestward for over 90 miles through several eastern counties on this Friday afternoon/early evening was likely the local area's most noteworthy individual storm of the 2020 convective season. In addition to dropping three fairly brief EF-0 tornadoes in southeastern Hamilton and northeastern Clay counties, its main calling card was large hail, with several reports of golf ball to slightly larger than baseball size stones in Clay/Nuckolls counties, and smaller hail to around quarter size as far north as Osceola. Interestingly, damaging winds were not a major player, with no ground-truth gusts in excess of 50 MPH. Focusing on specific storm reports, and starting with the three EF-0 tornadoes, they all occurred between 5-6 p.m. CDT, touching down briefly along a roughly 15-mile long corridor from near Interstate 80 a few miles south of Hampton, down to the Saronville area. Per storm surveys, the first two tornadoes were each on the ground for roughly 2 miles. While the majority of minor damage was confined to crops and trees, a lean-to shed was destroyed and a pivot overturned. As for the hail, the largest reported was 3 diameter between Clay Center and Harvard, but towns including Sutton and Nelson endured stones to at least tennis ball size. Flooding was not much of an issue, as the storm was progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch. ||Breaking down the meteorological background and event timing, this was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for South Central Nebraska, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C providing a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the afternoon. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding formidable mixed-layer CAPE around 4000 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection. As for what actually transpired, the main show was preceded by a broken line of non-severe, likely elevated storms that passed primarily through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 between 12:30-3:30 p.m. CDT. About the time this innocuous early afternoon activity was departing the local area to the southeast, a broken line of true, surface-based storms got going along the front in northeast Nebraska, with the southwestern-most cell building down into the far northeast corner of South Central Nebraska (eastern Nance/northeast Merrick/northern Polk counties) between 3-4 p.m. CDT. Within an hour thereafter, this tail end Charlie storm rapidly grew into a full-blown supercell over Polk/northern York counties, producing its first marginally-severe hail reports. During the following two hours (5-7 p.m. CDT), the storm anchored itself firmly to the surface front, with new updraft generation along its western edge promoting more of a southwestward propagation and causing it to grow larger in both intensity/size, becoming more of a supercell cluster. It was during this time that the brief tornadoes occurred along the storm's far western flank, likely driven by pronounced low-level vorticity stretching along the surface front. While the sporadic tornado touchdowns were brief, the storm continued to be a prolific hail-producer as it gradually exited the local area out of Nuckolls County into northern Kansas between 7-8 p.m. CDT, ending all South Central Nebraska convection for the night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second brief tornado over Clay County was confirmed through video and was located about 1.5 miles southeast of Saronville. This tornado lasted no more than a minute and there was no reported damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to high winds occurred over portions of Cheyenne, Sheridan, and Graham counties as a trough moved slowly across eastern Colorado into western Kansas. A ridge over the eastern United States blocked the low from moving from the western half of the country, which allowed the winds to impact the area for a few hours each day. Something unusual with this event, was the strong winds that occurred during the night Saturday into early Sunday morning. The strong to high winds produced gusts up to 60 mph and helped spread wildfires in Wichita, Norton, and Cheyenne counties. The fires in Wichita and Cheyenne counties were small field fires that were quickly extinguished with no structural damage. The fire in Norton County prompted a State of Emergency and the Kansas Forest Service flew their tanker plane to assist ground units with extinguishing the fire. The grass fire was mainly over open grass and cattle fields; however, an unknown amount of cattle fencing and a cattle pen was burned.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station located north of Bogue, Kansas recorded a peak wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between 8-930 p.m. CDT on this Friday evening, a lone severe storm roamed south-southeastward across portions of Osborne County, prompting a few reports of hail up to ping pong ball size. This supercell initiated in north central Osborne County, with the first report of quarter size hail from within the city of Osborne around 8:30 pm. CDT. During the next hour the storm tracked south-southeast through rural portions of the county as hail size increased to 1.5 diameter, with one resident reporting destroyed rose blooms. Around 9:30 p.m. CDT the now-weakening cell exited the county (and this North Central Kansas area altogether). Although additional, more widespread convection developed into the area a few hours later, these later-night storms were not severe. This sunset severe storm fired up slightly behind a surface cold front slipping southward through the region, as weak low level convergence was able to locally overcome fairly strong capping (as evidenced by 700 millibar temperature around 12C). Despite the passing front, surface dewpoints still held up in the upper 60s F near the storm, promoting decent instability as the evening mesoscale environment featured 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 35 knots of deep-layer wind shear. In the mid-upper levels, broad west-northwest flow prevailed over northern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail of quarter to ping pong ball size was reported along this swath.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arguably the most noteworthy individual thunderstorm of the 2020 convective season within this six-county North Central Kansas area rolled southward across portions of Jewell, Mitchell and mainly eastern Osborne counties on this Friday evening, highlighted by several reports of large to very large hail. Of the counties impacted by this supercell, Jewell was hardest-hit, as copious amounts of tennis ball to softball size hail stones crashed down onto areas in and near the communities of Mankato and Jewell, causing extensive damage to homes, vehicles and area crops. The hail size toned down somewhat farther south into Mitchell and Osborne counties, where limited reports included ping pong ball size stones in Cawker City and golf ball size south of Osborne. Although damaging winds were not a major player during this event, several mesonets clocked gusts of at least 40-50 MPH, and a Kansas Mesonet site near Jewell reached severe-criteria with 65 MPH. Flooding was not much of an issue, with convection staying progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch.||Breaking down event timing and meteorological background, this giant storm invaded northern Jewell County between 7-8 pm. CDT, having already propagated south-southwestward for roughly 90 miles since its inception in east central Nebraska about three hours prior. As it drifted southward into Mitchell County between 8-9 p.m. CDT it started merging with a much smaller, separate storm that had flared up over central Osborne County. Finally, between 9-10 p.m. CDT, the now-merged supercell cluster continued southward while exiting the local area into central Kansas, ending all local storms for the night. This was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for North Central Kansas, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided a fair distance south of a vigorous shortwave trough swinging across the Dakotas towards northern MN, resulting in fairly limited forcing aloft. Also working against convection (especially widespread severe) was a plume of warm mid level temperatures, with 700 millibar values of 12-14C promoting a healthy cap. On the other hand, low-level forcing was seasonably-strong, as a well-defined cold front slid southeastward into the area during the evening. Ahead of this boundary, a significantly-unstable airmass awaited, featuring temperatures in the upper 80s-low 90s F/dewpoints upper 60s-mid 70s F, yielding impressive mixed-layer CAPE up to around 4500 J/kg. This extreme instability, in the presence of sufficient deep-layer wind shear around 35 knots, clearly fostered a mesoscale environment capable of stout convection.

While the majority of minor damage was confined to crops and trees, a lean-to shed was destroyed and a pivot overturned. As for the hail, the largest reported was 3 diameter between Clay Center and Harvard, but towns including Sutton and Nelson endured stones to at least tennis ball size. Flooding was not much of an issue, as the storm was progressive enough to keep rainfall amounts largely under one inch. ||Breaking down the meteorological background and event timing, this was actually a fairly conditional severe weather setup for South Central Nebraska, with various pros and cons for/against robust activity. It was during this time that the brief tornadoes occurred along the storm's far western flank, likely driven by pronounced low-level vorticity stretching along the surface front. While the sporadic tornado touchdowns were brief, the storm continued to be a prolific hail-producer as it gradually exited the local area out of Nuckolls County into northern Kansas between 7-8 p.m. CDT, ending all South Central Nebraska convection for the night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranging in size from half dollars to baseballs was reported in Sutton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts for a couple of southern KS counties were quite impressive with totals over 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of 3.00 inches of rain was reported for the previous 24 hours.

Many other locations not in the blizzard warning, experience near blizzard conditions and had impacts warranting a Winter Storm warning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Personal weather station measured peak wind gust of 61 mph. Blizzard verified from area reports.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions verified by analysis of conditions from surrounding counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lack of significant precipitation maintained drought status during December.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe (D2) drought persisted through December.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mainly between midnight and 4 a.m. CDT on this early Thursday morning, scattered strong-to-briefly-severe thunderstorms rumbled along a narrow corridor of South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast, primarily affecting these counties: Dawson, Buffalo, Hall, Adams, Clay, Fillmore and Thayer. Although radar data suggested that spotty hail to at least nickel size likely occurred within various counties, ground-truth verification was quite limited, consisting of only a few reports of penny to quarter size stones in Hastings around 1:30 a.m. CDT, followed a short time later by the only severe-criteria report of the event: golf ball size hail at Inland in western Clay County. A few hours later (around 4 a.m. CDT), the final strong local storms of the morning dissipated over eastern Fillmore/Thayer counties. There were no reports of strong/severe wind gusts. ||This somewhat-unexpected nocturnal convection (at least in terms of intensity) initiated in the local area over Dawson County shortly before midnight CDT, roughly 50 miles east of a small cluster of strong storms already ongoing off to the west, and roughly 75-100 miles north of the centroid of a small mesoscale convective system (MCS) sliding across northern Kansas (in fact the local storms appeared to be a northward-displaced offshoot of the Kansas MCS). Whether or not the local convection was directly tied to the activity farther south, mesoscale analysis revealed that it was likely sparked by a subtle ribbon of low-mid level warm air/moisture advection within a weak southwesterly low level jet axis (winds at 850 millibars less than 25 knots). Convective parameters were at least marginally-supportive of sporadic intense updrafts, featuring around 1500 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and up to around 30 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

Mainly within an hour either side of midnight CDT on the night of Sunday the 9th into Monday the 10th, a fairly pronounced heat burst (perhaps a series of them) affected Rooks County, prompting both measured/estimated wind gusts up to around 70 MPH. On the south side of Stockton, a mesonet recorded a peak gust of 61 MPH, and there were reports of some minor tree damage in town. Another mesonet station between Palco and Zurich displayed tell-tale signs of a heat burst in its temperature/dewpoint data, as the observation around 9 p.m. CDT was 86/67 F, but closer to midnight had warmed/dried notably to 94/48 F, before gradually stabilizing (cooling/moistening) through the pre-dawn hours. The most telling personal evidence of heat burst activity came from Rooks County State Park, where a man relayed an account of being caught off guard by a low roaring sound followed by several minutes of strong winds he estimated to be at least 70 MPH, which damaged some trees. He noted how unusual the situation was given the lack of obvious thunderstorm activity in the immediate area. From a meteorological standpoint, this was a fairly classic setup for nocturnal heat burst activity. For one, radar data confirmed that Rooks County was underneath high-based, light precipitation, generally 20-60 miles north of a small cluster of thunderstorms drifting east-southeast outside the local area. Mesoscale analysis also confirmed very warm mid level temperatures were present (around 14 C at 700 millibars), along with steep mid level lapse rates. The preceding afternoon of the 9th was quite hot across north central Kansas, with high temperatures well into the mid-upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat burst wind gusts estimated to be as high as 70 MPH resulted in mainly some tree damage in and around the Stockton area, including at Rooks County State Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought intense non-thunderstorm and thunderstorm-related wind gusts to south central Nebraska on Sunday evening the 11th. This front entered western portions of the Hastings NWS county warning area (CWA) around 7pm CDT. The cold front already had a history of producing severe caliber, non-thunderstorm, straight line winds over western and central Nebraska, and this trend continued along and just behind the cold front as it marched through south central Nebraska. The strongest winds, initially, were focused roughly along an area from Furnas County northeast into Buffalo County, where measured and estimated wind gusts of 55-65 mph were fairly common. Damage reports from these areas were fairly typical for winds of this magnitude and mainly limited to tree and power line damage. By 7:30pm CDT, an area of showers and thunderstorms developed along and just behind the cold front over Kearney and Franklin Counties as the cold front continued to progress east. This activity reached roughly the Highway 281 corridor from Grand Island to Hastings around 8pm CDT. Wind gusts associated with the passage of the cold front had weakened slightly by this time, but were still quite strong around 50-55 mph, with mainly minor tree damage and power outages reported in the Tri Cities. After 8pm CDT, the area of thunderstorms began to expand northeast and connected up with existing thunderstorms that had already developed along the cold front over northeast and east central Nebraska, essentially filling in a gap that had existed in between the two thunderstorm clusters. Thunderstorm intensity increased just east of Hastings between 8pm CDT and 8:30pm CDT, such that the wind gusts produced by the thunderstorms exacerbated the already-high ambient synoptically driven non-thunderstorm wind gusts associated with the cold front. This resulted in the strongest wind gusts of the evening, generally 60 to 70mph, in a swath that covered portions of Clay, Fillmore, and Thayer Counties. Significant tree damage occurred in these areas, along with damage to a few empty grain bins. Another significant impact, albeit somewhat less obvious or common than typical tree/power line damage, was blowing dust and corn stalks (this event occurred during the harvest season) that led to reduced visibility and ultimately contributed to a four-vehicle accident along Highway 81 just north of Bruning. Another incidence of poor visibility caused a vehicle to leave the roadway in Clay County. ||The highest wind gust with this event was 71 mph, measured by a mesonet station in Thayer County. As mentioned above, the damaging wind events in the eastern half of the CWA were largely driven by convective winds that enhanced already-high ambient winds. Farther west, the severe wind was non-convective and driven by intense pressure rises behind the cold front on the order of 3-5 mb/2 hrs. Overall, this event was one of the more significant wind events of the season and was somewhat unique due to the narrow overlap, spatially and temporally, of both convective and non-convective damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH caused minor tree damage and downed power lines in Clay Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two separate rounds of mostly non-severe thunderstorms swept through South Central Nebraska from northwest-to-southeast on this Monday afternoon and evening. During the first round, one storm briefly pulsed up to severe levels over Polk County around 4:30 p.m. CDT, as estimated 60 MPH winds felled a large tree branch onto an attached garage in Osceola. Elsewhere in the area, a few near-severe-criteria storm reports included: 54 MPH gusts near Oxford (during the second round of storms), 52 MPH at York airport and penny to nickel size hail in Fillmore County. ||The first round of isolated to scattered convection affected mainly the northeastern one-third of the local area (primarily east of a Greeley-Aurora-Hebron line), first entering counties such as Greeley/Nance between 3-4 p.m. CDT and exiting Fillmore/Thayer counties between 6-7 p.m. CDT. Meanwhile, the second round of storms arrived a bit later and farther west (mainly affecting areas southwest of a Loup City-Hastings-Superior line), entering Dawson/Buffalo counties between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT and exiting southward into Kansas between 8-9 p.m. CDT. Long before reaching South Central Nebraska, both rounds of convection initiated well to the north-northwest (near the NE-SD border) early in the afternoon. This was a fairly classic northwest-flow-aloft event, as the Central Plains resided within the path of several small-scale disturbances tracking southeastward around the periphery of a larger-scale trough centered over south central Canada. Despite only modest low-level moisture in the wake of a secondary cold front, this convection made the most of steep low-level lapse rates and seasonably-cool mid level temps, with mid-late afternoon mesoscale parameters in South Central Nebraska featuring 1000-1500 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 25-35 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

A storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the overnight hours on October 24th, which continued October 25th into the early morning hours on October 26th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to 9 inches with local amounts a high as 10 to 14 inches from southern Garden County into Deuel County. North to northeast winds of 15 to 25 mph caused some minor blowing and drifting with visibilities as low as a half mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located in Bassett reported 8 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts from 4 to 8 inches were common across Rock County. North to northeast winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the overnight hours on October 24th, which continued October 25th into the early morning hours on October 26th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to 9 inches with local amounts a high as 10 to 14 inches from southern Garden County into Deuel County. North to northeast winds of 15 to 25 mph caused some minor blowing and drifting with visibilities as low as a half mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located 30 miles south of Valentine reported 8 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts from 4 to 8 inches were common across eastern Cherry County. North to northeast winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the overnight hours on October 24th, which continued October 25th into the early morning hours on October 26th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to 9 inches with local amounts a high as 10 to 14 inches from southern Garden County into Deuel County. North to northeast winds of 15 to 25 mph caused some minor blowing and drifting with visibilities as low as a half mile.

North winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred the afternoon of 11 October 2020 with wind gusts above 58 mph near Scottsbluff, Chadron, and Kimball.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scottsbluff RAWS site reported wind gusts of 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred the afternoon of 11 October 2020 with wind gusts above 58 mph near Scottsbluff, Chadron, and Kimball.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Charlie and Bravo Mesonet sites both reported sustained winds of 40 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred the afternoon of 11 October 2020 with wind gusts above 58 mph near Scottsbluff, Chadron, and Kimball.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dix UPR site reported peak gust of 63 mph. Kilo Mesonet site and Kimball AWOS site reported wind gusts in excess of 58 mph.

This resulted in the strongest wind gusts of the evening, generally 60 to 70mph, in a swath that covered portions of Clay, Fillmore, and Thayer Counties. Significant tree damage occurred in these areas, along with damage to a few empty grain bins. Another significant impact, albeit somewhat less obvious or common than typical tree/power line damage, was blowing dust and corn stalks (this event occurred during the harvest season) that led to reduced visibility and ultimately contributed to a four-vehicle accident along Highway 81 just north of Bruning. Another incidence of poor visibility caused a vehicle to leave the roadway in Clay County. ||The highest wind gust with this event was 71 mph, measured by a mesonet station in Thayer County. As mentioned above, the damaging wind events in the eastern half of the CWA were largely driven by convective winds that enhanced already-high ambient winds. Farther west, the severe wind was non-convective and driven by intense pressure rises behind the cold front on the order of 3-5 mb/2 hrs. Overall, this event was one of the more significant wind events of the season and was somewhat unique due to the narrow overlap, spatially and temporally, of both convective and non-convective damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 60 MPH was recorded by a mesonet station located 4 miles southwest of Harvard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought intense non-thunderstorm and thunderstorm-related wind gusts to south central Nebraska on Sunday evening the 11th. This front entered western portions of the Hastings NWS county warning area (CWA) around 7pm CDT. The cold front already had a history of producing severe caliber, non-thunderstorm, straight line winds over western and central Nebraska, and this trend continued along and just behind the cold front as it marched through south central Nebraska. The strongest winds, initially, were focused roughly along an area from Furnas County northeast into Buffalo County, where measured and estimated wind gusts of 55-65 mph were fairly common. Damage reports from these areas were fairly typical for winds of this magnitude and mainly limited to tree and power line damage. By 7:30pm CDT, an area of showers and thunderstorms developed along and just behind the cold front over Kearney and Franklin Counties as the cold front continued to progress east. This activity reached roughly the Highway 281 corridor from Grand Island to Hastings around 8pm CDT. Wind gusts associated with the passage of the cold front had weakened slightly by this time, but were still quite strong around 50-55 mph, with mainly minor tree damage and power outages reported in the Tri Cities. After 8pm CDT, the area of thunderstorms began to expand northeast and connected up with existing thunderstorms that had already developed along the cold front over northeast and east central Nebraska, essentially filling in a gap that had existed in between the two thunderstorm clusters. Significant tree damage occurred in these areas, along with damage to a few empty grain bins. Another significant impact, albeit somewhat less obvious or common than typical tree/power line damage, was blowing dust and corn stalks (this event occurred during the harvest season) that led to reduced visibility and ultimately contributed to a four-vehicle accident along Highway 81 just north of Bruning. Another incidence of poor visibility caused a vehicle to leave the roadway in Clay County. ||The highest wind gust with this event was 71 mph, measured by a mesonet station in Thayer County. As mentioned above, the damaging wind events in the eastern half of the CWA were largely driven by convective winds that enhanced already-high ambient winds. Farther west, the severe wind was non-convective and driven by intense pressure rises behind the cold front on the order of 3-5 mb/2 hrs. Overall, this event was one of the more significant wind events of the season and was somewhat unique due to the narrow overlap, spatially and temporally, of both convective and non-convective damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 62 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 1 mile southwest of Roseland.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 65 MPH caused downed tree branches in Bruning of at least 4 inches in diameter. An empty 500 gallen water tank was blown onto Main Street. There was a 4 vehicle accident on Highway 81 just north of Bruning due to poor visibility in blowing dust and corn stalks. Two of the vehicles were total losses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought intense non-thunderstorm and thunderstorm related wind gusts to north central Kansas on the evening of October 11th. This front entered western portions of north central Kansas between 7pm and 8pm CDT. The cold front already had a history of producing severe caliber, non-thunderstorm, straight line winds over western Nebraska and Kansas, and this trend continued along and just behind the cold front as it marched through north central Kansas. There were several reports of wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph across Phillips, Smith, and Osborne Counties. Damage reports from these areas were fairly typical for winds of this magnitude and mainly limited to tree and power line damage. Thunderstorms began to develop along the cold front as it moved farther east into Jewell County between 8:30pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorm intensity increased between 9pm CDT and 9:30pm CDT, such that the wind gusts produced by the thunderstorms enhanced the already-high ambient synoptically driven non-thunderstorm wind gusts associated with the cold front. This resulted in additional 60 to 65 mph wind gusts across portions of Jewell County. No specific damage reports were received from this area. Wind gusts decreased as thunderstorms exited Jewell County by 10pm CDT.||As mentioned above, the damaging wind events in the eastern half of north central Kansas were largely driven by convective winds that enhanced already-high ambient winds. Farther west, the severe wind was non-convective and driven by intense pressure rises behind the cold front on the order of 3-5 mb per 2 hrs. This event was somewhat unique due to the narrow overlap, spatially and temporally, of both convective and non-convective damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in tree damage and downed power lines across portions of the county, especially in the town of Osborne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two separate rounds of mostly non-severe thunderstorms swept through South Central Nebraska from northwest-to-southeast on this Monday afternoon and evening. During the first round, one storm briefly pulsed up to severe levels over Polk County around 4:30 p.m. CDT, as estimated 60 MPH winds felled a large tree branch onto an attached garage in Osceola. Elsewhere in the area, a few near-severe-criteria storm reports included: 54 MPH gusts near Oxford (during the second round of storms), 52 MPH at York airport and penny to nickel size hail in Fillmore County. ||The first round of isolated to scattered convection affected mainly the northeastern one-third of the local area (primarily east of a Greeley-Aurora-Hebron line), first entering counties such as Greeley/Nance between 3-4 p.m. CDT and exiting Fillmore/Thayer counties between 6-7 p.m. CDT. Meanwhile, the second round of storms arrived a bit later and farther west (mainly affecting areas southwest of a Loup City-Hastings-Superior line), entering Dawson/Buffalo counties between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT and exiting southward into Kansas between 8-9 p.m. CDT. Long before reaching South Central Nebraska, both rounds of convection initiated well to the north-northwest (near the NE-SD border) early in the afternoon. This was a fairly classic northwest-flow-aloft event, as the Central Plains resided within the path of several small-scale disturbances tracking southeastward around the periphery of a larger-scale trough centered over south central Canada. Despite only modest low-level moisture in the wake of a secondary cold front, this convection made the most of steep low-level lapse rates and seasonably-cool mid level temps, with mid-late afternoon mesoscale parameters in South Central Nebraska featuring 1000-1500 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 25-35 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

This was an active late Friday evening-early Saturday morning across this six-county North Central Kansas area, featuring limited severe weather in Rooks/Phillips counties and some relatively minor flooding mainly within the northeast one-third of Mitchell County. But for the majority of the area this was just a classic, stormy early-summer night (most places measured between 0.50-2.00 inches of rain). As for the handful of severe weather reports, the main issue was a brief burst of intense winds through Rooks County around 2 a.m. CDT, including measured unofficial gusts of 68 MPH north-northeast of Codell, 62 MPH in Stockton and 61 MPH at Plainville (no known damage reports). Hail-wise, the only report featured quarter size stones east of Phillipsburg shortly after 11 p.m. CDT. Regarding heavy rainfall/flooding, primarily northeast Mitchell County was drenched with multiple downpours between midnight-4 a.m. CDT, with several automated gauges and NWS/CoCoRaHS observers tallying 3-5, including 5.05 just northeast of Beloit (unofficial public report of 6 at Simpson). This prompted relatively minor/short-term flash flooding and areal flooding, and also drove the Solomon River out of its banks as the Beloit gauge crested around 22.4 feet on the afternoon of the 27th (flood stage 20 feet). ||Timing-wise, there were basically two main rounds of convection. The first round (mainly 10 p.m. to 2 a.m. CDT) featured generally isolated to scattered coverage, as storms developed directly overhead in response to the onset of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars). Then, primarily 2-4 a.m. CDT the next round charged in from the west in the form of a fairly compact linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) that had gotten its act together well before midnight along the KS/CO border. By 4 a.m. CDT, storm intensity had waned considerably across local counties, although mainly stratiform lighter rain held on through around sunrise. This was a fairly typical setup for active nocturnal storms in the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, broad zonal flow reigned as a low amplitude wave rode eastward out of CO during the night. Meanwhile at the surface, a nearly stationary front resided directly through the area in east-northeast to west-southwest fashion, as evening dewpoints averaged mid-60s to around 70 F. Though fairly warm mid-level temps/weak capping held storms at bay until after sunset, the onset of the low level jet easily sparked convection given a healthy reservoir of 2000-3000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE, with the main limiting factor to a more robust severe threat being only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.

Though fairly warm mid-level temps/weak capping held storms at bay until after sunset, the onset of the low level jet easily sparked convection given a healthy reservoir of 2000-3000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE, with the main limiting factor to a more robust severe threat being only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.

This was an active late Friday evening-early Saturday morning across this six-county North Central Kansas area, featuring limited severe weather in Rooks/Phillips counties and some relatively minor flooding mainly within the northeast one-third of Mitchell County. But for the majority of the area this was just a classic, stormy early-summer night (most places measured between 0.50-2.00 inches of rain). As for the handful of severe weather reports, the main issue was a brief burst of intense winds through Rooks County around 2 a.m. CDT, including measured unofficial gusts of 68 MPH north-northeast of Codell, 62 MPH in Stockton and 61 MPH at Plainville (no known damage reports). Hail-wise, the only report featured quarter size stones east of Phillipsburg shortly after 11 p.m. CDT. Regarding heavy rainfall/flooding, primarily northeast Mitchell County was drenched with multiple downpours between midnight-4 a.m. CDT, with several automated gauges and NWS/CoCoRaHS observers tallying 3-5, including 5.05 just northeast of Beloit (unofficial public report of 6 at Simpson). This prompted relatively minor/short-term flash flooding and areal flooding, and also drove the Solomon River out of its banks as the Beloit gauge crested around 22.4 feet on the afternoon of the 27th (flood stage 20 feet). ||Timing-wise, there were basically two main rounds of convection. The first round (mainly 10 p.m. to 2 a.m. CDT) featured generally isolated to scattered coverage, as storms developed directly overhead in response to the onset of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars). Then, primarily 2-4 a.m. CDT the next round charged in from the west in the form of a fairly compact linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) that had gotten its act together well before midnight along the KS/CO border. By 4 a.m. CDT, storm intensity had waned considerably across local counties, although mainly stratiform lighter rain held on through around sunrise. This was a fairly typical setup for active nocturnal storms in the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, broad zonal flow reigned as a low amplitude wave rode eastward out of CO during the night. Meanwhile at the surface, a nearly stationary front resided directly through the area in east-northeast to west-southwest fashion, as evening dewpoints averaged mid-60s to around 70 F. Though fairly warm mid-level temps/weak capping held storms at bay until after sunset, the onset of the low level jet easily sparked convection given a healthy reservoir of 2000-3000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE, with the main limiting factor to a more robust severe threat being only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the overnight hours on October 24th, which continued October 25th into the early morning hours on October 26th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to 9 inches with local amounts a high as 10 to 14 inches from southern Garden County into Deuel County. North to northeast winds of 15 to 25 mph caused some minor blowing and drifting with visibilities as low as a half mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Cooperative observer located 6 miles north of Gordon reported 6.5 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts from 6 to 8 inches were common across Sheridan County. North winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

North to northeast winds of 15 to 25 mph caused some minor blowing and drifting with visibilities as low as a half mile.

North to northeast winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located 22 miles southwest of Hyannis reported 8 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts from 6 to 8 inches were common across Grant County. North to northeast winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer located nine miles northeast of Harrison reported 7.0 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter nine miles northeast of Henry reported 6.0 inches of snow at 25/1251. Highest snow reported was five miles northeast of Henry with 7.0 inches at 25/1255PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highest snow report received was from an observer four miles northwest of Box Butte Dam who reported 12.0 inches of snow at 25/223PM. First report of warning level snow was received in Chadron at 25/1045 AM of 6.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought intense non-thunderstorm and thunderstorm-related wind gusts to south central Nebraska on Sunday evening the 11th. This front entered western portions of the Hastings NWS county warning area (CWA) around 7pm CDT. The cold front already had a history of producing severe caliber, non-thunderstorm, straight line winds over western and central Nebraska, and this trend continued along and just behind the cold front as it marched through south central Nebraska. The strongest winds, initially, were focused roughly along an area from Furnas County northeast into Buffalo County, where measured and estimated wind gusts of 55-65 mph were fairly common. Damage reports from these areas were fairly typical for winds of this magnitude and mainly limited to tree and power line damage. By 7:30pm CDT, an area of showers and thunderstorms developed along and just behind the cold front over Kearney and Franklin Counties as the cold front continued to progress east. This activity reached roughly the Highway 281 corridor from Grand Island to Hastings around 8pm CDT. Wind gusts associated with the passage of the cold front had weakened slightly by this time, but were still quite strong around 50-55 mph, with mainly minor tree damage and power outages reported in the Tri Cities. After 8pm CDT, the area of thunderstorms began to expand northeast and connected up with existing thunderstorms that had already developed along the cold front over northeast and east central Nebraska, essentially filling in a gap that had existed in between the two thunderstorm clusters. Thunderstorm intensity increased just east of Hastings between 8pm CDT and 8:30pm CDT, such that the wind gusts produced by the thunderstorms exacerbated the already-high ambient synoptically driven non-thunderstorm wind gusts associated with the cold front. This resulted in the strongest wind gusts of the evening, generally 60 to 70mph, in a swath that covered portions of Clay, Fillmore, and Thayer Counties. Significant tree damage occurred in these areas, along with damage to a few empty grain bins. Another significant impact, albeit somewhat less obvious or common than typical tree/power line damage, was blowing dust and corn stalks (this event occurred during the harvest season) that led to reduced visibility and ultimately contributed to a four-vehicle accident along Highway 81 just north of Bruning. Another incidence of poor visibility caused a vehicle to leave the roadway in Clay County. ||The highest wind gust with this event was 71 mph, measured by a mesonet station in Thayer County. As mentioned above, the damaging wind events in the eastern half of the CWA were largely driven by convective winds that enhanced already-high ambient winds. Farther west, the severe wind was non-convective and driven by intense pressure rises behind the cold front on the order of 3-5 mb/2 hrs. Overall, this event was one of the more significant wind events of the season and was somewhat unique due to the narrow overlap, spatially and temporally, of both convective and non-convective damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 71 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located 1 mile south-southeast of Davenport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The morning and early afternoon of Saturday the 6th featured scattered, mainly weak thunderstorms within northern and especially western portions of South Central Nebraska (particularly areas west of the Highway 183 corridor). However, one storm briefly spiked up to severe levels over far northern Furnas and southern Gosper counties between 8:30-9:30 a.m. CDT, yielding reports of quarter size hail covering Highway 283 several miles north of Arapahoe along with nickel size hail south-southwest of Smithfield. ||This short-lived morning severe storm was a bit of a surprise, as earlier activity that drifted through counties north of I-80 before sunrise was fairly weak, as were other morning/early afternoon storms that developed across portions of mainly Furnas/Gosper/Dawson/Phelps counties. All convection departed/lifted north of the local area by 1-2 p.m. CDT. As best could be surmised, this flare up of early-day convection was tied to a burst of low-mid level warm air advection, within the exit region of a gradually-weakening low level jet (evident at 850 millibars). At the surface, a fairly well-defined warm front blasted north across Nebraska over the course of the day. In the mid-upper levels, flow was fairly anemic over the local area as ridging prevailed aloft, downstream from a potent shortwave trough ejecting north-northeast across the Intermountain West. Mesoscale severe weather parameters in the Gosper County area around the time of the brief severe storm were relatively modest, featuring around 1000-2000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE but only 25 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

A smattering of strong to severe thunderstorms roamed South Central Nebraska from the early evening of Saturday the 20th into the very early morning of Sunday the 21st, prompting a few hail reports from widely-varying locations. The largest reported hail, ping pong to golf ball size, occurred in far southwestern Furnas County near Wilsonville. Later, quarter size stones fell from other storms at Wood River, Genoa and Silver Creek, although the late-night report from Silver Creek implied that much larger hail might have transpired (observer unable to confirm a maximum size). ||Isolated storms first drifted into western portions of the 24-county area between 6-8 p.m. CDT, after initiating a few hours prior in west-central Nebraska along a north-south oriented surface trough. These initial storms included the one that produced the large hail in Furnas County. Between 8-11 p.m. CDT the vast majority of limited storm activity was rather weak, with the main exception of the briefly-severe storm that produced the 1-inch hail in Hall County. Then, about the time it appeared that any severe threat had ended for the night, a small cluster of storms began intensifying over eastern Nance County around midnight CDT, likely in response to the onset of a fairly weak southwesterly low level jet. Over the next few hours, this convection briefly morphed into a supercell that drifted southeast across portions of Nance, Merrick and Polk counties (yielding the Genoa and Silver Creek hail reports) before departing the local area around 2 a.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was provided by a low-amplitude shortwave trough translating across Nebraska in west-northwest flow, well-south of a larger-scale trough anchored over south central Canada. Mesoscale parameters over South Central Nebraska during the evening were certainly supportive of severe storms, featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer reported mainly pea to nickel size hail, with occasional larger stones. Size of largest hail is unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was an active late Friday evening-early Saturday morning across this six-county North Central Kansas area, featuring limited severe weather in Rooks/Phillips counties and some relatively minor flooding mainly within the northeast one-third of Mitchell County. But for the majority of the area this was just a classic, stormy early-summer night (most places measured between 0.50-2.00 inches of rain). As for the handful of severe weather reports, the main issue was a brief burst of intense winds through Rooks County around 2 a.m. CDT, including measured unofficial gusts of 68 MPH north-northeast of Codell, 62 MPH in Stockton and 61 MPH at Plainville (no known damage reports). Hail-wise, the only report featured quarter size stones east of Phillipsburg shortly after 11 p.m. CDT. Regarding heavy rainfall/flooding, primarily northeast Mitchell County was drenched with multiple downpours between midnight-4 a.m. CDT, with several automated gauges and NWS/CoCoRaHS observers tallying 3-5, including 5.05 just northeast of Beloit (unofficial public report of 6 at Simpson). This prompted relatively minor/short-term flash flooding and areal flooding, and also drove the Solomon River out of its banks as the Beloit gauge crested around 22.4 feet on the afternoon of the 27th (flood stage 20 feet). ||Timing-wise, there were basically two main rounds of convection. The first round (mainly 10 p.m. to 2 a.m. CDT) featured generally isolated to scattered coverage, as storms developed directly overhead in response to the onset of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars). Then, primarily 2-4 a.m. CDT the next round charged in from the west in the form of a fairly compact linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) that had gotten its act together well before midnight along the KS/CO border. By 4 a.m. CDT, storm intensity had waned considerably across local counties, although mainly stratiform lighter rain held on through around sunrise. This was a fairly typical setup for active nocturnal storms in the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, broad zonal flow reigned as a low amplitude wave rode eastward out of CO during the night. Meanwhile at the surface, a nearly stationary front resided directly through the area in east-northeast to west-southwest fashion, as evening dewpoints averaged mid-60s to around 70 F. Though fairly warm mid-level temps/weak capping held storms at bay until after sunset, the onset of the low level jet easily sparked convection given a healthy reservoir of 2000-3000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE, with the main limiting factor to a more robust severe threat being only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24-hour rainfall amount of 5.05 inches was reported by a CoCoRaHs observer. In the south part of town, the NWS cooperative observer measured 4.20 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While the majority of South Central Nebraska had a mostly dry and storm-free late Friday evening-early Saturday morning, far south-southeast portions of the area (largely south of a Franklin-Geneva line) experienced a more active night as several storms rumbled through mainly during the 11 p.m. to 4 a.m. CDT time frame. Most of this convection was non-severe, but there was a lone report of half dollar size hail in Franklin from a briefly-feisty storm that snuck north out of Kansas. Radar data also suggested that marginally-severe hail might have affected southern portions of Nuckolls/Thayer counties, but there were no substantiating reports. Rainfall-wise, most locations under the main swath of storms measured 0.50-1.50. ||These overnight storms represented the far northern fringes of convection that mainly concentrated just south of the area across northern Kansas. Activity blossomed after dark in response to the onset of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars). This was a typical setup for active nocturnal convection in the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, broad zonal flow reigned as a low amplitude wave rode eastward out of CO during the night. Meanwhile at the surface, a nearly stationary front cut almost directly through the area in east-northeast to west-southwest fashion, as late-evening dewpoints averaged upper-60s to around 70 F. While fairly warm mid level temps/weak capping held pre-nightfall storms at bay in far South Central Nebraska, it was a close call, as an isolated severe storm blew up barely to the south (over Republic County KS) between 8-9 p.m. CDT. But then after dark, the onset of the low level jet easily ignited convection slightly north of the state line given a healthy reservoir of 2000-3000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE, with the main limiting factor to a more robust severe threat being only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.

A strong cold front pushed through the CWA with strong north winds behind it. A strong pressure gradient and cold air advection behind the cold front gave way to dust and wind gusts ranging from 55-75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This report was received from 1E of Scott State Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system caused winter storm conditions to develop during the overnight hours on October 24th, which continued October 25th into the early morning hours on October 26th. Total snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to 9 inches with local amounts a high as 10 to 14 inches from southern Garden County into Deuel County. North to northeast winds of 15 to 25 mph caused some minor blowing and drifting with visibilities as low as a half mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located in Mullen reported 7 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts from 5 to 7 inches were common across Hooker County. North to northeast winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

North to northeast winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

North to northeast winds ranged as high as 15 to 25 mph at times and caused minor blowing and drifting with visibility as low as a half mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report from Alliance reported 10.0 inches of snow at 25/0800. Highest snowfall report was from one mile northeast of Alliance at 25/1300 of 11.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 7.5 inches of snow in Gering at 25/645AM. Highest snow total reported was 12.0 inches nine miles southeast of Lyman at 25/1000AM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer reported 9.5 inches of snowfall received in Harrisburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from public seven miles north of Bushnell with maximum snowfall report of 12.0 inches. Interstate 80 closed through Kimball County 25/1600 with plows working over seven hours to clear the roadway for traffic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter in Potter reported 6.0 inches of snow. Highest snow report was 14.0 inches from spotter located in Dalton at 25/1317. Interstate 80 was closed in Cheyenne County 25/1600 with a closure time of of roughly up to nine hours as crews worked to clear the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the Nebraska Panhandle the evening of 24 October and continued into Sunday, October 25th, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from four miles south of Redington reported 7.0 inches of snow. Highest report received from eight miles northeast of Dalton of 14.0 inches at 25/513PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought intense non-thunderstorm and thunderstorm related wind gusts to north central Kansas on the evening of October 11th. This front entered western portions of north central Kansas between 7pm and 8pm CDT. The cold front already had a history of producing severe caliber, non-thunderstorm, straight line winds over western Nebraska and Kansas, and this trend continued along and just behind the cold front as it marched through north central Kansas. There were several reports of wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph across Phillips, Smith, and Osborne Counties. Damage reports from these areas were fairly typical for winds of this magnitude and mainly limited to tree and power line damage. Thunderstorms began to develop along the cold front as it moved farther east into Jewell County between 8:30pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorm intensity increased between 9pm CDT and 9:30pm CDT, such that the wind gusts produced by the thunderstorms enhanced the already-high ambient synoptically driven non-thunderstorm wind gusts associated with the cold front. This resulted in additional 60 to 65 mph wind gusts across portions of Jewell County. No specific damage reports were received from this area. Wind gusts decreased as thunderstorms exited Jewell County by 10pm CDT.||As mentioned above, the damaging wind events in the eastern half of north central Kansas were largely driven by convective winds that enhanced already-high ambient winds. Farther west, the severe wind was non-convective and driven by intense pressure rises behind the cold front on the order of 3-5 mb per 2 hrs. This event was somewhat unique due to the narrow overlap, spatially and temporally, of both convective and non-convective damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 64 MPH was recorded by a mesonet station located 1 mile west of Logan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A smattering of strong to severe thunderstorms roamed South Central Nebraska from the early evening of Saturday the 20th into the very early morning of Sunday the 21st, prompting a few hail reports from widely-varying locations. The largest reported hail, ping pong to golf ball size, occurred in far southwestern Furnas County near Wilsonville. Later, quarter size stones fell from other storms at Wood River, Genoa and Silver Creek, although the late-night report from Silver Creek implied that much larger hail might have transpired (observer unable to confirm a maximum size). ||Isolated storms first drifted into western portions of the 24-county area between 6-8 p.m. CDT, after initiating a few hours prior in west-central Nebraska along a north-south oriented surface trough. These initial storms included the one that produced the large hail in Furnas County. Between 8-11 p.m. CDT the vast majority of limited storm activity was rather weak, with the main exception of the briefly-severe storm that produced the 1-inch hail in Hall County. Then, about the time it appeared that any severe threat had ended for the night, a small cluster of storms began intensifying over eastern Nance County around midnight CDT, likely in response to the onset of a fairly weak southwesterly low level jet. Over the next few hours, this convection briefly morphed into a supercell that drifted southeast across portions of Nance, Merrick and Polk counties (yielding the Genoa and Silver Creek hail reports) before departing the local area around 2 a.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was provided by a low-amplitude shortwave trough translating across Nebraska in west-northwest flow, well-south of a larger-scale trough anchored over south central Canada. Mesoscale parameters over South Central Nebraska during the evening were certainly supportive of severe storms, featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.

This Wednesday evening featured the first somewhat-widespread severe thunderstorm event of 2020 within South Central Nebraska, with several reports of damaging winds and large hail focused primarily near and northeast of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Hebron. Overall, damaging winds were the bigger issue, highlighted by a measured gust of 79 MPH at the York airport shortly before 10 p.m. CDT. As these winds tore into town, they took down several large tree branches (a few entire trees), causing fairly widespread power outages and even partially-crushing an unoccupied car. About an hour before reaching York, measured winds of 70 MPH struck the Chapman area, flipping over irrigation pivots and taking down a light pole at a convenience store. Later in the evening, shortly before storms completely exited the local area, estimated 70 MPH winds took down a giant tree limb in Alexandria (3 ft. diameter/50 ft. long). Although the majority of wind damage focused within eastern counties, severe-criteria gusts were ongoing even as storms first entered the local area earlier in the evening, including 64 MPH at Ord airport. As for hail, the majority of limited reports were quarter size or smaller, although a few stones up to golf ball size were noted in North Loup.||Breaking down event timing and evolution, the scattered to numerous storms that eventually infiltrated South Central Nebraska first developed as separate storm clusters during the mid-late afternoon, one over northwest Nebraska and another in the NE/KS/CO border area. Between 7-9 p.m. CDT, both of these clusters entered northern and western portions of the local area. The southern one, which had been occasionally severe over southwest Nebraska, lost some steam as it moved east, yielding only slightly sub-severe wind gust reports in Furnas County. Meanwhile, the northern storm complex clearly established itself as dominant, charging southeastward as damaging winds peaked in intensity between 8:30-11:30 p.m. CDT. Shortly before midnight, the back edge of the now linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) exited southeast out of Thayer County, ending all storm activity for the night. Turning to the meteorological setup, this was not a strongly-forced event, with the main feature in the mid-upper levels consisting of a low-amplitude shortwave trough tracking east-southeast across Nebraska out of western SD over the course of the afternoon-evening. Surface features across South Central Nebraska ahead of the storms were fairly nondescript, dominated by weak high pressure and southerly-to-easterly breezes only around 10 MPH or less. However, fairly steep low-mid level lapse rates were in place, with damaging wind potential likely enhanced by fairly large surface dewpoint depressions heading into the evening (on the order of 25-30 degrees F). Evening mesoscale analysis over South Central Nebraska revealed 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 35-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most hail stones were smaller than quarters, but a few were as large as golf ball size.

Evening mesoscale analysis over South Central Nebraska revealed 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 35-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in a large tree limb being downed in Henderson, blocking a street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This Wednesday evening featured the first somewhat-widespread severe thunderstorm event of 2020 within South Central Nebraska, with several reports of damaging winds and large hail focused primarily near and northeast of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Hebron. Overall, damaging winds were the bigger issue, highlighted by a measured gust of 79 MPH at the York airport shortly before 10 p.m. CDT. As these winds tore into town, they took down several large tree branches (a few entire trees), causing fairly widespread power outages and even partially-crushing an unoccupied car. About an hour before reaching York, measured winds of 70 MPH struck the Chapman area, flipping over irrigation pivots and taking down a light pole at a convenience store. Later in the evening, shortly before storms completely exited the local area, estimated 70 MPH winds took down a giant tree limb in Alexandria (3 ft. diameter/50 ft. long). Although the majority of wind damage focused within eastern counties, severe-criteria gusts were ongoing even as storms first entered the local area earlier in the evening, including 64 MPH at Ord airport. As for hail, the majority of limited reports were quarter size or smaller, although a few stones up to golf ball size were noted in North Loup.||Breaking down event timing and evolution, the scattered to numerous storms that eventually infiltrated South Central Nebraska first developed as separate storm clusters during the mid-late afternoon, one over northwest Nebraska and another in the NE/KS/CO border area. Between 7-9 p.m. CDT, both of these clusters entered northern and western portions of the local area. The southern one, which had been occasionally severe over southwest Nebraska, lost some steam as it moved east, yielding only slightly sub-severe wind gust reports in Furnas County. Meanwhile, the northern storm complex clearly established itself as dominant, charging southeastward as damaging winds peaked in intensity between 8:30-11:30 p.m. CDT. Shortly before midnight, the back edge of the now linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) exited southeast out of Thayer County, ending all storm activity for the night. Turning to the meteorological setup, this was not a strongly-forced event, with the main feature in the mid-upper levels consisting of a low-amplitude shortwave trough tracking east-southeast across Nebraska out of western SD over the course of the afternoon-evening. Surface features across South Central Nebraska ahead of the storms were fairly nondescript, dominated by weak high pressure and southerly-to-easterly breezes only around 10 MPH or less. However, fairly steep low-mid level lapse rates were in place, with damaging wind potential likely enhanced by fairly large surface dewpoint depressions heading into the evening (on the order of 25-30 degrees F). Evening mesoscale analysis over South Central Nebraska revealed 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 35-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 79 MPH was recorded by the York Airport AWOS. Law enforcement reported downed power lines and resultant power outages across town and that 2 homes sustained damage due to fallen trees. The York News-Times reported that an unoccupied car was partially-crushed by a fallen tree on West Sixth Street.
