EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 65 MPH resulted in downed tree limbs in Deshler. Most branches were around 2 inches in diameter, the largest being approximately 1 foot in diameter and 25 feet long.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Precipitation continued below normal across northeast Nebraska, varying from 50 to 75 percent of normal. Temperatures were well-below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate (D1) drought evolved to severe (D2) drought conditions early in the month. Rainfall around 50 percent of normal contributed to the worsening short-term agricultural drought, despite temperatures averaging more than five degrees below normal at Sioux City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the aftermath of strong low pressure system and fresh snowpack, cold Arctic air tanked overnight temperatures the morning of the 27th into the minus 20 and 30 ranges. All climate sites across the Panhandle measured new record daily lows for the 27th. The minus 13 low temperature at Alliance Airport is being reviewed to be considered the all time coldest temperature in Nebraska history for October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nebraska Department of Roads sensor at Banner Road along North 71 around milepost 34.5 measured a minimum wind chill value of minus 41.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the aftermath of strong low pressure system and fresh snowpack, cold Arctic air tanked overnight temperatures the morning of the 27th into the minus 20 and 30 ranges. All climate sites across the Panhandle measured new record daily lows for the 27th. The minus 13 low temperature at Alliance Airport is being reviewed to be considered the all time coldest temperature in Nebraska history for October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nebraska Department of Roads sensor at Dalton along Highway 385 measured a period of wind chills colder than minus 30. The Sidney Airport also set a new low record with minus nine breaking the previous record of nine above set in 2017.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought intense non-thunderstorm and thunderstorm related wind gusts to north central Kansas on the evening of October 11th. This front entered western portions of north central Kansas between 7pm and 8pm CDT. The cold front already had a history of producing severe caliber, non-thunderstorm, straight line winds over western Nebraska and Kansas, and this trend continued along and just behind the cold front as it marched through north central Kansas. There were several reports of wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph across Phillips, Smith, and Osborne Counties. Damage reports from these areas were fairly typical for winds of this magnitude and mainly limited to tree and power line damage. Thunderstorms began to develop along the cold front as it moved farther east into Jewell County between 8:30pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorm intensity increased between 9pm CDT and 9:30pm CDT, such that the wind gusts produced by the thunderstorms enhanced the already-high ambient synoptically driven non-thunderstorm wind gusts associated with the cold front. This resulted in additional 60 to 65 mph wind gusts across portions of Jewell County. No specific damage reports were received from this area. Wind gusts decreased as thunderstorms exited Jewell County by 10pm CDT.||As mentioned above, the damaging wind events in the eastern half of north central Kansas were largely driven by convective winds that enhanced already-high ambient winds. Farther west, the severe wind was non-convective and driven by intense pressure rises behind the cold front on the order of 3-5 mb per 2 hrs. This event was somewhat unique due to the narrow overlap, spatially and temporally, of both convective and non-convective damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 66 MPH was measured by the Smith Center Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak shortwave pushed across northern Kansas with the bulk of the storms north of the warning area of the Dodge City NWS office. Once storm made its way across Scott County producing quarter size hail and gusty winds.

Although a few marginally-severe thunderstorms impacted the northwestern half of South Central Nebraska on this Sunday late afternoon/early evening, this event fell short of forecast expectations in terms of potential coverage/intensity of severe weather (more on this below). As for what actually happened, a handful of semi-discrete severe storms produced hail to half dollar size at Johnson Lake and nickel size near Sherman Reservoir, along with wind gusts around 60 MPH near Holdrege and Rockville. As for how the day played out, this seemed to be a case where factors such as the presence of early-day convection in/near the area, along with appreciable high level cloud cover much of the day, combined to hamper later-day airmass recovery and thus tempered the magnitude of the potential severe threat (SPC had upgraded most of South Central Nebraska to Enhanced Risk on morning Day 1 outlooks). ||The first sign of potential complications showed its hand early in the day as a few clusters of elevated, non-severe storms flared up between sunrise and late morning, affecting several counties along/east of Highway 281. Meanwhile, an unrelated batch of higher clouds rolled in from the west, prompting a multi-hour period of mostly cloudy skies over South Central Nebraska lasting well into the afternoon. Then, as skies started clearing and airmass recovery began, an extensive batch of strong/severe convection erupted to the south over Kansas, likely disrupting northward moisture advection and further inhibiting late afternoon destabilization. Nonetheless, despite these factors working against a local severe threat, a broken line of semi-discrete severe storms finally initiated around 6 p.m. CDT in northwestern counties, along a northeast-southwest oriented front. However, these storms did not maintain intensity long, weakening within 60-90 minutes. In their wake, one more rogue severe storm flared up around 8:30 p.m. CDT over Phelps/Harlan counties, but also faded fast. Finally, shortly after sunset a briefly-severe storm just west of the local area made a run toward Dawson County, but weakened as it moved in, effectively slamming the door on any further severe threat. Not surprisingly given the forecast expectations, the general synoptic setup appeared rather solid for severe storms. In the mid-upper levels, broad west-northwest flow prevailed over the Central Plains as a series of embedded disturbances rotated around the south side of a large-scale trough/closed low over south central Canada. At the surface, steady southerly breezes prevailed, to the east of a quasi-stationary front draped through western/north central NE. However, surface dewpoints remained fairly modest by late-June severe weather standards, averaging upper 50s-mid 60s F. Even so, afternoon mixed-layer CAPE reached 2000-3000 J/kg thanks to steep mid-level lapse rates, in the presence of  30-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 70 MPH. Emergency management reported that a three foot diameter and 50 foot long tree limb and a 1.5 to 2 foot diameter tree limb were blown down and blocking Main Street in the community of Alexandria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Albeit not as active as the previous evening, the evening of Thursday the 4th was the third consecutive with at least some severe storm activity in South Central Nebraska. This was truly a hit-and-miss, isolated to scattered event, as while storm coverage was fairly limited across the 24-county area as a whole, all four quadrants of it saw at least some convection. Overall, marginally-severe winds were the main issue, including measured gusts of 61 MPH at the Ord airport and 60 MPH at Waco, and estimated 60 MPH at Shelby, where the NWS cooperative observer reported downed tree branches up to 3 inches in diameter. Various other places clocked slightly sub-severe wind gusts of 50-55 MPH, including in or near Gothenburg, Johnson Lake, Arcadia, Gresham and Clay Center. Hail was less of an issue, with the only severe-criteria report consisting of quarter size stones in Sutton. ||Breaking down event evolution and timing, two small/separate storm clusters entered west-central and northern counties between 7-9 p.m. CDT, a continuation of activity that initiated hours earlier over the Nebraska Panhandle. These early evening storms produced strong-to-marginally severe winds mainly in Valley/Dawson/Gosper counties. Over the next few hours from 9-11:30 p.m. CDT, both of these storm clusters briefly weakened, only to re-intensify and even merge somewhat as they reached eastern portions of the area, prompting various hail/wind reports from counties such as Clay/Polk/York before exiting into eastern Nebraska. Meanwhile, back off to the southwest, a separate area of strong storms blossomed between 10 p.m. and midnight CDT in several counties along the Kansas border, but there were no ground-truth reports from this convection that departed into southeast Nebraska/northeast Kansas after midnight. Finally, one last weaker batch of storms roamed various northern/eastern counties between 1-4 a.m. CDT on Friday the 5th before all local storm activity ended for the night. Both at the surface and aloft, the same general environment that supported severe storms the prior evening remained in place for this round. In the mid-upper levels,  broad west-northwest flow containing various embedded, low-amplitude disturbances persisted over the region. At the surface, the same seasonably-hot and moderately unstable airmass persisted as well, as afternoon temperatures topped out in the low-mid 90s F with dewpoints ranging from upper 50s F in western counties to 65-70 F in the east. As strong to severe storms traversed the area in the evening, mesoscale parameters featured 1000-3000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH in Shelby and the NWS cooperative observer 3 miles northeast of town reported downed tree branches up to 3 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The morning and early afternoon of Saturday the 6th featured scattered, mainly weak thunderstorms within northern and especially western portions of South Central Nebraska (particularly areas west of the Highway 183 corridor). However, one storm briefly spiked up to severe levels over far northern Furnas and southern Gosper counties between 8:30-9:30 a.m. CDT, yielding reports of quarter size hail covering Highway 283 several miles north of Arapahoe along with nickel size hail south-southwest of Smithfield. ||This short-lived morning severe storm was a bit of a surprise, as earlier activity that drifted through counties north of I-80 before sunrise was fairly weak, as were other morning/early afternoon storms that developed across portions of mainly Furnas/Gosper/Dawson/Phelps counties. All convection departed/lifted north of the local area by 1-2 p.m. CDT. As best could be surmised, this flare up of early-day convection was tied to a burst of low-mid level warm air advection, within the exit region of a gradually-weakening low level jet (evident at 850 millibars). At the surface, a fairly well-defined warm front blasted north across Nebraska over the course of the day. In the mid-upper levels, flow was fairly anemic over the local area as ridging prevailed aloft, downstream from a potent shortwave trough ejecting north-northeast across the Intermountain West. Mesoscale severe weather parameters in the Gosper County area around the time of the brief severe storm were relatively modest, featuring around 1000-2000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE but only 25 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported to be covering Highway 283 approximately 6 miles north of Arapahoe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of October, severe drought (D2) conditions expanded into the remainder of Chase County. The cooperative station at Imperial reported 0.50 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 1.07 inches below the normal of 1.57 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the aftermath of strong low pressure system and fresh snowpack, cold Arctic air tanked overnight temperatures the morning of the 27th into the minus 20 and 30 ranges. All climate sites across the Panhandle measured new record daily lows for the 27th. The minus 13 low temperature at Alliance Airport is being reviewed to be considered the all time coldest temperature in Nebraska history for October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minimum wind chill of minus 33 measured at the Alliance Airport. In addition, a new record low was set of minus thirteen at the airport breaking the previous record of 1 degree above set back in 1911. The minus 13 measurement is being reviewed to be considered the all time coldest temperature in Nebraska history for October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the aftermath of strong low pressure system and fresh snowpack, cold Arctic air tanked overnight temperatures the morning of the 27th into the minus 20 and 30 ranges. All climate sites across the Panhandle measured new record daily lows for the 27th. The minus 13 low temperature at Alliance Airport is being reviewed to be considered the all time coldest temperature in Nebraska history for October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nebraska Department of Raods sensor near Scottsbluff along United States Highway 26 measured a minimum wind chill of 31 degrees. In addition, at Scottsbluff Airport a new low temperature was set with minus 10 breaking the previous record of 11 above set in 1925. This also broke the all time coldest low temperature for the month of October.

A few rounds of strong to marginally-severe thunderstorms affected this six-county North Central Kansas area between the pre-dawn and late afternoon hours on this Sunday. However, this event fell short of forecast expectations in terms of potential coverage/intensity of severe weather, yielding only a few reports of quarter size hail at Ionia (mid-morning) and near Natoma (mid-afternoon). As for how the day played out, this seemed to be a case where factors such as the presence of stubborn early-day convection, along with afternoon development initiating fairly early and in widespread fashion, combined to hinder appreciable airmass destabilization/recovery and thus tempered the magnitude of the potential severe threat (SPC assigned Enhanced Risk to North Central Kansas on Day 1 outlooks).||The first sign of potential complications showed its hand well-before sunrise, as a long-lived round of at least slightly-elevated storms initiated between 2-3 a.m. CDT over Phillips/Rooks/Osborne counties. Over the course of the next 11 hours or so (all the way into early afternoon) this activity evolved into a narrow/broken, north-south oriented band that slid eastward at a snail's pace as new cells continuously regenerated on its western flank. The majority of these storms were sub-severe, producing only small hail, but between 9 a.m. and noon CDT a few cores over Jewell/Mitchell counties pulsed up to severe levels per radar data and the lone ground-truth report of quarters at Ionia. At long last, this early-day convection finally (mostly) exited the local area around 1 p.m. CDT. However, because it had persisted so long into the day, it laid out an outflow boundary/effective warm front near the far southern edges of the local area. Thanks to afternoon heating and meager capping, it did not take long for several strong/severe storms to erupt within a few counties either side of the Interstate 70 corridor between 2-4 p.m. CDT. This resulted in considerable storm coverage across mainly Rooks/Osborne/Mitchell counties, but the only ground-truth severe report was quarter size hail near Natoma. Between 4-6 p.m. CDT, other strong storms moved up into Phillips County from the southwest. However, given that so much convection developed over the local area in a short time, along with the fact that a large severe complex had taken center stage in central/southwestern KS, storm intensity/coverage within North Central Kansas steadily dwindled and the area was all but storm-free by 7 p.m. CDT. Not surprisingly given the forecast expectations, the general synoptic setup appeared rather potent for severe storms. In the mid-upper levels, broad west-northwest flow prevailed over the Central Plains as a series of embedded disturbances rotated around the south side of a large-scale trough/closed low over south central Canada. At the surface, North Central Kansas resided southeast of a quasi-stationary front draped from northwest KS into northern NE. Prior to the eruption of mid-afternoon convection, mixed-layer CAPE reached 2000-4000 J/kg in the presence of 30-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

A few rounds of strong to marginally-severe thunderstorms affected this six-county North Central Kansas area between the pre-dawn and late afternoon hours on this Sunday. However, this event fell short of forecast expectations in terms of potential coverage/intensity of severe weather, yielding only a few reports of quarter size hail at Ionia (mid-morning) and near Natoma (mid-afternoon). As for how the day played out, this seemed to be a case where factors such as the presence of stubborn early-day convection, along with afternoon development initiating fairly early and in widespread fashion, combined to hinder appreciable airmass destabilization/recovery and thus tempered the magnitude of the potential severe threat (SPC assigned Enhanced Risk to North Central Kansas on Day 1 outlooks).||The first sign of potential complications showed its hand well-before sunrise, as a long-lived round of at least slightly-elevated storms initiated between 2-3 a.m. CDT over Phillips/Rooks/Osborne counties. Over the course of the next 11 hours or so (all the way into early afternoon) this activity evolved into a narrow/broken, north-south oriented band that slid eastward at a snail's pace as new cells continuously regenerated on its western flank. At long last, this early-day convection finally (mostly) exited the local area around 1 p.m. CDT. However, because it had persisted so long into the day, it laid out an outflow boundary/effective warm front near the far southern edges of the local area. Thanks to afternoon heating and meager capping, it did not take long for several strong/severe storms to erupt within a few counties either side of the Interstate 70 corridor between 2-4 p.m. CDT. This resulted in considerable storm coverage across mainly Rooks/Osborne/Mitchell counties, but the only ground-truth severe report was quarter size hail near Natoma. Between 4-6 p.m. CDT, other strong storms moved up into Phillips County from the southwest. However, given that so much convection developed over the local area in a short time, along with the fact that a large severe complex had taken center stage in central/southwestern KS, storm intensity/coverage within North Central Kansas steadily dwindled and the area was all but storm-free by 7 p.m. CDT. Not surprisingly given the forecast expectations, the general synoptic setup appeared rather potent for severe storms. In the mid-upper levels, broad west-northwest flow prevailed over the Central Plains as a series of embedded disturbances rotated around the south side of a large-scale trough/closed low over south central Canada. At the surface, North Central Kansas resided southeast of a quasi-stationary front draped from northwest KS into northern NE. Prior to the eruption of mid-afternoon convection, mixed-layer CAPE reached 2000-4000 J/kg in the presence of 30-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

A smattering of strong to severe thunderstorms roamed South Central Nebraska from the early evening of Saturday the 20th into the very early morning of Sunday the 21st, prompting a few hail reports from widely-varying locations. The largest reported hail, ping pong to golf ball size, occurred in far southwestern Furnas County near Wilsonville. Later, quarter size stones fell from other storms at Wood River, Genoa and Silver Creek, although the late-night report from Silver Creek implied that much larger hail might have transpired (observer unable to confirm a maximum size). ||Isolated storms first drifted into western portions of the 24-county area between 6-8 p.m. CDT, after initiating a few hours prior in west-central Nebraska along a north-south oriented surface trough. These initial storms included the one that produced the large hail in Furnas County. Between 8-11 p.m. CDT the vast majority of limited storm activity was rather weak, with the main exception of the briefly-severe storm that produced the 1-inch hail in Hall County. Then, about the time it appeared that any severe threat had ended for the night, a small cluster of storms began intensifying over eastern Nance County around midnight CDT, likely in response to the onset of a fairly weak southwesterly low level jet. Over the next few hours, this convection briefly morphed into a supercell that drifted southeast across portions of Nance, Merrick and Polk counties (yielding the Genoa and Silver Creek hail reports) before departing the local area around 2 a.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was provided by a low-amplitude shortwave trough translating across Nebraska in west-northwest flow, well-south of a larger-scale trough anchored over south central Canada. Mesoscale parameters over South Central Nebraska during the evening were certainly supportive of severe storms, featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranging in size from ping pong balls to golf balls was reported along this path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed into northeast Nebraska during the very late afternoon and early evening. As larger-scale and deeper lift forcing with the upper-level jet pushed out across the frontal boundary toward early evening, a few thunderstorms developed in the environment of 30-35 knots deep-layer shear and around 1000 J/kg of MLCAPE and quickly became linear, and resulted in mainly damaging wind.

A cold front pushed into northeast Nebraska during the very late afternoon and early evening. As larger-scale and deeper lift forcing with the upper-level jet pushed out across the frontal boundary toward early evening, a few thunderstorms developed in the environment of 30-35 knots deep-layer shear and around 1000 J/kg of MLCAPE and quickly became linear, and resulted in mainly damaging wind.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts occurred within the heavy rain core, but there was no hail.  Crops appeared undamaged by the wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought intense non-thunderstorm and thunderstorm related wind gusts to north central Kansas on the evening of October 11th. This front entered western portions of north central Kansas between 7pm and 8pm CDT. The cold front already had a history of producing severe caliber, non-thunderstorm, straight line winds over western Nebraska and Kansas, and this trend continued along and just behind the cold front as it marched through north central Kansas. There were several reports of wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph across Phillips, Smith, and Osborne Counties. Damage reports from these areas were fairly typical for winds of this magnitude and mainly limited to tree and power line damage. Thunderstorms began to develop along the cold front as it moved farther east into Jewell County between 8:30pm and 9pm CDT. Thunderstorm intensity increased between 9pm CDT and 9:30pm CDT, such that the wind gusts produced by the thunderstorms enhanced the already-high ambient synoptically driven non-thunderstorm wind gusts associated with the cold front. This resulted in additional 60 to 65 mph wind gusts across portions of Jewell County. No specific damage reports were received from this area. Wind gusts decreased as thunderstorms exited Jewell County by 10pm CDT.||As mentioned above, the damaging wind events in the eastern half of north central Kansas were largely driven by convective winds that enhanced already-high ambient winds. Farther west, the severe wind was non-convective and driven by intense pressure rises behind the cold front on the order of 3-5 mb per 2 hrs. This event was somewhat unique due to the narrow overlap, spatially and temporally, of both convective and non-convective damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 63 MPH was measured by a mesonet station located in Jewell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unorganized supercells formed along the dry line in Wallace/Logan counties and moved east into an increasingly unstable air mass. As the cells moved east, they merged into a line that extended from Greeley County to Sheridan County. The storms from this event produced a landspout tornado near Hoxie, KS, up to ping pong sized hail, and flash flooding in Grinnell, KS with a vehicle stuck in the water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm Chaster reported ping pong ball sized hail falling on US 83.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although storm coverage within this portion of North Central Kansas was quite limited on this Saturday evening, the one legitimate severe storm in the coverage area produced notably large hail up to 3 inches in diameter over far southern Rooks County. This hailer entered the county from the southwest shortly before 8 p.m. CDT, after drifting northeast for a few hours as a left split from activity that initiated near the intersection of Gove/Trego/Ness counties. Between 8-8:20 p.m. CDT, reports of hail ranging from quarter to greater than baseball size occurred along a narrow swath from six miles south-southwest of Plainville up to the south side of Plainville proper. Shortly thereafter, the storm weakened rapidly, with only the faintest radar echoes remaining by 8:45 p.m. CDT. Elsewhere within the local area on this evening, a strong storm tracked southeastward from southwestern Phillips to central Rooks counties, but yielded no ground-truth reports. The initial convective development over west-central Kansas (that eventually spawned the Rooks County hail storm) developed near a somewhat-subtle, north-south oriented surface trough. Forcing aloft was also somewhat subtle, as northern Kansas only received a glancing blow from the southern fringes of a broad mid-level trough focused from central Nebraska northward into the Dakotas. Nonetheless, once storms got going, the environment was certainly supportive of severe activity as mesoscale analysis featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and deep layer wind shear around 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranging in size from ping pong balls to 3 inches in diameter was reported along this path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong and severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front in Nebraska and northern Kansas producing some damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured on wunderground weather station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between 7-10 p.m. CDT on this Monday evening, a broken line of thunderstorms swept across this six-county North Central Kansas area from northwest-to-southeast. The vast majority of this activity was sub-severe, producing only gusty winds as high as 40-50 MPH and brief rainfall. However, one small cell pulsed up just enough to produce a marginally-severe measured gust of 58 MPH near Speed in southwestern Phillips County, shortly before 8 p.m. CDT. Although this fairly low-key line of convection increased in coverage a bit by the time it reached North Central Kansas, its origins could actually be traced back roughly 300 miles to the northwest, to isolated-scattered storms initiating early in the afternoon over southwestern SD and northwestern NE. In the mid-upper levels, a fairly pronounced northwest flow regime ruled the Central Plains, as the region resided within the path of several small-scale disturbances tracking southeastward around the periphery of a larger-scale trough centered over south central Canada. Despite only modest low-level moisture in the wake of a secondary cold front, this convection made the most of steep low-level lapse rates and seasonably-cool mid level temps, with early-evening mesoscale parameters in North Central KS featuring around 1000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 35-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

Two separate rounds of mostly non-severe thunderstorms swept through South Central Nebraska from northwest-to-southeast on this Monday afternoon and evening. During the first round, one storm briefly pulsed up to severe levels over Polk County around 4:30 p.m. CDT, as estimated 60 MPH winds felled a large tree branch onto an attached garage in Osceola. Elsewhere in the area, a few near-severe-criteria storm reports included: 54 MPH gusts near Oxford (during the second round of storms), 52 MPH at York airport and penny to nickel size hail in Fillmore County. ||The first round of isolated to scattered convection affected mainly the northeastern one-third of the local area (primarily east of a Greeley-Aurora-Hebron line), first entering counties such as Greeley/Nance between 3-4 p.m. CDT and exiting Fillmore/Thayer counties between 6-7 p.m. CDT. Meanwhile, the second round of storms arrived a bit later and farther west (mainly affecting areas southwest of a Loup City-Hastings-Superior line), entering Dawson/Buffalo counties between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT and exiting southward into Kansas between 8-9 p.m. CDT. Long before reaching South Central Nebraska, both rounds of convection initiated well to the north-northwest (near the NE-SD border) early in the afternoon. This was a fairly classic northwest-flow-aloft event, as the Central Plains resided within the path of several small-scale disturbances tracking southeastward around the periphery of a larger-scale trough centered over south central Canada. Despite only modest low-level moisture in the wake of a secondary cold front, this convection made the most of steep low-level lapse rates and seasonably-cool mid level temps, with mid-late afternoon mesoscale parameters in South Central Nebraska featuring 1000-1500 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 25-35 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in small tree limbs being downed across Osceola, with a larger branch approximately 2 feet in diameter falling onto and damaging an attached garage on the far south side of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong and severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front in Nebraska and northern Kansas producing some damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured by cnk asos.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong and severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front in Nebraska and northern Kansas producing some damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at 10 meter Kansas state Mesonet gauge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong and severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front in Nebraska and northern Kansas producing some damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at Marysville Municipal Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong and severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front in Nebraska and northern Kansas producing some damaging wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across portions of south central Nebraska during the evening of Tuesday, June 30th, along and just behind a cold front. Some of these thunderstorms became severe, bringing scattered instances of large hail, along with isolated severe wind. The first thunderstorm formed over Dawson County, just behind the cold front, around 8pm, and produced quarter size hail just north of Sumner. This storm continued to produce severe hail as it moved northeast into Custer County between 8pm and 9pm. A more extensive line of thunderstorms developed farther east around 8:30pm, from eastern Buffalo County northeast to Greeley County. This line moved east southeast. Southern portions of the line were the most intense and produced a swath of large hail reports ranging from quarter size up to half dollar size from Cairo into Grand Island. A severe wind gust of 62 mph was also measured at Central Nebraska Regional Airport (KGRI). The line of thunderstorms continued east southeast, affecting areas east of Highway 281 and north of Highway 6 between 9:45pm and midnight. However, no additional severe reports were received within these areas during this time.||The thunderstorms were supported by strong instability (mixed layer CAPE values of 4500-5500 J/kg) and modest effective shear (25-35kt). Steep mid level lapse rates near 8 C/km and a glancing influence from a progressive shortwave moving from Colorado into Nebraska Panhandle also aided in severe thunderstorm formation, though the position of this upper disturbance  kept the greatest deep layer shear displaced northwest from the cold front and strongest instability. The low level jet remained rather weak, thus the line of thunderstorms decreased in intensity after sunset with the onset of nocturnal cooling.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranging in size from quarters to ping pong balls was reported along the path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was an active late Saturday evening-early Sunday morning of thunderstorms across much of South Central Nebraska, featuring several reports of large hail and especially damaging winds mainly between midnight-3 a.m. CDT as two storm complexes rolled through and eventually merged. Focusing first on severe winds, most estimated or measured gusts were in the 50-70 MPH range and associated with primarily tree damage. However a few isolated structural damage reports were more suggestive of at least 75-80 MPH, including: 1) 10 power poles blown down and three grain bins destroyed (along with some overturned irrigation pivots) west of Aurora...2) grain bin damage and overturned pivots north of Minden. Hail was more limited overall, but stones reached golf ball size at Pauline and ping pong ball size in Davenport, while Hastings saw nickel to quarter size hail. Rainfall amounts varied considerably (most of South Central Nebraska had less than one-half inch), but a fairly narrow swath of at least 1.50-2.50 targeted parts of primarily Thayer/Nuckolls/Clay counties, with one unofficial report as high as 3.17 near Belvidere. Flooding was fairly minimal, although one rural road along the Fillmore/Thayer County line still had water running across it around sunrise. ||As for storm mode/evolution, this was a somewhat complex event. The first local convection of the night entered the Furnas County area out of northwest Kansas after 11 p.m. CDT, in the form of a compact linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) on a weakening trend. But then, between midnight-1 a.m. CDT, a broken band of intense, semi-discrete storms erupted out ahead of this MCS along a west-east axis centered from Phelps-Adams-Thayer counties (likely in response to the onset of a healthy low level jet). However, these initially semi-discrete storms (which accounted for all large hail reports) quickly consolidated/grew upscale into a new linear MCS that charged north-northeast across the Highway 6/Interstate 80 corridors between 1-2 a.m. CDT, gradually merging with the initial MCS racing up from the southwest in the process. During the ensuing hour, the two complexes completed a full merger; the northern end weakening as it reached far northeastern counties (such as Nance/Polk), while the southern end remained severe through Fillmore/Thayer counties before departing the local area into southeast Nebraska. This ended any severe threat for the night, although weaker storms and broader showers persisted until around sunrise in some spots. This was a ripe setup for severe nocturnal storms, especially with the exit region of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars) aimed into the heart of South Central Nebraska after dark, and tapping into a large reservoir of most-unstable CAPE as high as 2000-3000 J/kg. In the mid-upper levels, flow over the region was not overly-strong, but contained various low-amplitude disturbances and was in the process of transitioning more southwesterly in response to a larger-scale trough setting up over the northwestern United States. There were no distinct surface features across the local area, but steady light southeast breezes prior to storm initiation maintained seasonably-high dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70 F. Likely one of the main limiting factors against a more robust severe threat was only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 75 MPH damaged a grain bin and a shed. Several trees were damaged and 2 pivots were overturned.

There were no distinct surface features across the local area, but steady light southeast breezes prior to storm initiation maintained seasonably-high dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70 F. Likely one of the main limiting factors against a more robust severe threat was only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 70 MPH, downing tree limbs approximately 4 to 5 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was an active late Friday evening-early Saturday morning across this six-county North Central Kansas area, featuring limited severe weather in Rooks/Phillips counties and some relatively minor flooding mainly within the northeast one-third of Mitchell County. But for the majority of the area this was just a classic, stormy early-summer night (most places measured between 0.50-2.00 inches of rain). As for the handful of severe weather reports, the main issue was a brief burst of intense winds through Rooks County around 2 a.m. CDT, including measured unofficial gusts of 68 MPH north-northeast of Codell, 62 MPH in Stockton and 61 MPH at Plainville (no known damage reports). Hail-wise, the only report featured quarter size stones east of Phillipsburg shortly after 11 p.m. CDT. Regarding heavy rainfall/flooding, primarily northeast Mitchell County was drenched with multiple downpours between midnight-4 a.m. CDT, with several automated gauges and NWS/CoCoRaHS observers tallying 3-5, including 5.05 just northeast of Beloit (unofficial public report of 6 at Simpson). This prompted relatively minor/short-term flash flooding and areal flooding, and also drove the Solomon River out of its banks as the Beloit gauge crested around 22.4 feet on the afternoon of the 27th (flood stage 20 feet). ||Timing-wise, there were basically two main rounds of convection. The first round (mainly 10 p.m. to 2 a.m. CDT) featured generally isolated to scattered coverage, as storms developed directly overhead in response to the onset of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars). Then, primarily 2-4 a.m. CDT the next round charged in from the west in the form of a fairly compact linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) that had gotten its act together well before midnight along the KS/CO border. By 4 a.m. CDT, storm intensity had waned considerably across local counties, although mainly stratiform lighter rain held on through around sunrise. This was a fairly typical setup for active nocturnal storms in the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, broad zonal flow reigned as a low amplitude wave rode eastward out of CO during the night. Meanwhile at the surface, a nearly stationary front resided directly through the area in east-northeast to west-southwest fashion, as evening dewpoints averaged mid-60s to around 70 F. Though fairly warm mid-level temps/weak capping held storms at bay until after sunset, the onset of the low level jet easily sparked convection given a healthy reservoir of 2000-3000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE, with the main limiting factor to a more robust severe threat being only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread rainfall amounts of 3 to 6 inches were reported across the area, with the primary impact being numerous rural roads being covered in water and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unorganized supercells formed along the dry line in Wallace/Logan counties and moved east into an increasingly unstable air mass. As the cells moved east, they merged into a line that extended from Greeley County to Sheridan County. The storms from this event produced a landspout tornado near Hoxie, KS, up to ping pong sized hail, and flash flooding in Grinnell, KS with a vehicle stuck in the water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gove County Dispatch reported approximately 10 inches of water under the I-70 overpass at mile marker 86. A vehicle was reported to be stuck in the water. Flash flooding occurred due to training of cells within a line moving NE and then the line pushed east out of the area around an hour later. Damage costs to the vehicle are unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unorganized supercells formed along the dry line in Wallace/Logan counties and moved east into an increasingly unstable air mass. As the cells moved east, they merged into a line that extended from Greeley County to Sheridan County. The storms from this event produced a landspout tornado near Hoxie, KS, up to ping pong sized hail, and flash flooding in Grinnell, KS with a vehicle stuck in the water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A well documented landspout tornado occurred in Sheridan County. Numerous calls and reports were received. However, looking at the photographic and radar evidence, this appears to be one long-lived and slow moving landspout. A center pivot was overturned in a field and this is the only known damage from this event. As a result, an EF-0 rating was assigned with winds likely around 80 mph with this particular tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was an active late Saturday evening-early Sunday morning of thunderstorms across much of South Central Nebraska, featuring several reports of large hail and especially damaging winds mainly between midnight-3 a.m. CDT as two storm complexes rolled through and eventually merged. Focusing first on severe winds, most estimated or measured gusts were in the 50-70 MPH range and associated with primarily tree damage. However a few isolated structural damage reports were more suggestive of at least 75-80 MPH, including: 1) 10 power poles blown down and three grain bins destroyed (along with some overturned irrigation pivots) west of Aurora...2) grain bin damage and overturned pivots north of Minden. Hail was more limited overall, but stones reached golf ball size at Pauline and ping pong ball size in Davenport, while Hastings saw nickel to quarter size hail. Rainfall amounts varied considerably (most of South Central Nebraska had less than one-half inch), but a fairly narrow swath of at least 1.50-2.50 targeted parts of primarily Thayer/Nuckolls/Clay counties, with one unofficial report as high as 3.17 near Belvidere. Flooding was fairly minimal, although one rural road along the Fillmore/Thayer County line still had water running across it around sunrise. ||As for storm mode/evolution, this was a somewhat complex event. The first local convection of the night entered the Furnas County area out of northwest Kansas after 11 p.m. CDT, in the form of a compact linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) on a weakening trend. But then, between midnight-1 a.m. CDT, a broken band of intense, semi-discrete storms erupted out ahead of this MCS along a west-east axis centered from Phelps-Adams-Thayer counties (likely in response to the onset of a healthy low level jet). However, these initially semi-discrete storms (which accounted for all large hail reports) quickly consolidated/grew upscale into a new linear MCS that charged north-northeast across the Highway 6/Interstate 80 corridors between 1-2 a.m. CDT, gradually merging with the initial MCS racing up from the southwest in the process. During the ensuing hour, the two complexes completed a full merger; the northern end weakening as it reached far northeastern counties (such as Nance/Polk), while the southern end remained severe through Fillmore/Thayer counties before departing the local area into southeast Nebraska. This ended any severe threat for the night, although weaker storms and broader showers persisted until around sunrise in some spots. This was a ripe setup for severe nocturnal storms, especially with the exit region of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars) aimed into the heart of South Central Nebraska after dark, and tapping into a large reservoir of most-unstable CAPE as high as 2000-3000 J/kg. In the mid-upper levels, flow over the region was not overly-strong, but contained various low-amplitude disturbances and was in the process of transitioning more southwesterly in response to a larger-scale trough setting up over the northwestern United States. There were no distinct surface features across the local area, but steady light southeast breezes prior to storm initiation maintained seasonably-high dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70 F. Likely one of the main limiting factors against a more robust severe threat was only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.

A shortwave trough moved across the CWA with the surface boundary again along the I-70 corridor initiating a number of severe storms that pushed southeast through the afternoon and evening hours. Severe hail and winds were the primary threat but tornadoes were possible in the QLCS scenario, but none were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Outbuildings were destroyed an a pivot irrigation sprinkler was overturned by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It's quite rare that widespread/severe NON-thunderstorm winds take center stage over thunderstorms during June in South Central Nebraska, but that's exactly what happened on this Tuesday as an anomalously strong low pressure system (by June standards) churned through the Central Plains. For the vast majority of the local area, the number one story was several hours of intense north winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 40-60+ MPH in the wake of a powerful late-spring cold front. Based on a variety of official/unofficial sensors, some of the highest afternoon-evening gusts featured: 67 MPH in Doniphan, 65 MPH near Gothenburg, Roseland and Oxford, and 64 MPH at Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. Other official peak airport gusts included 62 MPH at Hastings and 60 MPH in Kearney.  These winds undoubtedly caused numerous instances of at least minor damage within the area, but a few known ones included: a large tree in Holdrege fell on a car and blocked a street; a few large branches in west Hastings crashed onto power lines and at least one house; downed power lines in Arapahoe and Harvard; 6-8 inch diameter tree limbs downed in Deshler. Although the overall-strongest winds started/ended several hours earlier in far western local counties compared to far eastern counties, for the majority of the area the worst winds concentrated during portions of the noon-10 p.m. CDT time frame.||Turning to thunderstorms, while non-severe activity was common across much of South Central Nebraska during the afternoon and evening, the vast majority of the area was spared severe storms. This was mainly due to the strong surface cold front passing through prior to robust development being able to get going (in fact most of the area had seasonably-cool temperatures in the 50s-60s during the afternoon). That being said, a few severe storms did flare up in eastern counties during the afternoon, including one elevated hailer that dropped stones to around golf ball size in the Henderson and Hampton areas. Farther southeast along the actual front, radar indicated severe wind/hail potential with near-surface-based storms in/near Thayer County, but there were no verifying reports (although gustnado activity was noted in far southeastern Thayer County). Rainfall-wise, 24-hour totals fell short of forecast expectations across the majority of the area, as most places measured less than 1 inch. However, a few localized pockets closer to 2 inches occurred primarily in portions of southern Thayer and southwestern Buffalo counties, including a very isolated bullseye of 2.80 at Hubbell.||Both in the mid-upper levels and at the surface, the intensity of this weather system was quite abnormal for June...more reminiscent of those that sometimes occur earlier in the spring. Aloft, a deep closed low slowly tracked from eastern CO around daybreak on the 9th to northeast KS by sunset, eventually departing the Central Plains into northern MO by sunrise on the 10th. The associated surface low center lumbered east across northern KS over the course of the day, deepening to around 993 millibars in the process. While the position and track of the surface low/cold front spared most of the area from severe storms, far southeast counties dodged a potentially significant threat during the afternoon as the environment just north of the northern KS surface low became conditionally supportive of supercells and possible tornadoes. In fact, mesoscale parameters in the Thayer County area briefly featured a potent combination of mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, deep layer wind shear of 50-70 knots and 0-1 kilometer shear of 20-30 knots. As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 65 MPH was recorded at 6:09 PM CDT by a mesonet station located 5 miles north-northwest of Oxford. A gust of 62 MPH was recorded by mesonet stations located 1 mile north of Oxford and 2 miles north-northeast of Cambridge right at 5:54 PM  CDT. These two stations also recorded wind gusts of 60 MPH earlier in the day, between 1:30 and 2:30 PM CDT. Tree limbs up to 6 inches in diameter were downed in Cambridge, and power lines were knocked down in Arapahoe.

As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 65 MPH was recorded at 6:09 PM CDT by a mesonet station located 1 mile southwest of Roseland. A gust of 62 MPH was recorded at 6:20 PM CDT by the Hastings Airport ASOS and gusts were estimated to be 60 MPH by an NWS Hastings employee located 2 miles north of Pauline at 745 PM CDT. Minor tree damage was reported on the west side of Hastings reported via social media on Twitter via KSNB-TV.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It's quite rare that widespread/severe NON-thunderstorm winds take center stage over thunderstorms during June in South Central Nebraska, but that's exactly what happened on this Tuesday as an anomalously strong low pressure system (by June standards) churned through the Central Plains. For the vast majority of the local area, the number one story was several hours of intense north winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 40-60+ MPH in the wake of a powerful late-spring cold front. Based on a variety of official/unofficial sensors, some of the highest afternoon-evening gusts featured: 67 MPH in Doniphan, 65 MPH near Gothenburg, Roseland and Oxford, and 64 MPH at Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. Other official peak airport gusts included 62 MPH at Hastings and 60 MPH in Kearney.  These winds undoubtedly caused numerous instances of at least minor damage within the area, but a few known ones included: a large tree in Holdrege fell on a car and blocked a street; a few large branches in west Hastings crashed onto power lines and at least one house; downed power lines in Arapahoe and Harvard; 6-8 inch diameter tree limbs downed in Deshler. Although the overall-strongest winds started/ended several hours earlier in far western local counties compared to far eastern counties, for the majority of the area the worst winds concentrated during portions of the noon-10 p.m. CDT time frame.||Turning to thunderstorms, while non-severe activity was common across much of South Central Nebraska during the afternoon and evening, the vast majority of the area was spared severe storms. This was mainly due to the strong surface cold front passing through prior to robust development being able to get going (in fact most of the area had seasonably-cool temperatures in the 50s-60s during the afternoon). That being said, a few severe storms did flare up in eastern counties during the afternoon, including one elevated hailer that dropped stones to around golf ball size in the Henderson and Hampton areas. Farther southeast along the actual front, radar indicated severe wind/hail potential with near-surface-based storms in/near Thayer County, but there were no verifying reports (although gustnado activity was noted in far southeastern Thayer County). Rainfall-wise, 24-hour totals fell short of forecast expectations across the majority of the area, as most places measured less than 1 inch. However, a few localized pockets closer to 2 inches occurred primarily in portions of southern Thayer and southwestern Buffalo counties, including a very isolated bullseye of 2.80 at Hubbell.||Both in the mid-upper levels and at the surface, the intensity of this weather system was quite abnormal for June...more reminiscent of those that sometimes occur earlier in the spring. Aloft, a deep closed low slowly tracked from eastern CO around daybreak on the 9th to northeast KS by sunset, eventually departing the Central Plains into northern MO by sunrise on the 10th. The associated surface low center lumbered east across northern KS over the course of the day, deepening to around 993 millibars in the process. While the position and track of the surface low/cold front spared most of the area from severe storms, far southeast counties dodged a potentially significant threat during the afternoon as the environment just north of the northern KS surface low became conditionally supportive of supercells and possible tornadoes. In fact, mesoscale parameters in the Thayer County area briefly featured a potent combination of mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, deep layer wind shear of 50-70 knots and 0-1 kilometer shear of 20-30 knots. As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 63 MPH was recorded at 7:41 PM CDT by a mesonet station located 4 miles east of Pauline. A gust of 62 MPH was recorded at 7:25 PM CDT by a mesonet station located 2 miles west-northwest of Fairfield. At 7:45 PM CDT, Emergency management reported that power lines were knocked down in the 200 block of North Fillmore in Harvard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Over a 36-hour period between the evening of Saturday the 24th and the late-morning of Monday the 26th, nearly the entire 24-county South Central Nebraska area saw at least one round of light-to-moderate snow (some places a few rounds). For the majority of places (except for some counties north of Interstate 80) these were the first measurable flakes of the 2020-21 season. However, totals differed considerably, ranging from 1 inch or less in several places, to as high as 3-5 (isolated 6) in others. This was due to variances in the placement of two primary, generally west-east oriented snow bands: 1) a northern band that spread amounts of 3-5 (isolated higher) across Valley/Greeley/northern Nance counties...2) a southern band that brought totals of generally 2-4 (isolated higher) to locations roughly 15-25 miles either side of line from Beaver City-Hastings. Within these two main stripes, a sampling of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative reports featured: 6 nine miles northwest of Ord and also at Wilsonville, 5 In Ord and near Wilcox, 4.5 eight miles north-northeast of Scotia, 4 in Spalding, 3.7 six miles south of Beaver City and 3.5 in Minden. In contrast, most locations outside these bands (including between them) only tallied around 1 or less (including at Grand Island, York, St. Paul, Central City, Superior and Hebron). Winds during this event were not overly-strong, but still enough to promote modest travel impacts from blowing snow/minor drifting thanks to sustained speeds generally 10-20 MPH/gusts up to around 30 MPH. While snow was clearly the main precipitation type, some areas also noted a light glaze of freezing drizzle (mainly on elevated surfaces). ||Although this was a somewhat-prolonged snow event for South Central Nebraska as a whole, it certainly did not snow area-wide the entire time, as the varied timing/placement of banding brought accumulation to some places well before others. Within the northern band north of Interstate 80, the majority of accumulation occurred on-and-off between the evening of the 24th and the late afternoon of the 25th. Meanwhile, within the southern band the majority of snow got underway on the evening of the 25th and peaked in intensity overnight before diminishing by daybreak on the 26th. However, one last, brief burst of heavier snow blossomed mainly 7-10 a.m. CDT, bringing the last half-inch to inch of accumulation to places such as Cambridge, Holdrege, Minden and the Highway 281 corridor between Hastings and Grand Island. In the mid-upper levels, the main forcing behind this early-season event stemmed from a series of small-scale disturbances/ribbons of mid-level saturation/frontogenesis zipping across the Central Plains in active west-southwest flow, focused out ahead of (south of) a large-scale, positively-tilted trough sinking slowly south-southeastward through the Northern/Central Rockies and Northern Plains. At the surface, the steady north-northeast breezes were largely driven by pressure rises emanating from a strong/expansive ridge axis migrating from the Northern Rockies on the morning of the 25th to the Nebraska area on the morning of the 26th (central pressure by this time around 1034 millibars). From a temperature standpoint, this snow event occurred right in the middle of what ended up being the overall-coldest week on record to occur so early in the fall season (per long-term historical data at both Grand Island and Hastings). More specifically, the week of the 22nd-28th averaged 16-17 degrees below normal, including five-straight days from the 23rd-27th with highs only maxing out between the upper 20s-low 40s F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches across the county, including NWS observer/CoCoRaHS totals as high as 6 nine miles northwest of Ord and 5 in Ord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was an active late Saturday evening-early Sunday morning of thunderstorms across much of South Central Nebraska, featuring several reports of large hail and especially damaging winds mainly between midnight-3 a.m. CDT as two storm complexes rolled through and eventually merged. Focusing first on severe winds, most estimated or measured gusts were in the 50-70 MPH range and associated with primarily tree damage. However a few isolated structural damage reports were more suggestive of at least 75-80 MPH, including: 1) 10 power poles blown down and three grain bins destroyed (along with some overturned irrigation pivots) west of Aurora...2) grain bin damage and overturned pivots north of Minden. Hail was more limited overall, but stones reached golf ball size at Pauline and ping pong ball size in Davenport, while Hastings saw nickel to quarter size hail. Rainfall amounts varied considerably (most of South Central Nebraska had less than one-half inch), but a fairly narrow swath of at least 1.50-2.50 targeted parts of primarily Thayer/Nuckolls/Clay counties, with one unofficial report as high as 3.17 near Belvidere. Flooding was fairly minimal, although one rural road along the Fillmore/Thayer County line still had water running across it around sunrise. ||As for storm mode/evolution, this was a somewhat complex event. The first local convection of the night entered the Furnas County area out of northwest Kansas after 11 p.m. CDT, in the form of a compact linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) on a weakening trend. But then, between midnight-1 a.m. CDT, a broken band of intense, semi-discrete storms erupted out ahead of this MCS along a west-east axis centered from Phelps-Adams-Thayer counties (likely in response to the onset of a healthy low level jet). However, these initially semi-discrete storms (which accounted for all large hail reports) quickly consolidated/grew upscale into a new linear MCS that charged north-northeast across the Highway 6/Interstate 80 corridors between 1-2 a.m. CDT, gradually merging with the initial MCS racing up from the southwest in the process. During the ensuing hour, the two complexes completed a full merger; the northern end weakening as it reached far northeastern counties (such as Nance/Polk), while the southern end remained severe through Fillmore/Thayer counties before departing the local area into southeast Nebraska. This ended any severe threat for the night, although weaker storms and broader showers persisted until around sunrise in some spots. This was a ripe setup for severe nocturnal storms, especially with the exit region of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars) aimed into the heart of South Central Nebraska after dark, and tapping into a large reservoir of most-unstable CAPE as high as 2000-3000 J/kg. In the mid-upper levels, flow over the region was not overly-strong, but contained various low-amplitude disturbances and was in the process of transitioning more southwesterly in response to a larger-scale trough setting up over the northwestern United States. There were no distinct surface features across the local area, but steady light southeast breezes prior to storm initiation maintained seasonably-high dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70 F. Likely one of the main limiting factors against a more robust severe threat was only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.

This was an active late Saturday evening-early Sunday morning of thunderstorms across much of South Central Nebraska, featuring several reports of large hail and especially damaging winds mainly between midnight-3 a.m. CDT as two storm complexes rolled through and eventually merged. Focusing first on severe winds, most estimated or measured gusts were in the 50-70 MPH range and associated with primarily tree damage. However a few isolated structural damage reports were more suggestive of at least 75-80 MPH, including: 1) 10 power poles blown down and three grain bins destroyed (along with some overturned irrigation pivots) west of Aurora...2) grain bin damage and overturned pivots north of Minden. Hail was more limited overall, but stones reached golf ball size at Pauline and ping pong ball size in Davenport, while Hastings saw nickel to quarter size hail. Rainfall amounts varied considerably (most of South Central Nebraska had less than one-half inch), but a fairly narrow swath of at least 1.50-2.50 targeted parts of primarily Thayer/Nuckolls/Clay counties, with one unofficial report as high as 3.17 near Belvidere. Flooding was fairly minimal, although one rural road along the Fillmore/Thayer County line still had water running across it around sunrise. ||As for storm mode/evolution, this was a somewhat complex event. The first local convection of the night entered the Furnas County area out of northwest Kansas after 11 p.m. CDT, in the form of a compact linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) on a weakening trend. But then, between midnight-1 a.m. CDT, a broken band of intense, semi-discrete storms erupted out ahead of this MCS along a west-east axis centered from Phelps-Adams-Thayer counties (likely in response to the onset of a healthy low level jet). However, these initially semi-discrete storms (which accounted for all large hail reports) quickly consolidated/grew upscale into a new linear MCS that charged north-northeast across the Highway 6/Interstate 80 corridors between 1-2 a.m. CDT, gradually merging with the initial MCS racing up from the southwest in the process. During the ensuing hour, the two complexes completed a full merger; the northern end weakening as it reached far northeastern counties (such as Nance/Polk), while the southern end remained severe through Fillmore/Thayer counties before departing the local area into southeast Nebraska. This ended any severe threat for the night, although weaker storms and broader showers persisted until around sunrise in some spots. This was a ripe setup for severe nocturnal storms, especially with the exit region of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet (evident at 850 millibars) aimed into the heart of South Central Nebraska after dark, and tapping into a large reservoir of most-unstable CAPE as high as 2000-3000 J/kg. In the mid-upper levels, flow over the region was not overly-strong, but contained various low-amplitude disturbances and was in the process of transitioning more southwesterly in response to a larger-scale trough setting up over the northwestern United States. There were no distinct surface features across the local area, but steady light southeast breezes prior to storm initiation maintained seasonably-high dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70 F. Likely one of the main limiting factors against a more robust severe threat was only modest deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH. Some tin was blown into a tree.

On the evening of Tuesday the 2nd into the very early morning of Wednesday the 3rd, a cluster of strong to briefly-severe thunderstorms rumbled through the southwestern quadrant of South Central Nebraska (primarily affecting counties south of Interstate 80 and west of Highway 281). While most of this activity was sub-severe, a briefly-more-intense storm prompted a lone report of quarter size hail near Stamford around 10:45 p.m. CDT (penny size hail occurred in Beaver City shortly before this). ||Initially, South Central Nebraska remained mostly storm-free during the peak heating of late afternoon/early evening, but not by very far, as counties slightly to the west within southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas saw a few strong to severe storms develop near a slow-moving cold front. Eventually, between 8-10 p.m. CDT, a loosely-organized cluster of multicell convection that evolved from this early activity propagated east into far southwestern local counties. Then, between 10 p.m. and midnight CDT a few embedded cells intensified enough to prompt severe thunderstorm warnings for parts of Furnas/Harlan/Phelps counties (although the quarter size hail near Stamford was the only ground-truth verification). After midnight, the dominant cell within the cluster gradually weakened as it traversed parts of Franklin/Kearney counties, dissipating by 2 a.m. CDT over western Adams County. While the evening mesoscale environment in South Central Nebraska was obviously sufficient for a marginally-severe storm, it was not supportive of widespread severe activity given that respectable mixed-layer CAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg was offset by weak deep-layer wind shear of no more than 25 knots. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided under fairly anemic quasi-zonal flow, as the primary upper jet (and resultant stronger shear) resided farther north over the Dakotas.

It's quite rare that widespread/severe NON-thunderstorm winds take center stage over thunderstorms during June in South Central Nebraska, but that's exactly what happened on this Tuesday as an anomalously strong low pressure system (by June standards) churned through the Central Plains. For the vast majority of the local area, the number one story was several hours of intense north winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 40-60+ MPH in the wake of a powerful late-spring cold front. Based on a variety of official/unofficial sensors, some of the highest afternoon-evening gusts featured: 67 MPH in Doniphan, 65 MPH near Gothenburg, Roseland and Oxford, and 64 MPH at Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. Other official peak airport gusts included 62 MPH at Hastings and 60 MPH in Kearney.  These winds undoubtedly caused numerous instances of at least minor damage within the area, but a few known ones included: a large tree in Holdrege fell on a car and blocked a street; a few large branches in west Hastings crashed onto power lines and at least one house; downed power lines in Arapahoe and Harvard; 6-8 inch diameter tree limbs downed in Deshler. Although the overall-strongest winds started/ended several hours earlier in far western local counties compared to far eastern counties, for the majority of the area the worst winds concentrated during portions of the noon-10 p.m. CDT time frame.||Turning to thunderstorms, while non-severe activity was common across much of South Central Nebraska during the afternoon and evening, the vast majority of the area was spared severe storms. This was mainly due to the strong surface cold front passing through prior to robust development being able to get going (in fact most of the area had seasonably-cool temperatures in the 50s-60s during the afternoon). That being said, a few severe storms did flare up in eastern counties during the afternoon, including one elevated hailer that dropped stones to around golf ball size in the Henderson and Hampton areas. Farther southeast along the actual front, radar indicated severe wind/hail potential with near-surface-based storms in/near Thayer County, but there were no verifying reports (although gustnado activity was noted in far southeastern Thayer County). Rainfall-wise, 24-hour totals fell short of forecast expectations across the majority of the area, as most places measured less than 1 inch. However, a few localized pockets closer to 2 inches occurred primarily in portions of southern Thayer and southwestern Buffalo counties, including a very isolated bullseye of 2.80 at Hubbell.||Both in the mid-upper levels and at the surface, the intensity of this weather system was quite abnormal for June...more reminiscent of those that sometimes occur earlier in the spring. Aloft, a deep closed low slowly tracked from eastern CO around daybreak on the 9th to northeast KS by sunset, eventually departing the Central Plains into northern MO by sunrise on the 10th. The associated surface low center lumbered east across northern KS over the course of the day, deepening to around 993 millibars in the process. While the position and track of the surface low/cold front spared most of the area from severe storms, far southeast counties dodged a potentially significant threat during the afternoon as the environment just north of the northern KS surface low became conditionally supportive of supercells and possible tornadoes. In fact, mesoscale parameters in the Thayer County area briefly featured a potent combination of mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, deep layer wind shear of 50-70 knots and 0-1 kilometer shear of 20-30 knots. As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH based on surrounding area observations. Emergency management reported that 6-8 inch diameter tree limbs were downed in Deshler.
