EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of October, extreme drought (D3) conditions, expanded to the western half of Sheridan County, while severe drought (D2) conditions expanded into the eastern half of the county.  The cooperative station at Gordon 6N reported 0.81 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.74 inches below the normal of 1.55 inches. The cooperative station at Ellsworth 2W reported 0.88 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.23 inches below the normal of 1.11 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Over a 36-hour period between the evening of Saturday the 24th and the late-morning of Monday the 26th, nearly the entire 24-county South Central Nebraska area saw at least one round of light-to-moderate snow (some places a few rounds). For the majority of places (except for some counties north of Interstate 80) these were the first measurable flakes of the 2020-21 season. However, totals differed considerably, ranging from 1 inch or less in several places, to as high as 3-5 (isolated 6) in others. This was due to variances in the placement of two primary, generally west-east oriented snow bands: 1) a northern band that spread amounts of 3-5 (isolated higher) across Valley/Greeley/northern Nance counties...2) a southern band that brought totals of generally 2-4 (isolated higher) to locations roughly 15-25 miles either side of line from Beaver City-Hastings. Within these two main stripes, a sampling of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative reports featured: 6 nine miles northwest of Ord and also at Wilsonville, 5 In Ord and near Wilcox, 4.5 eight miles north-northeast of Scotia, 4 in Spalding, 3.7 six miles south of Beaver City and 3.5 in Minden. In contrast, most locations outside these bands (including between them) only tallied around 1 or less (including at Grand Island, York, St. Paul, Central City, Superior and Hebron). Winds during this event were not overly-strong, but still enough to promote modest travel impacts from blowing snow/minor drifting thanks to sustained speeds generally 10-20 MPH/gusts up to around 30 MPH. While snow was clearly the main precipitation type, some areas also noted a light glaze of freezing drizzle (mainly on elevated surfaces). ||Although this was a somewhat-prolonged snow event for South Central Nebraska as a whole, it certainly did not snow area-wide the entire time, as the varied timing/placement of banding brought accumulation to some places well before others. Within the northern band north of Interstate 80, the majority of accumulation occurred on-and-off between the evening of the 24th and the late afternoon of the 25th. Meanwhile, within the southern band the majority of snow got underway on the evening of the 25th and peaked in intensity overnight before diminishing by daybreak on the 26th. However, one last, brief burst of heavier snow blossomed mainly 7-10 a.m. CDT, bringing the last half-inch to inch of accumulation to places such as Cambridge, Holdrege, Minden and the Highway 281 corridor between Hastings and Grand Island. In the mid-upper levels, the main forcing behind this early-season event stemmed from a series of small-scale disturbances/ribbons of mid-level saturation/frontogenesis zipping across the Central Plains in active west-southwest flow, focused out ahead of (south of) a large-scale, positively-tilted trough sinking slowly south-southeastward through the Northern/Central Rockies and Northern Plains. At the surface, the steady north-northeast breezes were largely driven by pressure rises emanating from a strong/expansive ridge axis migrating from the Northern Rockies on the morning of the 25th to the Nebraska area on the morning of the 26th (central pressure by this time around 1034 millibars). From a temperature standpoint, this snow event occurred right in the middle of what ended up being the overall-coldest week on record to occur so early in the fall season (per long-term historical data at both Grand Island and Hastings). More specifically, the week of the 22nd-28th averaged 16-17 degrees below normal, including five-straight days from the 23rd-27th with highs only maxing out between the upper 20s-low 40s F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches across most of the county, including NWS observer/CoCoRaHS totals of 3.5 in Minden and also near Wilcox.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Over a 36-hour period between the evening of Saturday the 24th and the late-morning of Monday the 26th, nearly the entire 24-county South Central Nebraska area saw at least one round of light-to-moderate snow (some places a few rounds). For the majority of places (except for some counties north of Interstate 80) these were the first measurable flakes of the 2020-21 season. However, totals differed considerably, ranging from 1 inch or less in several places, to as high as 3-5 (isolated 6) in others. This was due to variances in the placement of two primary, generally west-east oriented snow bands: 1) a northern band that spread amounts of 3-5 (isolated higher) across Valley/Greeley/northern Nance counties...2) a southern band that brought totals of generally 2-4 (isolated higher) to locations roughly 15-25 miles either side of line from Beaver City-Hastings. Within these two main stripes, a sampling of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative reports featured: 6 nine miles northwest of Ord and also at Wilsonville, 5 In Ord and near Wilcox, 4.5 eight miles north-northeast of Scotia, 4 in Spalding, 3.7 six miles south of Beaver City and 3.5 in Minden. In contrast, most locations outside these bands (including between them) only tallied around 1 or less (including at Grand Island, York, St. Paul, Central City, Superior and Hebron). Winds during this event were not overly-strong, but still enough to promote modest travel impacts from blowing snow/minor drifting thanks to sustained speeds generally 10-20 MPH/gusts up to around 30 MPH. While snow was clearly the main precipitation type, some areas also noted a light glaze of freezing drizzle (mainly on elevated surfaces). ||Although this was a somewhat-prolonged snow event for South Central Nebraska as a whole, it certainly did not snow area-wide the entire time, as the varied timing/placement of banding brought accumulation to some places well before others. Within the northern band north of Interstate 80, the majority of accumulation occurred on-and-off between the evening of the 24th and the late afternoon of the 25th. Meanwhile, within the southern band the majority of snow got underway on the evening of the 25th and peaked in intensity overnight before diminishing by daybreak on the 26th. However, one last, brief burst of heavier snow blossomed mainly 7-10 a.m. CDT, bringing the last half-inch to inch of accumulation to places such as Cambridge, Holdrege, Minden and the Highway 281 corridor between Hastings and Grand Island. In the mid-upper levels, the main forcing behind this early-season event stemmed from a series of small-scale disturbances/ribbons of mid-level saturation/frontogenesis zipping across the Central Plains in active west-southwest flow, focused out ahead of (south of) a large-scale, positively-tilted trough sinking slowly south-southeastward through the Northern/Central Rockies and Northern Plains. At the surface, the steady north-northeast breezes were largely driven by pressure rises emanating from a strong/expansive ridge axis migrating from the Northern Rockies on the morning of the 25th to the Nebraska area on the morning of the 26th (central pressure by this time around 1034 millibars). From a temperature standpoint, this snow event occurred right in the middle of what ended up being the overall-coldest week on record to occur so early in the fall season (per long-term historical data at both Grand Island and Hastings). More specifically, the week of the 22nd-28th averaged 16-17 degrees below normal, including five-straight days from the 23rd-27th with highs only maxing out between the upper 20s-low 40s F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 2 to 6 inches across the county, including NWS observer/CoCoRaHS totals as high as 6 in Wilsonville and 3.7 six miles south of Beaver City.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 1 to 3 inches across most of the county, including NWS observer/CoCoRaHS totals of 2.5 six miles south of Wilcox and 1.5 in Franklin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The overnight of Saturday the 17th into the morning of Sunday the 18th brought the first measurable snow of the 2020-21 season to portions of South Central Nebraska, but solely focusing within counties north of Interstate 80. While amounts up to around 1 extended as far south as roughly a Loup City to Genoa line, the overall-highest (and heavier-than-forecast) totals of 3-5 targeted mainly the northern halves of Valley and Greeley counties. There, CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative reports included: 5 in Spalding and also nine miles northwest of Ord, 4 in Ord and also eight miles north-northeast of Scotia, and 3.1 in Greeley. This was a wet/sticky snow given surface temperatures in the low 30s F, and although steady north winds of 10-20 MPH (highest early in the event) likely promoted some minor drifting, travel impacts were held to a relative minimum given various factors such as fairly warm ground temperatures and the event occurring on a weekend night. ||Breaking down event evolution and timing, precipitation started out as a chilly rain on the evening of the 17th, eventually switching over to snow around midnight CDT as low-level temperatures cooled in the wake of a seasonably-strong cold front that breezed southward several hours prior. Transient snow bands persisted across northern portions of South Central Nebraska through the pre-dawn hours of the 18th before snow largely ended/moved out by 6-7 a.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels forcing was primarily driven by a strong, narrow ribbon of mid-level frontogenesis (especially evident at 700 millibars) aligned along the southern periphery of a broad, large-scale trough centered well to the north over southern Canada. At the surface, the aforementioned cold front brought a dramatic-but-brief change in the weather to the area, as high temperatures on the 18th did not escape the 30s F within the freshly snow-covered areas, only 24 hours after climbing well into the 60s on the 17th. However, this early-season snow melted rapidly over the next few days as readings rebounded to around 50 degrees on the 19th and around 60 on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Overnight snow totals ranged from 1 to 5 inches, with the highest amounts focused within the northern half of the county, including NWS observer/CoCoRaHS totals of 5 nine miles northwest of Ord, 4.9 five miles southwest of Elyria and 4 in Ord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the majority of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, October marked at least the third-consecutive month of below normal precipitation. However, for a relatively-focused zone within the heart of the area this was actually the fifth-straight dry month. As a result, the U.S. Drought Monitor continued an areal-expansion of both D2 Severe and D1 Moderate Drought during October. Focusing first on the D2 situation: as October began, D2 was already assigned to portions of nine counties in the center of the area (including all/nearly all of Kearney and Adams). Then a week later, portions of eight more counties joined the mix, including a westward extension of the initial D2 area to include sizable portions of counties such as Dawson/Gosper, and also a completely separate area of D2 farther north that encompassed the vast majority of Valley, Greeley, Sherman and Howard counties. Later in the month, a southward expansion of the southern D2 area brought most of Furnas County into the fold, resulting in a total of 18 counties at least partially-assigned Severe Drought by the end of the month. More specifically, the geographic coverage of D2 in South Central Nebraska ballooned from 9 to 37 percent during October. Outside of the worst-off D2 area, both D1 Moderate Drought and D0 Abnormally Dry also increased in coverage, with D1 introduced to all/most of York and Fillmore counties and D0 expanding to include the remainder of Thayer/Nuckolls counties. In other words, the entire 24-county area was assigned some U.S. Drought Monitor category by month's end. ||Taking a closer look at October precipitation, needless to say it was a notably-dry month: not only was the vast majority of the area below normal, but most of it tallied merely 10-50 percent of normal (normals generally 1.50-2.00). The overall-driest conditions concentrated near/south of Interstate 80, where NWS observer totals included a paltry 0.08 at Nelson, 0.11 eight miles south of Elwood (and also at Ravenna and Superior) and 0.12 at Red Cloud and Hebron. On the wetter side of things (but still below normal), parts of mainly far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) measured as much as 1.00-1.50, thanks mainly to early-season snowfall. Over the longer-term five-month period covering June-October, much of particularly the D2 areas only totaled 5-8 (generally 30-50% of normal). A few of the very driest NWS stations during this stretch included: Minden 5.08 (driest on record), Kearney airport 5.14 (3rd-driest), Hastings airport 5.87 (driest on record) and St. Paul 6.28 (3rd-driest). Temperature-wise, although October as a whole averaged 2-4 degrees F cooler-than-normal across South Central Nebraska (thanks mainly to a very cold late-month stretch), the first part of the month featured a blast of early-fall heat as highs in most places soared well into the 80s for a full week between the 5th-11th. Although no widespread/major drought impacts were noted locally during October, one indicator of the increasingly-dry conditions unfolded on the evening of the 11th as high winds prompted areas of blowing dust, greatly-reducing visibility and reportedly contributing to at least a few traffic accidents.

A few of the very driest NWS stations during this stretch included: Minden 5.08 (driest on record), Kearney airport 5.14 (3rd-driest), Hastings airport 5.87 (driest on record) and St. Paul 6.28 (3rd-driest). Temperature-wise, although October as a whole averaged 2-4 degrees F cooler-than-normal across South Central Nebraska (thanks mainly to a very cold late-month stretch), the first part of the month featured a blast of early-fall heat as highs in most places soared well into the 80s for a full week between the 5th-11th. Although no widespread/major drought impacts were noted locally during October, one indicator of the increasingly-dry conditions unfolded on the evening of the 11th as high winds prompted areas of blowing dust, greatly-reducing visibility and reportedly contributing to at least a few traffic accidents.

For the majority of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, October marked at least the third-consecutive month of below normal precipitation. However, for a relatively-focused zone within the heart of the area this was actually the fifth-straight dry month. As a result, the U.S. Drought Monitor continued an areal-expansion of both D2 Severe and D1 Moderate Drought during October. Focusing first on the D2 situation: as October began, D2 was already assigned to portions of nine counties in the center of the area (including all/nearly all of Kearney and Adams). Then a week later, portions of eight more counties joined the mix, including a westward extension of the initial D2 area to include sizable portions of counties such as Dawson/Gosper, and also a completely separate area of D2 farther north that encompassed the vast majority of Valley, Greeley, Sherman and Howard counties. Later in the month, a southward expansion of the southern D2 area brought most of Furnas County into the fold, resulting in a total of 18 counties at least partially-assigned Severe Drought by the end of the month. More specifically, the geographic coverage of D2 in South Central Nebraska ballooned from 9 to 37 percent during October. Outside of the worst-off D2 area, both D1 Moderate Drought and D0 Abnormally Dry also increased in coverage, with D1 introduced to all/most of York and Fillmore counties and D0 expanding to include the remainder of Thayer/Nuckolls counties. In other words, the entire 24-county area was assigned some U.S. Drought Monitor category by month's end. ||Taking a closer look at October precipitation, needless to say it was a notably-dry month: not only was the vast majority of the area below normal, but most of it tallied merely 10-50 percent of normal (normals generally 1.50-2.00). The overall-driest conditions concentrated near/south of Interstate 80, where NWS observer totals included a paltry 0.08 at Nelson, 0.11 eight miles south of Elwood (and also at Ravenna and Superior) and 0.12 at Red Cloud and Hebron. On the wetter side of things (but still below normal), parts of mainly far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) measured as much as 1.00-1.50, thanks mainly to early-season snowfall. Over the longer-term five-month period covering June-October, much of particularly the D2 areas only totaled 5-8 (generally 30-50% of normal). A few of the very driest NWS stations during this stretch included: Minden 5.08 (driest on record), Kearney airport 5.14 (3rd-driest), Hastings airport 5.87 (driest on record) and St. Paul 6.28 (3rd-driest). Temperature-wise, although October as a whole averaged 2-4 degrees F cooler-than-normal across South Central Nebraska (thanks mainly to a very cold late-month stretch), the first part of the month featured a blast of early-fall heat as highs in most places soared well into the 80s for a full week between the 5th-11th. Although no widespread/major drought impacts were noted locally during October, one indicator of the increasingly-dry conditions unfolded on the evening of the 11th as high winds prompted areas of blowing dust, greatly-reducing visibility and reportedly contributing to at least a few traffic accidents.

On the evening of Tuesday the 2nd into the very early morning of Wednesday the 3rd, a cluster of strong to briefly-severe thunderstorms rumbled through the southwestern quadrant of South Central Nebraska (primarily affecting counties south of Interstate 80 and west of Highway 281). While most of this activity was sub-severe, a briefly-more-intense storm prompted a lone report of quarter size hail near Stamford around 10:45 p.m. CDT (penny size hail occurred in Beaver City shortly before this). ||Initially, South Central Nebraska remained mostly storm-free during the peak heating of late afternoon/early evening, but not by very far, as counties slightly to the west within southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas saw a few strong to severe storms develop near a slow-moving cold front. Eventually, between 8-10 p.m. CDT, a loosely-organized cluster of multicell convection that evolved from this early activity propagated east into far southwestern local counties. Then, between 10 p.m. and midnight CDT a few embedded cells intensified enough to prompt severe thunderstorm warnings for parts of Furnas/Harlan/Phelps counties (although the quarter size hail near Stamford was the only ground-truth verification). After midnight, the dominant cell within the cluster gradually weakened as it traversed parts of Franklin/Kearney counties, dissipating by 2 a.m. CDT over western Adams County. While the evening mesoscale environment in South Central Nebraska was obviously sufficient for a marginally-severe storm, it was not supportive of widespread severe activity given that respectable mixed-layer CAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg was offset by weak deep-layer wind shear of no more than 25 knots. In the mid-upper levels, the local area resided under fairly anemic quasi-zonal flow, as the primary upper jet (and resultant stronger shear) resided farther north over the Dakotas.

This Wednesday evening featured the first somewhat-widespread severe thunderstorm event of 2020 within South Central Nebraska, with several reports of damaging winds and large hail focused primarily near and northeast of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Hebron. Overall, damaging winds were the bigger issue, highlighted by a measured gust of 79 MPH at the York airport shortly before 10 p.m. CDT. As these winds tore into town, they took down several large tree branches (a few entire trees), causing fairly widespread power outages and even partially-crushing an unoccupied car. About an hour before reaching York, measured winds of 70 MPH struck the Chapman area, flipping over irrigation pivots and taking down a light pole at a convenience store. Later in the evening, shortly before storms completely exited the local area, estimated 70 MPH winds took down a giant tree limb in Alexandria (3 ft. diameter/50 ft. long). Although the majority of wind damage focused within eastern counties, severe-criteria gusts were ongoing even as storms first entered the local area earlier in the evening, including 64 MPH at Ord airport. As for hail, the majority of limited reports were quarter size or smaller, although a few stones up to golf ball size were noted in North Loup.||Breaking down event timing and evolution, the scattered to numerous storms that eventually infiltrated South Central Nebraska first developed as separate storm clusters during the mid-late afternoon, one over northwest Nebraska and another in the NE/KS/CO border area. Between 7-9 p.m. CDT, both of these clusters entered northern and western portions of the local area. The southern one, which had been occasionally severe over southwest Nebraska, lost some steam as it moved east, yielding only slightly sub-severe wind gust reports in Furnas County. Meanwhile, the northern storm complex clearly established itself as dominant, charging southeastward as damaging winds peaked in intensity between 8:30-11:30 p.m. CDT. Shortly before midnight, the back edge of the now linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) exited southeast out of Thayer County, ending all storm activity for the night. Turning to the meteorological setup, this was not a strongly-forced event, with the main feature in the mid-upper levels consisting of a low-amplitude shortwave trough tracking east-southeast across Nebraska out of western SD over the course of the afternoon-evening. Surface features across South Central Nebraska ahead of the storms were fairly nondescript, dominated by weak high pressure and southerly-to-easterly breezes only around 10 MPH or less. However, fairly steep low-mid level lapse rates were in place, with damaging wind potential likely enhanced by fairly large surface dewpoint depressions heading into the evening (on the order of 25-30 degrees F). Evening mesoscale analysis over South Central Nebraska revealed 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 35-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Precipitation continued below normal across northeast Nebraska, varying from 50 to 75 percent of normal. Temperatures were well-below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate (D1) drought evolved to severe (D2) drought conditions early in the month. Rainfall around 50 percent of normal contributed to the worsening short-term agricultural drought, despite temperatures averaging more than three degrees below normal at Concord. Crop damage is an estimate from insured losses. Information provided by the United States Department of Agriculture.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of October, extreme (D3) drought conditions expanded into the western 2/3rds of Garden County. Severe drought conditions persisted across the eastern third of Garden County through the end of October. The cooperative station at Lisco reported 0.53 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.68 inches below the normal of 1.21 inches. The cooperative station at Oshkosh reported 0.57 inches of precipitation which was 0.68 inches below the normal of 1.25 inches. The cooperative station at Crescent Lakes NWR reported 0.50 inches for the month. This was 0.77 inches below the normal of 1.27 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of October, extreme (D3) drought conditions expanded to all but the eastern quarter of Deuel County. For the eastern quarter of the county, severe (D2) drought conditions persisted through the end of October.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: For the month of October, severe drought (D2) conditions persisted over southwestern Grant County.

The overall-driest conditions concentrated near/south of Interstate 80, where NWS observer totals included a paltry 0.08 at Nelson, 0.11 eight miles south of Elwood (and also at Ravenna and Superior) and 0.12 at Red Cloud and Hebron. On the wetter side of things (but still below normal), parts of mainly far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) measured as much as 1.00-1.50, thanks mainly to early-season snowfall. Over the longer-term five-month period covering June-October, much of particularly the D2 areas only totaled 5-8 (generally 30-50% of normal). A few of the very driest NWS stations during this stretch included: Minden 5.08 (driest on record), Kearney airport 5.14 (3rd-driest), Hastings airport 5.87 (driest on record) and St. Paul 6.28 (3rd-driest). Temperature-wise, although October as a whole averaged 2-4 degrees F cooler-than-normal across South Central Nebraska (thanks mainly to a very cold late-month stretch), the first part of the month featured a blast of early-fall heat as highs in most places soared well into the 80s for a full week between the 5th-11th. Although no widespread/major drought impacts were noted locally during October, one indicator of the increasingly-dry conditions unfolded on the evening of the 11th as high winds prompted areas of blowing dust, greatly-reducing visibility and reportedly contributing to at least a few traffic accidents.

For the majority of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, October marked at least the third-consecutive month of below normal precipitation. However, for a relatively-focused zone within the heart of the area this was actually the fifth-straight dry month. As a result, the U.S. Drought Monitor continued an areal-expansion of both D2 Severe and D1 Moderate Drought during October. Focusing first on the D2 situation: as October began, D2 was already assigned to portions of nine counties in the center of the area (including all/nearly all of Kearney and Adams). Then a week later, portions of eight more counties joined the mix, including a westward extension of the initial D2 area to include sizable portions of counties such as Dawson/Gosper, and also a completely separate area of D2 farther north that encompassed the vast majority of Valley, Greeley, Sherman and Howard counties. Later in the month, a southward expansion of the southern D2 area brought most of Furnas County into the fold, resulting in a total of 18 counties at least partially-assigned Severe Drought by the end of the month. More specifically, the geographic coverage of D2 in South Central Nebraska ballooned from 9 to 37 percent during October. Outside of the worst-off D2 area, both D1 Moderate Drought and D0 Abnormally Dry also increased in coverage, with D1 introduced to all/most of York and Fillmore counties and D0 expanding to include the remainder of Thayer/Nuckolls counties. Over the longer-term five-month period covering June-October, much of particularly the D2 areas only totaled 5-8 (generally 30-50% of normal). A few of the very driest NWS stations during this stretch included: Minden 5.08 (driest on record), Kearney airport 5.14 (3rd-driest), Hastings airport 5.87 (driest on record) and St. Paul 6.28 (3rd-driest). Temperature-wise, although October as a whole averaged 2-4 degrees F cooler-than-normal across South Central Nebraska (thanks mainly to a very cold late-month stretch), the first part of the month featured a blast of early-fall heat as highs in most places soared well into the 80s for a full week between the 5th-11th. Although no widespread/major drought impacts were noted locally during October, one indicator of the increasingly-dry conditions unfolded on the evening of the 11th as high winds prompted areas of blowing dust, greatly-reducing visibility and reportedly contributing to at least a few traffic accidents.

For the majority of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, October marked at least the third-consecutive month of below normal precipitation. However, for a relatively-focused zone within the heart of the area this was actually the fifth-straight dry month. As a result, the U.S. Drought Monitor continued an areal-expansion of both D2 Severe and D1 Moderate Drought during October. Focusing first on the D2 situation: as October began, D2 was already assigned to portions of nine counties in the center of the area (including all/nearly all of Kearney and Adams). Then a week later, portions of eight more counties joined the mix, including a westward extension of the initial D2 area to include sizable portions of counties such as Dawson/Gosper, and also a completely separate area of D2 farther north that encompassed the vast majority of Valley, Greeley, Sherman and Howard counties. Later in the month, a southward expansion of the southern D2 area brought most of Furnas County into the fold, resulting in a total of 18 counties at least partially-assigned Severe Drought by the end of the month. More specifically, the geographic coverage of D2 in South Central Nebraska ballooned from 9 to 37 percent during October. Outside of the worst-off D2 area, both D1 Moderate Drought and D0 Abnormally Dry also increased in coverage, with D1 introduced to all/most of York and Fillmore counties and D0 expanding to include the remainder of Thayer/Nuckolls counties. In other words, the entire 24-county area was assigned some U.S. Drought Monitor category by month's end. ||Taking a closer look at October precipitation, needless to say it was a notably-dry month: not only was the vast majority of the area below normal, but most of it tallied merely 10-50 percent of normal (normals generally 1.50-2.00). This Wednesday evening featured the first somewhat-widespread severe thunderstorm event of 2020 within South Central Nebraska, with several reports of damaging winds and large hail focused primarily near and northeast of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Hebron. Overall, damaging winds were the bigger issue, highlighted by a measured gust of 79 MPH at the York airport shortly before 10 p.m. CDT. As these winds tore into town, they took down several large tree branches (a few entire trees), causing fairly widespread power outages and even partially-crushing an unoccupied car. About an hour before reaching York, measured winds of 70 MPH struck the Chapman area, flipping over irrigation pivots and taking down a light pole at a convenience store. Later in the evening, shortly before storms completely exited the local area, estimated 70 MPH winds took down a giant tree limb in Alexandria (3 ft. diameter/50 ft. long). Although the majority of wind damage focused within eastern counties, severe-criteria gusts were ongoing even as storms first entered the local area earlier in the evening, including 64 MPH at Ord airport. As for hail, the majority of limited reports were quarter size or smaller, although a few stones up to golf ball size were noted in North Loup.||Breaking down event timing and evolution, the scattered to numerous storms that eventually infiltrated South Central Nebraska first developed as separate storm clusters during the mid-late afternoon, one over northwest Nebraska and another in the NE/KS/CO border area. Between 7-9 p.m. CDT, both of these clusters entered northern and western portions of the local area. The southern one, which had been occasionally severe over southwest Nebraska, lost some steam as it moved east, yielding only slightly sub-severe wind gust reports in Furnas County. Meanwhile, the northern storm complex clearly established itself as dominant, charging southeastward as damaging winds peaked in intensity between 8:30-11:30 p.m. CDT. Shortly before midnight, the back edge of the now linear mesoscale convective system (MCS) exited southeast out of Thayer County, ending all storm activity for the night. Turning to the meteorological setup, this was not a strongly-forced event, with the main feature in the mid-upper levels consisting of a low-amplitude shortwave trough tracking east-southeast across Nebraska out of western SD over the course of the afternoon-evening. Surface features across South Central Nebraska ahead of the storms were fairly nondescript, dominated by weak high pressure and southerly-to-easterly breezes only around 10 MPH or less. However, fairly steep low-mid level lapse rates were in place, with damaging wind potential likely enhanced by fairly large surface dewpoint depressions heading into the evening (on the order of 25-30 degrees F). Evening mesoscale analysis over South Central Nebraska revealed 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 35-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

Albeit not as active as the previous evening, the evening of Thursday the 4th was the third consecutive with at least some severe storm activity in South Central Nebraska. This was truly a hit-and-miss, isolated to scattered event, as while storm coverage was fairly limited across the 24-county area as a whole, all four quadrants of it saw at least some convection. Overall, marginally-severe winds were the main issue, including measured gusts of 61 MPH at the Ord airport and 60 MPH at Waco, and estimated 60 MPH at Shelby, where the NWS cooperative observer reported downed tree branches up to 3 inches in diameter. Various other places clocked slightly sub-severe wind gusts of 50-55 MPH, including in or near Gothenburg, Johnson Lake, Arcadia, Gresham and Clay Center. Hail was less of an issue, with the only severe-criteria report consisting of quarter size stones in Sutton. ||Breaking down event evolution and timing, two small/separate storm clusters entered west-central and northern counties between 7-9 p.m. CDT, a continuation of activity that initiated hours earlier over the Nebraska Panhandle. These early evening storms produced strong-to-marginally severe winds mainly in Valley/Dawson/Gosper counties. Over the next few hours from 9-11:30 p.m. CDT, both of these storm clusters briefly weakened, only to re-intensify and even merge somewhat as they reached eastern portions of the area, prompting various hail/wind reports from counties such as Clay/Polk/York before exiting into eastern Nebraska. Meanwhile, back off to the southwest, a separate area of strong storms blossomed between 10 p.m. and midnight CDT in several counties along the Kansas border, but there were no ground-truth reports from this convection that departed into southeast Nebraska/northeast Kansas after midnight. Finally, one last weaker batch of storms roamed various northern/eastern counties between 1-4 a.m. CDT on Friday the 5th before all local storm activity ended for the night. Both at the surface and aloft, the same general environment that supported severe storms the prior evening remained in place for this round. In the mid-upper levels,  broad west-northwest flow containing various embedded, low-amplitude disturbances persisted over the region. At the surface, the same seasonably-hot and moderately unstable airmass persisted as well, as afternoon temperatures topped out in the low-mid 90s F with dewpoints ranging from upper 50s F in western counties to 65-70 F in the east. As strong to severe storms traversed the area in the evening, mesoscale parameters featured 1000-3000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

It's quite rare that widespread/severe NON-thunderstorm winds take center stage over thunderstorms during June in South Central Nebraska, but that's exactly what happened on this Tuesday as an anomalously strong low pressure system (by June standards) churned through the Central Plains. For the vast majority of the local area, the number one story was several hours of intense north winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 40-60+ MPH in the wake of a powerful late-spring cold front. Based on a variety of official/unofficial sensors, some of the highest afternoon-evening gusts featured: 67 MPH in Doniphan, 65 MPH near Gothenburg, Roseland and Oxford, and 64 MPH at Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. Other official peak airport gusts included 62 MPH at Hastings and 60 MPH in Kearney.  These winds undoubtedly caused numerous instances of at least minor damage within the area, but a few known ones included: a large tree in Holdrege fell on a car and blocked a street; a few large branches in west Hastings crashed onto power lines and at least one house; downed power lines in Arapahoe and Harvard; 6-8 inch diameter tree limbs downed in Deshler. Although the overall-strongest winds started/ended several hours earlier in far western local counties compared to far eastern counties, for the majority of the area the worst winds concentrated during portions of the noon-10 p.m. CDT time frame.||Turning to thunderstorms, while non-severe activity was common across much of South Central Nebraska during the afternoon and evening, the vast majority of the area was spared severe storms. This was mainly due to the strong surface cold front passing through prior to robust development being able to get going (in fact most of the area had seasonably-cool temperatures in the 50s-60s during the afternoon). That being said, a few severe storms did flare up in eastern counties during the afternoon, including one elevated hailer that dropped stones to around golf ball size in the Henderson and Hampton areas. Farther southeast along the actual front, radar indicated severe wind/hail potential with near-surface-based storms in/near Thayer County, but there were no verifying reports (although gustnado activity was noted in far southeastern Thayer County). Rainfall-wise, 24-hour totals fell short of forecast expectations across the majority of the area, as most places measured less than 1 inch. However, a few localized pockets closer to 2 inches occurred primarily in portions of southern Thayer and southwestern Buffalo counties, including a very isolated bullseye of 2.80 at Hubbell.||Both in the mid-upper levels and at the surface, the intensity of this weather system was quite abnormal for June...more reminiscent of those that sometimes occur earlier in the spring. Aloft, a deep closed low slowly tracked from eastern CO around daybreak on the 9th to northeast KS by sunset, eventually departing the Central Plains into northern MO by sunrise on the 10th. The associated surface low center lumbered east across northern KS over the course of the day, deepening to around 993 millibars in the process. While the position and track of the surface low/cold front spared most of the area from severe storms, far southeast counties dodged a potentially significant threat during the afternoon as the environment just north of the northern KS surface low became conditionally supportive of supercells and possible tornadoes. In fact, mesoscale parameters in the Thayer County area briefly featured a potent combination of mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, deep layer wind shear of 50-70 knots and 0-1 kilometer shear of 20-30 knots. As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received via mPING.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It's quite rare that widespread/severe NON-thunderstorm winds take center stage over thunderstorms during June in South Central Nebraska, but that's exactly what happened on this Tuesday as an anomalously strong low pressure system (by June standards) churned through the Central Plains. For the vast majority of the local area, the number one story was several hours of intense north winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 40-60+ MPH in the wake of a powerful late-spring cold front. Based on a variety of official/unofficial sensors, some of the highest afternoon-evening gusts featured: 67 MPH in Doniphan, 65 MPH near Gothenburg, Roseland and Oxford, and 64 MPH at Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. Other official peak airport gusts included 62 MPH at Hastings and 60 MPH in Kearney.  These winds undoubtedly caused numerous instances of at least minor damage within the area, but a few known ones included: a large tree in Holdrege fell on a car and blocked a street; a few large branches in west Hastings crashed onto power lines and at least one house; downed power lines in Arapahoe and Harvard; 6-8 inch diameter tree limbs downed in Deshler. Although the overall-strongest winds started/ended several hours earlier in far western local counties compared to far eastern counties, for the majority of the area the worst winds concentrated during portions of the noon-10 p.m. CDT time frame.||Turning to thunderstorms, while non-severe activity was common across much of South Central Nebraska during the afternoon and evening, the vast majority of the area was spared severe storms. This was mainly due to the strong surface cold front passing through prior to robust development being able to get going (in fact most of the area had seasonably-cool temperatures in the 50s-60s during the afternoon). That being said, a few severe storms did flare up in eastern counties during the afternoon, including one elevated hailer that dropped stones to around golf ball size in the Henderson and Hampton areas. As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of October, severe drought (D2) conditions persisted across all of Keith County. The cooperative observer at Kingsley Dam reported 0.47 inches of precipitation. This was 0.80 inches below the normal of 1.27 inches. The cooperative station at Ogallala reported 0.25 inches which was 1.02 inches below the normal of 1.27 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of October, severe drought (D2) conditions continued across all of Perkins County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of October, severe drought (D2) expanded into the remainder of Hayes County. The cooperative station at Hayes Center reported 0.24 inches of precipitation. This was 1.53 inches below the normal of 1.77 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms that developed in eastern Colorado moved across the border into northwestern Kansas and continued to move east into the overnight hours of June 26th. Thunderstorms contained wind gusts up to an estimated 90 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KGLD ASOS reported a 59 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station K5WLC reported a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pictures received of 4 power poles snapped or blown down due to strong thunderstorm winds. Time is radar estimated and speed is estimated by storm damage.

Although the overall-strongest winds started/ended several hours earlier in far western local counties compared to far eastern counties, for the majority of the area the worst winds concentrated during portions of the noon-10 p.m. CDT time frame.||Turning to thunderstorms, while non-severe activity was common across much of South Central Nebraska during the afternoon and evening, the vast majority of the area was spared severe storms. This was mainly due to the strong surface cold front passing through prior to robust development being able to get going (in fact most of the area had seasonably-cool temperatures in the 50s-60s during the afternoon). That being said, a few severe storms did flare up in eastern counties during the afternoon, including one elevated hailer that dropped stones to around golf ball size in the Henderson and Hampton areas. Farther southeast along the actual front, radar indicated severe wind/hail potential with near-surface-based storms in/near Thayer County, but there were no verifying reports (although gustnado activity was noted in far southeastern Thayer County). Rainfall-wise, 24-hour totals fell short of forecast expectations across the majority of the area, as most places measured less than 1 inch. However, a few localized pockets closer to 2 inches occurred primarily in portions of southern Thayer and southwestern Buffalo counties, including a very isolated bullseye of 2.80 at Hubbell.||Both in the mid-upper levels and at the surface, the intensity of this weather system was quite abnormal for June...more reminiscent of those that sometimes occur earlier in the spring. Aloft, a deep closed low slowly tracked from eastern CO around daybreak on the 9th to northeast KS by sunset, eventually departing the Central Plains into northern MO by sunrise on the 10th. The associated surface low center lumbered east across northern KS over the course of the day, deepening to around 993 millibars in the process. While the position and track of the surface low/cold front spared most of the area from severe storms, far southeast counties dodged a potentially significant threat during the afternoon as the environment just north of the northern KS surface low became conditionally supportive of supercells and possible tornadoes. In fact, mesoscale parameters in the Thayer County area briefly featured a potent combination of mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, deep layer wind shear of 50-70 knots and 0-1 kilometer shear of 20-30 knots. As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 63 MPH was recorded at 6:19 PM CDT by a mesonet station located 5 miles north of Inavale.

The Grand Island ASOS recorded the following gusts: 64 MPH at 7:07 PM CDT, 61 MPH at 6:49 PM CDT, and 58 MPH at 5:51 PM CDT. An estimated 60 mph wind gust was reported at 6:38 PM CDT in Doniphan by an NWS employee. A 58 mph wind gusts was recorded at 7:00 PM CDT 3 miles west northwest of Alda.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It's quite rare that widespread/severe NON-thunderstorm winds take center stage over thunderstorms during June in North Central Kansas, but that's exactly what happened on this Tuesday as an anomalously strong low pressure system (by June standards) advanced through the Central Plains. For sure, the number one weather story across these six counties was several hours of intense north winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 40-60+ MPH in the wake of a powerful late-spring cold front. Based on a variety of unofficial sensors, some of the highest afternoon-evening gusts featured: 66 MPH near Logan, 62 MPH in rural eastern Rooks County, 59 MPH near Kirwin and 58 MPH at Phillipsburg airport and also near Webber. These winds undoubtedly caused several instances of mainly minor damage within the area, but ground-truth reports were quite limited. For the majority of this area, the overall-worst winds concentrated during portions of the noon-midnight CDT time frame. Turning to thunderstorms, while non-severe activity was common across much of North Central Kansas during the late afternoon and especially evening, this area narrowly dodged a severe storm threat due mainly to a strong surface cold front and dryline passing through prior to robust development taking place along these boundaries. However, a few strong to severe storms materialized just barely off to the east-northeast within counties such as Republic KS and Thayer NE. ||Both in the mid-upper levels and at the surface, the intensity of this weather system was quite abnormal for June...more reminiscent of those that sometimes occur earlier in the spring. Aloft, a deep closed low slowly tracked from eastern CO around daybreak on the 9th to northeast KS by sunset, eventually departing the Central Plains into northern MO by sunrise on the 10th. The associated surface low center lumbered east through northern KS over the course of the day (nearly directly across the local area), deepening to around 993 millibars in the process. While the position and track of the surface low/cold front spared most of the area from severe storms, especially Jewell/Mitchell counties dodged a potentially significant threat as the environment briefly became conditionally supportive of supercells and possible tornadoes during the afternoon. In fact, mesoscale parameters in this area briefly featured a potent combination of mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, deep layer wind shear of 50-70 knots and 0-1 kilometer shear of 20-30 knots. As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 62 MPH was recorded at 9:59 PM CDT by a mesonet station located 9 miles north-northeast of Codell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed across the CWA bringing strong winds behind it, all non-thunderstorm induced. The gradient was really tight aided by the tropical disturbance remnants making its way through Missouri. Gusts as high as 78 mph were reported with many reports over the 58 mph threshold.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed at a location 4 NE Hayne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed across the CWA bringing strong winds behind it, all non-thunderstorm induced. The gradient was really tight aided by the tropical disturbance remnants making its way through Missouri. Gusts as high as 78 mph were reported with many reports over the 58 mph threshold.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed at the Hugoton airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of October, severe drought (D2) conditions expanded into southeastern and east central Lincoln County. The cooperative station at Wallace 2W reported 0.24 inches of precipitation. This was 1.35 inches below the normal of 1.59 inches. The cooperative station at Hershey 5SSE reported 0.26 inches of precipitation in October. This was 1.40 inches below the normal of 1.66 inches. At the North Platte Airport, 0.38 inches of precipitation fell which was 1.17 inches below the normal of 1.55 inches. At the cooperative station in Brady, 0.24 inches of precipitation fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) expanded into all of Frontier County during the month of October. The cooperative station at Curtis reported 0.17 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 1.53 inches below the normal of 1.70 inches. The cooperative station at Eustis 2NW reported 0.18 inches of precipitation. This was 1.62 inches below the normal of 1.80 inches. The cooperative station at Stockville reported 0.13 inches of precipitation which was 1.72 inches below the normal of 1.85 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) conditions expanded into southeastern Garfield county during October. The cooperative station at Ericson 8WNW tallied 1.19 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.80 inches below the normal of 2.09 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It's quite rare that widespread/severe NON-thunderstorm winds take center stage over thunderstorms during June in North Central Kansas, but that's exactly what happened on this Tuesday as an anomalously strong low pressure system (by June standards) advanced through the Central Plains. For sure, the number one weather story across these six counties was several hours of intense north winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 40-60+ MPH in the wake of a powerful late-spring cold front. Based on a variety of unofficial sensors, some of the highest afternoon-evening gusts featured: 66 MPH near Logan, 62 MPH in rural eastern Rooks County, 59 MPH near Kirwin and 58 MPH at Phillipsburg airport and also near Webber. These winds undoubtedly caused several instances of mainly minor damage within the area, but ground-truth reports were quite limited. For the majority of this area, the overall-worst winds concentrated during portions of the noon-midnight CDT time frame. Turning to thunderstorms, while non-severe activity was common across much of North Central Kansas during the late afternoon and especially evening, this area narrowly dodged a severe storm threat due mainly to a strong surface cold front and dryline passing through prior to robust development taking place along these boundaries. However, a few strong to severe storms materialized just barely off to the east-northeast within counties such as Republic KS and Thayer NE. ||Both in the mid-upper levels and at the surface, the intensity of this weather system was quite abnormal for June...more reminiscent of those that sometimes occur earlier in the spring. Aloft, a deep closed low slowly tracked from eastern CO around daybreak on the 9th to northeast KS by sunset, eventually departing the Central Plains into northern MO by sunrise on the 10th. The associated surface low center lumbered east through northern KS over the course of the day (nearly directly across the local area), deepening to around 993 millibars in the process. While the position and track of the surface low/cold front spared most of the area from severe storms, especially Jewell/Mitchell counties dodged a potentially significant threat as the environment briefly became conditionally supportive of supercells and possible tornadoes during the afternoon. In fact, mesoscale parameters in this area briefly featured a potent combination of mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, deep layer wind shear of 50-70 knots and 0-1 kilometer shear of 20-30 knots. As for the unusual nature of such intense northerly winds so late in the spring, it's worth noting that howling speeds of 50-70 knots a few thousand feet above the ground (at 850 millibars) registered 3-4 standard deviations above normal for the date...basically off the charts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 MPH was recorded at 10:04 PM CDT by a mesonet station located near Hunter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred the afternoon of 11 October 2020 with wind gusts above 58 mph near Scottsbluff, Chadron, and Kimball.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chadron ASOS reported wind gusts in excess of 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought conditions expanded into additional areas across western and north central Nebraska in October. By the end of the month, severe to extreme drought conditions were present in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, as well as generally south of Interstate 80 and US Highway 26. Severe drought conditions also expanded into portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties during the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought (D2) conditions expanded into the southern half of Wheeler county during the month of October. The cooperative station at Bartlett 1W reported 1.02 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 1.21 inches below the normal of 2.23 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the day unseasonably strong winds occurred over Northwest Kansas.  The peak gust reported was 64 MPH at Goodland.  These winds blew down a tree, tree limbs, and shingles.||The high winds caused a dust storm at two locations in Cheyenne County during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High wind gusts were reported at 9 SSE of Sharon Springs and 4 W of Wallace.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the day unseasonably strong winds occurred over Northwest Kansas.  The peak gust reported was 64 MPH at Goodland.  These winds blew down a tree, tree limbs, and shingles.||The high winds caused a dust storm at two locations in Cheyenne County during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near zero visibility was reported on Highway 36 from the Colorado state line to three miles east into Cheyenne County.  Near zero visibility was also reported in Wheeler.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed across the CWA bringing strong winds behind it, all non-thunderstorm induced. The gradient was really tight aided by the tropical disturbance remnants making its way through Missouri. Gusts as high as 78 mph were reported with many reports over the 58 mph threshold.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed at the Liberal airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rogue storm developed across the far northern sections of central Kansas and ultimately transformed into a squall line that moved eastward across the remaining sections of central and portions of south central Kansas.  Of note, was the widespread heavy rain that fell across much of the area. Rainfall amounts were consistently in the 1.25 to 3.5 inch range for many locations.  The sites with rainfall amounts higher than 3 inches were individually added.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured wind gust of 33 mph was also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind damage to a steel grain bin was noted and a center pivot irrigation system was blown over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep trough across the western U.S. combined with a stationary front across the region allowed a couple of severe thunderstorms to develop.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed off the Rockies in a line north of I-70 with a few clusters of storms to the south of I-70. As the storms moved east into Kansas, they produced wind gusts up to 70 mph causing blowing dust to reduce visibility in Rawlins County. The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Greeley County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hill City ASOS observed thunderstorm wind gusts of 64 mph at 0153 UTC to 67 mph at 0155 UTC.

The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Greeley County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing dust associated with an estimated 50 mph thunderstorm wind gust reduced visibility to 100 yards across agricultural fields approximately 2.3 miles WNW of McDonald near the intersection of County Road P and County Line Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter observed an estimated 30 mph wind gust associated with a severe thunderstorm that caused blowing dust to reduce visibility down to 1/4 mile. Location of the report is near the intersection of 1600th Road and D5 Lane approximately 1 mile W of Dresden.

An unseasonably strong low pressure system moved across potions of central and south central Kansas during the late evening hours or June 9th and the early morning hours of June 10th, 2020. Tree limbs were knocked down across central and south central Kansas, with most of the limbs 5 to 6 inches in diameter.  Some power pole were also knocked down.  The winds gusted as high as 59 mph at Wichita Eisenhower National airport, with numerous reports of tree damage in Wichita, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The gust was reported in Westfall, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong low pressure system moved across potions of central and south central Kansas during the late evening hours or June 9th and the early morning hours of June 10th, 2020. Tree limbs were knocked down across central and south central Kansas, with most of the limbs 5 to 6 inches in diameter.  Some power pole were also knocked down.  The winds gusted as high as 59 mph at Wichita Eisenhower National airport, with numerous reports of tree damage in Wichita, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wichita Eisenhower National airport reported a 57 mph gusts at 1242am.  Also 3 or 4 different locations on the west side of town, reported 6 to 8 inch tree limbs down. McConnell Air Force base also reported a wind gust to 55 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One report of quarter size hail was reported from overnight thunderstorms, which dissipated after sunrise on 6/28.

Unseasonably strong winds occurred for a third straight day.  The majority of the high winds occurred along the Colorado/Kansas border, with more sporadic damage and/or high wind gusts to the east.  Noteworthy damage reports include three inch diameter tree limbs being blown down in St. Francis which may have also caused power poles to be broken, the high winds pushing two semis together on I-70 near Kanorado, and a truck being flipped that was towing a trailer near Lenora.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of over 60 MPH occurred across the county.  The high winds also caused some shingles to be blown off a house, and a one inch diameter tree limb to be blown down in St. Francis.  In addition, three inch diameter tree limbs were blown down in St. Francis, which may have lead to power poles being broken as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across portions of south central Nebraska during the evening of Tuesday, June 30th, along and just behind a cold front. Some of these thunderstorms became severe, bringing scattered instances of large hail, along with isolated severe wind. The first thunderstorm formed over Dawson County, just behind the cold front, around 8pm, and produced quarter size hail just north of Sumner. This storm continued to produce severe hail as it moved northeast into Custer County between 8pm and 9pm. A more extensive line of thunderstorms developed farther east around 8:30pm, from eastern Buffalo County northeast to Greeley County. This line moved east southeast. Southern portions of the line were the most intense and produced a swath of large hail reports ranging from quarter size up to half dollar size from Cairo into Grand Island. A severe wind gust of 62 mph was also measured at Central Nebraska Regional Airport (KGRI). The line of thunderstorms continued east southeast, affecting areas east of Highway 281 and north of Highway 6 between 9:45pm and midnight. However, no additional severe reports were received within these areas during this time.||The thunderstorms were supported by strong instability (mixed layer CAPE values of 4500-5500 J/kg) and modest effective shear (25-35kt). Steep mid level lapse rates near 8 C/km and a glancing influence from a progressive shortwave moving from Colorado into Nebraska Panhandle also aided in severe thunderstorm formation, though the position of this upper disturbance  kept the greatest deep layer shear displaced northwest from the cold front and strongest instability. The low level jet remained rather weak, thus the line of thunderstorms decreased in intensity after sunset with the onset of nocturnal cooling.

The first thunderstorm formed over Dawson County, just behind the cold front, around 8pm, and produced quarter size hail just north of Sumner. This storm continued to produce severe hail as it moved northeast into Custer County between 8pm and 9pm. A more extensive line of thunderstorms developed farther east around 8:30pm, from eastern Buffalo County northeast to Greeley County. This line moved east southeast. Southern portions of the line were the most intense and produced a swath of large hail reports ranging from quarter size up to half dollar size from Cairo into Grand Island. A severe wind gust of 62 mph was also measured at Central Nebraska Regional Airport (KGRI). The line of thunderstorms continued east southeast, affecting areas east of Highway 281 and north of Highway 6 between 9:45pm and midnight. However, no additional severe reports were received within these areas during this time.||The thunderstorms were supported by strong instability (mixed layer CAPE values of 4500-5500 J/kg) and modest effective shear (25-35kt). Steep mid level lapse rates near 8 C/km and a glancing influence from a progressive shortwave moving from Colorado into Nebraska Panhandle also aided in severe thunderstorm formation, though the position of this upper disturbance  kept the greatest deep layer shear displaced northwest from the cold front and strongest instability. The low level jet remained rather weak, thus the line of thunderstorms decreased in intensity after sunset with the onset of nocturnal cooling.

A severe wind gust of 62 mph was also measured at Central Nebraska Regional Airport (KGRI). The line of thunderstorms continued east southeast, affecting areas east of Highway 281 and north of Highway 6 between 9:45pm and midnight. However, no additional severe reports were received within these areas during this time.||The thunderstorms were supported by strong instability (mixed layer CAPE values of 4500-5500 J/kg) and modest effective shear (25-35kt). Steep mid level lapse rates near 8 C/km and a glancing influence from a progressive shortwave moving from Colorado into Nebraska Panhandle also aided in severe thunderstorm formation, though the position of this upper disturbance  kept the greatest deep layer shear displaced northwest from the cold front and strongest instability. The low level jet remained rather weak, thus the line of thunderstorms decreased in intensity after sunset with the onset of nocturnal cooling.

A few thunderstorms moved through central Kansas and produced hail from quarter to two inches in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea to golf ball sized hail fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak shortwave trough moved across the CWA under weak flow and interacted with a boundary draped across the I-70 corridor to initiate thunderstorms along HWY 283 to Dodge City. Sufficient CAPE and daytime heating sparked a number of storms that contained severe hail up to the size of golf balls in some locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moved across the CWA with the surface boundary again along the I-70 corridor initiating a number of severe storms that pushed southeast through the afternoon and evening hours. Severe hail and winds were the primary threat but tornadoes were possible in the QLCS scenario, but none were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was about 2 inches deep across Highway 183, especially near Road R.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled out stationary front served as the focal point for thunderstorm development mid afternoon on June 3rd. Thunderstorms first developed just south of the Nebraska/South Dakota border, then tracked southeast. Severe storms were first reported in north central Nebraska. Additional development took place further south along the front in portions of central, then southwestern Nebraska. Hail up to 2 inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind gusts of 70 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ping pong ball sized hail reported at this location.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to quarter sized hail covering the ground at this location.

Across western and north central Nebrasaka in November, precipitation was below normal for the month of November. Conditions were driest in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, western Sandhills, and southwestern Nebraska.  Locations in the eastern Sandhills and portions of central Nebraska had near normal to slightly below normal precipitation for the month. By the end of the month, extreme (D3) drought conditions had expanded into most of southwestern Nebraska. Temperatures were well above normal for November as Imperial recorded its 3rd warmest November on record. Broken Bow recorded its 4th warmest November and North Platte its 9th warmest November on record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions remained unchanged across Deuel county in November. The eastern quarter of the county remained in severe (D2) drought, while the western 3/4ths of the county remained in extreme (D3) drought.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of November, drought severity remained unchanged across Arthur county. Severe (D2) drought conditions were present over the western half of the county. EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of November, extreme (D3) drought conditions expanded into all of  Chase County. The cooperative station at Imperial reported 0.12 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.57 inches below the normal of 0.69 inches. Temperatures were well above normal for the month of November as Imperial recorded its 3rd warmest November on record. On the 3rd of November, the high in Imperial was 85 degrees which tied the all time record high for the month of November.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of November, severe (D2) drought expanded into far southern Custer county. The cooperative observer at Callaway 8WSW reported 0.47 inches of precipitation for the month. At the Broken Bow airport, 0.80 inches of precipitation fell. This was 0.15 inches below the normal of 0.95 inches. The cooperative station at Anselmo 2SE reported 0.80 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.32 inches below the normal of 1.12 inches. Temperatures were well above normal for the month as Broken Bow recorded its 4th warmest November on record.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter estimated wind gust by amateur measuring device in addition to half inch hail measured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The derecho that was moving through southeast Wyoming and northeast Colorado continued across the Nebraska Panhandle with severe and significant wind gusts. Received numerous reports of sheds blown over, metal roofs ripped off outbuildings, and large trees uprooted. Two injuries were reported as metal siding was blown across a highway striking two motorcyclists.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: AWOS station K1BW - Bravo Madis reported wind gust 14 miles west of Harrisburg, NE.

An ice storm began late Nov 9 and continued into Nov 10. It led to power outages and tree damage across 11 counties. The maximum ice measurement was 1.06 inches. Counties in colder air received less and significantly more snow with a maximum of 10 inches record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported that ice had led to power outages and significant tree damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An ice storm began late Nov 9 and continued into Nov 10. It led to power outages and tree damage across 11 counties. The maximum ice measurement was 1.06 inches. Counties in colder air received less and significantly more snow with a maximum of 10 inches record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports from public concerning ice. Multiple power outage reports. Numerous reports of damaged trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled out stationary front served as the focal point for thunderstorm development mid afternoon on June 3rd. Thunderstorms first developed just south of the Nebraska/South Dakota border, then tracked southeast. Severe storms were first reported in north central Nebraska. Additional development took place further south along the front in portions of central, then southwestern Nebraska. Hail up to 2 inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind gusts of 70 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds and quarter sized hail reported at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across western and north central Nebrasaka in November, precipitation was below normal for the month of November. Conditions were driest in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, western Sandhills, and southwestern Nebraska.  Locations in the eastern Sandhills and portions of central Nebraska had near normal to slightly below normal precipitation for the month. By the end of the month, extreme (D3) drought conditions had expanded into most of southwestern Nebraska. Temperatures were well above normal for November as Imperial recorded its 3rd warmest November on record. Broken Bow recorded its 4th warmest November and North Platte its 9th warmest November on record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of November, drought severity remained unchanged across Sheridan County.  The western half of the county was in extreme (D3) drought with the eastern half of the county in severe (D2) drought. The cooperative station at Gordon 6N reported 0.41 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.30 inches below the normal of 0.71 inches. The cooperative station at Ellsworth 2W reported 0.21 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.25 inches below the normal of 0.46 inches.

The cooperative station at Lisco reported 0.27 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.36 inches below the normal of 0.63 inches. The cooperative station at Oshkosh reported 0.25 inches of precipitation which was 0.25 inches below the normal of 0.50 inches. The cooperative station at Crescent Lakes NWR reported 0.22 inches for the month. This was 0.38 inches below the normal of 0.60 inches. The cooperative station at Oshkosh 8SW reported 0.26 inches of precipitation for the month. This was 0.39 inches below the normal of 0.65 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across western and north central Nebrasaka in November, precipitation was below normal for the month of November. Conditions were driest in the eastern Nebraska Panhandle, western Sandhills, and southwestern Nebraska.  Locations in the eastern Sandhills and portions of central Nebraska had near normal to slightly below normal precipitation for the month. EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the month of November, extreme (D3) drought conditions expanded into the southern half of Lincoln county. Along the Platte River Valley in central Lincoln county, severe (D2) drought conditions expanded slightly during the month into east central portions of the county. The cooperative station at Wallace 2W reported 0.23 inches of precipitation for November. This was 0.41 inches below the normal of 0.64 inches. The cooperative station at Hershey 5SSE reported 0.34 inches of precipitation in November. This was 0.22 inches below the normal of 0.56 inches. At the North Platte Airport, 0.28 inches of precipitation fell which was 0.36 inches below the normal of 0.64 inches. At the cooperative station in Brady, 0.16 inches of precipitation fell. Temperatures were well above normal for the month as North Platte recorded its 9th warmest November on record. On the 6th, the high in North Platte was 87 degrees. This broke the all time record high for the month of November.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between 9 p.m. and midnight CDT on this Wednesday evening, a smattering of mostly-weak thunderstorms rumbled from west-to-east across portions of this six-county North Central Kansas area, as the vast majority of severe storms in the region focused at least slightly off to the north and east. However, between 10:30-11:15 p.m. CDT, one small storm cluster flared up to severe levels over Jewell County, yielding a lone ground-truth report of measured 68 MPH winds in the far northeast corner of the county near Webber. Radar also indicated that this storm might have produced severe-criteria hail over mainly central sections of the county, but there were no verifying reports. In the mid-upper levels, this was not a strongly-forced event, with the main feature consisting of a low-amplitude shortwave trough tracking east-southeast across Nebraska out of western SD over the course of the afternoon-evening. Surface features in North Central Kansas during the evening were fairly nondescript, dominated by weak high pressure and generally southerly breezes around 10 MPH or less. However, fairly steep low-mid level lapse rates were in place, as evening mesoscale analysis revealed around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 35 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

A shortwave trough moved across the CWA with the surface boundary again along the I-70 corridor initiating a number of severe storms that pushed southeast through the afternoon and evening hours. Severe hail and winds were the primary threat but tornadoes were possible in the QLCS scenario, but none were reported.

A shortwave trough moved across the CWA with the surface boundary again along the I-70 corridor initiating a number of severe storms that pushed southeast through the afternoon and evening hours. Severe hail and winds were the primary threat but tornadoes were possible in the QLCS scenario, but none were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be around 80 MPH.
