EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The derecho that was moving through southeast Wyoming and northeast Colorado continued across the Nebraska Panhandle with severe and significant wind gusts. Received numerous reports of sheds blown over, metal roofs ripped off outbuildings, and large trees uprooted. Two injuries were reported as metal siding was blown across a highway striking two motorcyclists.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of a roof blown off a building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The derecho that was moving through southeast Wyoming and northeast Colorado continued across the Nebraska Panhandle with severe and significant wind gusts. Received numerous reports of sheds blown over, metal roofs ripped off outbuildings, and large trees uprooted. Two injuries were reported as metal siding was blown across a highway striking two motorcyclists.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of power poles broken along a 3 to 4 mile stretch of road 1 mile west of McGrew.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled out stationary front served as the focal point for thunderstorm development mid afternoon on June 3rd. Thunderstorms first developed just south of the Nebraska/South Dakota border, then tracked southeast. Severe storms were first reported in north central Nebraska. Additional development took place further south along the front in portions of central, then southwestern Nebraska. Hail up to 2 inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind gusts of 70 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts, estimated at 65 MPH, were reported at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough crossing the area and a warm front situated across northern Kansas helped to focus scattered thunderstorms, a few severe, across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Corn in the field was partially stripped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms extended south into Southwest Nebraska behind a weak cold front moving eastward.  The largest hail reported was baseball size near Palisade.  The same storms broke limbs off of trees at the same location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs of unknown size were blown down by the wind gusts.  This came with hail up to baseball size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms extended south into Southwest Nebraska behind a weak cold front moving eastward.  The largest hail reported was baseball size near Palisade.  The same storms broke limbs off of trees at the same location.
Unseasonably strong winds occurred at McCook, leading to a gust of 58 MPH being measured at the airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at the McCook airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Individual thunderstorms formed in southwest Nebraska and moved southeast into Kansas. As a thunderstorm entered northeast Norton County, it produced a 62 mph wind gust.
Unseasonably strong wind gusts occurred across far Southwest Nebraska.  The highest gust reported for the event was 68 MPH at the McCook airport.  The high winds also uprooted a tree in Benkelman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was uprooted in Benkelman from the high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably strong wind gusts occurred across far Southwest Nebraska.  The highest gust reported for the event was 68 MPH at the McCook airport.  The high winds also uprooted a tree in Benkelman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust for the county was reported at three WNW of Trenton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably strong wind gusts occurred across far Southwest Nebraska.  The highest gust reported for the event was 68 MPH at the McCook airport.  The high winds also uprooted a tree in Benkelman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak wind gust was reported at the McCook airport.  The high winds also caused a power line to be blown down that lead to a fire in a tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought status for Greeley and Wichita counties largely remained unchanged.  The D3 drought status expended eastward some into Greeley County, while Wichita County remained unchanged.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation for the month was on either side of two inches for the county.  This was 0.93 to 0.81 below normal for the month.  The southwest corner of the county worsened to D3 drought during the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moved across the CWA with the surface boundary again along the I-70 corridor initiating a number of severe storms that pushed southeast through the afternoon and evening hours. Severe hail and winds were the primary threat but tornadoes were possible in the QLCS scenario, but none were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak shortwave trough moved across northern portions of the area and into northwest Kansas, sparking a few thunderstorms that moved southward. Decent mid-level lapse rates and low level shear gave enough instability to produce damaging winds and quarter size hai.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system produced highs winds of 30 to 40 mph with gust of 60 to around 70 mph across southwest into central Nebraska. The strongest wind gusts occurred during the daytime hours into the early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby Imperial ASOS recorded a wind gust of 66 mph at 145 pm MST. Wind gusts exceeding 60 mph were common across Perkins County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brief landspout tornado formed in southern Dundy County. The tornado appeared to form as a storm was developing as it moved east northeast towards Benkelman, ahead of an incoming line of storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dundy County Dispatch received a report of a possible landspout 10 miles west of Benkelman. Landspout was in contact with the ground for 30 seconds. A review of radar data determined this event did occur as weather conditions were favorable for development.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed across the CWA bringing strong winds behind it, all non-thunderstorm induced. The gradient was really tight aided by the tropical disturbance remnants making its way through Missouri. Gusts as high as 78 mph were reported with many reports over the 58 mph threshold.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed at the Cimarron National Grasslands mesonet station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak landspout tornado was reported in Wallace County ahead of a weak cold front that was moving east during the mid afternoon. Behind the weak front, a cluster of thunderstorms developed between Goodland and St. Francis.  Hail up to nickel size was reported with these storms.  North of Kanorado two inches of rainfall was reported to have fallen in a half hour.  However no flooding was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed in eastern Colorado during the afternoon moving northeast behind an outflow boundary. As the storms entered into southwest Nebraska, they merged with thunderstorms that developed in northeast Colorado to form a line of storms along the outflow boundary. This line of storms produced hail up to penny sized sized in Dundy County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea to penny sized hail reported at the location.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to penny sized hail reported at the location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed off the Rockies in a line north of I-70 with a few clusters of storms to the south of I-70. As the storms moved east into Kansas, they produced wind gusts up to 70 mph causing blowing dust to reduce visibility in Rawlins County. The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Greeley County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter observed an estimated 60 mph wind gust as a strong precipitation embedded thunderstorm moved over the location.

As the storms moved east into Kansas, they produced wind gusts up to 70 mph causing blowing dust to reduce visibility in Rawlins County. The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Greeley County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire official reported ongoing 60 mph wind gusts causing blowing dirt and near zero visibility.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed off the Rockies in a line north of I-70 with a few clusters of storms to the south of I-70. As the storms moved east into Kansas, they produced wind gusts up to 70 mph causing blowing dust to reduce visibility in Rawlins County. The storms also produced up to penny sized hail in Greeley County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter observed estimated 65 mph wind gusts that broke a few live 2 inch diameter tree limbs and also caused blowing dust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed across the CWA bringing strong winds behind it, all non-thunderstorm induced. The gradient was really tight aided by the tropical disturbance remnants making its way through Missouri. Gusts as high as 78 mph were reported with many reports over the 58 mph threshold.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Liberal airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface boundary was draped across the northern sections of the CWA with an MCS that developed over northeastern Colorado that made its way across western and northern counties along this boundary. Damaging wind was the main threat with ample DCAPE usually associated in MCS like events.

A surface boundary was draped across the northern sections of the CWA with an MCS that developed over northeastern Colorado that made its way across western and northern counties along this boundary. Damaging wind was the main threat with ample DCAPE usually associated in MCS like events.

A surface boundary was draped across the northern sections of the CWA with an MCS that developed over northeastern Colorado that made its way across western and northern counties along this boundary. Damaging wind was the main threat with ample DCAPE usually associated in MCS like events.

A surface boundary was draped across the northern sections of the CWA with an MCS that developed over northeastern Colorado that made its way across western and northern counties along this boundary. Damaging wind was the main threat with ample DCAPE usually associated in MCS like events.

A surface boundary continued to be draped across northern counties with a weak upper level disturbance pushing out of Colorado. No severe weather occurred but a watch along with a slight risk was issued for these areas of west central to north central Kansas. Gusty winds up to 40-50 mph along with hail up to pennies occurred but no severe weather reports were reported.

A rogue storm developed across the far northern sections of central Kansas and ultimately transformed into a squall line that moved eastward across the remaining sections of central and portions of south central Kansas.  Of note, was the widespread heavy rain that fell across much of the area. Rainfall amounts were consistently in the 1.25 to 3.5 inch range for many locations.  The sites with rainfall amounts higher than 3 inches were individually added.

A weak landspout tornado was reported in Wallace County ahead of a weak cold front that was moving east during the mid afternoon.  No damage was reported with the landspout. |As the front moved east a brief dust storm was reported west of Goodland.  Behind the weak front, a cluster of thunderstorms developed between Goodland and St. Francis.  Hail up to nickel size was reported with these storms.  North of Kanorado two inches of rainfall was reported to have fallen in a half hour.  However no flooding was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged from pea to dime size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong downburst winds hit Sidney Nebraska the afternoon of 8 July 2020.

Large hail reported with a severe thunderstorm in Kimball County Nebraska, the evening of 3 July 2020.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Conditions with temperatures at record or near-record warm levels on December 22 underwent a drastic change over a brief 24 hour period, as a sharp upper-level trough in westerly flow amplified while translating from the Pacific Northwest to the Plains. Low pressure developed and deepened rapidly while moving from South Dakota around 0000CST December 23 to the northern Great Lakes by 0600CST December 24.||Very steep lower to mid-level lapse rates and lift focused within a 200-250hPa deep layer supportive of effective dendritic growth resulted in intense precipitation banding over a 5 to 8 hour period. Winds in the lower mixed layer reached 40 to 60 knots as Arctic air surged into the area behind the system, producing numerous hours of widespread whiteout conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted as high as 47 mph at South Sioux City, and despite a lack of pre-storm snow cover, snowfall which accumulated to 3.0 inches at Sioux City and 1.5 inches at Emerson resulted in widespread whiteout conditions for several hours. Travel was not advised during the blizzard across all of northeast NE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thanks to a somewhat-unexpectedly potent combination of intense northwest winds and relatively-minimal snow, mainly the daytime hours on this Wednesday featured several hours of near-blizzard to outright-blizzard conditions across most of South Central Nebraska, shutting down several highways for a time and snarling pre-Christmas travel. Various law enforcement agencies reported dozens of traffic accidents and slide-offs (fortunately none fatal within the local area) and the following main highways were reported closed at various times: Interstate 80 between York and Kearney, Highway 281 between Grand Island and Hastings, Highway 30 from Grand Island-Kearney, Highway 34 from Grand Island-York, Highway 6 from Hastings-Kenesaw and Highway 81 near Shelby (all had re-opened by late afternoon). In Adams County, snowplows were pulled off the road for several hours due to very poor visibility. As for areal coverage of white-out conditions, the worst/longest-lasting issues focused within counties both along/north of Highway 6 and also along/east of Highway 183 (including the Tri Cities). Within this area, most places endured at least semi-frequent blizzard conditions for 6-8 hours while accumulating 1-3 of snow, while far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) saw blizzard conditions for as long as 10-12 hours and received slightly-higher snow amounts up to 3-4. Meanwhile, the situation was not as severe within far southern/southwest counties especially near the Kansas border, where snow was lighter/less-intense compared to farther north (amounts mainly under 1) and didn't last as long. Although the magnitude of wintry precipitation/blizzard impacts varied somewhat across South Central Nebraska, all 24 counties dealt with at least 9-12 hours of feisty northwest winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 45-60+ MPH. A few of the highest official peak gusts at airports included: 76 MPH at Ord and 61 MPH at Grand Island, Hastings and York. While there were no known reports of substantial wind damage, NWS observers near both Arcadia and Shelby noted that several small tree branches were downed. ||Getting into more detail regarding event timing and meteorological background, the main driving force in the mid-upper levels was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Nebraska-Kansas during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. At the surface, the associated low pressure center gradually intensified from around 994 millibars as it crossed Nebraska during the overnight-early morning of the 22nd-23rd, to 988 millibars by mid-day in the IA-MN-WI border area, and then maintained intensity while reaching Lake Superior overnight. Locally, the initial surge of strong northwest winds crossed South Central Nebraska during the pre-dawn of the 23rd behind the main synoptic cold front, but gusts largely held under 50 MPH. The overall-strongest winds ended up occurring between mid-morning and mid-afternoon, corresponding to the peak surface pressure gradient between the departing/deepening low and strong high pressure nosing in from the west-northwest (for a few hours the west-to-east gradient across the state of Nebraska averaged near 25 millibars!) As for snowfall timing, an initial, narrow band swept across most of the area during the pre-dawn hours, but the primary, broad zone of mainly light-to-moderate snow (with brief heavier bursts) gradually overspread South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast during the morning, eventually departing in similar fashion during the afternoon. Actual falling/accumulating snow ended across most of the area between 2-4 p.m., but lingering blowing snow and ground blizzard conditions held on for a few more hours...until gusts diminished more consistently to around 30 MPH-or-less after nightfall. From a forecast review perspective, the intense winds and at least minor blowing snow impacts were fairly well-anticipated, as a High Wind Warning was issued for the entire area 12-18 hours in advance and a Winter Weather Advisory (for the majority of the area) was issued 6-18 hours out. However, especially the southward extent of accumulating snow and the resultant potential for all-out blizzard conditions was not as well foreseen (especially as far south as the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors), with several counties not placed under official Blizzard Warnings until rather late in the game. For sure, one of the biggest takeaways/reminders from this event was that even minimal snowfall can wreak havoc on travel in the presence of powerful winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on surrounding observations, periodic gusts near 60 MPH and sustained speeds near 40 MPH occurred across the county. The intense winds, combined with snow, promoted blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thanks to a somewhat-unexpectedly potent combination of intense northwest winds and relatively-minimal snow, mainly the daytime hours on this Wednesday featured several hours of near-blizzard to outright-blizzard conditions across most of South Central Nebraska, shutting down several highways for a time and snarling pre-Christmas travel. Various law enforcement agencies reported dozens of traffic accidents and slide-offs (fortunately none fatal within the local area) and the following main highways were reported closed at various times: Interstate 80 between York and Kearney, Highway 281 between Grand Island and Hastings, Highway 30 from Grand Island-Kearney, Highway 34 from Grand Island-York, Highway 6 from Hastings-Kenesaw and Highway 81 near Shelby (all had re-opened by late afternoon). In Adams County, snowplows were pulled off the road for several hours due to very poor visibility. As for areal coverage of white-out conditions, the worst/longest-lasting issues focused within counties both along/north of Highway 6 and also along/east of Highway 183 (including the Tri Cities). Within this area, most places endured at least semi-frequent blizzard conditions for 6-8 hours while accumulating 1-3 of snow, while far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) saw blizzard conditions for as long as 10-12 hours and received slightly-higher snow amounts up to 3-4. Meanwhile, the situation was not as severe within far southern/southwest counties especially near the Kansas border, where snow was lighter/less-intense compared to farther north (amounts mainly under 1) and didn't last as long. Although the magnitude of wintry precipitation/blizzard impacts varied somewhat across South Central Nebraska, all 24 counties dealt with at least 9-12 hours of feisty northwest winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 45-60+ MPH. A few of the highest official peak gusts at airports included: 76 MPH at Ord and 61 MPH at Grand Island, Hastings and York. While there were no known reports of substantial wind damage, NWS observers near both Arcadia and Shelby noted that several small tree branches were downed. ||Getting into more detail regarding event timing and meteorological background, the main driving force in the mid-upper levels was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Nebraska-Kansas during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. At the surface, the associated low pressure center gradually intensified from around 994 millibars as it crossed Nebraska during the overnight-early morning of the 22nd-23rd, to 988 millibars by mid-day in the IA-MN-WI border area, and then maintained intensity while reaching Lake Superior overnight. Locally, the initial surge of strong northwest winds crossed South Central Nebraska during the pre-dawn of the 23rd behind the main synoptic cold front, but gusts largely held under 50 MPH. The overall-strongest winds ended up occurring between mid-morning and mid-afternoon, corresponding to the peak surface pressure gradient between the departing/deepening low and strong high pressure nosing in from the west-northwest (for a few hours the west-to-east gradient across the state of Nebraska averaged near 25 millibars!) As for snowfall timing, an initial, narrow band swept across most of the area during the pre-dawn hours, but the primary, broad zone of mainly light-to-moderate snow (with brief heavier bursts) gradually overspread South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast during the morning, eventually departing in similar fashion during the afternoon. Actual falling/accumulating snow ended across most of the area between 2-4 p.m., but lingering blowing snow and ground blizzard conditions held on for a few more hours...until gusts diminished more consistently to around 30 MPH-or-less after nightfall. From a forecast review perspective, the intense winds and at least minor blowing snow impacts were fairly well-anticipated, as a High Wind Warning was issued for the entire area 12-18 hours in advance and a Winter Weather Advisory (for the majority of the area) was issued 6-18 hours out. However, especially the southward extent of accumulating snow and the resultant potential for all-out blizzard conditions was not as well foreseen (especially as far south as the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors), with several counties not placed under official Blizzard Warnings until rather late in the game. For sure, one of the biggest takeaways/reminders from this event was that even minimal snowfall can wreak havoc on travel in the presence of powerful winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periodic gusts near 60 MPH and sustained speeds near 40 MPH occurred across the county. The peak gusts of the day included 62 MPH, which was recorded at 2:33 PM by a mesonet station located 1 mile northwest of Wood River, and 61 MPH, which was recorded at 1:28 PM by the Grand Island Central Nebraska Regional Airport ASOS. The intense winds, combined with snow, promoted blizzard conditions.

The peak gust of the day was 60 MPH, which was recorded at 10:55 AM by a mesonet station located 2 miles north-northwest of Gothenburg. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Conditions with temperatures at record or near-record warm levels on December 22 underwent a drastic change over a brief 24 hour period, as a sharp upper-level trough in westerly flow amplified while translating from the Pacific Northwest to the Plains. Low pressure developed and deepened rapidly while moving from South Dakota around 0000CST December 23 to the northern Great Lakes by 0600CST December 24.||Very steep lower to mid-level lapse rates and lift focused within a 200-250hPa deep layer supportive of effective dendritic growth resulted in intense precipitation banding over a 5 to 8 hour period. Winds in the lower mixed layer reached 40 to 60 knots as Arctic air surged into the area behind the system, producing numerous hours of widespread whiteout conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted as high as 52 mph 2 miles east of Concord, and despite a lack of pre-storm snow cover, snowfall which accumulated to 3.5 inches at Concord resulted in widespread whiteout conditions for several hours. Travel was not advised during the blizzard across all of northeast NE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thanks to a somewhat-unexpectedly potent combination of intense northwest winds and relatively-minimal snow, mainly the daytime hours on this Wednesday featured several hours of near-blizzard to outright-blizzard conditions across most of South Central Nebraska, shutting down several highways for a time and snarling pre-Christmas travel. Various law enforcement agencies reported dozens of traffic accidents and slide-offs (fortunately none fatal within the local area) and the following main highways were reported closed at various times: Interstate 80 between York and Kearney, Highway 281 between Grand Island and Hastings, Highway 30 from Grand Island-Kearney, Highway 34 from Grand Island-York, Highway 6 from Hastings-Kenesaw and Highway 81 near Shelby (all had re-opened by late afternoon). In Adams County, snowplows were pulled off the road for several hours due to very poor visibility. As for areal coverage of white-out conditions, the worst/longest-lasting issues focused within counties both along/north of Highway 6 and also along/east of Highway 183 (including the Tri Cities). Within this area, most places endured at least semi-frequent blizzard conditions for 6-8 hours while accumulating 1-3 of snow, while far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) saw blizzard conditions for as long as 10-12 hours and received slightly-higher snow amounts up to 3-4. Meanwhile, the situation was not as severe within far southern/southwest counties especially near the Kansas border, where snow was lighter/less-intense compared to farther north (amounts mainly under 1) and didn't last as long. Although the magnitude of wintry precipitation/blizzard impacts varied somewhat across South Central Nebraska, all 24 counties dealt with at least 9-12 hours of feisty northwest winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 45-60+ MPH. A few of the highest official peak gusts at airports included: 76 MPH at Ord and 61 MPH at Grand Island, Hastings and York. While there were no known reports of substantial wind damage, NWS observers near both Arcadia and Shelby noted that several small tree branches were downed. ||Getting into more detail regarding event timing and meteorological background, the main driving force in the mid-upper levels was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Nebraska-Kansas during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. At the surface, the associated low pressure center gradually intensified from around 994 millibars as it crossed Nebraska during the overnight-early morning of the 22nd-23rd, to 988 millibars by mid-day in the IA-MN-WI border area, and then maintained intensity while reaching Lake Superior overnight. Locally, the initial surge of strong northwest winds crossed South Central Nebraska during the pre-dawn of the 23rd behind the main synoptic cold front, but gusts largely held under 50 MPH. The overall-strongest winds ended up occurring between mid-morning and mid-afternoon, corresponding to the peak surface pressure gradient between the departing/deepening low and strong high pressure nosing in from the west-northwest (for a few hours the west-to-east gradient across the state of Nebraska averaged near 25 millibars!) As for snowfall timing, an initial, narrow band swept across most of the area during the pre-dawn hours, but the primary, broad zone of mainly light-to-moderate snow (with brief heavier bursts) gradually overspread South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast during the morning, eventually departing in similar fashion during the afternoon. Actual falling/accumulating snow ended across most of the area between 2-4 p.m., but lingering blowing snow and ground blizzard conditions held on for a few more hours...until gusts diminished more consistently to around 30 MPH-or-less after nightfall. From a forecast review perspective, the intense winds and at least minor blowing snow impacts were fairly well-anticipated, as a High Wind Warning was issued for the entire area 12-18 hours in advance and a Winter Weather Advisory (for the majority of the area) was issued 6-18 hours out. However, especially the southward extent of accumulating snow and the resultant potential for all-out blizzard conditions was not as well foreseen (especially as far south as the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors), with several counties not placed under official Blizzard Warnings until rather late in the game. For sure, one of the biggest takeaways/reminders from this event was that even minimal snowfall can wreak havoc on travel in the presence of powerful winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on surrounding observations, periodic gusts near 60 MPH and sustained speeds near 40 MPH occurred across the county. The intense winds, combined with light snow, resulted in near-blizzard conditions at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low tracked across the Texas panhandle into northwestern Oklahoma that produced snow on the backside across southern counties of the CWA along the border. Reports up to a foot in the warning areas of Meade to Barber County with lesser amounts for the next tier of counties west and north of this line. Coupled with strong north winds gusting up to 30-40 mph, substantial impacts in the warning and advisory areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine inches of snow was observed in Ashland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across the area with high wind after the frontal passaged observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed at the Johnson airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thanks to a somewhat-unexpectedly potent combination of intense northwest winds and relatively-minimal snow, mainly the daytime hours on this Wednesday featured several hours of near-blizzard to outright-blizzard conditions across most of South Central Nebraska, shutting down several highways for a time and snarling pre-Christmas travel. Various law enforcement agencies reported dozens of traffic accidents and slide-offs (fortunately none fatal within the local area) and the following main highways were reported closed at various times: Interstate 80 between York and Kearney, Highway 281 between Grand Island and Hastings, Highway 30 from Grand Island-Kearney, Highway 34 from Grand Island-York, Highway 6 from Hastings-Kenesaw and Highway 81 near Shelby (all had re-opened by late afternoon). In Adams County, snowplows were pulled off the road for several hours due to very poor visibility. As for areal coverage of white-out conditions, the worst/longest-lasting issues focused within counties both along/north of Highway 6 and also along/east of Highway 183 (including the Tri Cities). Within this area, most places endured at least semi-frequent blizzard conditions for 6-8 hours while accumulating 1-3 of snow, while far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) saw blizzard conditions for as long as 10-12 hours and received slightly-higher snow amounts up to 3-4. Meanwhile, the situation was not as severe within far southern/southwest counties especially near the Kansas border, where snow was lighter/less-intense compared to farther north (amounts mainly under 1) and didn't last as long. Although the magnitude of wintry precipitation/blizzard impacts varied somewhat across South Central Nebraska, all 24 counties dealt with at least 9-12 hours of feisty northwest winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 45-60+ MPH. A few of the highest official peak gusts at airports included: 76 MPH at Ord and 61 MPH at Grand Island, Hastings and York. While there were no known reports of substantial wind damage, NWS observers near both Arcadia and Shelby noted that several small tree branches were downed. ||Getting into more detail regarding event timing and meteorological background, the main driving force in the mid-upper levels was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Nebraska-Kansas during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. At the surface, the associated low pressure center gradually intensified from around 994 millibars as it crossed Nebraska during the overnight-early morning of the 22nd-23rd, to 988 millibars by mid-day in the IA-MN-WI border area, and then maintained intensity while reaching Lake Superior overnight. Locally, the initial surge of strong northwest winds crossed South Central Nebraska during the pre-dawn of the 23rd behind the main synoptic cold front, but gusts largely held under 50 MPH. The overall-strongest winds ended up occurring between mid-morning and mid-afternoon, corresponding to the peak surface pressure gradient between the departing/deepening low and strong high pressure nosing in from the west-northwest (for a few hours the west-to-east gradient across the state of Nebraska averaged near 25 millibars!) As for snowfall timing, an initial, narrow band swept across most of the area during the pre-dawn hours, but the primary, broad zone of mainly light-to-moderate snow (with brief heavier bursts) gradually overspread South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast during the morning, eventually departing in similar fashion during the afternoon. Actual falling/accumulating snow ended across most of the area between 2-4 p.m., but lingering blowing snow and ground blizzard conditions held on for a few more hours...until gusts diminished more consistently to around 30 MPH-or-less after nightfall. From a forecast review perspective, the intense winds and at least minor blowing snow impacts were fairly well-anticipated, as a High Wind Warning was issued for the entire area 12-18 hours in advance and a Winter Weather Advisory (for the majority of the area) was issued 6-18 hours out. However, especially the southward extent of accumulating snow and the resultant potential for all-out blizzard conditions was not as well foreseen (especially as far south as the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors), with several counties not placed under official Blizzard Warnings until rather late in the game. For sure, one of the biggest takeaways/reminders from this event was that even minimal snowfall can wreak havoc on travel in the presence of powerful winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on surrounding observations, periodic gusts near 60 MPH and sustained speeds near 40 MPH occurred across the county. The intense winds, combined with light snow, resulted in near-blizzard conditions at times.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 2 to 4 inches across the county, and combined with wind gusts exceeding 60 MPH, blizzard conditions occurred. A CoCoRaHS observer from 9 miles northwest of Ord reported a total of 4.0 inches. The Cooperative Observer from Ord reported a total of 3.1 inches.

Meanwhile, the situation was not as severe within far southern/southwest counties especially near the Kansas border, where snow was lighter/less-intense compared to farther north (amounts mainly under 1) and didn't last as long. Although the magnitude of wintry precipitation/blizzard impacts varied somewhat across South Central Nebraska, all 24 counties dealt with at least 9-12 hours of feisty northwest winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 45-60+ MPH. A few of the highest official peak gusts at airports included: 76 MPH at Ord and 61 MPH at Grand Island, Hastings and York. While there were no known reports of substantial wind damage, NWS observers near both Arcadia and Shelby noted that several small tree branches were downed. ||Getting into more detail regarding event timing and meteorological background, the main driving force in the mid-upper levels was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Nebraska-Kansas during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. At the surface, the associated low pressure center gradually intensified from around 994 millibars as it crossed Nebraska during the overnight-early morning of the 22nd-23rd, to 988 millibars by mid-day in the IA-MN-WI border area, and then maintained intensity while reaching Lake Superior overnight. Locally, the initial surge of strong northwest winds crossed South Central Nebraska during the pre-dawn of the 23rd behind the main synoptic cold front, but gusts largely held under 50 MPH. The overall-strongest winds ended up occurring between mid-morning and mid-afternoon, corresponding to the peak surface pressure gradient between the departing/deepening low and strong high pressure nosing in from the west-northwest (for a few hours the west-to-east gradient across the state of Nebraska averaged near 25 millibars!) As for snowfall timing, an initial, narrow band swept across most of the area during the pre-dawn hours, but the primary, broad zone of mainly light-to-moderate snow (with brief heavier bursts) gradually overspread South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast during the morning, eventually departing in similar fashion during the afternoon. Actual falling/accumulating snow ended across most of the area between 2-4 p.m., but lingering blowing snow and ground blizzard conditions held on for a few more hours...until gusts diminished more consistently to around 30 MPH-or-less after nightfall. From a forecast review perspective, the intense winds and at least minor blowing snow impacts were fairly well-anticipated, as a High Wind Warning was issued for the entire area 12-18 hours in advance and a Winter Weather Advisory (for the majority of the area) was issued 6-18 hours out. However, especially the southward extent of accumulating snow and the resultant potential for all-out blizzard conditions was not as well foreseen (especially as far south as the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors), with several counties not placed under official Blizzard Warnings until rather late in the game. For sure, one of the biggest takeaways/reminders from this event was that even minimal snowfall can wreak havoc on travel in the presence of powerful winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 1 to 3 inches across the county, and combined with wind gusts near 60 MPH, blizzard conditions occurred. The Cooperative Observer from Loup City reported a total of 2.8 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds up to 47 mph sustained and wind gusts up to 61 mph were observed in Sherman County from the afternoon of 12/22/20 through the morning of 12/23/20. Both the max sustained winds of 47 mph and the max wind gust of 66 mph were recorded at the Goodland, KS ASOS. The high winds also caused blowing snow which reduced visibility to 1/4 of a mile during the morning of 12/23/20. Key impacts: blowing snow, high winds.

Meanwhile, the situation was not as severe within far southern/southwest counties especially near the Kansas border, where snow was lighter/less-intense compared to farther north (amounts mainly under 1) and didn't last as long. Although the magnitude of wintry precipitation/blizzard impacts varied somewhat across South Central Nebraska, all 24 counties dealt with at least 9-12 hours of feisty northwest winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 45-60+ MPH. A few of the highest official peak gusts at airports included: 76 MPH at Ord and 61 MPH at Grand Island, Hastings and York. While there were no known reports of substantial wind damage, NWS observers near both Arcadia and Shelby noted that several small tree branches were downed. ||Getting into more detail regarding event timing and meteorological background, the main driving force in the mid-upper levels was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Nebraska-Kansas during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. At the surface, the associated low pressure center gradually intensified from around 994 millibars as it crossed Nebraska during the overnight-early morning of the 22nd-23rd, to 988 millibars by mid-day in the IA-MN-WI border area, and then maintained intensity while reaching Lake Superior overnight. Locally, the initial surge of strong northwest winds crossed South Central Nebraska during the pre-dawn of the 23rd behind the main synoptic cold front, but gusts largely held under 50 MPH. The overall-strongest winds ended up occurring between mid-morning and mid-afternoon, corresponding to the peak surface pressure gradient between the departing/deepening low and strong high pressure nosing in from the west-northwest (for a few hours the west-to-east gradient across the state of Nebraska averaged near 25 millibars!) As for snowfall timing, an initial, narrow band swept across most of the area during the pre-dawn hours, but the primary, broad zone of mainly light-to-moderate snow (with brief heavier bursts) gradually overspread South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast during the morning, eventually departing in similar fashion during the afternoon. Actual falling/accumulating snow ended across most of the area between 2-4 p.m., but lingering blowing snow and ground blizzard conditions held on for a few more hours...until gusts diminished more consistently to around 30 MPH-or-less after nightfall. From a forecast review perspective, the intense winds and at least minor blowing snow impacts were fairly well-anticipated, as a High Wind Warning was issued for the entire area 12-18 hours in advance and a Winter Weather Advisory (for the majority of the area) was issued 6-18 hours out. However, especially the southward extent of accumulating snow and the resultant potential for all-out blizzard conditions was not as well foreseen (especially as far south as the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors), with several counties not placed under official Blizzard Warnings until rather late in the game. For sure, one of the biggest takeaways/reminders from this event was that even minimal snowfall can wreak havoc on travel in the presence of powerful winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 1 to 2 inches across the county, and combined with wind gusts near 60 MPH, blizzard conditions occurred. A total of 1.1 inches was reported at the NWS Hastings office located 4 miles north of Hastings. A NWS employee reported a total of 1.3 inches on the south side of Hastings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thanks to a somewhat-unexpectedly potent combination of intense northwest winds and relatively-minimal snow, mainly the daytime hours on this Wednesday featured several hours of near-blizzard to outright-blizzard conditions across most of South Central Nebraska, shutting down several highways for a time and snarling pre-Christmas travel. Various law enforcement agencies reported dozens of traffic accidents and slide-offs (fortunately none fatal within the local area) and the following main highways were reported closed at various times: Interstate 80 between York and Kearney, Highway 281 between Grand Island and Hastings, Highway 30 from Grand Island-Kearney, Highway 34 from Grand Island-York, Highway 6 from Hastings-Kenesaw and Highway 81 near Shelby (all had re-opened by late afternoon). In Adams County, snowplows were pulled off the road for several hours due to very poor visibility. As for areal coverage of white-out conditions, the worst/longest-lasting issues focused within counties both along/north of Highway 6 and also along/east of Highway 183 (including the Tri Cities). Within this area, most places endured at least semi-frequent blizzard conditions for 6-8 hours while accumulating 1-3 of snow, while far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) saw blizzard conditions for as long as 10-12 hours and received slightly-higher snow amounts up to 3-4. A few of the highest official peak gusts at airports included: 76 MPH at Ord and 61 MPH at Grand Island, Hastings and York. While there were no known reports of substantial wind damage, NWS observers near both Arcadia and Shelby noted that several small tree branches were downed. ||Getting into more detail regarding event timing and meteorological background, the main driving force in the mid-upper levels was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Nebraska-Kansas during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on surrounding observations, snowfall totals ranged from 1 to 2 inches across the county, and combined with wind gusts near 60 MPH, blizzard conditions occurred. A total of only 0.8 inch was reported at the Grand Island Central Nebraska Regional Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds up to 42 mph sustained and wind gusts up to 61 mph were observed in Wallace County beginning the night of 12/22/20 through the morning of 12/23/20. The max sustained winds of 42 mph were recorded 9 miles south-southeast of Sharon Springs, KS and the max wind gust of 61 mph was recorded at the 4 miles west of Wallace, KS. Key impacts: high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high sustained winds, including wind gusts up to 60 mph, were observed in Cheyenne County from the night of 12/22/20 through the afternoon of 12/23/20. The max wind gust of 60 mph was recorded at 6 miles north-northwest of McDonald, KS. Blowing snow caused by the high winds reduced visibility down to 1/2 of a mile in some areas on the morning of 12/23/20. Key impacts: blowing snow, high winds.

The max wind gust of 66 mph was recorded in Colby, KS. The high winds caused blowing snow which reduced visibility down to 1/4 of a mile in some areas on the morning of 12/23/20. Key impacts: blowing snow, high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the later evening of Monday the 14th and the early evening of Tuesday the 15th, most of South Central Nebraska received at least a shallow coating of snow, although only a handful of counties in the western half of the area reported amounts as high as 3-5 inches. Within these five counties (Dawson, Buffalo, Gosper, Furnas, Phelps), a few of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer measurements included: 5 at Sumner and six miles southwest of Lexington, 4.5 six miles south-southeast of Lexington, 4.1 four miles south of Cozad, 3.8 at Cambridge and 3.2 eight miles south of Elwood. Outside of these five counties, the vast majority of the remainder of South Central Nebraska received anywhere from a light dusting up to around 2. Winds were not much of a factor, with sustained speeds only averaging 5-15 MPH. Temperatures were also not overly-cold through this event, mainly low-mid 20s F. ||Breaking down event evolution and timing, snow got underway in western local counties mainly between 9 p.m. and midnight, and then continued intermittently throughout much of the morning and afternoon of the 15th while gradually expanding eastward to affect more of the area. Within the western counties that received the most snow, the majority of accumulation occurred by noon, but at least occasional light snow/flurries hung around until late in the afternoon. In the mid-upper levels, the main player behind this relatively low-key snow event was a shortwave trough traversing eastward across the central United States, but with the primary closed low/vorticity maximum focused a bit south of the local area, generally along the Kansas-Oklahoma border. At the surface, the relatively light winds across South Central Nebraska were largely a result of the primary surface low pressure system remaining hundreds of miles to the south-southwest (mainly over eastern New Mexico/west Texas).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals from area CoCoRaHS observers included 5 inches from 6 miles southwest of Lexington as well as from Sumner, 4.1 inches from 4 miles south of Cozad, and 3.5 inches from 1 mile east of Lexington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds up to 41 mph sustained and wind gusts up to 60 mph were observed in Rawlins County from the night of 12/22/20 through the morning of 12/23/20. Both the max sustained winds of 41 mph and the max wind gust of 60 mph were recorded at the Atwood, KS AWOS. The high winds caused blowing snow which reduced visibility down to less than 1/4 of a mile in some areas on the morning of 12/23/20. Key impacts: blowing snow, high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening, and through following morning, multiple bands of moderate to heavy snowfall rates moved north over parts of Northwest Kansas.  Up to eight inches of snow was reported from these bands, with the highest amounts over Rawlins County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county ranged from 5.5 to 6.  Key impacts:  heavy snowfall, slick roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening, and through following morning, multiple bands of moderate to heavy snowfall rates moved north over parts of Northwest Kansas.  Up to eight inches of snow was reported from these bands, with the highest amounts over Rawlins County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts of six inches were reported in Dundy County and Sherman County.  The same bands moved over Cheyenne County, so by proximity this county should have also received six inches of snowfall.  Key impacts:  heavy snowfall, slick roads.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county ranged from a couple inches in the southeast part of the county to eight inches in the Atwood and McDonald area. Key impacts:  heavy snowfall, slick roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of light wintry precipitation set up near the CO/KS border on December 2nd. Light snow was seen during the morning hours that transitioned to freezing drizzle later in the day. This precipitation caused hazardous road conditions that led to a vehicle accident in Sherman County, KS during the evening hours. The reported morning snowfall totals ranged from 0.1-0.5 with 0.03-0.04 of liquid equivalent precipitation for the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported an accident via social media involving a jack knifed semi truck on I-70 at mile marker 9 due to slick roads caused by freezing drizzle and light snow in the county. The report was received at 6:55 PM on 12/2/20. Key impacts: traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of December 27th, two large bands of snow developed in Colorado and moved into northwest Kansas. The northern most band formed over northeast Colorado and gradually moved south and east along the Kansas-Nebraska-Colorado border. The second band formed over southeast Colorado and slowly moved north into Greeley and Wichita counties before eventually merging with the northern band. Throughout the multi-day event, numerous small bands developed and moved across northwest Kansas producing snow that ranged in depth from a trace to 6 inches, with amounts increasing from south to north across the area. Light freezing drizzle produced a glaze of ice in Logan County. The highest snowfall totals occurred in northwest Sheridan County. Injuries were reported with accidents in Wichita, Logan, and Gove counties. Multiple non-injury accidents also occurred across Thomas, Logan, and Gove counties. Numerous vehicle slide-offs were also reported across Sherman, Thomas, and Cheyenne counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple bands of snow produced light snow accumulations across Cheyenne County ranging from 1 to 2 inches. At 6:58 pm CST on December 28th, a semi-truck traveling north-bound on KS-27 near the Kansas-Nebraska state line slid at the base of a hill due to snow-packed roads. The semi blocked both lanes of traffic for four hours with police units from Dundy County, Nebraska and Cheyenne County, Kansas responding to the situation. No injuries were reported. Key impacts: transportation delays, traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds up to 40 mph sustained were observed in Norton County during the morning of 12/23/20. The max sustained winds of 40 mph were recorded at the Norton, KS ASOS. Key impacts: high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds up to 47 mph sustained were observed in Logan County during the morning of 12/23/20. The max sustained winds of 47 mph were recorded at 9 miles west-southwest of Winona, KS. A report was received via social media of a small, unsecured shed that was destroyed by the high winds at 12:15 AM CST. Key impacts: blowing debris, property damage, high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds up to 42 mph sustained and wind gusts up to 58 mph were observed in Gove County starting in the morning of 12/23/20 that lasted until the afternoon of 12/23/20. Both the max sustained winds of 42 mph and the max wind gust of 58 mph were recorded 3 miles east-southeast of Oakley. Key impacts: high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For roughly 24 hours between the very early mornings of Friday the 11th and Saturday the 12th, much of South Central Nebraska saw its first 3-inch-or-greater snowfall of the 2020-21 season, including the Tri Cities. The highest amounts mainly in the 3-6 range (but localized higher) concentrated within a southwest-to-northeast swath bisecting the heart of the area, generally 20 miles either side of a line from near Cambridge-Minden-Doniphan-Shelby. Within this zone, a sampling of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer measurements featured: 8.1 three miles northeast of Shelby, 6.5 at Stromsburg, 6.4 in Grand Island, 6.3 in Holdrege and 6.0 at Osceola. Again though, most places within the main corridor checked in between 3-5, including 5.1 at NWS Hastings, 4.8 at Cambridge, 4.4 three miles north of York and 3.5 at Kearney airport. Meanwhile, both north and south of the primary snow band, totals dropped off considerably to no more than 1-2 (including places such as Ord, Greeley, Superior and Hebron). North winds were not overly-impactful, but strong enough to cause some minor blowing/drifting thanks to sustained speeds typically 15-20 MPH and occasional gusts around 30 MPH. While snow was by far the dominant precipitation type, a few observers (including at Osceola) reported a brief period of sleet/graupel early on. Temperatures during this event hovered within a few degrees either side of freezing. ||Timing-wise, while at least light snow/flurries affected much of the area for roughly 24 hours, the vast majority of steadier snow and accumulation occurred during the daytime and evening hours of the 11th. Forcing in the mid-upper levels was clearly tied to a modestly-strong shortwave trough tracking east through the Central Plains, probably most evident at 700 millibars as a closed low slid along/just south of the Nebraska-Kansas border. At the surface, the steady (but not overly-strong) north winds were driven by a modest pressure gradient between a broad high centered over the Dakotas/south-central Canada, and a fairly weak low that gradually drifted northeast from Oklahoma toward central Illinois (central pressure around 1006 millibars early evening on the 11th).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 4.4 inches was measured by a Cooperative Observer located 3 miles north of York. A CoCoRaHS observer located 6 miles north of Bradshaw measured 5.0 inches.

Forcing in the mid-upper levels was clearly tied to a modestly-strong shortwave trough tracking east through the Central Plains, probably most evident at 700 millibars as a closed low slid along/just south of the Nebraska-Kansas border. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the later evening of Monday the 14th and the early evening of Tuesday the 15th, most of South Central Nebraska received at least a shallow coating of snow, although only a handful of counties in the western half of the area reported amounts as high as 3-5 inches. Within these five counties (Dawson, Buffalo, Gosper, Furnas, Phelps), a few of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer measurements included: 5 at Sumner and six miles southwest of Lexington, 4.5 six miles south-southeast of Lexington, 4.1 four miles south of Cozad, 3.8 at Cambridge and 3.2 eight miles south of Elwood. Outside of these five counties, the vast majority of the remainder of South Central Nebraska received anywhere from a light dusting up to around 2. Winds were not much of a factor, with sustained speeds only averaging 5-15 MPH. Temperatures were also not overly-cold through this event, mainly low-mid 20s F. ||Breaking down event evolution and timing, snow got underway in western local counties mainly between 9 p.m. and midnight, and then continued intermittently throughout much of the morning and afternoon of the 15th while gradually expanding eastward to affect more of the area. Within the western counties that received the most snow, the majority of accumulation occurred by noon, but at least occasional light snow/flurries hung around until late in the afternoon. In the mid-upper levels, the main player behind this relatively low-key snow event was a shortwave trough traversing eastward across the central United States, but with the primary closed low/vorticity maximum focused a bit south of the local area, generally along the Kansas-Oklahoma border. At the surface, the relatively light winds across South Central Nebraska were largely a result of the primary surface low pressure system remaining hundreds of miles to the south-southwest (mainly over eastern New Mexico/west Texas).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.0 inches was reported at the Kearney Regional Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of December 27th, two large bands of snow developed in Colorado and moved into northwest Kansas. The northern most band formed over northeast Colorado and gradually moved south and east along the Kansas-Nebraska-Colorado border. The second band formed over southeast Colorado and slowly moved north into Greeley and Wichita counties before eventually merging with the northern band. Throughout the multi-day event, numerous small bands developed and moved across northwest Kansas producing snow that ranged in depth from a trace to 6 inches, with amounts increasing from south to north across the area. Light freezing drizzle produced a glaze of ice in Logan County. The highest snowfall totals occurred in northwest Sheridan County. Injuries were reported with accidents in Wichita, Logan, and Gove counties. Multiple non-injury accidents also occurred across Thomas, Logan, and Gove counties. Numerous vehicle slide-offs were also reported across Sherman, Thomas, and Cheyenne counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple bands of snow produced up to 2 inches of snow across Sherman County. Roads became snow-packed during the event, resulting in numerous slide-offs. The slide-offs most often occurred along US-24, KS-27, and I-70. Sherman County dispatch reported a passenger vehicle accident on the Kanas side of the Colorado-Kansas state line at 7:30 pm MST on December 28th. No injuries were reported. Key impacts: transportation delays, traffic accidents.

Throughout the multi-day event, numerous small bands developed and moved across northwest Kansas producing snow that ranged in depth from a trace to 6 inches, with amounts increasing from south to north across the area. Light freezing drizzle produced a glaze of ice in Logan County. The highest snowfall totals occurred in northwest Sheridan County. Numerous vehicle slide-offs were also reported across Sherman, Thomas, and Cheyenne counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple snow bands moved across Thomas County producing snow amounts of 2 to 3.7 inches. The highest snow totals occurred in the northeast corner of the county with 3.7 inches of snow reported near Rexford. Numerous slide-offs were reported during the event, particularly on I-70 and US-83. On December 28th, two accidents were reported with no injuries. At 6 pm CST, a semi-truck and a passenger vehicle collided near mile marker 60 on I-70. At  9:52 pm CST, a passenger vehicle slide off the road and into a ditch on County Road 31 half a mile off US-83. Key impacts: transportation delays, traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing snow caused by high winds was observed at NWS Goodland on the morning of 12/23/20. The blowing snow reduced visibility down to 1/4 of a mile. Key impacts: hazardous traveling conditions, blowing snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front high winds, including gusts up to 62 mph, were observed in Greeley County during the morning of 12/23/20. The max wind gust of 62 mph was recorded at the Tribune, KS AWOS. The high winds also caused blowing dust which reduced visibility to 2 miles during the morning of 12/23/20. Key impacts: high winds, blowing dust.

While snow was by far the dominant precipitation type, a few observers (including at Osceola) reported a brief period of sleet/graupel early on. Temperatures during this event hovered within a few degrees either side of freezing. ||Timing-wise, while at least light snow/flurries affected much of the area for roughly 24 hours, the vast majority of steadier snow and accumulation occurred during the daytime and evening hours of the 11th. Forcing in the mid-upper levels was clearly tied to a modestly-strong shortwave trough tracking east through the Central Plains, probably most evident at 700 millibars as a closed low slid along/just south of the Nebraska-Kansas border. At the surface, the steady (but not overly-strong) north winds were driven by a modest pressure gradient between a broad high centered over the Dakotas/south-central Canada, and a fairly weak low that gradually drifted northeast from Oklahoma toward central Illinois (central pressure around 1006 millibars early evening on the 11th).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 3 to 6 inches across the county (based on nearby reports and NOHRSC Snowfall Analysis).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For roughly 24 hours between the very early mornings of Friday the 11th and Saturday the 12th, much of South Central Nebraska saw its first 3-inch-or-greater snowfall of the 2020-21 season, including the Tri Cities. The highest amounts mainly in the 3-6 range (but localized higher) concentrated within a southwest-to-northeast swath bisecting the heart of the area, generally 20 miles either side of a line from near Cambridge-Minden-Doniphan-Shelby. Within this zone, a sampling of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer measurements featured: 8.1 three miles northeast of Shelby, 6.5 at Stromsburg, 6.4 in Grand Island, 6.3 in Holdrege and 6.0 at Osceola. Again though, most places within the main corridor checked in between 3-5, including 5.1 at NWS Hastings, 4.8 at Cambridge, 4.4 three miles north of York and 3.5 at Kearney airport. Meanwhile, both north and south of the primary snow band, totals dropped off considerably to no more than 1-2 (including places such as Ord, Greeley, Superior and Hebron). North winds were not overly-impactful, but strong enough to cause some minor blowing/drifting thanks to sustained speeds typically 15-20 MPH and occasional gusts around 30 MPH. While snow was by far the dominant precipitation type, a few observers (including at Osceola) reported a brief period of sleet/graupel early on. Temperatures during this event hovered within a few degrees either side of freezing. ||Timing-wise, while at least light snow/flurries affected much of the area for roughly 24 hours, the vast majority of steadier snow and accumulation occurred during the daytime and evening hours of the 11th. Forcing in the mid-upper levels was clearly tied to a modestly-strong shortwave trough tracking east through the Central Plains, probably most evident at 700 millibars as a closed low slid along/just south of the Nebraska-Kansas border. At the surface, the steady (but not overly-strong) north winds were driven by a modest pressure gradient between a broad high centered over the Dakotas/south-central Canada, and a fairly weak low that gradually drifted northeast from Oklahoma toward central Illinois (central pressure around 1006 millibars early evening on the 11th).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS observer located 6 miles southwest of Lexington measured a snowfall total of 5.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the later evening of Monday the 14th and the early evening of Tuesday the 15th, most of South Central Nebraska received at least a shallow coating of snow, although only a handful of counties in the western half of the area reported amounts as high as 3-5 inches. Within these five counties (Dawson, Buffalo, Gosper, Furnas, Phelps), a few of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer measurements included: 5 at Sumner and six miles southwest of Lexington, 4.5 six miles south-southeast of Lexington, 4.1 four miles south of Cozad, 3.8 at Cambridge and 3.2 eight miles south of Elwood. Outside of these five counties, the vast majority of the remainder of South Central Nebraska received anywhere from a light dusting up to around 2. Winds were not much of a factor, with sustained speeds only averaging 5-15 MPH. Temperatures were also not overly-cold through this event, mainly low-mid 20s F. ||Breaking down event evolution and timing, snow got underway in western local counties mainly between 9 p.m. and midnight, and then continued intermittently throughout much of the morning and afternoon of the 15th while gradually expanding eastward to affect more of the area. Within the western counties that received the most snow, the majority of accumulation occurred by noon, but at least occasional light snow/flurries hung around until late in the afternoon. In the mid-upper levels, the main player behind this relatively low-key snow event was a shortwave trough traversing eastward across the central United States, but with the primary closed low/vorticity maximum focused a bit south of the local area, generally along the Kansas-Oklahoma border. At the surface, the relatively light winds across South Central Nebraska were largely a result of the primary surface low pressure system remaining hundreds of miles to the south-southwest (mainly over eastern New Mexico/west Texas).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals were estimated to range from 2 to 4 inches across the northern half of the county (based on nearby reports and NOHRSC Snowfall Analysis).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although parts of this six-county North Central Kansas area received a very light dusting of snow on this Wednesday, it managed to avoid the steadier snow and blizzard conditions that slammed parts of Nebraska only 50-100 miles to the north. However, it could not avoid the same feisty northwest winds that its northern neighbor endured, as much of the day featured sustained speeds commonly 30-40 MPH and gusts of 45-60+ MPH. While observations from nearby/surrounding counties strongly suggest that all six local counties observed at least sporadic/brief instances of sustained 40 MPH and/or 58+ MPH gusts, the only verified severe-criteria gusts within the area included 61 MPH at the Phillipsburg airport and 58 MPH at Rooks County Regional Airport. There were no known ground-truth damage reports. ||In the mid-upper levels, the main driving force behind this high wind event was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Kansas-Nebraska during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. At the surface, the associated low pressure center gradually intensified from around 994 millibars as it crossed North Central Kansas during the overnight-early morning of the 22nd-23rd, to 988 millibars by mid-day in the IA-MN-WI border area, and then maintained intensity while reaching Lake Superior overnight. Locally, the initial surge of strong northwest winds passed through between midnight-3 a.m. behind the main synoptic cold front, but gusts largely peaked around 50 MPH or less. The overall-strongest winds of the day then occurred several hours later between mid-morning and early-afternoon, corresponding to the peak surface pressure gradient between the departing/deepening low and strong high pressure nosing in from the west-northwest (for much of the day the west-to-east gradient across the state of Kansas averaged 12-15 millibars). Between 5-7 p.m. wind gusts diminished to around 30 MPH or less, and they further decreased through the remainder of the night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periodic gusts near 60 MPH and sustained speeds near 40 MPH occurred across the county. The peak gust of the day was 61 MPH, which was recorded at 9:53 AM and 12:53 PM by the Phillipsburg Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of December 27th, two large bands of snow developed in Colorado and moved into northwest Kansas. The northern most band formed over northeast Colorado and gradually moved south and east along the Kansas-Nebraska-Colorado border. The second band formed over southeast Colorado and slowly moved north into Greeley and Wichita counties before eventually merging with the northern band. Throughout the multi-day event, numerous small bands developed and moved across northwest Kansas producing snow that ranged in depth from a trace to 6 inches, with amounts increasing from south to north across the area. Light freezing drizzle produced a glaze of ice in Logan County. The highest snowfall totals occurred in northwest Sheridan County. Injuries were reported with accidents in Wichita, Logan, and Gove counties. Multiple non-injury accidents also occurred across Thomas, Logan, and Gove counties. Numerous vehicle slide-offs were also reported across Sherman, Thomas, and Cheyenne counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple snow bands moved across Wichita county, producing only a trace of snow. While snow accumulations were low, roads became slick. At 8:07 am CST on December 29th, a passenger vehicle accident was reported on KS-25 near mile marker 118. One person was injured. Key impacts: traffic accident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of December 27th, two large bands of snow developed in Colorado and moved into northwest Kansas. The northern most band formed over northeast Colorado and gradually moved south and east along the Kansas-Nebraska-Colorado border. The second band formed over southeast Colorado and slowly moved north into Greeley and Wichita counties before eventually merging with the northern band. Throughout the multi-day event, numerous small bands developed and moved across northwest Kansas producing snow that ranged in depth from a trace to 6 inches, with amounts increasing from south to north across the area. Light freezing drizzle produced a glaze of ice in Logan County. The highest snowfall totals occurred in northwest Sheridan County. Injuries were reported with accidents in Wichita, Logan, and Gove counties. Multiple non-injury accidents also occurred across Thomas, Logan, and Gove counties. Numerous vehicle slide-offs were also reported across Sherman, Thomas, and Cheyenne counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple bands of snow moved across Logan County during the event, producing a range of snow from a trace to 1.8 inches. The Logan County Emergency Manager also reported freezing drizzle that accumulated a glaze of ice on surfaces. Several slide-offs occurred on I-70 along with two accidents. At 7:49 pm CST on December 28th, a rollover accident occurred on US-40 between County Roads 360 and 370 with a passenger vehicle containing five passengers. Three injuries were reported. At 11:36 pm CST on December 28th, a 2 passenger vehicle collision occurred on I-70 near mile marker 79. No injuries were reported with the second accident. Key impacts: transportation delays, traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The northwestern portion of Kansas saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning in the afternoon hours of December 22nd that continued until the afternoon hours of December 23rd. The Goodland, KS ASOS recorded both the highest sustained winds at 46 mph and the highest wind gust at 66 mph. These winds caused damage to property as well as reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing dust and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing snow caused by high winds was observed via Kansas Department of Highways camera during the afternoon of 12/23/20. The blowing snow reduced visibility down to an estimated 1/4 of a mile. Key impacts: hazardous traveling conditions, blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The far southwestern portion of Nebraska saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning during the overnight hours of December 22nd that continued until the  afternoon hours of December 23rd. The highest sustained winds were recorded 2 miles northwest of Haigler, NE at 45 mph while the highest wind gust was recorded at the McCook, NE airport of 70 mph. These winds caused reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Due to a cold front, high winds up to 40 mph sustained and wind gusts up to 70 mph were observed in Red Willow County from the night of 12/22/20 through the morning of 12/23/20. Both the max sustained winds of 40 mph and the max wind gust of 70 mph were recorded at the McCook, NE ASOS. Blowing snow caused by the high winds reduced visibility down to 1/2 mile in some areas on the morning of 12/23/20. Key impacts: blowing snow, high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The far southwestern portion of Nebraska saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning during the overnight hours of December 22nd that continued until the  afternoon hours of December 23rd. The highest sustained winds were recorded 2 miles northwest of Haigler, NE at 45 mph while the highest wind gust was recorded at the McCook, NE airport of 70 mph. These winds caused reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds including wind gusts up to 65 mph were observed in Hitchcock County from the night of 12/22/20 into the morning of 12/23/20. The max wind gust of 65 mph was recorded 3 miles west-northwest of Trenton, NE. Key impacts: high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system lifted northward through Arkansas and into Missouri from New Years Eve into New Years Day. Freezing rain spread into southeast Kansas during the evening hours of Thursday, December 31. The freezing rain continued into January 1, 2021 before transitioning over to snow with minor accumulations reported. Ice accumulations that continued into January 1, 2021 resulted in tree damage and scattered power outages on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain overspread the county during the evening hours of December 31. Public reports of estimated ice accumulations were around .10 to .15 inches, with the higher amounts across the northern sections of the county. This storm continued into January 1, 2021.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system lifted northward through Arkansas and into Missouri from New Years Eve into New Years Day. Freezing rain spread into southeast Kansas during the evening hours of Thursday, December 31. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimates of between 0.10 and 0.20 inches of flat ice accretion by midnight.  This storm continued into January 1 of 2021.
