The highest amounts mainly in the 3-6 range (but localized higher) concentrated within a southwest-to-northeast swath bisecting the heart of the area, generally 20 miles either side of a line from near Cambridge-Minden-Doniphan-Shelby. Within this zone, a sampling of the highest CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer measurements featured: 8.1 three miles northeast of Shelby, 6.5 at Stromsburg, 6.4 in Grand Island, 6.3 in Holdrege and 6.0 at Osceola. Again though, most places within the main corridor checked in between 3-5, including 5.1 at NWS Hastings, 4.8 at Cambridge, 4.4 three miles north of York and 3.5 at Kearney airport. Meanwhile, both north and south of the primary snow band, totals dropped off considerably to no more than 1-2 (including places such as Ord, Greeley, Superior and Hebron). North winds were not overly-impactful, but strong enough to cause some minor blowing/drifting thanks to sustained speeds typically 15-20 MPH and occasional gusts around 30 MPH. While snow was by far the dominant precipitation type, a few observers (including at Osceola) reported a brief period of sleet/graupel early on. Temperatures during this event hovered within a few degrees either side of freezing. ||Timing-wise, while at least light snow/flurries affected much of the area for roughly 24 hours, the vast majority of steadier snow and accumulation occurred during the daytime and evening hours of the 11th. Forcing in the mid-upper levels was clearly tied to a modestly-strong shortwave trough tracking east through the Central Plains, probably most evident at 700 millibars as a closed low slid along/just south of the Nebraska-Kansas border. At the surface, the steady (but not overly-strong) north winds were driven by a modest pressure gradient between a broad high centered over the Dakotas/south-central Canada, and a fairly weak low that gradually drifted northeast from Oklahoma toward central Illinois (central pressure around 1006 millibars early evening on the 11th).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 2.6 inches was measured in Orleans. Higher totals were likely in northern portions of the county based on surrounding reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of December 27th, two large bands of snow developed in Colorado and moved into northwest Kansas. The northern most band formed over northeast Colorado and gradually moved south and east along the Kansas-Nebraska-Colorado border. The second band formed over southeast Colorado and slowly moved north into Greeley and Wichita counties before eventually merging with the northern band. Throughout the multi-day event, numerous small bands developed and moved across northwest Kansas producing snow that ranged in depth from a trace to 6 inches, with amounts increasing from south to north across the area. Light freezing drizzle produced a glaze of ice in Logan County. The highest snowfall totals occurred in northwest Sheridan County. Injuries were reported with accidents in Wichita, Logan, and Gove counties. Multiple non-injury accidents also occurred across Thomas, Logan, and Gove counties. Numerous vehicle slide-offs were also reported across Sherman, Thomas, and Cheyenne counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple bands of snow moved across Gove County producing a range of snow amounts from a trace to 2 inches. Numerous slide-offs were reported on I-70 and KS-212. At 5:28 pm CST on December 28th, a rollover accident involving a passenger vehicle occurred near mile marker 99 on I-70. No injuries were reported. At 6:05 pm CST on December 28th, a two semi-truck collision occurred resulting in one injury and a truck stuck in a ditch. The accident occurred near mile marker 99 on I-70. Key impacts: transportation delays, traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple bands of snow moved northeast across northwest Kansas producing snow ranging in amount from a trace to 2 inches. The highest snow accumulations occurred in Sherman, Wallace, and Decatur counties. Vehicle slide-offs were reported in Thomas, Sherman, and Sheridan counties due to the slick road conditions. Two no-injury accidents were reported in Sherman County near the Kansas-Colorado state line the morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow accumulated across Sherman County ranging in amounts from 1 to 2 inches. Two accidents with no injuries occurred near the Colorado-Kansas state line on I-70 around 6:15 am MST. The first accident was a rollover van. The second accident was a semi-truck that jack-knifed into a ditch. A passenger vehicle spin-out also occurred on I-70 near mile marker 31 around 6:20 am MST due to slick roads. No injuries were reported. Key impacts: traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The far southwestern portion of Nebraska saw non-thunderstorm high sustained winds and gusts associated with a cold front beginning during the overnight hours of December 22nd that continued until the  afternoon hours of December 23rd. The highest sustained winds were recorded 2 miles northwest of Haigler, NE at 45 mph while the highest wind gust was recorded at the McCook, NE airport of 70 mph. These winds caused reduced visibilities in the area due to blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds up to 45 mph sustained were observed in Dundy County during the night of 12/22/20 to the morning of 12/23/20. The max sustained wind of 45 mph was recorded 2 miles northwest of Haigler, NE. Key impacts: high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During December, 20 of the 24 counties in South Central Nebraska were either completely or partially-included in Severe Drought (D2)-or-worse, per weekly issuances of the U.S. Drought Monitor. Of these 20 counties, 18 of them spent the entire month in either Severe (D2) or Extreme Drought (D3), while portions of western Merrick and far western Nance counties were added into the D2 mix starting on the 8th. Overall though, and not surprisingly given this was a winter month (and non-growing season), drought categories changed very little during December. However, the mainly status quo (and not worsening) drought situation could also be credited to some positive precipitation trends, as roughly two-thirds of the area received at least slightly above normal monthly totals (commonly 0.65-1.10) and roughly 80 percent of the area reported at least one-half inch (a respectable amount by December standards). In fact, for much of the western half of the area (generally west of Highway 281), December ended a four-month stretch of solidly below normal precipitation that had defined August-November.||Detailing specific drought categories during December (and going from worst to best): There was no change whatsoever in the areal coverage of D3, which continued to include all of Furnas/Gosper counties, along with adjacent portions of Dawson/Phelps/Harlan/far southwestern Buffalo (total of six affected counties). To the east-northeast of there, all-or-some of 14 counties (but especially those along/west of Highway 281) spent all-or-most of the month in D2. Meanwhile, the remaining four far-eastern local counties (along the Highway 81 corridor) largely maintained Moderate Drought (D1) status during December, although much of Thayer and far southeastern Fillmore/Nuckolls counties actually improved to Abnormally Dry (D0) early in the month (effectively reverting back to what was assigned there in late-October). Per several dozen NWS cooperative observers/official stations, a few of the overall-highest December precipitation totals within South Central Nebraska featured: 1.51 at Osceola, 1.30 three miles northeast of Shelby and 1.20 at Grand Island (Central Nebraska Regional Airport). In contrast, a few of the lowest (and below normal) tallies included: 0.26 at Harlan County Lake, 0.29 in Red Cloud and 0.29 in Franklin. Temperature-wise, although certainly not as big of a drought-factor as it would have been during the growing season, December was the second-straight warmer-than-average month, with most local stations averaging around 5 degrees F above normal.

In fact, for much of the western half of the area (generally west of Highway 281), December ended a four-month stretch of solidly below normal precipitation that had defined August-November.||Detailing specific drought categories during December (and going from worst to best): There was no change whatsoever in the areal coverage of D3, which continued to include all of Furnas/Gosper counties, along with adjacent portions of Dawson/Phelps/Harlan/far southwestern Buffalo (total of six affected counties). To the east-northeast of there, all-or-some of 14 counties (but especially those along/west of Highway 281) spent all-or-most of the month in D2. Meanwhile, the remaining four far-eastern local counties (along the Highway 81 corridor) largely maintained Moderate Drought (D1) status during December, although much of Thayer and far southeastern Fillmore/Nuckolls counties actually improved to Abnormally Dry (D0) early in the month (effectively reverting back to what was assigned there in late-October). Per several dozen NWS cooperative observers/official stations, a few of the overall-highest December precipitation totals within South Central Nebraska featured: 1.51 at Osceola, 1.30 three miles northeast of Shelby and 1.20 at Grand Island (Central Nebraska Regional Airport). In contrast, a few of the lowest (and below normal) tallies included: 0.26 at Harlan County Lake, 0.29 in Red Cloud and 0.29 in Franklin. Temperature-wise, although certainly not as big of a drought-factor as it would have been during the growing season, December was the second-straight warmer-than-average month, with most local stations averaging around 5 degrees F above normal.

A storm system lifted northward through Arkansas and into Missouri from New Years Eve into New Years Day. Freezing rain spread into southeast Kansas during the evening hours of Thursday, December 31. The freezing rain continued into January 1, 2021 before transitioning over to snow with minor accumulations reported. Ice accumulations that continued into January 1, 2021 resulted in tree damage and scattered power outages on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reports of widespread flat ice accumulations estimated between 0.10 and 0.20 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A batch of strong winds moved across central and south central Kansas during the nighttime hours of December 22nd-23rd with speeds ranging from 50-55mph. Another round of strong winds occurred during the afternoon at a few sites with speeds peaking at 58 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Salina Regional Airport reported a peak wind gust of 58 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Hutchinson Regional Airport measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site located 7 SSW of Westfall measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite near to slightly above normal precipitation occurring over Northwest Kansas, the D2 Severe to D3 Extreme Drought status did not change for December.  Precipitation amounts ranged from 0.25 to 1 which is near normal for December.  Counties in the D2 Severe Drought include Wichita, Sheridan, the southeastern half of Logan and Norton counties, and the northwestern half of Graham.  The rest of Northwest Kansas was in D3 Extreme Drought.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation across the county ranged from 0.50 to 1.  This was near the normal precipitation range of 0.25 to 1.  Key impacts:  drought.

During December, portions of three of the six North Central Kansas counties remained in Severe Drought (D2)-or-worse per weekly issuances of the U.S. Drought Monitor, as overall there was very little change to local drought categories during the month despite prevailing below normal precipitation (not unusual for a winter month outside the growing season). More specifically, D2 remained intact across much of northern Phillips and Smith counties along with far northwestern Jewell County, while Extreme Drought (D3) lingered within the extreme northwest edge of Phillips County. Outside of the D2/D3 areas, the remainder of the six-county area was a varied mix of Moderate Drought (D1) and Abnormally Dry (D0), as portions of Jewell, Mitchell, eastern Osborne and southeastern Smith counties actually improved to D0 early in the month (effectively reverting back to what was assigned there in late-October). ||Going into more detail regarding December precipitation trends, it was a fairly dry month across North Central Kansas, marking the fourth month out of the last five to feature prevailing below normal precipitation across most of the area (November being the only somewhat-wetter exception in some spots). The majority of NWS cooperative observer/CoCoRaHS stations only reported between 0.15-0.40 for the month (or generally 25-50 percent of normal). Measured extremes ranged from as much as 0.49 ten miles south-southwest of Beloit and 0.46 in Beloit, to as little as 0.09 near Damar and 0.12 in Smith Center. More significantly, and from a longer-duration perspective covering the five-month-stretch from August-December, a few of the very-driest NWS observer precipitation totals within/near the D3/D2 area included 2.02 at Logan (driest on record), 2.07 at Phillipsburg (driest on record) and 2.71 in Smith Center (2nd-driest on record). Temperature-wise, although certainly not as big of a drought-factor as it would have been during the growing season, December was the second-straight warmer-than-average month, with most local stations averaging 5-6 degrees F above normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Only a few days after South Central Nebraska had melted off the vast majority of lingering snow cover from earlier in the month, a moderately-strong winter storm rolled through between the evening of Monday the 28th and afternoon of Tuesday the 29th, dropping a fresh blanket of 2-8 inches of snow in most locales, followed by a light coating of sleet and freezing rain/drizzle especially in southeast counties. Overall though, snow was clearly the main story, especially within northern counties along/north of Highway 92 where the highest amounts of 5-8 concentrated, including CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer totals of: 7.4 in St. Paul and Ord, 6.8 at Greeley, 6.5 in Loup City and also two miles west of Genoa, and 6.1 in North Loup. Southward from there, slightly-lower amounts of 3-5 prevailed within counties along the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors, including totals of 5 at Sumner, 4.1 at NWS Hastings, 4.0 in Grand Island and 3.5 in Clay Center and Geneva. Farther south yet, the overall-lowest snowfall of 1-3 fell within far southern counties along the Kansas border. However, especially areas in/near Nuckolls and Thayer counties saw some steadier periods of light freezing rain and sleet showers during the latter stages of the event, although ice accumulation was generally only around one-tenth of an inch and potential travel issues solely from icing were likely muted given that it fell onto freshly-fallen snow. Locations farther north and west (including the Tri Cities area) also saw a light wintry mix of sleet and freezing drizzle in the wake of departing snow, but icing amounted to just a light glaze and the travel impacts from snow-covered roads were far more of a factor (though no closures of main highways occurred). Winds were not overly-strong during the main period of snow, but steady east-southeast speeds of 10-20 MPH with occasional gusts as high as 25-30 MPH were enough to cause some modest blowing/drifting. Temperatures during most of the event hovered in the 20s F.||Taking a closer look at how things unfolded, the majority of snow accumulation occurred between 9 p.m. on the 28th and sunrise on the 29th, as a northwest-to-southeast oriented band of moderate to briefly-heavy snow steadily advanced across South Central Nebraska from southwest-to-northeast. This primary band was driven by a fairly classic case of low-mid level isentropic lift and mid level frontogenesis (especially evident at 700 millibars), with this forcing focused downstream from a larger-scale, positively-tilted trough positioned from the Desert Southwest into the Central Rockies. However, things changed character near and especially after sunrise on the 29th in the wake of the main snow band, as the combination of lower-level warm air advection and an intrusion of drier mid-level air from the southwest (with resultant steepening lapse rates) allowed precipitation to transition from predominantly snow to mainly isolated to scattered sleet showers and areas of light freezing rain/drizzle. Any steadier/measurable precipitation gradually departed the majority of the local area from west-to-east between sunrise and noon, although pesky light freezing drizzle hung around in some places until early evening. At the surface, the modestly-breezy east-southeast winds that peaked between midnight-noon were driven by a decent pressure gradient between a strong/expansive 1035 millibar high departing eastbound through the Midwest and a 1008 millibar low centered over Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow amounts ranged from 5 to 8 inches across the county. Cooperative Observer reports included 7.4 inches at Ord, 6.1 inches at North Loup, and 5.1 inches from 2 miles west of Arcadia. CoCoRaHS observer reports included 6.7 inches from 5 miles southwest of Elyria and 5.0 inches from 9 miles northwest of Ord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite near to slightly above normal precipitation occurring over Northwest Kansas, the D2 Severe to D3 Extreme Drought status did not change for December.  Precipitation amounts ranged from 0.25 to 1 which is near normal for December.  Counties in the D2 Severe Drought include Wichita, Sheridan, the southeastern half of Logan and Norton counties, and the northwestern half of Graham.  The rest of Northwest Kansas was in D3 Extreme Drought.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation across the county ranged from 0.25 to 0.50.  This was near the normal precipitation range of 0.25 to 0.50.  Key impacts:  drought.

Winds were not overly-strong during the main period of snow, but steady east-southeast speeds of 10-20 MPH with occasional gusts as high as 25-30 MPH were enough to cause some modest blowing/drifting. Temperatures during most of the event hovered in the 20s F.||Taking a closer look at how things unfolded, the majority of snow accumulation occurred between 9 p.m. on the 28th and sunrise on the 29th, as a northwest-to-southeast oriented band of moderate to briefly-heavy snow steadily advanced across South Central Nebraska from southwest-to-northeast. This primary band was driven by a fairly classic case of low-mid level isentropic lift and mid level frontogenesis (especially evident at 700 millibars), with this forcing focused downstream from a larger-scale, positively-tilted trough positioned from the Desert Southwest into the Central Rockies. However, things changed character near and especially after sunrise on the 29th in the wake of the main snow band, as the combination of lower-level warm air advection and an intrusion of drier mid-level air from the southwest (with resultant steepening lapse rates) allowed precipitation to transition from predominantly snow to mainly isolated to scattered sleet showers and areas of light freezing rain/drizzle. Any steadier/measurable precipitation gradually departed the majority of the local area from west-to-east between sunrise and noon, although pesky light freezing drizzle hung around in some places until early evening. At the surface, the modestly-breezy east-southeast winds that peaked between midnight-noon were driven by a decent pressure gradient between a strong/expansive 1035 millibar high departing eastbound through the Midwest and a 1008 millibar low centered over Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow amounts ranged from 3 to 5 inches across the county. The Cooperative Observer 4 miles north of Aurora reported 4.3 inches. A CoCoRaHS observer from 2 miles south of Hordville reported 5.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Only a few days after South Central Nebraska had melted off the vast majority of lingering snow cover from earlier in the month, a moderately-strong winter storm rolled through between the evening of Monday the 28th and afternoon of Tuesday the 29th, dropping a fresh blanket of 2-8 inches of snow in most locales, followed by a light coating of sleet and freezing rain/drizzle especially in southeast counties. Overall though, snow was clearly the main story, especially within northern counties along/north of Highway 92 where the highest amounts of 5-8 concentrated, including CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer totals of: 7.4 in St. Paul and Ord, 6.8 at Greeley, 6.5 in Loup City and also two miles west of Genoa, and 6.1 in North Loup. Southward from there, slightly-lower amounts of 3-5 prevailed within counties along the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors, including totals of 5 at Sumner, 4.1 at NWS Hastings, 4.0 in Grand Island and 3.5 in Clay Center and Geneva. Farther south yet, the overall-lowest snowfall of 1-3 fell within far southern counties along the Kansas border. However, especially areas in/near Nuckolls and Thayer counties saw some steadier periods of light freezing rain and sleet showers during the latter stages of the event, although ice accumulation was generally only around one-tenth of an inch and potential travel issues solely from icing were likely muted given that it fell onto freshly-fallen snow. Winds were not overly-strong during the main period of snow, but steady east-southeast speeds of 10-20 MPH with occasional gusts as high as 25-30 MPH were enough to cause some modest blowing/drifting. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite near to slightly above normal precipitation occurring over Northwest Kansas, the D2 Severe to D3 Extreme Drought status did not change for December.  Precipitation amounts ranged from 0.25 to 1 which is near normal for December.  Counties in the D2 Severe Drought include Wichita, Sheridan, the southeastern half of Logan and Norton counties, and the northwestern half of Graham.  The rest of Northwest Kansas was in D3 Extreme Drought.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation across the county ranged from 0.25 to 1.  This was near the normal precipitation range of 0.50 to 1.  Key impacts:  drought.

Locations farther north and west (including the Tri Cities area) also saw a light wintry mix of sleet and freezing drizzle in the wake of departing snow, but icing amounted to just a light glaze and the travel impacts from snow-covered roads were far more of a factor (though no closures of main highways occurred). Winds were not overly-strong during the main period of snow, but steady east-southeast speeds of 10-20 MPH with occasional gusts as high as 25-30 MPH were enough to cause some modest blowing/drifting. Temperatures during most of the event hovered in the 20s F.||Taking a closer look at how things unfolded, the majority of snow accumulation occurred between 9 p.m. on the 28th and sunrise on the 29th, as a northwest-to-southeast oriented band of moderate to briefly-heavy snow steadily advanced across South Central Nebraska from southwest-to-northeast. This primary band was driven by a fairly classic case of low-mid level isentropic lift and mid level frontogenesis (especially evident at 700 millibars), with this forcing focused downstream from a larger-scale, positively-tilted trough positioned from the Desert Southwest into the Central Rockies. However, things changed character near and especially after sunrise on the 29th in the wake of the main snow band, as the combination of lower-level warm air advection and an intrusion of drier mid-level air from the southwest (with resultant steepening lapse rates) allowed precipitation to transition from predominantly snow to mainly isolated to scattered sleet showers and areas of light freezing rain/drizzle. Any steadier/measurable precipitation gradually departed the majority of the local area from west-to-east between sunrise and noon, although pesky light freezing drizzle hung around in some places until early evening. At the surface, the modestly-breezy east-southeast winds that peaked between midnight-noon were driven by a decent pressure gradient between a strong/expansive 1035 millibar high departing eastbound through the Midwest and a 1008 millibar low centered over Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches across most of the county. Cooperative Observer reports included 3.5 inches in Geneva and 3.0 inches from 4 miles south of Shickley. CoCoRaHS observer reports included 4.5 inches from 4 miles northwest of Milligan and 3.0 inches from 2 miles west-southwest of Tobias.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Only a few days after South Central Nebraska had melted off the vast majority of lingering snow cover from earlier in the month, a moderately-strong winter storm rolled through between the evening of Monday the 28th and afternoon of Tuesday the 29th, dropping a fresh blanket of 2-8 inches of snow in most locales, followed by a light coating of sleet and freezing rain/drizzle especially in southeast counties. Overall though, snow was clearly the main story, especially within northern counties along/north of Highway 92 where the highest amounts of 5-8 concentrated, including CoCoRaHS/NWS cooperative observer totals of: 7.4 in St. Paul and Ord, 6.8 at Greeley, 6.5 in Loup City and also two miles west of Genoa, and 6.1 in North Loup. Southward from there, slightly-lower amounts of 3-5 prevailed within counties along the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors, including totals of 5 at Sumner, 4.1 at NWS Hastings, 4.0 in Grand Island and 3.5 in Clay Center and Geneva. Farther south yet, the overall-lowest snowfall of 1-3 fell within far southern counties along the Kansas border. However, especially areas in/near Nuckolls and Thayer counties saw some steadier periods of light freezing rain and sleet showers during the latter stages of the event, although ice accumulation was generally only around one-tenth of an inch and potential travel issues solely from icing were likely muted given that it fell onto freshly-fallen snow. Locations farther north and west (including the Tri Cities area) also saw a light wintry mix of sleet and freezing drizzle in the wake of departing snow, but icing amounted to just a light glaze and the travel impacts from snow-covered roads were far more of a factor (though no closures of main highways occurred). Winds were not overly-strong during the main period of snow, but steady east-southeast speeds of 10-20 MPH with occasional gusts as high as 25-30 MPH were enough to cause some modest blowing/drifting. Temperatures during most of the event hovered in the 20s F.||Taking a closer look at how things unfolded, the majority of snow accumulation occurred between 9 p.m. on the 28th and sunrise on the 29th, as a northwest-to-southeast oriented band of moderate to briefly-heavy snow steadily advanced across South Central Nebraska from southwest-to-northeast. Any steadier/measurable precipitation gradually departed the majority of the local area from west-to-east between sunrise and noon, although pesky light freezing drizzle hung around in some places until early evening. At the surface, the modestly-breezy east-southeast winds that peaked between midnight-noon were driven by a decent pressure gradient between a strong/expansive 1035 millibar high departing eastbound through the Midwest and a 1008 millibar low centered over Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow amounts ranged from 1 to 3 inches across most of the county (highest north). A total of 3.5 was reported by a CoCoRaHS observer four miles southwest of Bladen, while an NWS coop observer measured 3.2 four miles southwest of Blue Hill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thanks to a somewhat-unexpectedly potent combination of intense northwest winds and relatively-minimal snow, mainly the daytime hours on this Wednesday featured several hours of near-blizzard to outright-blizzard conditions across most of South Central Nebraska, shutting down several highways for a time and snarling pre-Christmas travel. Various law enforcement agencies reported dozens of traffic accidents and slide-offs (fortunately none fatal within the local area) and the following main highways were reported closed at various times: Interstate 80 between York and Kearney, Highway 281 between Grand Island and Hastings, Highway 30 from Grand Island-Kearney, Highway 34 from Grand Island-York, Highway 6 from Hastings-Kenesaw and Highway 81 near Shelby (all had re-opened by late afternoon). In Adams County, snowplows were pulled off the road for several hours due to very poor visibility. As for areal coverage of white-out conditions, the worst/longest-lasting issues focused within counties both along/north of Highway 6 and also along/east of Highway 183 (including the Tri Cities). Within this area, most places endured at least semi-frequent blizzard conditions for 6-8 hours while accumulating 1-3 of snow, while far northern counties (such as Valley/Greeley) saw blizzard conditions for as long as 10-12 hours and received slightly-higher snow amounts up to 3-4. Meanwhile, the situation was not as severe within far southern/southwest counties especially near the Kansas border, where snow was lighter/less-intense compared to farther north (amounts mainly under 1) and didn't last as long. Although the magnitude of wintry precipitation/blizzard impacts varied somewhat across South Central Nebraska, all 24 counties dealt with at least 9-12 hours of feisty northwest winds, commonly sustained 30-40 MPH and gusting 45-60+ MPH. A few of the highest official peak gusts at airports included: 76 MPH at Ord and 61 MPH at Grand Island, Hastings and York. While there were no known reports of substantial wind damage, NWS observers near both Arcadia and Shelby noted that several small tree branches were downed. ||Getting into more detail regarding event timing and meteorological background, the main driving force in the mid-upper levels was the passage of a deep, slightly-positively-tilted trough, with its primary vorticity maximum tracking from the Central Rockies on the evening of the 22nd, and then across the heart of Nebraska-Kansas during the day on the 23rd before departing into the Upper Midwest/Upper Great Lakes through the evening-overnight. At the surface, the associated low pressure center gradually intensified from around 994 millibars as it crossed Nebraska during the overnight-early morning of the 22nd-23rd, to 988 millibars by mid-day in the IA-MN-WI border area, and then maintained intensity while reaching Lake Superior overnight. Locally, the initial surge of strong northwest winds crossed South Central Nebraska during the pre-dawn of the 23rd behind the main synoptic cold front, but gusts largely held under 50 MPH. The overall-strongest winds ended up occurring between mid-morning and mid-afternoon, corresponding to the peak surface pressure gradient between the departing/deepening low and strong high pressure nosing in from the west-northwest (for a few hours the west-to-east gradient across the state of Nebraska averaged near 25 millibars!) As for snowfall timing, an initial, narrow band swept across most of the area during the pre-dawn hours, but the primary, broad zone of mainly light-to-moderate snow (with brief heavier bursts) gradually overspread South Central Nebraska from west-northwest to east-southeast during the morning, eventually departing in similar fashion during the afternoon. Actual falling/accumulating snow ended across most of the area between 2-4 p.m., but lingering blowing snow and ground blizzard conditions held on for a few more hours...until gusts diminished more consistently to around 30 MPH-or-less after nightfall. From a forecast review perspective, the intense winds and at least minor blowing snow impacts were fairly well-anticipated, as a High Wind Warning was issued for the entire area 12-18 hours in advance and a Winter Weather Advisory (for the majority of the area) was issued 6-18 hours out. However, especially the southward extent of accumulating snow and the resultant potential for all-out blizzard conditions was not as well foreseen (especially as far south as the Interstate 80/Highway 6 corridors), with several counties not placed under official Blizzard Warnings until rather late in the game. For sure, one of the biggest takeaways/reminders from this event was that even minimal snowfall can wreak havoc on travel in the presence of powerful winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periodic gusts exceeding 60 MPH and sustained speeds near 40 MPH occurred across the county. The peak gust of the day was 76 MPH, which was recorded at 11:51 AM by the Ord Airport ASOS. The NWS cooperative observer near Arcadia reported several small tree limbs blown down. Also, the intense winds, combined with snow, promoted blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the evening and overnight hours a strong complex of thunderstorms moved through northeast Kansas and crossed into northwest Missouri. These storms brought some high winds that measured 70-80 mph at times. However, most of the damage through the area was minor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported a large tree down across a road in town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Play set was knocked over.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree of approximately 18 inches in diameter snapped a the base.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the evening and overnight hours a strong complex of thunderstorms moved through northeast Kansas and crossed into northwest Missouri. These storms brought some high winds that measured 70-80 mph at times. However, most of the damage through the area was minor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree branch around 1 foot in diameter fell into some nearby powerlines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management reported 61 mph gust in Tonganoxie. Power went out in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the evening and overnight hours a strong complex of thunderstorms moved through northeast Kansas and crossed into northwest Missouri. These storms brought some high winds that measured 70-80 mph at times. However, most of the damage through the area was minor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS employee reported their patio table was flipped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As part of a larger severe weather event some tree damage occurred in Leavenworth, Kansas due to strong thunderstorm winds. More damage occurred east of this area into western Missouri. The next night a similar event took place, with late evening and overnight thunderstorms producing some damage further east into Missouri, but a lone report of wind damage came in from the Kansas side.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported a tree down on a house in Leavenworth.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A four inch diameter red oak branch snapped off near West 87th and Goddard.
